HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

TEARS BUT NO ANGER AS OFFICERS MEET
Waking in his hospital room, Transit Police Officer Desmond Robinson asked to see Peter Del-Debbio, the police officer who shot him in the subway on Monday. In the meeting that followed, both men cried and hugged, between the tangle of tubes attached to Officer Robinson and the cast on Officer Del-Debbio's arm, while Officer Del-Debbio repeated, "I'm sorry," over and over. A1.
In response to the shooting, a panel will study the racial attitudes of police officers. B3.
 

KUNSTLER FIRM BARRED IN BOMB-PLOT TRIAL
A Federal judge disqualified two of New York City's best-known and most aggressive lawyers from defending their last remaining client in the conspiracy trial of a blind Egyptian cleric, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, and 12 others. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
INVESTIGATIVE POWER URGED FOR AGENCY
As the City Council opened public hearings on a bill to establish a permanent agency to monitor police corruption, Speaker Peter F. Vallone strongly urged that such a panel be authorized to conduct independent investigations and to subpoena witnesses. B3.
 
7 TOP HOUSING POLICE OFFICIALS WILL QUIT
At a time of major transition for their department, seven high-ranking members of the Housing Authority police force have filed for retirement. B3.
 
REGION
 
A-PLANT PROMPTS TAX INCREASES
 Already paying among the highest utility rates and property taxes in the nation, Suffolk County residents face still higher taxes to refund $60 million to the Long Island Lighting Company for overassessment of the defunct Shoreham nuclear power plant. B5.
 
AUTHOR FINDS MYSTERY LOCALE IN NEWARK
In Newark's disorder and decay, Valerie Wilson Wesley sees rich material for murder mysteries. Her first, "When Death Comes Stealing," unfolds against the backdrop of the city's brooding neighborhoods, which Ms. Wilson Wesley hopes to harvest for a series of whodunits. B5.
 
2 CHARGED IN ABUSE OF TEEN-AGE GIRLS
Two men have been charged with luring two 13-year-old girls to a house, serving them alcohol and showing them pornographic videos before sexually abusing them, the Nassau County police said. B5.
 
ADMIRERS DEBATE STATUE FOR EINSTEIN
For decades, scientists have interpreted the theories of Albert Einstein. Now the borough of Princeton, where Einstein spent his final years, is trying to interpret his wishes; specifically, what he would think about a proposal to erect a statue of him. B5.
 
OFFICIAL SUSPENDED DUE TO BIAS CHARGE
Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell suspended the head of his office's criminal bureau in Albany after a woman said that her answering machine had taped him saying that homosexuals "shouldn't have kids." B4.
 
18 HURT WHEN DRIVER RAMS CROWD
A man trying to help his girlfriend as she argued with several people was accused by the police of driving his car through the group, injuring 18 people, including his girlfriend. B4.
 
SYRACUSE GETS ELECTRIC VEHICLE FACTORY
Giving New York State a foothold in a new high-tech industry, a plant assembling battery-powered vehicles is to open early next year in the Syracuse area, state officials said. B4.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: IN WASHINGTON;
U.S. Rejects Castro's Proposal for Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
A day after President Fidel Castro of Cuba proposed broad talks as a step toward ending the refugee crisis, the Clinton Administration rejected his overture, insisting that such talks would prove fruitless because Mr. Castro appears resolutely opposed to the reforms sought by Washington.
Even as many members of Congress urged President Clinton to agree to a high-level dialogue on the trade embargo, political reform and other points of contention, Administration officials insisted that such talks were unnecessary on the ground that Mr. Castro persists in blocking the changes he knows are needed to satisfy his people. 
 Mr. Clinton said late today that the only talks with Cuba that he favored were continuations of discussions on immigration issues. The United States has held low-level talks, usually twice a year, with Cuba on immigration matters since 1984 as a way of controlling the flow of Cubans and settling immigration disputes.
Mr. Clinton told reporters that the American people should not panic over the huge exodus of Cuban refugees, which has totaled more than 10,000 since last Friday. On that day, Mr. Clinton sought to slow the flow by ending a 28-year-old policy of admitting nearly all Cuban refugees.
"I would urge the American people to be firm and be calm about what is going on here now," he said. "We must not let any nation, even a nation as close to us as Cuba, even with so many American citizens of Cuban descent, control the immigration policy of the United States and violate the borders of the United States."
 
Fewer Picked Up Thursday
 The Coast Guard said 1,620 Cubans were picked up today in the Straits of Florida as of 10 P.M. Several officials said this might signal that the exodus was slowing because a total of 3,096 were picked up on Wednesday. An official said one reason for the drop-off was that bad weather might be temporarily slowing departures from Cuba.
At a White House news briefing, Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff presented the Administration's position in rebuffing Havana's calls for comprehensive talks with Cuba.
"Our position is that we are not going to enter into a dialogue with Castro or the Cuban Government over the pace and nature of change in Cuba," he said. "That is something that he is hearing every day, increasingly, from the Cuban people, and the people who are coming out are telling it more publicly than they did before. That's where the dialogue should take place."
Later in the day, Mr. Clinton said that Mr. Castro "needs to be in consultation with his own folks" and that "the people of Cuba want democracy and free markets."
 
Cost to Taxpayers
 For the first time, Pentagon officials estimated today what a continuing impasse would mean to the American taxpayer. They said it would cost $100 million to expand the capacity of the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base to hold 45,000 refugees, and $20 million a month to feed and shelter them.
In a two-and-a-half hour appearance on Cuban television Wednesday night, Mr. Castro suggested that he might stop the exodus of refugees if the Administration agreed to direct talks on a range of issues, including Washington's 31-year-old trade embargo against Cuba.
"Solutions that are real, realistic and just would benefit the United States as well as us," said Mr. Castro, who took power in 1959.
The Cuban leader acknowledged that he had changed his policy on emigration two weeks ago, saying he told his Coast Guard to allow Cubans to leave freely on rafts.
Mr. Castro said the main factors fueling the exodus were the punitive trade embargo and Washington's failure to allow in more Cubans who apply for visas in Havana. He said these policies "compel illegal immigration," and he accused Washington of "creating a concentration camp" at Guantanamo Bay.
Mr. Tarnoff, who has become the Administration's coordinator on Cuba, had a harsh reaction to Mr. Castro's speech, saying: "Once again, there was an attempt by the Cuban leader to lay the responsibility for the crisis in Cuba at the foot of the United States. We simply reject that premise, and that is the reason that we do not believe it is useful to have a dialogue with Castro."
In rejecting a dialogue with Mr. Castro, the Administration is following the policy advocated by the Cuban-American National Foundation, the nation's most powerful Cuban-American organization, which favors a worldwide economic embargo of Cuba, rather than a dialogue.
 
Comments From Senators
 Even as many Cuban-Americans applauded the Administration's refusal to enter into broad talks with Havana, several members of Congress urged the President to pursue such talks.
Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere, said: "Some open negotiations with Castro makes sense. It's anachronistic not to do it."
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, one of the Republican Party's senior spokesmen on foreign policy, urged Mr. Clinton not to rule out using military force in dealing with Cuba.
"We have to indicate a great power cannot be trifled with," he said on Fox Morning News. "And in the event that Fidel Castro and others are prepared, really, to test the United States, we're prepared to strike back. And I would not rule out military force."
Administration officials said the Treasury Department would release new regulations on Friday further restricting travel and commerce with Cuba. One official said that under the new regulations, the Administration will, to a far greater degree than before, require Americans to obtain licenses to travel to Cuba or send money there.
To put more pressure on Mr. Castro, Mr. Clinton announced plans on Saturday to ban the flow of some $500 million that Cuban-Americans send each year to friends and relatives in Cuba. Under the new regulations, such remittances will be allowed only for emergencies and only after a license is received, an official said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed and Dow Falls After 2-Day Rally

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Almost as fast as the stock market's rally appeared, it disappeared. The leading stock indexes closed mixed yesterday, as a two-day surge of nearly 100 points on the Dow Jones industrial average failed to gather more steam.
The Dow, which had climbed on Tuesday and Wednesday, fell 16.84 points, to 3,829.89, yesterday. Some analysts said that rather than breaking out into a substantial rally, the market was simply establishing a new -- but higher -- trading range of 3,725 to 3,900 on the Dow. 
 "I'm not surprised that the market didn't follow through," said Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist at C. H. Dean & Associates, which manages $4 billion in stocks and fixed-income securities. "Frankly, I don't really see why it was so bloody giddy on Wednesday."
 
 
Mixed Factors
 Like the stock indexes, the factors that usually move the market were mixed yesterday. The dollar was up against the Japanese yen, which helped stocks, but down against the German mark, which hurt them.
Also depressing stocks was a decline in bond prices after the announcement of economic data, including jobless claims, whose strength might prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again. Commodity prices were up slightly, which also might have hurt stocks.
But it also became more evident yesterday that the market's rally on Wednesday was something of a fluke, rather than a true change in the market's sentiment.
The rally may have been prompted in part by the unexpected consequences of a sophisticated hedging strategy devised by a single Wall Street firm, Loomis, Sayles & Company. The strategy involves a new kind of stock option called "flex options" and may have stampeded other stock traders into buying stocks in the last few hours of trading on Wednesday.
 
 
Nasdaq Index Gains
 But for the most part, much of the market held onto gains yesterday, while the Nasdaq over-the-counter market continued its rise. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 0.96 point, to 468.07. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.43 point, to 258.18, with advancing stocks lagging declining stocks by 1,057 to 1,122. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.86 point, to 447.12. But the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index advanced 3.08 points, to 754.80.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was near normal, with 284 million shares changing hands, slightly below this year's daily average of 286 million shares.
The stocks that soared on Wednesday, including Caterpillar, International Paper and Eastman Kodak, headed down yesterday.
There were other notable stocks. Shares of Piper Jaffray, the Minneapolis stock brokerage firm, fell 2, to 11 5/8, after The Wall Street Journal reported that the firm could lose more than $700 million from investments in mortgage-backed securities.
America West Airlines, which had been under court supervision for the last three years, emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law protection yesterday. Its stock rose 1/4, to 3 3/8, in active trading.
 
 
Novell Advances
 Shares of Novell, the computer-networking company that is closely followed by investors in high-technology stocks, rose 7/8, to 15 5/8. After the market had closed on Wednesday, Novell announced that its third-quarter earnings were lower than Wall Street's estimates, but the company planned to cut 1,750 jobs from a recent acquisition, Wordperfect, for a savings of at least $40 million.
Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 16 fell, led by Caterpillar, which dropped 2 3/8, to 112.
Of the 500 stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 259 fell, led by Wal-Mart, which fell 1/2, to 24 1/8, following its announcement that it might expand into Europe and Central America.
The most active stock, with 5.6 million shares traded, was Intel, which rose 15/16 , to 65 1/8. Dell Computer, whose products use Intel's microchips, reported higher second-quarter earnings. Dell is a direct-mail retailer of personal computers.

HEADLINE: Mexico Agains Calls U.S. Investors

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
The Mexicans have voted. Now it's the Americans' turn.
United States corporations and investors are poised for a new round of ventures in Mexico after the ruling party's recent victory in an election they regard as clean enough, at least, to be valid. 
 Mexican stocks have jumped, anticipating and then responding to the success of Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party's presidential candidate. Corporate expansions and direct investments will come more gradually, however, since they take more than a phone call to arrange and can be much harder to reverse.
 
Dusting Off Proposals
 Already, though, the rustling and shuffling heard in many American corporate offices come from plans for Mexican investment being pulled out of the drawers and off the shelves where they had been put when the party, known as P.R.I., faltered early this year with the peasant rebellion in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas and the assassination of P.R.I.'s initial presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio.
"We were waiting to see the results of the election before we did anything,' said Sheila Gallagher, a spokeswoman for the Centex Corporation, the largest American home builder. Laurence E. Hirsch, Centex's chief executive, while refusing to describe his plans there, said, "An election that didn't elect the P.R.I. would have led one to wonder about the consequences."
The Mexican Government, although committed to free markets, has a far greater role in the economy than the United States Government, thereby making national elections that much more of a business issue. Just as ancient Romans reckoned periods of time by consulships, Mexican business people frame their long-range plans by the sexenio, the six-year presidential term.
Now, much more than before, Americans are planning for the coming sexenio as well. "Is the politics -- let's call it an opening -- going to keep moving in the same direction as the economic opening?" asked Hugo Verdegaal, the head of international corporate finance for Citibank in New York. "The election confirmed to a lot of people that is the case."
Mr. Verdegaal said that rather than reacting suddenly to the vote, American and Mexican corporations began to breathe more easily a few months ago as the P.R.I. began to recover from the peasant uprising and Mr. Colosio's assassination. Citibank now expects to help finance Government infrastructure projects, especially in electric power, that were put off until after the election.
United States investment in Mexico has grown rapidly in recent years, with a burst after Congress approved the North American Free Trade Agreement in November. Much new investment by American corporations is bound to be quiet, even furtive. They crank out news releases when they ship more products to Mexico, but not when they ship jobs.
The investment momentum slowed this year, but Jaime Alatorre, president of the Mexican Investment Board, expects a strong revival. Just this week, he and his staff began calling back American companies that in the last few months had postponed decisions on Government projects or investments of their own.
"Ports, power generation," he began in a phone interview, as if going down a list. "A number of them in textiles, garments. Those projects will be moving much faster. There are projects in the area of auto parts."
Some apparel work for American corporations will soon move to Mexico from Asia to qualify for the trade pact's tariff reductions on exports to the United States, he said. As for auto parts, the Big Three auto companies are asking suppliers to set up factories near the auto makers' Mexican assembly plants.
 
Hopeful About Reform
 American companies are encouraged not only by Mr. Zedillo's allegiance to current economic policies but also by the chances that he will revive other, stalled reforms. "That's a main topic: the Government itself delaying liberalization until after the elections," said Ronald J. Johansson, a partner in the Kenneth Leventhal & Company real estate consulting firm.
Despite opposition from the Mexican Legislature, the Government is already proposing to bundle home mortgages and sell them as investment securities. This step could vastly expand home ownership through more readily available mortgages, as well as create opportunities for American investors and financiers.
The American real estate and financial services industries could be among the first to see business improve, not only from reforms but also from rising business confidence. Mexican executives, after all, were at least as jittery as American executives in their country.
Eduardo Vidal, a partner with the Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom law firm in New York, said he is leaving for Mexico next week to help two companies, including one building a water-treatment system for Cancun, raise money in the American markets. "That's the biggest thing we export: services," he said. "Lawyers, accountants, investment bankers."
Mexican companies seeking larger or more modern offices will find that even in Mexico City buildings with dependable elevators, air-conditioning and wiring for computers, phones and facsimile machines are scarce. Mr. Johansson speaks of one client, cautiously active in Mexico for a decade, who is now preparing to build office towers.
 
A Crowded Market
 Still, prospects in Mexico are not as bright as some companies believe. Many will find Mexican markets already crowded, particularly in fields like American-style retailing. Market research is primitive and income disparities are increasing, with doubts about just how many Mexicans can consume in a manner to which Americans are accustomed. To fend off kidnappers, Mexican business leaders must employ their own platoons of bodyguards.
Mark Robertson, the director of Cushman & Wakefield's real estate leasing partnership in Mexico, is resolutely upbeat, noting that the political fears raised by the Chiapas uprising and the assassination of Mr. Colosio have eased. But even he has some worries. "If the people in Chiapas wave their rifles up and down and pull their ski masks back on," he said, "those who have not made an investment may put it on hold."

HEADLINE: Apartheid's Arms-Maker Finds Respectability

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Talk about political baggage: This company armed the police who terrorized black townships. It helped white South Africa secretly make an atomic weapon. Its biggest export customer in sub-Saharan Africa was the former regime in Rwanda. It flouted international arms-trafficking sanctions.
For Armscor, the Armaments Corporation of South Africa, fitting into the gentler, democratic South Africa of Nelson Mandela would seem to require a tour de force of political dexterity. 
 And that is exactly what the weapons industry here has undertaken, recasting itself as a people-friendly generator of jobs and technology, a proponent of openness and international law, and a linchpin of the Government's social uplift program.
"Watch it spread the pollen and make the honey," Armscor says of the industry it bestrides, in a new advertising campaign that features plump, cartoon honeybees flitting over a field of daisies.
Already the South African weapons industry, for which Armscor is the main conduit, has won over prominent veterans of the liberation movement, who have discovered that weapons seem less repugnant when they are your own.
 
Backed by Defense Minister
 The most enthusiastic booster is Joe Modise, the former African National Congress guerrilla leader who is now Minister of Defense. But President Mandela has also conferred his slightly more ambiguous blessing on the industry's plans to aggressively increase foreign arms sales.
The fate of the arms industry has sharply divided Mr. Mandela's party, where many new officials favor diverting money from the military budget for housing and schools, and some are dismayed at the notion of a worldwide weapons trade bearing the Nelson Mandela seal of approval.
"Couldn't we produce something else that is not deadly?" asked Thenjiwe Mtintso, a former anti-apartheid guerrilla who now sits on the parliamentary committee overseeing the military, where she questions both the morality and economic trickle-down of making weapons.
On Saturday, Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu chided Mr. Mandela, his fellow Nobel Peace Prize laureate, for not moving to dismantle Armscor and curtail the weapons trade.
"Our President could easily become the target of demonstrations and pickets, and we cannot keep quiet," he told a church gathering.
The last few years have been rough on South African arms- makers, a tight-knit network of contractors public and private, with Government-owned Armscor at its hub.
Armscor manufactures nothing itself -- not since its production arm was spun off two years ago as a separate, state-owned conglomerate called Denel, which sells everything from bullets and grenades to tank turrets and combat helicopters.
Overseen by a board appointed by the Defense Minister, Armscor now is an acquisitions company. It purchases weapons for the army and police, cultivates the domestic industry with planning and technical advice, and licenses all arms exports. No legal arms trade takes place without its involvement.
 
Arms Spending Cut
 Since South Africa withdrew its army in 1988 from Angola, where it was fighting to overthrow the Cuban-backed Government, Pretoria has cut its weapons spending more than 40 percent. Where the old Armscor employed 27,000 people, its offspring, Armscor and Denel, now employ about 15,000.
While military spending is growing -- in Mr. Mandela's first budget, it is to increase 10 percent, to about $3.3 billion -- the new money is paying to merge the old defense force with former guerrillas and black homeland armies, not to buy weapons.
The industry's first solution has been to turn to foreign customers.
Despite United Nations sanctions against the apartheid government, South Africa built a formidable weapons industry that is the country's largest exporter of manufactured goods, with more than $150 million in foreign sales last year.
The largest customers are Middle Eastern countries like Oman and Dubai, which buy artillery and armored vehicles. South Africa also sells technology to the Far East, and small arms to South America.
 
Rise in Export Trade
 With sanctions lifted last May, said Tielman de Waal, the executive general manager of Armscor, South African exports, now about half a percent of the world market, are expected to double by the end of the year, and then quickly double again.
The most rapid growth is expected to be in the neighboring states of southern Africa, where Armscor will arrange the servicing and eventual replacement of old weapons supplied by the Soviet bloc.
"These are our natural markets, because we're close by and we have a pretty good reputation for quality," said Brigadier William Suss, senior researcher at the Institute for Defense Policy, a Johannesburg research organization. "If you were on the receiving end at one stage, you are easily convinced how effective these weapons are."
Although industry officials say they have little hope of capturing much business in the advanced and well-protected Western markets, South African weapons are enjoying a new-found respectability there too.
One major impediment is the United States, which has retained a ban on importing and exporting South African weapons because Armscor and affiliated companies are under indictment for smuggling out American components to circumvent sanctions against South Africa and Iraq.
Armscor has offered to pay large fines to dispose of the case, and industry officials say the reason Americans have refused a deal is that they want to protect American weapons-makers from new competition.
 
Civilian Production an Option
 Another front in the industry's survival plan is Mr. Mandela's war against poverty.
Armscor officials said they had approached Government ministries and provincial officials proposing that Armscor become an official acquisition agent for purchases of medical equipment, vehicles, water purification systems, electrical generators and other goods.
As it did with weapons, Armscor would nurture domestic manufacturers for these products, which could then be exported, creating jobs. Much of the work, in fact, would logically go to weapons companies, officials said, since swords and ploughshares are often not so different.
"What is a tent but a low-cost housing system?" said Andre Buys, the head of the Armscor planning department.
Most weapons-makers have already diversified beyond armaments. Even at Denel, which until recently was banned from non-military work, about 14 percent of production is now commercial, ranging from composite pipe to cricket bats.
Armscor said its overtures to Government officials have been warmly received, although there is also suspicion, not only from military critics but also from some private companies who worry that Armscor and its siblings will become state-sponsored competitors.
"There is a feeling in industry that the playing field is not entirely level," said William P. Venter, executive chairman of Allied Electronics Corporation, a major producer of civilian and military technology.
 
A New Beginning?
 Armscor is adamant that it has turned over a new leaf, and should be forgiven its past.
"It is true that the armaments industry was developed under the system of apartheid," said Mr. de Waal. "Is that a reason to deny its contribution to the gross domestic product?"
Company officials say they now respect international agreements limiting the spread of arms. Mr. de Waal said the company will happily abide by decisions of the Mandela Government not to permit arms sales to dictators or countries facing civil wars, and will support fuller disclosure of the secretive arms budget.
The company announced it was halting export of land mines, which are blamed for thousands of civilian casualties. A $60 million shipment of guns, ammunition and grenades to Rwanda was canceled after the Government began massacring the Tutsi ethnic minority.
Armscor began courting congress leaders more than two years ago, meeting with Mr. Modise and other anti-apartheid activists.
 
Anti-Apartheid Writer Hired
 In May the company hired Enoch Sithole, until recently the star political writer for The New Nation, an ardently pro-congress weekly newspaper, as its chief lobbyist.
"I've written various articles against this company," Mr. Sithole said. "But they assured me they want to work with the new Government. It's not that I am an ardent supporter of producing and exporting armaments, but if such activity is practiced at all in the world, there's no reason South Africa shouldn't."
Jacklyn Cock, a sociologist and leader of the Military Research Group, which advises military critics in Parliament, said opponents of the military industry are heavily out-gunned in the new Government by the odd new "militarist alliance" of white officers from the apartheid army and black guerrillas from the anti-apartheid struggle.
But while that may win the industry official support for its overseas ventures, it is not likely to protect the domestic arms budget from further cutting, said Brigadier Suss.
"No matter how much support Armscor has in the Cabinet," he said, "the fact remains that in the long run you will always have four corvettes for the Navy and not a new hospital, or 60 Pilatus aircraft and not schools. It will always remain a problem of how much money you are prepared to spend."

HEADLINE: Toyota Profit Declines for A 4th Year

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation, hurt by the strong yen and a weak Japanese car market, today reported its fourth consecutive annual decline in profits, with net income falling to the lowest level in at least a decade.
But Japan's largest and richest automobile company also said it thought the worst was over, and predicted that sales and profits would rise in the coming year. 
 For the fiscal year that ended on June 30, Toyota's consolidated net income fell 28.7 percent, to 125.8 billion yen, or $1.27 billion when converted at a rate of 99 yen to the dollar. The figure is only slightly more than a quarter of the 441.3 billion yen income reported in Toyota's peak year, which ended in June 1990.
 
 
 
Revenues Fall 8.3%
 Toyota's revenues fell 8.3 percent, to 9.36 trillion yen, or $94.6 billion, the first decline since 1986.
Worldwide vehicle sales fell 7.5 percent, to 4.13 million units. Sales in Japan, the company's largest market, fell 6.9 percent, to 2.01 million units; overseas sales fell 8.1 percent, to 2.12 million vehicles.
Toyota did not get much help from the United States, where the auto market has been strong. From January through July, its sales in terms of vehicles sold were up only 2 percent, compared with a rise of 9 percent for the market as a whole.
By contrast, the Honda Motor Company reported on Wednesday a big gain in quarterly profits, in part because of buoyant sales in the United States. Nissan is also seeing strong growth in the American market. Unlike its two Japanese rivals, Toyota has no prominent new products to spur its American sales.
Still, Toyota avoided what it feared most -- a loss. Last year at this time, with the dollar just above 100 yen, Toyota had said it might face its first operating loss in the fiscal year 1994.
Like other Japanese companies, Toyota has been shifting its manufacturing abroad, partly to cope with the strong yen. But that means that production in Japan has been dropping, leaving a problem of overcapacity.
 
 
 
Program to Cut Costs
 Toyota is in the midst of a cost-cutting binge, and said it achieved savings of 150 billion yen, or about $1.5 billion, in the last year. It expects to cut another 100 billion yen, or $1 billion, in the coming year. Most of the savings have come from changes in the design of its cars, with the rest coming from cost-cutting in manufacturing and distribution.
Total vehicle sales in Japan have declined for three years and may decline this year as well. But there are growing signs that Japan is pulling out of its long recession and that the sales slump may be ending.
Toyota also announced that it would change to a fiscal year ending on March 31, to conform with the practice of most Japanese companies. That means its current fiscal year, which began in July, will last only nine months.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Cuba Strain Cools Haiti's Invasion Fever

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The red-and-blue banners that stretch across main streets in Port-au-Prince read, "No to the U.S. invasion." But the colors are beginning to fade after being up for more than a month, because the likelihood of such an invasion to reinstate the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, seems to have grown dimmer for many Haitians.
The State Department's attention in the region seems to be focused on Cuba, and what Haitians once called invasion fever seems to have broken. 
 Though United States warships still sit off Haiti as part of a United Nations embargo that continues to squeeze the economy, Haitians who once said "when" in relation to the invasion are now saying "if."
Stanley Schrager, spokesman for the United States Embassy here, said that Washington's resolve in Haiti had not weakened and that there was still only one acceptable resolution to the political stalemate: for the military-backed leadership to step down, making way for Father Aristide to return to power.
But to his supporters, what seems to be Washington's preoccupation with Cuba is bad news, and gives the Haitian military exactly what it wants: more time to wait out the sanctions and to wait for Father's Aristide's term to expire in 1996.
After nearly three years of oppression and broken promises by the Haitian authorities, the Clinton Administration's talk of an invasion gave some Aristide supporters hope that the exit of the military leaders would be hastened. Now that feeling of optimism fades with every headline about Cubans fleeing their country, said one supporter of Father Aristide.
"It is like the U.S. can only solve one problem at a time," a young woman said.
She said she was willing to suffer under the embargo, to eat less, walk everywhere she goes, even risk the killings of the poor people that continue to leave back roads dotted with corpses, as long as there was some end in sight. But Washington, she asserted, is behaving like a bully, taunting one child, threatening to fight, but running away just to taunt another child.
"I feel sorry for the Cubans who are suffering," she said, "but I don't believe they are suffering as much as we are."
In the meantime, Haiti's military continues to conduct drills with a civilian militia and to talk of repelling an invasion by the United States. Last week, it paraded a new unit, armed only with machetes, past the presidential palace.
For those in power, Washington's confrontation with Cuba could not have come at a better time, some Haitians said. Foreign journalists, who chronicled the abuses suffered by Haitians, have left the country by the dozens in the last few weeks, many seeking visas to Cuba.
The hardships of the embargo, however, do not reach into the military barracks or the headquarters where Lieut. Gen. Raul Cedras and his colleagues seem prepared to wait it out indefinitely since coming to power in a coup in September 1991.
One man who voted for Father Aristide said, "If you do see someone wading ashore, it won't be the marines." It would be some lost Cuban, he said.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: IN MIAMI;
Cuban Group Forges Link to Clinton

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 25

 BODY:
For the moment at least, the refugee exodus from Cuba has given Jorge Mas Canosa, a longtime supporter of Republican Presidents, access to the inner circles of a Democratic White House.
Mr. Mas, president of the Cuban American National Foundation and an enthusiastic supporter of Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, today praised President Clinton's revised policies on Cuba, policies Mr. Mas had a hand in shaping in a meeting with Mr. Clinton last Friday. 
 "He's a man who stands for democracy and freedom," Mr. Mas said in an interview today. "What the President did has nothing to do with politics; it came out of his own convictions. He took the initiative on a policy based on principle."
As much as he admired former Presidents Reagan and Bush, Mr. Mas said, "they never took a stand against Castro the way Mr. Clinton has, despite all their rhetoric."
 
Welcomes Castro's Criticism
 The President's action had long been sought by Mr. Mas and his foundation, a group of wealthy Cuban business leaders in Miami. Mr. Clinton's order established that Mr. Mas once again had the ear of a President and was in a position to push a hard line against Fidel Castro's attempts to form a new accommodation with Washington over the United States economic embargo and other matters.
The Cuban leader, in a long televised talk from Havana on Wednesday night, mentioned Mr. Mas and the Cuban American National Foundation several times, calling them "fascist mafia," an appellation that Mr. Mas today seemed almost comforted by.
"It shows that what we are doing has hurt him," Mr. Mas said. "He put me in good company with Mr. Clinton and the foundation with the U.S. Government."
In announcing that he was halting cash transfers to Cuba and curtailing charter flights to the island, Mr. Clinton was reversing course. Last year, over the opposition of the foundation, Mr. Clinton expanded programs to relieve hardships imposed on the Cuban people by the deterioration of economic conditions in a Communist government no longer subsidized by Moscow.
 
Tensions Easing in Miami
 Mr. Mas also endorsed the Administration's order that all refugees be held in detention until democracy is instituted in Cuba, reversing a longstanding policy of granting political asylum to most Cubans who reach the United States. His concerns over the order were allayed by White House agreement that the President would "punish" Mr. Castro for allowing the refugees to depart Cuba through the new curtailments on cash and travel. Mr. Mas's support helped turn around the initial outrage expressed by Cuban-Americans who believed the rafters were being betrayed.
Mr. Mas was also unstinting in his praise of Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, who invited Mr. Mas to last Friday's meeting with the President in the Cabinet Room of the White House. This development must be particularly unsettling to Republicans who had come to rely on partisan support from Mr. Mas and generous campaign contributions from the foundation's millionaires.
The candidate most upset must be Jeb Bush, the former President's son, who has been seen as the foundation's favorite in the Republican primary in September to choose an opponent of Mr. Chiles in his bid for re-election this fall.
Mr. Mas, a hard-driving man who fled to Miami in 1960 and later established a successful engineering and construction concern, was among five Miami civic and government leaders invited by Governor Chiles to discuss the growing refugee crisis with the President.
 
Meeting Not Contentious
 Mr. Chiles, in a telephone interview today, said Mr. Mas had not pushed his views with the President to the exclusion of the opinions of others in the group. "I believe everyone there was all united that Castro was the problem," he said. "The meeting was never one of contention. Mas Canosa wanted a full blockade right away and the President said he would not take it off the table but it was not something he would consider right now."
Like two old warhorses, Mr. Mas and Mr. Castro have been at each other's throats for years. When Mr. Mas received Washington's backing for Radio Marti in 1986 to broadcast to Cuba, and later obtained Congressional financing for Television Marti, relations between the two countries were chilled after years of growing accommodation.
Mr. Mas talked about Mr. Castro's Wednesday night speech with the growl of someone who smells victory.
"Castro has been a pretty good offensive machine," Mr. Mas said, "but last night on television he was rambling around and -- for him -- left speechless.
"President Clinton stood up to him and it was Castro who blinked," he continued, savoring the sight of an old adversary groping for words to describe Washington's refusal to accept a new round of refugees.
"Castro probably has played one of his last cards and Clinton stole the initiative away," Mr. Mas said. "He outsmarted Castro."
 
Not at Point of Invasion
 The game plan now, he continued, is to wait and see if the most desperate Cubans, aware now that Mr. Clinton will not permit them to enter the United States, will remain home and work for Mr Castro's removal.
"Mr. Clinton has to be prudent and continue monitoring the situation," Mr. Mas said, ruling out negotiations with Havana that would provide Mr. Castro the means to stay in power.
Asked if he favored an invasion of Cuba by exiles and refugees armed and supported by the United States military, Mr. Mas replied, "We have not reached that point yet."
He and most Cuban-Americans supported a United States blockade of Cuba, which he said could deplete the island's fuel reserves within three months and cause political collapse sometime after.
"It's a very viable option which I think the President has close to his heart," he said. "He gave us all encouragement and it is being seriously considered. But first we must see how the new restrictions on travel and cash transfers work out."
 
Looking for One Departure
 He said he was sad for the rafters who face a long time in detention in Miami and the Navy's Guantanamo Bay base in Cuba, "but most important to us are the 11 million people still in Cuba."
"We can't spend our life taking care of rafters and diverting our attention from Cuba," he said.
He paused a moment and said: "You know, a solution doesn't take the exit of thousands of rafters. It takes the exit of only one man and his name is Fidel Castro. But he'll never leave peacefully.
"I'm asked if I promote bloodshed in Cuba. I would like to see a peaceful, nonviolent civilized transition to democracy. No one wants blood. But it will be Castro's responsibility to see it doesn't happen.
"But what he is promoting is violence on the Cuban people."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Give Up Most of Their Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday, giving back nearly all of the previous day's gains, as traders were concerned that an economic report today would show that the economy has not slowed that much.
Chris Moore, a senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said it was obvious that the market was worried about today's revised report on the second-quarter gross domestic product, which is likely to show a growth rate stronger than the previously released 3.7 percent. He expects the number will be about 4 percent. Many analysts fear that the report will suggest that inflation pressures are still building. 
 "The concern was confirmed by the selling that took the market out of its pre-auction levels and buoyed rates toward the highs of the week again," Mr. Moore said.
Bond prices dipped slightly in early trading, and managed to hold onto most of Wednesday's gains into the afternoon, helped by a firmer dollar in the currency markets. But by late in the day, the price of the 30-year bond had fallen 29/32 , to 9920/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.53 percent, from 7.46 percent on Wednesday.
The bond market shrugged off two economic reports that were released yesterday.
The National Association of Realtors said existing-home sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent in July, to 3.95 million units annualized, in line with expectations and generally consistent with the cooling off in the housing market in recent months.
The relatively flat existing-home sales report included gains of 2.4 percent in the West and a 1 percent decline in the Midwest, while the Northeast dropped 4.8 percent and the South dipped seven-tenths of 1 percent. The report also noted that the median price of a home fell to $111,500, from $112,800 in June. But economists see the existing-home sales report as a bit of a lagqard, because the figures are based on a mix of contract signings and closings, with new-home sales just contract signings, so they say that it just does not carry much weight with the market.
In a separate report yesterday, jobless claims fell 3,000, to 322,000 for the week ended Aug 20, in line with expectations. Traders said a Reuters survey of economists had predicted the number would come in at 329,000. Analysts said the unemployment claims continue to disclose strength in the employment market, an indication that will be tested by next Friday's August employment report.
"Existing-home sales showed that the Fed's higher interest rate policy is having its desired effect on the pace of U.S.'s improving economy," Mr. Moore said, "while the lower claims report was indicative of a healthy economy," which, he added, was capable of "sustaining a recovery in a rising interest rate environment."
Mr. Moore said market expectations for today's revised G.D.P. ranged from 3.5 percent to 4.5 percent. He said the G.D.P. number could be the catalyst to push the long end of the market up to 7.75 percent, which is the the ceiling of its trading range since April.
Elsewhere in the municipal bond market, the decline was not as bad since many investors bought bonds to hedge against higher taxes and also because this year there were fewer new issues.

HEADLINE: A Back-to-Basics U-Turn in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOYOTA CITY, Japan

 BODY:
As part of its quality testing, the Toyota Motor Corporation used to require that sunroofs on its automobiles be opened and closed 1,500 times in a room cooled to 22 degrees below zero Fahrenheit. Then it occurred to the company that few people opened their sunroofs even once when it was that cold outside.
To cut costs, the required testing has been reduced to 500 times at a temperature of only 4 degrees below zero. 
 The modification might seem trivial, but it is part of a broader change of mind-set that is sweeping through Japan's largest car company and through the rest of the nation's auto industry. After years of building fancier and more expensive cars, Japanese auto makers are being forced to move back toward less expensive vehicles with fewer frills and less obsessive attention to detail, a shift that they contend will not compromise basic quality or reliability.
"With excessive standards, we designed over-engineered cars," said Akihiro Wada, a senior managing director at Toyota. A few years ago, he said, "we had a philosophy that as long as we made good-quality vehicles, no matter how expensive they were, people would be satisfied."
Now, however, the first expression out of a Japanese auto executive's mouth is likely to be "value for money." In a sense, Japan's automobile companies, which first made their mark with low-priced but reliable vehicles, are returning to their roots.
The new philosophy has found its expression in a series of relatively inexpensive vehicles that have been introduced in Japan in the last few months and have done quite well.
Toyota's new small sport-utility vehicle, known as the RAV 4 and made on a lightly automated assembly line here, is considered to be the first embodiment of the new approach by Japan's largest car company. Other newly introduced inexpensive cars that have done well include Mazda's Familia, known in the United States as the Protege, and some versions of Nissan's Sunny, known as the Sentra in the United States.
The auto companies are reacting to changes in Japan's automobile market. Sales of new cars here have declined for three years, though there are signs that the downturn is ending. With Japan still in an economic slump, people here are looking for less expensive cars than they sought during the boom of the so-called bubble economy in the late 1980's.
But the same lessons will be applied to the models sold abroad, where Japanese cars, especially at the low end of the market, have become less competitive in the last two years, in part because the Japanese yen has become more expensive in relation to the dollar. The cost-trimming may become apparent with the redesigned 1995 Mazda Protege and the 1996 Honda Civic.
"Now the Japanese are realizing that despite the yen being at 98, they still have to have a substantial presence in the low-priced car market," said Chris W. Cedergren, senior vice president of Auto Pacific Inc., a consulting firm in Santa Ana, Calif. He said that while Japanese small cars were at least $1,500 more expensive than comparable American models, the new models to be introduced starting next year would erase the price gap.
 
 
 
A Jolt of 'Neon Shock'
 In the American market, Japanese auto makers took their eye off the low end as they moved into luxury and sports cars. In part, that was because voluntary restraints on Japan's exports to the United States in the 1980's encouraged the companies to use their limited allotment to sell expensive cars, not low-priced ones.
But now, the markets for luxury and sports cars are sluggish. And Detroit, helped by the rising yen and its own revamping, has mounted a new attack at the low end with cars like Chrysler's Neon.
"We had what we call Neon shock," said Luke Bierens, an engineer at the factory here in the city where Toyota has its headquarters and where the RAV 4 is built. He said that when engineers took apart the new Chrysler subcompact, they found Toyota used as many as 10 components in places where Chrysler used one.
Another reason for a return to basics is that much of the new demand for motor vehicles will come from developing nations in Asia and Latin America, where most people cannot afford expensive cars.
Whether Japan can still compete in the low end of the market is open to question. Some of the new inexpensive cars achieve their lower prices not only through true cost-cutting, but also by leaving out popular equipment like radios or air-conditioners.
Many executives and analysts here say it will be difficult or impossible to cut costs enough to make Japan's exports competitive at 100 or 95 yen to the dollar, especially with Japan's tradition of lifetime employment. That means manufacturing will continue to shift to the United States and other countries.
 
 
 
Danger of Cutting Too Much
 Moreover, there is a risk that skimping too much could undermine the Japanese industry's most precious asset: the reputation for reliability that gave Japanese cars an edge in the United States.
"I'm afraid the quality will be less," said Akira Oshikawa, an independent industry analyst and former official of the Japan Auto Parts Industries Association.
But auto officials insist that they will retain the quality. "We are not lowering the standard for the customer," Mr. Wada of Toyota said. "We are just lowering the excesses."
To cut costs, companies are reducing the number of models they offer and the number of varieties of each car. Japanese car companies offer dozens of steering wheels for some models in their home market in an effort to satisfy each customer's preference, an option they are limiting.
For instance, for the new Camry introduced in Japan this year, Toyota is offering only 44 possible variations of models and basic equipment, compared with 66 for the previous Camry. The total number of parts in the car dropped to 2,300 from 3,900.
Other cost savings will be achieved by sharing parts among different models rather than designing each part from scratch, from revamping the research and development process and pressing the parts suppliers for lower prices.
Because it takes four years to develop and build a new model, and the cost-cutting efforts have been under way in earnest for only two years, the full results have not yet been seen. But some of the models coming out achieve partial cost savings.
 
 
 
Sorry, No Radio
 The new Mazda Familia has a base price of 970,000 yen, or $9,700, which in Japan is inexpensive. The new cars are priced about $300 to $900 less than the previous generation of Familias. The company achieved the lower price by reducing the number of models offered, making parts common to different models and eliminating some features, like the radio, in the basic model.
In the United States, the same Mazda car, known as the Protege, is going on sale at prices starting at $12,000. The list price will range from the same to $400 less than the previous model, despite the yen's rise.
Nissan has developed a new two-door version of its low-end Sunny, with a base price of less than 900,000 yen, or $9,000. On Aug. 24, it introduced a new Cefiro sedan, a mid- to high-range car, at prices 5 percent lower than the previous generation's.
Nissan has not announced the price for either car in the United States, where they will go on sale next year. But it has been aggressive in pricing other models in North America.
The base model of the new Nissan Maxima, which was introduced this year, costs at least 6 percent below the price of the previous Maxima, despite the fact that it is being exported from Japan while the yen is strong.
Some American critics contend that Nissan is "dumping" cars -- selling them below cost to gain market share. Nissan said it had cut costs by sharing the Maxima's platform with another model, changing to a simpler suspension and eliminating frills like a keyless locking system.
 
 
 
A Low-Priced Hit
 But the most-talked-about vehicle in the new low-price category is Toyota's RAV 4, considered one of Japan's first "post bubble" automobiles. It has a base price in Japan of 1.6 million yen, or $16,000, compared with prices of at least 2 million yen, or $20,000, for most larger sport-utility vehicles.
Toyota has been selling more than 5,000 of the vehicles a month since the RAV 4 was introduced in May, far exceeding its monthly target of 2,000 units. Orders from Japanese buyers have backed up into November. The vehicle is also being exported to Western Europe, and Toyota is considering whether to produce it in the United States. As an import, the RAV 4 would face a 25 percent American tariff because it would be classified as a truck.
The basic model has no air-conditioner, no tilt steering wheel, and only an AM radio. There are fewer alternatives offered than in the past -- only 10 steering wheel choices, for instance.
Many parts are shared with other Toyota models. The steering wheels come from the Celica; the buttons for optional power windows from the Corolla, and the engine, transmission and front suspension from the Japanese version of the Camry. In all, 20 to 30 percent of the car's components are shared with other vehicles, said Keiichi Kanda, a manager at the Motomachi plant, where the RAV 4 is made. Ten years ago, Mr. Kanda said, there was almost no sharing of components among models.
 
 
 
Simpler Assembly Process
 Costs have also been cut by simplifying the assembly line, which is not as automated as those in some plants built by Toyota in the late 1980's, when the auto maker was bedazzled by technology and the cost savings it promised.
"We went along with the cover story," said Mikio Kitano, the manager of the Motomachi plant and a Toyota director. "We tried to do everything by machine." But the savings proved elusive, he said, because the equipment cost so much.
The less complex RAV 4 assembly line cost only a third as much to build as the one in Toyota's most automated factory, the Tahara plant. Truck-type models also tend to be less expensive to assemble than the more elaborate luxury automobiles.
At Tahara, where the Lexus is made, Toyota tried to use machine-vision systems to guide robots in aligning the tires so the lug nuts could be fastened. Here at Motomachi, a round piece of plastic juts out of the center of the wheels. The big hole in the tire's center slides onto the piece of plastic, guiding the tire into place.
And while at some modern factories, cars ride on special dollies that can be raised or lowered depending on the task to be performed, at Motomachi it is the height of the workers that is adjusted, by raising wooden platforms on the floor.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Using less-automated methods, Toyota has reduced production costs at its Motomachi plant in Toyota City, Japan. The factory produces Toyota's new RAV 4 sport vehicle. (Andrew Pollack/The New York Times)
 
Diagram: "Controlling Costs To Compete Better"
 Japanese auto companies are going back to their roots by using parts common to several models to reduce development and manufacturing costs and taking out luxury features to create cars they hope can compete in the low-end market. Manufacturers are also building less-automated assemblylines and changing their product tests in an effort to control costs. Changes in Toyota's new RAV 4,right which is available only in Japan thus far, reflect this approach. (Source: Toyota Motor Corp.)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Yen As Optimism on Trade Rises

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Signs that negotiators from the United States and Japan were making progress on trade issues helped to lift the dollar against the yen yesterday.
But the dollar fell against the mark and other leading currencies after a German Government report showed a surprising surge in that country's inflation. The increased prompted speculation that the Bundesbank would stop lowering interest rates, or would even raise them, to control inflation. 
 American and Japanese negotiators engaged in positive discussions aimed at opening Japan's insurance market to foreign companies, according to a Japanese Finance Ministry official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
 
 
'Sense of Optimism'
 The talks on insurance are part of the so-called framework talks on ways to reduce Japan's $60 billion annual trade surplus with the United States, which many traders and analysts regard as the true source of the yen's strength.
"There is a sense of optimism that the U.S. and Japan will make progress in this month's trade talks," said Michael Faust, a portfolio manager at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, a San Mateo, Calif., money manager with $1 billion on assets.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 99.65 yen, up from 99.01 yen on Wednesday, its third gain this week. The dollar fell to 1.5423 marks, from 1.5473 marks on Wednesday.
The dollar started rising in Tokyo trading after the Bank of Japan bought dollars for a third day, traders said. The central bank often intervenes to keep the yen from rising because a too-strong yen hurts Japanese exporters.
 
 
Inflation in Western Germany
 Those gains, however, failed to support the dollar against the mark. The dollar fell against the mark after the German Government said inflation in western Germany rose a bigger-than-expected 3 percent in August from a year earlier.
The dollar fell further after Guntram Palm, a member of the Bundesbank's policy making council, said the central bank could start raising interest rates if money supply growth continued to exceed targets. Germany's money supply grew 9.9 percent in July, above the Bundesbank's target range of 4 to 6 percent.
Some traders were skeptical that the Bundesbank would raise rates abruptly after lowering them for almost two years. In any case, the central bank was unlikely to make any move until after parliamentary elections on Oct. 16, they said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
An argument over magazine research is causing concern among marketers and agencies.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A DISPUTE over magazine research methodology is roiling agencies, advertisers, media executives and researchers. They are becoming increasingly concerned that the quarrel could call into question the validity of data used to buy billions of dollars worth of print advertisements annually.
The dispute involves a once-confidential draft report by members of a committee of the Magazine Publishers of America, the trade organization representing the nation's magazine industry. The draft report questioned the way some data are compiled by the Simmons Market Research Bureau, one of the two companies that conduct research among consumers to determine which magazines and newspapers they read, how often they read those publications and how much time they spend reading each issue. 
 The draft report, in examining research of Simmons and its rival, Mediamark Research Inc., concluded that the basis for data reported by Simmons after 1990, when it changed how its surveys were conducted, was perplexing. Specifically, the draft report questioned how Simmons surveys from 1991 through 1993 found a steep decline in potential readers of magazines -- or "screens" in the language of media research.
The draft report declared this puzzling because, at the same time, the Simmons research found that the number of full-time readers, or "reads," had suffered no corresponding decline. Such a divergence between the two sets of figures is unusual.
Simmons went on the offensive after articles about the draft report appeared last month in Inside Research, a newsletter, and Inside Media, a trade publication.
"We have always tried to work with any client or association that wants to look at our data," Ellen Cohen, president at Simmons in New York, said yesterday.
"But this was mishandled," she added. "If you get confidential information and you leak it, you stop being professional."
James R. Guthrie, executive vice president for marketing development at the publishers association in New York, said he believed that complaints about a breach of confidentiality were "a convenient red herring."
Putting aside the he-said, she-said aspects of the contretemps, it does raise some significant issues.
"We need to make sure the industry has good data," said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. That organization, known as the Four A's, is the agency industry counterpart of the publishers association. The media departments at member agencies use Simmons and Mediamark data as the basis for deciding which publications to buy advertising space in -- and which to withhold their dollars from.
"The data used to make buying decisions need to be reliable and accepted on a broad-scale basis," Mr. Drake said, "so this is naturally of concern to us."
John Motavalli, editor at Inside Media in New York, said the draft report raised another important question.
"If Simmons's numbers turn out to be very badly flawed, and become unacceptable, the only source of data," he said, would be Mediamark. "And there would be a single source of research in magazines the way in TV the only source is Nielsen."
That would be problematic, he added, because "agencies should have a multiplicity of facts" when making decisions as crucial as allocating print advertising budgets.
Mr. Guthrie agreed that it "would not be in our interest at all to have one of the services on the ropes or out of business, because a monopoly situation only cuts down on your options."
The Four A's is seeking to quell the dispute by inviting executives from the publishers association, Simmons and Mediamark to a meeting in New York on Sept. 23.
"We're serving as a facilitator for what we view as a fact-finding meeting," Mr. Drake said, "to give the parties an opportunity to present their points of view."
All those invited have agreed to attend, along with executives of the Advertising Research Foundation, which establishes standards for ad research. Mr. Guthrie, in a letter sent on Wednesday to that organization, asked its executives to review the draft report.
"Our hope is that the A.R.F. will supervise any further action it believes should be taken," Mr. Guthrie wrote in his letter, a copy of which he read yesterday. "A.R.F. is the appropriate body for further discussion."
Michael J. Naples, president of the research foundation, said that he would "get the right parties together to take a look at it and decide what to do."
"If it comes down to assessing an individual commercial firm, that isn't something we do," he added. "We need to see if it's generalizable as an industry issue, if there's something we can do that's constructive."

HEADLINE: Initial Claims By Jobless Fall

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Fewer Americans applied for first-time state unemployment benefits last week than any week since July, the Labor Department said today.
The four-week moving average, a less volatile representation of the underlying labor market than the weekly totals, declined for the fifth week in a row and was at the lowest level since Dec. 25, 1993. 
 "There is not anything surprising in the report, but claims do remain subdued and they suggest the labor market is fairly healthy," said David Sloan, senior economist at IDEA Inc.
The Labor Department said new claims in the week that ended last Saturday fell to 322,000 from a revised 325,000 the previous week. It was the lowest level since the last week of July, when the level of claims was 315,000.

HEADLINE: Home-Resale Drop Posted

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes fell for the third straight month in July as demand for housing continued to be hurt by rising interest rates, a real estate trade group said today.
The group, the National Association of Realtors, said sales of existing single-family homes dipped three-tenths of 1 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.95 million. 
 The July decline followed drops of 3.6 percent in June and three-tenths of 1 percent in May. Since January, sales of previously owned homes have fallen in five out of seven months as demand has been hurt by rising interest rates that were initiated when the Federal Reserve began tightening credit to ward off inflationary pressures.
Still, industry executives noted that the July sales pace was 2.6 percent higher than it was a year ago and that even with the rise in rates, mortgages were at relatively low levels, especially compared with the mid-1980's.
The national median price for an existing single-family home was $111,500 in July, down 1.2 percent from a median price of $112,800 in June. The median is the midpoint where half the homes cost more and half cost less.
The biggest decline was in the Northeast, a drop of 4.8 percent, which left sales at an annual rate of 600,000 units. Sales were also off in the South.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Oh, Strike That: Talks Put Off Until Further Notice

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
With the temperature rising on the last day of the second week of the baseball strike, mediators recessed talks indefinitely yesterday, leaving the owners and players no less rigid in their positions than when they began face-to-face bargaining two days ago.
The heat came from each side in a give-and-take discussion of the owners' salary-cap proposal, according to participants in the second bargaining session, attended by 12 owners and club executives and a large group of players. 
 Not that the two sides were screaming at each other, but the four-member mediation team apparently felt that the talks were in danger of sliding backward, if that were possible, and they didn't want the situation to deteriorate.
"At this point it's our determination to recess these negotiations, subject to call," John Calhoun Wells, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said after the two sides had met and caucused for three and half hours. "We will remain in close contact with both sides, exploring the most productive and useful format for resumption of these negotiations."
 
Strike Plods On
 And so, with 181 games and perhaps 375 home runs lost forever, the strike plods on. With 38 days and 488 games left in the scheduled season, nothing has happened that offers any hope for an agreement to rescue some of those days and games. The owners still want their salary cap, and the players still want no part of it.
The decision to recess the talks was made after a half-hour meeting the mediators had with each side's negotiating team. During that session, one of the participants, referring to some of the heated comments made earlier in the big meeting, remarked, "If we keep going, it's going to be like bullfrogs croaking on a pond."
Bullfrogs, it seems, are very competitive, striving to see which one can croak the longest, the deepest and the loudest. That, according to some of the participants, was how the meeting at the Hotel Inter-Continental was proceeding.
One of the more heated exchanges, they said, took place between Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox, one of baseball's most noted bullfrogs, and several union officials.
 
'We'll Do a Deal'
 Reinsdorf, people in the room related, kept saying the players should tell the owners what percentage of the owners' revenue they wanted and "we'll do a deal." After he asked again, "What percentage do you want?" Donald Fehr, the union chief, shot back, "How much profit do you want?" Reinsdorf did not croak an answer.
The owners have proposed to change baseball's economic system by placing a limit on club payrolls and have offered to give the players 50 percent of their revenue for their total compensation, including salaries, bonuses, daily meal money and pension and health care benefits.
The players have rejected the entire proposal, but the owners keep urging them to make a counterproposal, including any percentage they want. The players won't do that because they then would be accepting the concept of a salary cap.
One of the players' arguments against a cap is that it would inhibit free agency, preventing players from moving to teams whose caps are full or too close to full to offer the free agent a decent contract.
In a long opening statement at yesterday's meeting, David Glass, chairman of the Kansas City Royals and president and chief executive officer of Wal-Mart Stores, told the players baseball had to be more competitive to get entertainment dollars.
Glass also said, according to people at the table, "I don't understand how our plan can affect free agency."
Union officials figured he knew, but they explained it anyway. "There was a bit of an education process going on," Doyle Pryor, a union lawyer, said.
Educational sessions were conducted in smaller groups, too. During the lunch break, Wendy Selig-Prieb, vice president of the Milwaukee Brewers, responded to criticism the day before by Curt Schilling of the Philadelphia Phillies about the Brewers' general and administrative expenses. Those costs came under fire in the analysis of the clubs' financial data by Roger Noll, a Stanford University economist who was hired by the union to examine financial data provided by the owners.
Selig-Prieb, daughter of Bud Selig, the team's principal owner and the acting commissioner, explained to some players yesterday that the Brewers had picked up significant extra costs when they assumed operation of County Stadium and its expenses, thus swelling the general and administrative expenses.
Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief negotiator, said that during the last hour and a half of the meeting, owners and players had other side conversations. He seemed to think some of them might become productive. "I don't know what they all were," he said at a news conference. "I may hear about some of them."
 
Smaller Groups Expected
 Ravitch returned to his office to meet with his group of 12 club representatives. There was no indication whether any of them would return to the bargaining table, but Ravitch said that when talks resume he expects the groups to be smaller, the negotiating teams perhaps being joined by some owners and some players.
Fehr said he didn't know what the makeup of the management group would be in future sessions, but he said: "We're not going to exclude players and we're not going to have a press blackout. Other than that, whatever arrangement makes Dick feel better about it, that's what we'll do."
The mediators planned to talk with each side, engaging in a form of shuttle diplomacy to determine the right time for the next session. It is not expected before sometime next week.
Asked if the recess means talks have broken off, Fehr said, "We're not at the stage where somebody walked out in a huff and said, 'I don't want to talk to you again.' We're at the stage where there isn't anything to talk about."
Ravitch said he didn't think the lack of progress at these meetings was a foregone conclusion. "Nobody could know from day to day what's going to happen," he said.
Fehr, not surprisingly, did not agree with Ravitch's assessment
 
Cheering for the Cap
 "We suggested ahead of time these meetings would produce mostly a cheer session for Dick and the salary cap and that's mostly what they produced," Fehr said. "There has been no movement, no indication there's going to be any movement. The clubs are exactly where they planned to be. Their schedule has some time to run. How long we don't know."
In response to a question, Fehr said he believed one of the reasons the owners won't take their salary-cap proposal off the table is their intention to implement it unilaterally in the off season.
"If you change to another proposal," he said, "you have to make a unilateral imposition consistent with your last proposal. The adherence to the cap proposal, he added, is evidence that they do not want to reach agreement."
With the chances of salvaging any part of the season or the post-season dwindling with each unproductive day, John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox said management has thought of the possibility of playing the World Series later in a domed stadium but that it was impractical and "almost impossible" because of stadium commitments.
"It's unfair to the fans of those teams," he added. "We'd take that into consideration." But he added, "If it was absolutely necessary to have the World Series, it's possible we'd give it serious consideration."
The way Schilling, the Phillies' pitcher, sees it, no consideration will be necessary.
"I don't think we're playing baseball again this year," he said, a touch of sadness in his voice, "unless there's a complete reversal of fortune."
