HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber 

 BODY:

New to the Circle
"I've been aware I had to find a successor for some time," Theodore Mann said yesterday, telling why he recently named Josephine R. Abady co-artistic director of Circle in the Square.
Mr. Mann, himself the artistic director of the organization he helped found in 1951, is 70 years old, and for the last 18 months he has been desperately trying to keep the Circle, which hasn't put on a show since May 1993, from drowning in debt. 
 "I wanted someone who had been a director and someone who had run a theater," said Mr. Mann. "Someone who had faced the problems that an institutional theater faces, who could find sources of new funding. In other words, someone who has been in it up to the neck."
Ms. Abady, whom people call Josie, is in her 40's. She spent six years as the artistic director of the Cleveland Play House before her surprise dismissal in January by a board that was apparently dissatisfied with her nontraditional, occasionally risky programming. Before that she was the artistic director of the Berkshire Theater Festival for nine years. Both theaters were financially struggling when she went to them, and both were in better shape when she left. In a joint interview with Mr. Mann yesterday, she said she was about to sign a four-year contract, with an option to renew, that would elevate her to the position of sole artistic director in the fourth year, with Mr. Mann assuming the title of producing director and maintaining a voice in programming, but ceding the creative authority to Ms. Abady.
She enters a vexing situation. The theater, at 254 West 50th Street, has a debt of $1.3 million, the staff is down to five full-timers and there are 8,000 paid subscribers from a year ago who are owed a season. That season -- three plays chosen by Mr. Mann: a 20th-anniversary production of "The Shadow Box," by Michael Cristofer; "Uncle Vanya," starring Tom Courtenay, and a new American play Mr. Mann would not yet name -- will cost $4.1 million to put on, including debt service. Most of that is supposed to be covered by ticket sales, but of course money has to be raised to put a show on to begin selling tickets for it. The theater's estimate of what it will need to begin mounting the first show, now planned for November, is $250,000 to $300,000.
"It's very difficult to raise money for debt service," Ms. Abady said. "We're doing O.K. Could we be doing better? Yes. Are we going to raise what we need to get started? Yes."
Ms. Abady and Mr. Mann said their aim was to bring the theater into the 21st century with big, adventurous shows, giving as examples "The Kentucky Cycle" and "Abe Lincoln in Illinois." The emphasis will be on American plays, including a commitment to one new play a year, and they say they would like to establish a repertory company.
"Those are our dreams," said Ms. Abady, who will not direct a show this year so she can concentrate on setting the theater's financing and administration on a new road. "Now you want to talk about reality?"
 
'On the Waterfront'
 Over the Fourth of July weekend, Marcus Ticotin was talking to his former brother-in-law, and thence came the possibility that Budd Schulberg's dramatization of his own famous screenplay, "On the Waterfront," would come to Broadway.
Mr. Ticotin's sister, it turns out, is the actress Rachel Ticotin, who was once married to David Caruso, the one-foot-out-the-door star of television's "N.Y.P.D. Blue." And after a visit over the holiday weekend, it occurred to Mr. Ticotin, a producer of ballet and opera, that Mr. Caruso could be a contender for the role of Terry Malloy, the boxer-turned-dock worker who stands up to the mob, whom Marlon Brando made legend in Elia Kazan's 1954 film.
Mr. Ticotin then broached the idea to a friend, Mitchell Maxwell, a producer of films and Broadway shows (including the current revival of "Damn Yankees"). A result: Two weeks ago, the two men bought from Mr. Schulberg the rights to produce his play on Broadway between now and the spring of 1996.
Mr. Maxwell said this week that the play, which had its most significant previous production in 1988 at the Cleveland Play House (where it was directed by Josephine Abady, and where Terry Malloy was played by Grant Show, who is now, of course, a star of television's "Melrose Place"), lends itself to an extravagant production. It has a cast of 19, with action taking place simultaneously in more than one place onstage, and deserves to be produced "like a musical without the music." The money is in place for a production that could get on a Broadway stage as early as next spring, and if not, he said, then definitely in the fall.
Mr. Maxwell said the budget for the show was $1.5 million to $1.8 million, and it is already accounted for, guaranteed by his own company, Workin' Man Films. The show will go on, he said, with or without David Caruso, who is, Mr. Maxwell confirmed, the first choice for the role, and has been asked for a commitment of six months of performances. Mr. Maxwell added that obviously Mr. Caruso wouldn't be paid anything like the $50,000 a week he has been reported to have been offered.
Mr. Caruso, who hasn't been on stage in years (his manager, Chris Wright, said he didn't remember the last time), has just signed to star in "Jade," a movie thriller for $2 million. Conventional career-management wisdom would have it that he ought to do a few more movies to establish his drawing power and crank his price up before trying anything as risky as a Broadway play, where critics will be gunning for him and the money isn't anywhere near as good. So is Mr. Caruso actually considering this?
Yes, said Mr. Wright.
"The interest is sincere and the project is intriguing," he said. "The question is availability."
 
How Risky
 Two plays crossing in the night. "Suburbia," Eric Bogosian's raucous drama now finishing its run at Lincoln Center Theater, was a candidate for Broadway this fall at a Shubert theater, but the Shuberts decided against supporting the move.
"They decided it was overly risky, as opposed to risky," said Bernard Gersten, the executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater.
Meanwhile, Cynthia Ozick's "Blue Light," now at the Bay Street Theater Festival in Sag Harbor, L.I., could be on its way. The Shuberts have made an offer that has been termed, by one of the play's producers, David Brown, "economically feasible." And Bernard Jacobs, the Shubert president, acknowledges that they have been talking.
"But I don't know that anything has been decided," he said. As for "Suburbia," he added, "I never like to say why we didn't do anything."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Old Friends and Bad Plans" -- Fred Ward is to play Vinnie, a double-dealing blackmailer in "Simpatico," Sam Shepard's new play about old friends, incriminating pictures and the Kentucky Derby. The play, which failed to land a commercial production last season, is to open at the Joseph Papp Public Theater on Nov. 1, with a cast that also includes Beverly D'Angelo, Marcia Gay Harden and Ed Harris.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 3; Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Sculpture Under the Sky: Free, Daring and Soon Departed

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
A CENTURY ago, there were two kinds of outdoor sculpture in New York City: sculpture that commemorated and sculpture that decorated. American Presidents, Arctic explorers, even heroic huskies found themselves cast in bronze in Central Park. Nymphs and angels and animals of stone were de rigueur on fountains and facades across the city.
Things have changed with time. Heroism counts for less in our uncommemorative age and modernist architecture of glass and steel has little use for ornament. Yet, as even a glancing look at recent outdoor sculpture reveals, the form still flourishes. Detached from old uses, it is perhaps more marginal than of yore, but it is also more adventurous: as often abstract as figurative, politically critical rather than celebratory, confrontational rather than seductive, perfectly willing to trade permanence for ephemerality. 
 Adventurousness has liabilities. A few years ago, Richard Serra's "Tilted Arc" in Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan was judged user-hostile and carted away. And much experimental outdoor work by younger artists has a tough time landing a venue. None of the pieces seen on this summer's outdoor sculpture tour will be staying where they are and a common outdoor exhibition format is the group show in which several disparate works are corraled on a kind of sculptural wildlife preserve. But even under these conditions, the work has at least the potential for vivifying the city through a street-level participation unknown to gallery-bound art.
Roosevelt Island is as good a place as any to begin an outdoor sculpture tour, though the work on hand is of mixed quality. For the second summer, Manhattan's nonprofit Sculpture Center has organized a group show here and installed it in the lower level of the Motorgate (the island's transportation complex), just under the Roosevelt Island Bridge to Queens.
Site may not be everything to sculpture, but it can mean a lot, and this exceptionally dour space tends to dim the already feeble wattage of this year's show. Luisa Caldwell tries to perk it up by covering four of the structure's columns with bright wallpaper, converting them to sculpture by default. Her 19th-century French black floral patterns set against a red ground have a certain pizazz, but not nearly enough to warm their chilly surroundings.
Andrew Dunhill's steel assemblage of squat, interlocking stars and blocks is sensibly middle-of-the-road traditional. Satoru Takahashi's piece is more off-beat. He has created a bus stop shelter equipped with Plexiglas hemispheres that accommodate the viewer's head. From inside, they offer a distorted fish-eye view of the street. Moderately entertaining.
Only Itty Neuhaus's "Padded Landing" hints at the kind of sheer visual zaniness that outdoor work can shoot for. Ms. Neuhaus has encased an entire car frame in what looks like a colossal brioche and suspended it in a net from the Motorgate's high ceiling. Is it flying or being gently lowered to its parking space, cushioned against a fall? Whatever, it is a witty response to its garagelike setting and a reminder of the traffic streaming across the bridge overhead.
On the Queens side of that bridge is Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, where close to 40 works, large and small, sit on a scrappy 4.5-acre waterfront lot facing Manhattan. There's a relaxed, informal feeling to Socrates, with works under way, under repair, in storage and just completed sitting in close proximity.
Some of the sculptures are by familiar artists in characteristic form. One of Chris MacDonald's overgrown wooden toys is here, as are three painted bronze figures by John Ahearn and a recent piece by the Socrates Park founder, Mark di Suvero. Mr. di Suvero was one of the pioneers of large-scale abstract outdoor sculpture 30-plus years ago, and his angled, stretching "Iroquois" exemplifies the enthrallment with space over mass that was modernism's redefinition of the genre.
Of particular interest, though, are several pieces by less well-known artists constituting this summer's show, "International 1993/ 94." The works vary in style and in quality, but there are some common links. References to nature, for example, abound. The four cast-iron fish in Jack Pospisil's "Salmon Cycle" refer to the river; Beth Galston's metal treehouse incorporating birch saplings recalls the forests that once grew along the shores, while Gunilla Bandolin's key-shaped, brick-lined amphitheater leads directly into a mound of earth.
Win Knowlton's remarkable "East River Landscape" -- a big rough disk of concrete with tires, bottles, duck decoys and other river detritus embedded in it -- is a cautionary vision of what nature in the immediate locale has become under the assault of industry, while John Hock has transformed immense machine parts -- including the barrel of a cement mixer -- into a funny, blundering bouquet to industry itself.
 
MetrotTech Center
 Ursula von Rydingsvard's three sculptures at two different locations within the sprawling Metrotech Center in Downtown Brooklyn are also monumental, but their spirit is gravely poetic.
Like most of Ms. von Rydingsvard's work, they are made of fragrant cedar beams laminated and then chiseled, sawn and gouged. One piece looks like a massive wall pocked with hacked-out indentations, another like the remains of an ancient ship. A third consists of 16 separate logs lying side by side on the ground. Carved with spiral patterns, they suggest outsized ritual instruments whose precise purpose is obscure. Expressionistic, romantic, redolent of myth, Ms. von Rydingsvard's works are like little oases of Teutonic reserve amid the bustling commercial activity at Metrotech.
 
Long Island University
 Much of the work at Long Island University, just across the street from the Metrotech Center, represents a complete departure from Ms. von Rydingsvard's hand-wrought, material-rich approach. The school's Fifth Annual Outdoor Sculpture Exhibition, organized by Marian Griffiths, includes several pieces of Conceptual sculpture that can barely be seen at all.
Even the most concrete piece has been carefully integrated into its surroundings. David Kramer's large, flat, black, steel "X" constitutes an apt political emblem for Downtown Brooklyn. At the same time, the elaborate girding welded to its back side amusingly mimics the structural support of a Dime Savings Bank billboard directly across the street, setting up an interesting web of socio-economic associations.
From that point on, the work in the show gets lighter and lighter, to charming effect. True, Michael Merchant's slim pavilion of upright poles is easy enough to spot. It holds 20 Instamatic cameras, which passers-by are invited to use for picture-taking (borrowing is on the honor system and Mr. Merchant processes the film free). But Lee Boroson's baby-blue inflated rubber bladders, clinging like helium balloons to a courtyard wall, and Lisa Hein's red banner, whose only emblem is a smile-shaped cut that lets the breeze pass through, are all but invisible to even the most attentive eye.
Judith Simonian has come up with the most discreet work of all: two trash cans at opposite sides of the university's main plaza linked by invisible speaking tubes for quick information exchanges or a casual tryst. Ms. Simonian's low-tech, radically anti-monumental mode could easily become precious, but it represents one of contemporary art's distinctive formal contributions: it is a sculpture of the inconspicuous and the physically inconsequential, requiring viewers' patience but rewarding it with an intimacy seldom associated with public work.
 
Snug Harbor
 Site-specific work in a similar vein can be found at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island, a former refuge for retired sailors whose grand Greek Revival buildings and shade-dappled grounds make it one of the city's most delightful parks.
Of the works in this year's annual outdoor sculpture show, called "Thresholds and Transitions," Kate Dodd's "now you see it, now you don't" "Meander" takes full advantage of its setting. The piece exists almost entirely as traces of Day-Glo orange paint marking a route through the Snug Harbor grounds in Livingston. The first stroke appears on a bench set under the portico of Main Hall; others show up here and there on pavement or as colored paper pulp pressed into the bark of trees. The path ends with a ramshackle wooden perch over a wooded glade, by which point Ms. Dodd's peripatetic, performative work has offered the diligent viewer total submersion in Snug Harbor's serene terrain. (Unfortunately, the Parks Department has fears that some of Ms. Dodd's materials may be environmentally unsound and her piece is scheduled for removal in the near future.)
Of the other pieces in this year's show, Jim Hirschfield's "Synesthetic Dream" is technically an indoor installation assembled in a turretlike gatehouse on the grounds. Bringing together digital clocks, orchids, painted glass vases, pinned butterflies and atmospheric lighting, he creates an environment in which physical dimensions are ambiguous and time is palpably on the move. The effect borders on sci-fi hokum, but hokum skillfully done.
The best work is Leone and Macdonald's "Outhouse," a steel door, its central panel missing, set on hinges within a frame. A bronze knob on one side is marked with the word "Us," on the other side with "Them," and the door swings both ways, giving insiders and outsiders, whatever those terms may mean, equal access. And thanks to its thoughtful siting, the piece has much to say about outdoor sculpture itself, old and new. Looking through the door from one direction, one sees a view of the waterway called the Kill van Kull; looking through from the other, the 19th-century obelisk-shaped tomb of Snug Harbor's founder, Robert Richard Randall. Nature and culture are conflated, and the moral preoccupations of our own time are linked to the memorial concerns of another.
 
Battery Park City
 Tyrone Mitchell's "Chair in the Sky: For Charles Mingus," on the south end of the Esplanade at Battery Park City, is poignant evidence, in fact, that the commemorative spirit in outdoor sculpture lives on. Mr. Mitchell has constructed a small chair from scraps of found wood cast in bronze, and set it high on a pole against the sky within sight of another impressive outdoor work, the Statue of Liberty. The chair is based on the form of an African king's throne and in place of a likeness of the great jazz musician, Mr. Mitchell has placed a low pyramid on the seat, as if to channel energy -- the music of the spheres, perhaps -- down to this spot.
 
Central Park
 Judith Shea's new work, "The Other Monument," at Doris C. Freedman Plaza -- commissioned, like Mr. Mitchell's, by the Public Art Fund -- is also commemorative, symbolically rich and politically nuanced. Its spare, dark-stained wooden figure on horseback stands atop a 10-foot-tall boxy platform at the southeast entrance to Central Park, just behind Augustus Saint-Gaudens's gilded equestrian monument to Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman.
While Saint-Gaudens's sculpture honors a Civil War leader, Ms. Shea's speaks in memory of American slaves, to whom comparable monuments were never erected and many of whose graves have been obliterated. Whether the Union that Sherman fought for can ever be realized as long as racial disharmony exists is one of the many questions Ms. Shea's figure raises. And historically speaking, there is some logic in the fact that while Sherman will continue his triumphant sculptural ride on Fifth Avenue in perpetuity, "The Other Munument" will have left its spot by this time next year.
 
Riverbank State Park
 Another of the summer's figurative works also has a message to convey. Robert Ressler's "No Heat," in the striking, still-new park along the Hudson in West Harlem called Riverbank State Park, consists of two huge carved wooden legs set in a striding position. The feet are shod in thick sandals and the trousers on one leg are rolled up to mid-calf, explaining the work's title: in street parlance, this sartorial touch is a visual code indicating that the wearer is not carrying a gun strapped to the ankle.
If "No Heat," which is still being worked on at Riverbank, is neither the grandest nor the subtlest of the outdoor sculptures on view in the city, it gives a fair sense of the genre's distinctive potential. It exploits the kind of eye-catching scale that plein air siting permits, and it shrewdly addresses itself to the concerns of the community in which it appears. Mr. Ressler's piece, like public work throughout the centuries, will be a recurrent, even daily experience for its viewers, subliminally shaping their lives and sharpening their vision in ways that physically less available art cannot. It is heartening to see contemporary public sculpture, with all its strengths and weaknesses, embrace this responsibility.

Walk west on Liberty Street and make left onto South End Avenue; continue on the avenue to South Cove. There is free street parking in Battery Park City, as well as several parking lots.

"International 1993/94," through the fall. The tram leaves Manhattan every hour on the hour from 59th Street and Second Avenue and is met about eight minutes later by the bus at the tram station on Roosevelt Island; the bus then picks up passengers at the Roosevelt Island subway station and arrives at the Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City eight minutes later. It arrives at the Sculpture Center on Roosevelt Island 33 minutes after the hour. The fare, $8, includes the round-trip tram and bus rides and admissions to all the cultural institutions on its run; $5 for students, children and the elderly. Information: (212) 832-4540, Extension 386.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Starring John Candy and Various Crude Jokes

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
What if the citizens of Prosperity, a frontier town in the Old West, got fed up with their pioneer existence and decided to head back East? And what if they chose for the leader of their wagon train a drunken tub of a man who can barely tell left from right? That is the less-than-scintillating premise of "Wagons East!," a dimwitted comedy that like the addled wagonmaster John Harlow (John Candy), who tries to lead them home, takes all the wrong turns.
"Wagons East!" has the distinction of being Candy's final film, and it is dedicated to his memory. That, unfortunately, is its only distinction. Directed by Peter Markle, from a screenplay by Matthew Carlson, this series of loosely strung-together gags is so desperate for humor that it falls back on jokes about flatulence and penis size. Candy, who was a gifted comic actor, has little to do but lumber around and act endearingly dumb. 
 Most of the passengers on the wagon train are contemporary urban types who find themselves way out of their element. Richard Lewis is a neurotic surgeon who has developed a phobia about wielding a scalpel, and who during the trek insists on conducting group-therapy sessions. And when he finally does pick up a scalpel, watch out!
Another traveler is a homosexual bookseller who has given up trying to peddle Jane Austen to the rough-and-ready frontiersmen at whom he is always making eyes. As played by John C. McGinley, he is a walking dictionary of stereotypically effeminate gay mannerisms. Ellen Greene plays Belle, a whore with a heart of gold, with the same Betty Boop voice she brought to "Little Shop of Horrors."
On their eastward trek, the travelers accidentally stray into Sioux Indian territory and are menaced first by a professional gunslinger and then by the United States Cavalry. Both the gunslinger, whom Ed Lauter plays as a Clint Eastwood caricature, and the cavalry are mobilized by a greedy railroad baron who sees the party's retreat as signaling a trend-setting economic threat.
Typical of the movie's humor is the moment when a bellicose young Indian protests to his father that he despises his name, which subtitles reveal means Little Feather. On the spot he is rechristened with a name that means Big Snake That Makes Women Faint. "Wagons East!" is the kind of movie that stops in its tracks every time it tries to tell a joke, and it is invariably one that is not worth repeating.
"Wagons East!" is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It has off-color humor and mild violence.

WAGONS EAST!

HEADLINE: Cuba: Time to Talk

 BODY:
Well, why not open broad negotiations with the Castro regime?
The Clinton Administration was quick to rebuff Fidel Castro's proposal of multi-issue talks yesterday. Washington anticipated a propaganda session where Havana would offer to keep its unhappy citizens from leaving only if the U.S. promised to ease its economic embargo, halt anti-Castro radio broadcasts and maybe throw in the return of the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base to Cuba as well. 
 The Administration says immigration is the only issue it will talk about. Washington should respond more creatively, insisting that any discussion of issues between the two countries must also include democracy and human rights.
Fidel Castro has had his dictatorial way with Cuba for the past 35 years, brooking no dissent, turning neighbors into spies and driving many of his own people to risk their lives to get away. He blames the U.S. for troubles of his own making and would sooner see Cuba's economy collapse than make concessions to foreign demands.
If that kind of behavior disqualified a regime from negotiations, Washington would never have been able to reach out to Mao's China or Kim Il Sung's North Korea. Neither could it have talked with Syria about Mideast peace terms, Bosnian Serbs about cease-fires or Haiti's generals about the return of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
In diplomacy, it is often more important for governments to talk to their enemies than to their friends. That is how Israel reached agreement with the Palestine Liberation Organization. But for most of the past three and a half decades, Washington has never seriously considered talking to Havana.
It ought to consider such talks now. The Castro regime's present weakness makes this an especially promising moment to negotiate, if Washington plays its hand effectively.
Once a genuine menace as a Soviet outpost, Cuba has power to influence American politics that has outlasted the cold war. Hundreds of thousands of Cuban emigres are now U.S. voters and their most vocal leaders have made any dialogue with Cuba a domestic political taboo. The Administration is understandably reluctant to challenge that taboo. It does not need any new political problems. Yet its attempt to improvise unilateral responses to the refugee challenge is already damaging its own credibility and jeopardizing broader American interests.
For what good cause is the Administration preventing Cuban-Americans from helping their families stretch meager budgets with dollar payments? Has it not yet learned the importance of setting, and holding to, its foreign policy priorities?
The Cuban-American hard-liners from whom the Administration is taking its cues want to escalate internal tensions in Cuba rapidly in order to force an explosion, and perhaps a U.S. intervention, that would bring the Castro regime down in flames. The Administration itself is not prepared to go that far, nor is it clear that such an Armageddon scenario would serve Cuban democracy or America's best interests. Many Cuban-Americans also shy away from a confrontation that could turn their own relatives into sacrificial victims.
By agreeing to wide-ranging talks with Cuba now, and insisting on the broadest possible agenda, the U.S. may find it has some bargaining power to help Cubans struggling for democratic change. The alternative is to punish Cubans and embarrass the United States. That would not hurt Mr. Castro nearly so much as it would damage Mr. Clinton.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Why Two Cops Were Shot in the Subway

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Two cops are wounded by police bullets in frenzied crossfire on a New York subway platform. The people and the press demand to know why such a thing happened, and who was responsible.
Why? Two young thugs strolled into the subway, one with a handgun and the other with a shotgun. That is why. The rest is the consequence of cops risking their lives to do their duty. 
 One plainclothes officer, gun drawn, chased the two men. He was shot by mistake by an off-duty policeman also wearing civilian clothes, who was then shot by a transit officer.
Who was responsible? The two men who carried their guns into the subway, criminals in the act.
Cause and responsibility seem to me obvious. But living in this city you would certainly never guess it. The press, lawyers, public, even the police all concentrate not on the thugs and how armed hoods can strut about streets and subways, but on how come cops do not react unfailingly to the sight of a man aiming his gun by bowing, checking the wristband color of the day and exchanging badge numbers and calling cards.
One day science may tell us how to hire only cops with infallible control over their adrenaline, heart rate and brain signals. Meantime, I want to see, read or hear a lot more about the guns and how the criminals got them, who owned them before and how many death merchants are peddling guns on what streets. That's the how come I want to know.
I want to know about every crime the men committed before taking guns into the subway. And please, easy on the bit about how their neighbors say what good boys they were.
Mayor Giuliani and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton have stood by the officers while ordering the necessary inquiries. But I am sorry they missed a chance to tear the head off New Yorkers.
They should have said that our city, like the whole United States, is fouled by guns, stinks of them. Say it plain: Until we do something about that deathly stench the men and women we hire to protect us will be doing their duty knowing that every minute of every tour they are surrounded by muggers, killers and thieves in greater number, expertise and firepower than the world has ever experienced.
I favor total registration and licensing of guns and government control of all gun sales outlets. I know very many Americans will fight every move. The rest of us can fight back with every political, intellectual and economic tool we have, win when we can and return to fight again.
But is that really all, no way for us to fight guns ourselves?
If I were mayor, I would lead the essential attitude-change campaign, from a button in my lapel to organizing parades, demonstrations, neighborhood watches, rewards; and do that for the rest of my term.
If I were a rich man, I would put big philanthropy money into anti-gun causes; maybe then my chauffeur could park outside my favorite restaurant without getting a gun stuck in his ear.
A teacher: I would fill my walls with anti-gun truths, and my children's heads. A clergyman: I would not have to be told.
If I were a politician I would fight for tougher anti-gun laws, and if I were a judge I would enforce them. If I were a member of a civil liberties group I would insist that it re-examine its positions against allowing search for guns, or blocking public housing tenants from having their buildings swept.
As a journalist, I can ask print editors and TV news producers to put more violence into the news, a different kind, the violence of truth.
I would tell cameramen on the spot to get tight close-ups of the wounds if at all possible. I would ask the police -- or courts if necessary -- for pre-autopsy pictures from the morgue, and print them.
The pictures would sicken children and grown-ups, which would be the purpose. It would be one antidote of truth against the lies we constantly see in movies, TV reruns and videos: gun-shot people with no viscera hanging out of their bodies, no feces dripping from their clothes.
None of these ideas will end America's gun disgrace. Only a few generations of voters will do that. But it is a lot more useful to do something against guns yourself, any decent thing, than just hang around clucking at cops for having found themselves on a subway platform when two men strutted in, smug with firepower.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON'S ALLIES ON HEALTH CONCEDE THAT BROAD PLAN IS ALL BUT DEAD THIS YEAR

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Democratic Congressional leaders and White House officials today all but conceded any chance of passing universal health insurance legislation this year. But they vowed to press on for what they can get, and suggested they would take anything that did more good than harm.
As the Senate decamped for a two-week break, and the House extended its own vacation to match, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, both took sober stock of the remaining prospects for health insurance legislation and laid some groundwork for what might yet be won. 
 In one sense, Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Panetta were simply stating the obvious. But their comments also reflected the reality that the Senate's adjournment without acting on health was an irretrievable step and that the President will have to choose between settling for something far less than the universal health coverage he has insisted on and nothing at all.
Mr. Mitchell said that anything that might be passed "clearly will not be a bill as comprehensive as I would prefer, but there's much that can be done that would represent progress."
For his part, Mr. Panetta maintained public optimism, saying he still hoped that a break from the Capitol's rancor and glare would let a bipartisan group of Senate moderates forge a compromise that would meet Mr. Clinton's fundamental goals. But he said that Mr. Clinton could accept a plan that called for only incremental changes -- like insurance law changes to prevent companies from denying coverage to sick people -- as long as Congress did not portray it as fulfilling the task of health care restructuring.
"That is something the President would look at," Mr. Panetta said, though he steadfastly refused to say what options Mr. Clinton might accept, saying it was too soon to say what Congress might present. "But it isn't health care reform and nobody should be misled that it's health care reform."
Mr. Clinton himself spoke to reporters in careful terms. "I certainly don't want to embrace an approach that will do more harm than good and that won't achieve our objectives," he said. "But let's see what they're doing, and see what people are feeling like after they get a night's sleep or two." At another point, he said passage of the crime bill showed it was possible to pass complex, sweeping legislation, "So I'm not prepared to make a final judgment on that at this time."
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, campaigning in Oklahoma for Representative James M. Inhofe, the Republican Senate nominee there, issued a statement warning that there was so little time left on the legislative calendar that "unless we sacrifice Congressional action on everything else," there was no way the Senate could pass a health care bill that went beyond the basic insurance provisions in Mr. Dole's own bill.
No words could disguise the change that had come over the Capitol.
Corridors that had rung just 24 hours earlier with fierce oratory and dueling news conferences were silent this morning, as Senators hurried home to campaign or vacation, and skeletal staffs stayed behind to work.
The White House's best hope for some action still seemed to rest with a bipartisan group of moderates led by Senator John H. Chafee, the Rhode Island Republican who was one of seven members of his party to break ranks and help the Democrats pass the $30 billion crime bill on Thursday. The group is working on a scaled-back proposal for insurance law changes and deficit reduction.
"We think there's still time to come up with good legislation," Mr. Chafee said as he left Mr. Mitchell's office at midday with Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat and co-leader of the group. But he added, "That doesn't mean it's easy."
Mr. Mitchell said this afternoon that the meeting had gone very well and that "there are many ways where there is a common objective and we'll be able to think of ways to reach a common objective and find ways to reach agreement."
 
More Ideas Take Shape
 Mr. Chafee and Mr. Breaux said their staffs would put their proposals into legislative language and continue working with Mr. Mitchell's aides to delineate points of agreement and remaining differences. But they said they had still not determined whether their proposals would take the form of a completely new bill, amendments to Mr. Mitchell's, or some third, even more whittled-down plan.
As it is, the moderate group's plan relies on new subsidies to increase health insurance coverage to 92 percent of Americans over the next decade, up from 85 percent now, and cuts in growth in Medicare and Medicaid to reduce the Federal deficit by about $100 billion over the same period. Mr. Mitchell's proposal aims to increase coverage to 95 percent and could require employers to cover half their workers' insurance costs if the goal is not met.
The moderates are not the only ones still at work. Democratic Senators on the liberal edge of the party, like Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and Tom Harkin of Iowa, have begun looking for their own minimalist plan, one that might increase coverage for children and the elderly without a new bureaucracy or large tax increases.
But the barriers to any bill are formidable. Just before the final vote on the crime bill, Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who is one of Mr. Dole's potential rivals for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination, took the floor to say that the good news today was that all such plans were dead.
 
Ardent Opponent of Change
 "The Clinton plan is dead, Clinton-Mitchell 1 is dead, Clinton-Mitchell 2 is dead, Clinton-Mitchell 3 is dead and Clinton-Chafee is dead," said Mr. Gramm, who has vowed to fight the Democrats hammer and tongs on the topic.
Mr. Mitchell, asked about that, just smiled. "He said that about the crime bill and he said that about the President's economic plan last year," the leader said. "On two for two, he's been wrong, and I hope that it will be three for three."
Prospects for action in the House, where leaders are waiting for official cost estimates of various pending bills, are just as uncertain. And now, with the Senate away until Sept. 12, House leaders today revised their schedule to return the same day, instead of right after Labor Day. The majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, was at home in St. Louis and made no statement, his office said.
Just as the White House officials have repeatedly refused to be drawn into defining universal coverage, Mr. Panetta, at a luncheon meeting with reporters, declined to say just what incremental steps the President might accept. The Administration has consistently contended, for example, that requiring insurers to accept all customers, even those with health problems, without guarantees of universal coverage could encourage healthy people to wait until they were sick to buy insurance. That would leave insurers with sicker and sicker risk pools, and driving up premiums for everyone else.
 
No Use in Speculating
 "To start speculating now -- it doesn't make any more sense to do that now than it did six months ago," Mr. Panetta said. "What the President is not prepared to do is sign a bill that comes to him under the guise of health care reform but does not meet the needs that he laid out."
Saying that Mr. Clinton had not changed his bottom line, Mr. Panetta said anything portrayed as health care reform had "to be in the Mitchell mode: you can transition it in, but at the end of the transition, you have to arrive at universal coverage."
Mr. Chafee predicted that as businesses realized inaction by Congress this fall could lead to a patchwork of conflicting new insurance requirements imposed by state legislatures, they would support uniform nationwide changes. Otherwise, he said, "they're going to be nibbled to death."
Mr. Breaux added, "I think everybody loses if we don't do anything." But dressed in an open-necked tropical shirt and on his way to a 2:40 P.M. flight to New Orleans, he also hollered good-naturedly at reporters: "Go home! It's vacation time."
Mr. Chafee, too, was headed home, where he faces a re-election race. But, perhaps mindful of the adage that it's easier to tear down a barn than to build one, he had another stop first: the National Building Museum in downtown Washington, to see an exhibit on barn-building.
"I'm a barn nut," he said as he rushed off for a quick chat with Mr. Dole's staff.

But let's see what they're doing, and see what people are feeling like after they get a night's sleep or two."

HEADLINE: Leonard Lesser, 79, A.F.L.-C.I.O. Aide

 BODY:
Leonard Lesser, a lawyer, advocate for the poor and union official who worked in Washington for almost 50 years, died on Wednesday at the home of his daughter in Washington. He was 79.
The cause was cancer, said his daughter, Susan Leighton. 
 Mr. Lesser began his career in Washington in 1939 as a lawyer with the Federal Security Agency, a forerunner of what today is the Department of Health and Human Services. He transferred to the Department of Labor during World War II.
In 1949 Mr. Lesser moved to Detroit to serve as a lawyer with the United Automobile Workers union, and in 1955 he returned to Washington to become general counsel to the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
In 1968 Mr. Lesser left the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and helped found the Center for Community Change, a national philanthropic organization that provides support and advocacy for low-income neighborhoods. He remained as an official of the group until his death.
During his career Mr. Lesser made contributions to legislation affecting expanded pension and unemployment benefits, health insurance programs and welfare.
Mr. Lesser was a graduate of City College of New York and Harvard Law School.
His wife, Muriel, died in 1974. In addition to his daughter, he is survived by a son, Thomas, of Conway, Mass.; his companion, Joan Aron of Washington, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE POLICY;
Refugees Ebb but Tide of Criticism Is Rising

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Thanks to stormy weather, the Clinton Administration got some relief today in the Cuban refugee crisis, but it met heavy Congressional criticism for tightening sanctions and refusing to hold broad talks with President Fidel Castro.
As a result of storms and high waves, the number of Cubans setting out to sea dropped precipitously. The Coast Guard picked up 629 Cubans in the Straits of Florida today as of 10 P.M., a far lower rate than during the previous seven days, when a total of 11,810 Cubans were rescued. 
 President Clinton told reporters that he was encouraged about the decrease in refugees, saying the weather "may or may not have something to do with that." "We just need to be calm, steady and firm," he said. "I think we will work through it just fine."
Members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee who met with Administration officials criticized the President's harsher policy toward Cuba, warning that it would backfire and increase the flow of refugees.
 
Senators Criticize Policy
 The criticism intensified as the Administration announced details carrying out the President's order of Aug. 20 to slash the flow of dollars and American travelers going to Cuba. The new regulations are intended to cut off the flow of more than $150 million that Administration officials say is entering Cuba each year.
"The Cuban Government will no longer have access to these U.S. dollars which have so long helped to sustain the Castro regime," said R. Richard Newcomb, the Treasury Department official overseeing enforcement of the new sanctions.
Under the new regulations released today by the Treasury, Cuban-Americans, who could previously travel freely to visit family members in Cuba, will only be allowed to go for emergencies like terminal illness.
The new regulations also bar Americans or foreigners in the United States from sending money to Cuba unless they can demonstrate that it is for an emergency, like helping an elderly cousin buy medicine. Previously, Americans were allowed to send up to $300 every three months.
Although the new measures will squeeze many poor Cubans, Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, insisted that the sanctions are aimed at hurting Mr. Castro and not the Cuban people.
After meeting late Thursday with Administration officials to discuss Cuba, several senior members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee attacked the new policy.
"The President's policy goes in the wrong direction," Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who is the committee's chairman, said in an interview. "We should ease the embargo because then Cubans will have less incentive to leave and come to Florida. By increasing the embargo, it's increasing the number of people who want to escape the Castro regime."
Senator Pell also criticized President Clinton for rejecting Mr. Castro's call to hold wide-ranging, high-level talks to defuse the crisis. "The more contact between adversaries, the better off we are," he said.
Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican, described Thursday's meeting as an "unmerciful pile-on" in which the six senators present harangued Alexander Watson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, and Morton H. Halperin, a senior National Security Council official. The Senators at the meeting included Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, and Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin.
Senator Lugar said: "The President should not categorically rule out the possibility and usefulness of talks with our adversary at this point. We have found it useful to talk to North Korea, Syria and the Chinese. A great power with substantial diplomatic and military authority ought never be in a situation where it can't discuss what's on its mind."
Senator Dodd said: "They're trapping themselves by adopting a position of no discussions or negotiations. That's a dangerous position to put themselves in."
A task force of former government officials and academics also criticized the Administration's refusal to hold broad talks with Havana. The task force, organized by Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington research center, is headed by former Attorney General Elliot Richardson. It includes Argentina's former President, Raul Alfonsin; McGeorge Bundy, national security adviser to President Kennedy, and John C. Whitehead, deputy secretary of state under President Reagan.
"We urge the two governments to turn away from confrontation and begin to negotiate the issues that divide them," the group said. They also urged the President to reverse his decision to restrict charter flights and curtail remittances to Cuba.
The new sanctions limit the gift parcels to medicine, food and other relief items, effective today.
Under the new regulations, except for the purpose of financing lawful immigration, cash remittances will be permitted only on a case-by-case basis through specific licensing.
Previously, professional researchers could travel freely to Cuba, but under the new rules, researchers will need licenses. The new rules also permit travel by human rights investigators and people on educational or religious missions.
The regulations continue to allow Government officials, journalists and foreign diplomats to travel freely to Cuba. But they revoke previous rules on travel financed by foreign governments or by Cuba.
Administration officials estimated that 50,000 people traveled from the United States to Cuba last year, pumping an estimated $100 million into Cuba's economy. One official said that the new restrictions would cut travel to Cuba by 80 to 90 percent.
Some members of Congress insist the Administration's new sanctions are not tough enough. "We should have a naval blockade around Cuba," said Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, Republican of Florida. "The Administration should use its diplomatic capital to persuade its allies to support such a blockade."
Rather than restricting travel to Cuba, Senator Lugar called on the Administration to increase the flow of tourists, students, satellite dishes and radios to Cuba. That, he said, would increase the flow of Western ideas and help undermine Mr. Castro.

CUBA EASES STAND ON TALKS
 LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Roberto Robaina of Cuba said today that his Government "wouldn't refuse" if the United States wanted to discuss immigration without bringing in other issues.
"Cuba wouldn't refuse if, in the strictly immigration area, there is some interest in having conversations," he said in Bolivia, where he was on an official visit. "We would be ready to listen."
Cuban officials had said earlier this week that their Government would not discuss the current exodus of refugees from Cuba with the United States without discussing a broad range of other outstanding issues.

STATE: RHODE ISLAND, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: CLINTON ADMINISTRATION (90%);

HEADLINE: President Foresees Safer U.S.

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
In exulting over the passage of the $30 billion crime bill, President Clinton predicted wondrous results.
"This crime bill is going to make every neighborhood in America safer," he said, looking forward to the prospect that police officers will no longer be outgunned by criminals, who will also be deterred from crime by the possibility of life in prison as a result of the "three strikes and you're out" provision. 
 But even some of the most ardent supporters of the legislation acknowledge that the crime package, which was the subject of weeks of heated debate, will probably accomplish far less. If there is any lessening of crime, it would only come gradually, they say. Others say the main achievement of the legislation will be to make the public feel that the Government is trying to respond to a growing concern.
The bill cleared its last legislative hurdle Thursday night after the Democrats won over enough Republican votes to overcome a procedural challenge. The legislation, which the President plans to sign when he returns from his vacation next month, bans the sale and possession of 19 models of semiautomatic weapons and other weapons that are nearly identical to those models. It also provides grants to local governments to hire more police officers, variously estimated at 20,000 to 100,000 nationwide; increases from two to 60 the number of Federal offenses for which someone may be sentenced to death, and provides for life sentences for criminals convicted of a third violent felony or drug offenses if the third conviction is a Federal crime.
 
Symbolic Value of Legislation
 Some scholars, removed from the partisan bickering, say it is uncertain whether the measure will appreciably reduce crime. Yet a leading authority said that even if it did not reduce crime, it would have a genuine symbolic benefit for a nation increasingly troubled by crime and the perception that it is growing out of control.
"To talk about its efficacy is to miss the point," said Frank Zimring, a law professor at the University of California at Berkeley. "It is far more important as a symbolic denunciation and expression of concern than as a serious crime counter-measure."
Professor Zimring singled out one part of the legislation that has drawn the most analysis and greatest skepticism: the assertion that the measure provides for the hiring of 100,000 new police officers around the nation.
"It is simply not 100,000 extra police and everybody knows that," he said.
The measure is supposed to increase the number of police in the nation, not immediately but over six years. Yet it provides only about $9 billion, which analysts have said means that local governments would have to supplement the funds they receive with their own revenues.
Moreover, the money from the Federal pie gets smaller each year, leaving the local government with an increasing burden until it has to assume the entire salary of the officer.
 
Reluctance Is Foreseen
 "A lot of cities are going to be reluctant to take this money for this purpose," said Jonathan Rubinstein, a former police officer who has written extensively about policing. Mr. Rubinstein said a local government had to figure that hiring a police officer was a 50-year financial commitment, 20 years on the force and 30 years of pension. "When the money runs out, you can't just lay these people off," he said.
There are more than 20,000 police jurisdictions in the United States and with that in mind, 20,000 to 100,000 new officers does not look like such a large addition, he said.
Which is why, in the debate, Senator John Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, described the crime bill as a down payment on an aggressive commitment to reduce crime.
Gerald Caplan, the dean at the McGeorge School of Law in Sacramento, Calif., said the crime bill was at the least a demonstration that the Government was trying to respond to public concern about crime.
Dean Caplan, who served as director of the National Institute of Justice, a Federal research agency, from 1973 to 1977, said he had long been a skeptic about whether the Federal Government could effectively reduce crime, which has historically been a local concern. "But the revenues available at the local level have not kept pace with both crime and the public frustration about it," he said.
That frustration, he said, is a result of a new breed of criminals on the street who are often as young as 14 and have guns and little social conscience. "These are not good candidates for rehabilitation," he said.
The "three strikes and you're out" provision may have serious flaws, he said, but it will eventually keep some of these criminals behind bars so they cannot commit more crimes.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
No Telling When Sides Will Open Talks Again

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
A deafening silence descended on baseball yesterday as the players strike entered its third week. Following two days of earnest but unproductive and sometimes heated conversation between club officials and players, the visitors to the bargaining table returned home and the principal negotiators retreated to their offices.
John Calhoun Wells, the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, spoke briefly with members of each side but did not suggest a date for the resumption of talks. Wells recessed negotiations Thursday before the owners and players could become too angry with each other and damage future efforts. 
 Just when that future will be is not known. Asked when he might call the two sides back to the table, Wells said from Washington: "That decision won't be made until next week. That'll be driven by our sense of timing based on conversations with the players and the owners."
 
Midweek at the Earliest
 It's most likely the negotiating teams will meet next week but probably not before Wednesday, which is the last day before the start of what usually is the last month of the season. The strike has already wiped out 195 games of the season.
Asked yesterday if he thought the season would resume, Donald Fehr, the head of the players' union, said: "The likelihood goes down with each day you don't have an agreement. I can't tell you at this point if the owners want to resume it."
Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief negotiator, said the owners indeed want to get back to playing, but he added: "There will be no baseball until there is a collective bargaining agreement. There will be no collective bargaining agreement until this issue is resolved."
The issue, stated in various ways by management, is a salary cap, cost control, cost certainty, sharing of the owners' revenue.

 
'A Simple Proposition'
 "We are talking about a simple proposition that was stated clearly and unequivocally at the meeting yesterday," Ravitch said. "How do we divide revenues between us? That has to be addressed and resolved and everything else will fall into place."
Whatever terminology is used, the players view the owners' attempt to change the economic system as an effort to lower their salaries artificially and to impede the movement of free agents.
"What is clear in this negotiation," Fehr said after the second owners-players session, "is the owners' goal is exactly the same as it's been in every negotiation dating back to at least 1976: 'We will impose a series of impediments to free agency. We're going to set up roadblocks.' Sooner or later, this industry has to get past the point where it says someone can't take a job where he wants on whatever terms he can get. The owners won't let him do that. The owners want to limit job opportunities. I don't know how to get anywhere from that position."
 
Not an Inch of Progress
 The two sides have moved nowhere. Chances are, when they return to the table, their positions will be the same. If each side is testing the other, to see if the other will blink or fold, both sides are passing the tests with flying colors.
Ravitch said that after having had private conversations with players during the two days of talks, some owners reported that the players were convinced the owners are not serious about their pursuit of a salary cap and ultimately will change their position. Yet, Ravitch said, the players seemed to be impressed with the sincerity of the views the owners expressed.
When Fehr was asked yesterday if he thought the owners were coming to the conclusion the players will not cave in, he said: "Some of them already know that. Those are the ones that want to carry it past the end of the year."
Was he suggesting that those owners -- the ones who presumably want to reach the point where they can implement the cap unilaterally -- were banking on the players' resolve to carry on their strike through the end of the season?
"I don't know if they're banking on it, but they expected it or they've come to realize it," he said.
Fehr said he wasn't certain who "they" are. "I don't know if there is a 'they' anymore," he said. "What if we're really in the worst situation: They can't get 21 votes for any proposition the players will accept."
He referred to the owners' rule that requires a three-fourths vote of the 28 owners to approve an agreement that would end the strike.
Fehr said he wasn't sure how anyone would proceed from this stagnant point.
"Who knows?" he said. "There are no rules at this stage. There are no expectations."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Rich Bowls, Big Deals, But Better?

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
WE are now supposed to comprehend the difference between a coalition and an alliance. A century and a quarter has passed since the day students from Princeton and Rutgers gathered to begin the process that would one day connect the phrase "smash-mouth" to the mission of American higher education. It seemed like a good idea at the time.
Decades before professional leagues expanded west and south, their game created connections between fragmented rural populations and faraway cities. College football overcame its early brutality to define a sense of time and place. The game provided something that most major league franchises could not and never will, the comfort of lasting personal traditions, passed on in the form of living, breathing heirlooms shared by a region, a state or a nation. The Dodgers could up and move a continent away. The Philadelphia Athletics could leave for Kansas City. But Penn State wasn't going anywhere. 
 But it has, without the need for a single moving van. This is not the fault of anyone near Mount Nittany, whose administrators are far from alone. Emotionally, the Lions moved west when they agreed to join the Big Ten four years ago. Texas and Texas A&M, among others, will soon move north, as they help create the Big 12, leave the Southwest Conference in a lingering death and reduce the importance of the Cotton Bowl forever.
That is the way of the college football industry in the 90's. Every now and then the music starts, and everyone walks apprehensively in a big circle, and when the music suddenly stops you had better be in a seat. Little else matters anymore. Fear has given us the new semantics game, the distinction between a coalition and an alliance. A coalition is this year's convoluted arrangement of bowl games; an alliance is next year's equally convoluted deal. Please don't ask about the deal after that.
With each new arrangement, each new bowl game mating dance and conference reconfiguration, the college football establishment is stepping closer to the danger of forfeiting its most valuable possession -- its soul.
As experts unconcerned with the impact on the lives of players continue to scream for a megadollar playoff scheme, football's traditions have become as much of a problem as a blessing. Basketball has been free to move, to experiment, to meet the demands of the market, because with the exception of a handful of hotbeds, college basketball tradition can now be defined by who played on ESPN last night.
But football traditions were evolving even as James Naismith was tinkering with his peach baskets and his rules. From the time Yale fans took this Princeton concept and turned it into an excuse for a tailgate party, the experience became more personal. Which is why the followers of the game, having held their traditions so close, are having a hard time letting go.
Penn State, to its credit, realized the psychic damage of a made-over schedule and set out to do something about it by resuming its emotional series with Pittsburgh three years from now. But the limitations of Big Ten scheduling will force those games to be played in early to mid-September, far from the feel of season-ending games in the cold and snow, a sensation about as natural as eating pumpkin pie at a Labor Day picnic.
When the game reaches the point when too many deals destroy the feel, when the haves achieve their goal of squeezing out the have-nots, we may one day wake up to find a junior varsity National Football League, devoid of the charm that has held the attention of generations.
Florida and Florida State will have no shortage of emotion when they meet on Thanksgiving weekend. But the Gators already understand that they will somehow have to ration their energy because any hope for a national championship would next hinge on the outcome of the Southeastern Conference championship game the next Saturday at Atlanta. The same thing has happened to Alabama-Auburn. And the soon-to-come annual fund-raiser known as the Big 12 championship game could have the same effect on Texas-Texas A&M and Nebraska-Oklahoma.
This is not a vote against progress, or a plea to return to the days of back-stabbing, double-dealing, smoke-filled bowl deals. But as Nebraska and West Virginia begin a new season tomorrow, the decision-makers should consider the possibility that the Rose Bowl is not a barrier. It is an economically healthy reminder of what the sport should be, a game with enormous emotional value beyond polls or rankings or alleged "significance," a warm winter day that has managed to retain its importance because it is so much like the ones that were passed on to us.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In college, tradition is just a tailgate away. (Barton Silverman)

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

Markets
Investors returned to the stock market in a big way this week, bidding up stocks for the largest one-week gain in 19 months. Investors are encouraged by stabilizing bond prices, a rising dollar and, above all, a more optimistic picture of a sound, low-inflation economy. The Dow gained 51.16 points yesterday. [Page 35.] 
 Treasury prices rose sharply after the Commerce Department reported that the economy grew at an annual rate of 3.8 percent, in a revision that was less than what the bond market had expected. A stronger dollar also aided government securities. [43.]
The dollar surged against the German mark and other currencies in a rally prompted by the G.D.P. report. Many traders say the dollar has finally rebounded from a seven-month slump. [46.]
Coffee prices climbed to more than $2 a pound. Traders worry that a drought in Brazil, the biggest coffee producer, will further damage its crop at a time when seasonal demand rises. [46.]
 
Companies
 Bidding for the Madison Square Garden sports and entertainment empire appears to be nearing a climax. A team of ITT and Cablevision, competing against Liberty Media, is said to have the higher bid -- $1.05 billion -- on the table. [35.]
Customers can download their food and their Internet mail in the cafe of the Dallas Infomart, a convention and sales center known as a high-technology showcase. At the newly opened High Tech Cafe, the goal is to wine, dine and be on line. [35.]
General Motors and the U.A.W. are waging a war of inches as the company seeks to cut costs and the union tries to save jobs. A move to a just-in-time delivery system makes the auto maker more vulnerable to strikes like the one this week at a parts plant in Anderson, Ind. With so much power over production residing at the local level, the union and the company are essentially bargaining year-round, hammering out piece by piece the shape of the new, more efficient General Motors. News Analysis. [35.]
Toyota Motor announced that it would raise prices in the United States an average of 3.5 percent. Japanese auto makers have been forced to raise prices more often and more sharply because of the rising value of the yen against the dollar. [37.]
Shares of both Comdisco and I.B.M. rose after the companies said they had settled a three-year-old lawsuit. I.B.M. had accused Comdisco of taking other manufacturers' memory chips and marketing them as genuine I.B.M. parts. [37.]
 The Fox network gained control of the ABC affiliate in New Orleans and NBC affiliates in Honolulu and Mobile, Ala. [37.]
 
The Economy
Gorwth in gross domestic product was revised to 3.8 percent for the second quarter, up slightly from an annual rate of 3.7 percent. The report, showing a higher level of unsold goods and less Federal spending, signaled to many economists that growth would slacken to a range of 2 to 3 percent in the current quarter. [35.]
 Competitive pressures for more high technology in the workplace appear to produce wider differences between the rich and the poor, the Federal Reserve chairman said. [43.]
 
Your Money
 Beware of hidden charges when buying bonds. Investors should inquire about the costs of buying bonds and be wary of brokers who balk at such questions or give evasive answers. [33.]
Barton M. Biggs sees stocks poised for recovery, and that should hearten investors because he is looking particularly prescient at the moment. Mr. Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management, predicted late last year that short-term interest rates would rise and roil securities markets worldwide. [33.]
A hybrid of a home loan and a fixed insurance annuity is being promoted as a way for consumers to diversify and build a nest egg. But the mortgage, called the Asset Integrated Mortgage, may not be the best way for most people to save. [33.]
Auto insurers are looking at the credit histories of applicants, as well as their driving records. Allstate will now ask for credit ratings when underwriting new auto policies in 39 states. [34.]

HEADLINE: Technology Seen as Widening Income Gap

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 26

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that competitive pressures for the introduction of more high technology into the workplace appeared to produce wider differences between the rich and the poor in industrial societies.
Speaking at the Federal Reserve's annual conference here today, Mr. Greenspan said that "where such market forces are allowed to play out more evidently, such as in the United States, the unemployment rate is lower and measured income inequality higher." 
 The trade-off between income inequality and technology was described today by Paul Krugman, a Stanford University economist. Mr. Greenspan told the audience here that "the argument for this trade-off is a persuasive one."
If the free market is allowed to operate, then new technologies will continue to be introduced that allow skilled workers to replace unskilled workers, Mr. Krugman said.
As governments seek to balance this effect through expanded unemployment benefits, there will be less incentive for unemployed people to accept jobs that may pay less than their former jobs, so unemployment will tend to rise, he said.
 
A Main Worry
 Evidence that the gap between rich and poor is widening has become a pet concern of Mr. Greenspan, who is fond of pointing out that more and more of the economy's output consists of ideas made into products, like computer software, rather than bulky goods like cars and refrigerators that still require brawn.
Mr. Greenspan also repeated his previous criticisms of the theory that unemployment can be reduced by allowing inflation to rise. "Any tendency to seek a bit of macro policy relief by pushing on the outer limits of monetary policy risks longer-term financial instability," he said.
The theory that sustained reductions in unemployment can be achieved through higher inflation was popular during the 1960's and early 1970's, but it was widely discredited among academic economists when both inflation and unemployment rose in the late 1970's. Most economists now favor keeping inflation low at all times because large increases in inflation have tended to produce very modest gains in employment, while large increases in unemployment have then been needed to bring inflation down slightly.
Roughly half the members of the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy committee are attending the conference, as are top central bank officials from Germany, Japan, South Korea, Canada, Spain, Chile, Mexico and New Zealand.

HEADLINE: After a Lull, Stocks Come Roaring Back

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Tentatively at first, but then with increasing assurance, investors returned to the stock market this week. And with a 51-point surge in the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday, they bid up stock prices for the largest one-week gain in 19 months.
Until this week, the stock market had been stagnant at best. Individual investors, as well as institutions commanding billions of dollars in assets, had pulled back from the market and put much of their holdings into cash. 
 But encouraged by stabilizing bond prices, a rising dollar and, above all, a more optimistic picture of a sound, low-inflation United States economy, they have begun to buy stocks again.
It will take a few more weeks of rising stock prices to confirm that this week's rally is the rekindling of the powerful surge in the stock market that was halted abruptly on Feb. 4, when the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates to fight inflation. But some analysts say this is the real thing.
Barton M. Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management, said he had been expecting a market rally for more than a month, and this may be it. "Slow growth and low inflation around the world are bullish for long-term financial assets, particularly stocks," he said.
Yesterday, the Dow rose 51.16 points, to 3,881.05, a rise of 1.34 percent. For the week, the increase totaled 125.65 points, or 3.3 percent.
The previous one-week record this year, according to the New York Stock Exchange, was nearly 107 points, or 2.9 percent, for the week that ended on May 20. During the week that ended on Feb. 5, 1993, the Dow rose 132 points.
The broader indexes, with more stocks than the Dow's 30 blue-chip companies, were also up for the week. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was up 2.2 percent, and the Nasdaq composite index of more than 4,500 stocks was up 2.8 percent.
"Some people here doubt that this rally is the real thing, but I don't," said Jerry W. Mill, who helps to manage nearly $3 billion of stocks for Invesco Funds Group in Denver and has been optimistic about the market throughout the summer.
Some funds in the company once had 5 cents of every dollar invested allocated to cash, but earlier this summer increased the cash allocation to 20 cents on the dollar, he said. "A lot of people with high cash levels are putting them to work" and buying stocks, Mr. Mill said.
Matthew Avery, senior portfolio manager for the Franklin Group of Funds in San Mateo, Calif., said he planned to keep his cash levels at about 13 cents of every dollar, but could change his mind. He also manages about $3 billion of stocks. "Having a solid week like this opens everyone's minds to the positive factors moving the market," he said.
True, many analysts say the rally will be short-lived because it is fueled by a variety of temporary factors, chiefly professional traders who lost their bets that the market was going to fall.
As the last of these traders buy or sell shares to stem their losses, the market will plateau and the rally will stall, these analysts say.
The biggest factor in yesterday's rise was yet more evidence of a sound economy growing with little inflation. Government economists reported a revised growth rate of 3.8 percent in the output of the nation's goods and services, a slower-than-expected rate for the period from March to June.
 
A Boon to Investors
 A reversal in market sentiment would mean an unlocking of much of the money now parked in short-term cash instruments. It would also mean a boon to investors who have increasingly tucked away billions of dollars in stock-related investments.
Investors already seem to be anticipating some sort of rise. Stock mutual funds alone swelled by more than $2.2 billion in the week that ended last Wednesday, according to AMG Data Services.
Unlike institutional investors, individuals have continued to pour money into stocks, despite the market's poor showing this year; still, last week's increase was the largest since mid-June, according to AMG's weekly data. Such stock funds now have assets of $754 billion.
The market's move this week is significant. The seven-month halt in the stock market's advance has frustrated millions of investors who have seen their individual stock portfolios, stakes in mutual funds, or pension fund investments in stocks grow little, if at all.
But now, $1,000 invested for the year to date in the 30 stocks represented in the Dow index makes a profit of $33.80. While still small, it is better than the small loss or no gain before this week.
In the 160 business days to Friday, Aug. 19, the Dow moved scarcely at all, up just 1.31 points, to 3,755.40. But because of this week's advance, the Dow has risen nearly 127 points this year, or 3.38 percent.
 
A Notable Number
 The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above average, with 305.6 million shares changing hands, or about 7 percent higher than this year's average of 286 million shares. The number is even more notable for being 15 percent higher than the more restrained summer volume of 265 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.64 points, to 260.82, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,508 to 699. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.44 points, to 449.56.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 23 rose, led by Caterpillar, which rose 3 5/8, to 115 5/8, on no immediate news.
Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 392 rose, led by General Electric, which rose 1 1/8, to 50 3/4, on no immediate news.
Stocks were also higher in Asia and Europe yesterday. Japanese stocks gained as the yen stabilized against the dollar. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 28.20 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, at 20,471.49. But the Nikkei was down 41.21 for the week.
The Hang Seng index of 33 stocks in Hong Kong climbed 62.97 points, or about seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 9,399.08.
Stocks in both Britain and France rose for the fourth day. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 issues rose 30.9 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 3,265.1. In Paris, the CAC index of 40 issues gained 36.22 points, or 1.79 percent, to 2,062.74.
