HEADLINE: Quarter's Economic Growth Revised to 3.8%, Up Slightly

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
More signs of a slowing economy emerged today as the Commerce Department, revising its initial estimates of growth in the second quarter, reported a higher level of unsold goods and markedly less Federal spending..
The gross domestic product was revised upward slightly, to an annual rate of 3.8 percent from 3.7 percent, far less than most analysts had expected.
"Growth was not as ebullient" as the 4 percent or more that was widely anticipated, said Carol A. Stone, senior economist at Nomura Securities in New York. "So the chances for an early further tightening by the Federal Reserve are reduced." 
 The report immediately ignited strong rallies in the bond and stock markets, which in their joint aversion to higher interest rates have customarily moved together in recent years. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond fell to 7.48 percent from 7.53 percent. [Page 43.]
 Today's report seemed to confirm for many economists a belief that economic growth will slacken to a range of 2 percent to 3 percent for the current quarter with any pickup during the autumn being modest. Many economists contend that 2.5 percent is the fastest pace the economy can sustain without a rise in inflation.
"This is clearly suggestive of a growth downshift," said Stephen S. Roach, a top economist at Morgan Stanley, pointing particularly to today's data indicating that the buildup in inventories was more concentrated than previously thought in domestically produced items.
Data on inventories are among the most difficult economic figures to interpret since it is almost never clear whether a rise, say, reflects a sudden absence of customers or a burst of confidence by retailers or manufacturers. Moreover, inventory figures tend to be statistically confusing since the broadest gauge of economic performance -- the gross domestic product -- rises when goods and services are produced without regard to whether anybody buys them.
So, while a jump in inventories contributed substantially to second-quarter growth -- accounting for 63 percent of it -- analysts assume that the buildup in goods will lead to some subsequent cuts in production and that in any event such a contribution to G.D.P. is unlikely to be repeated.
"Speculation that the inventory overhang going into the third quarter would be less threatening was dashed quickly" by today's revision, Donald E. Maude of the Scotia McLeod brokerage firm said.
 
'Onto a Slower Path'

 
 Spending on personal consumption, about two-thirds of all economic activity, was revised only slightly higher, today's report showed, to a pace of 1.4 percent from 1.2 percent.
"Growth clearly is moving onto a slower path," said Robert G. Dederick, a former Commerce Department official who is executive vice president of the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
He predicts a 2.6 percent pace for the current period, about a percentage point less than the average for the first two quarters of 1994, when growth was 3.3 percent and 3.8 percent, respectively. In late July, the department estimated that second-quarter growth in G.D.P. -- the total value of goods and services produced -- was at a seasonally adjusted constant-dollar pace of 3.7 percent.
Even with lackluster spending lately, today's data showed that the personal savings rate had edged down to 3.9 percent from the 4 percent initial estimated in late July.
 
No Jump in Prices

 
 Inflation gauges associated with G.D.P. data showed little change in today's report, with the fixed-weight price index for gross domestic purchases edging up to a 3.3 percent pace from 3.2. In current dollars, G.D.P. growth was at a 6.9 percent pace during the spring instead of the 6.8 percent first estimated a month ago.
The biggest upward adjustment in the G.D.P. data was an extra $2.3 billion for business inventories, with final sales of domestic product now showing a 1.4 percent gain instead of 1.5 percent.
The sharpest downward revision was a $3.6 billion drop in the figure for purchases by the Federal Government, but Ms. Stone also noted a decline for brokerage services.
The Government's first assessment of corporate profits for the quarter, also a part of today's report, showed sharp improvement. Profits from current production surged 7.7 percent after falling 4.8 percent in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Coffee Jumps on Concerns About Brazil's Dry Weather

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Coffee prices jumped above $2 a pound yesterday as traders became increasingly concerned that dry weather in Brazil would further damage its coffee crop at a time when seasonal demand rises.
In other commodity markets, oil prices slid while copper surged. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 0.09 point, to 230.88. 
 At the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, coffee for December delivery soared 13.35 cents, to $2.1115, breaking the $2 level for the first time in three weeks.
"We are heading toward the peak demand period at a time when consumer stocks have been falling and the outlook is for contracting supply and ongoing weather uncertainty for Brazil," said Sandra Kaul, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc.
 
A Frost and a Lack of Rain
 With the Brazilian trees about to flower, the lack of rain during the last two months could curtail next year's crop.
"There is increasing concern that the coffee trees in Brazil need rain now, not a month from now," another trader said.
Brazil's coffee plantations, which produce roughly one-quarter of the world's supply, were already hit by frosts in late June and early July that damaged about 40 percent of the trees.
"This is only the start of a big rally," said Judith Ganes of Merrill Lynch & Company. The highs seen in coffee prices this summer, she said, "should be eclipsed in the fall and winter months when coffee consumption peaks."
Ms. Ganes said demand for coffee would outpace supply this year, but price increases trickling down to the retail level would eventually cause a decline in coffee drinking.
"If we look back in history, there is usually a one-year gap between a big price increase and a drop in consumption," she said. "Consumption now is stable, at least in the U.S."
 
Oil Prices Down
 Crude oil prices closed sharply lower in largely technical trading. The October contract for crude oil fell 38 cents, to $17.14 a barrel.
Copper prices rose to their highest levels in nearly five weeks, helped by rallies in stocks and bonds. September copper was up 2.55 cents at $1.118 a pound.
Mike Frawley of Dean Witter said the fundamentals for copper prices continued to be positive and "physical demand remains strong."
Copper prices were also bolstered by the Commerce Department's report on the gross domestic product. The report, which showed signs of a slowing economy, suggested that no further increases in interest rates were down the road, which would hurt copper demand, said Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential Securities Inc.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Brokers' Hidden Charges On Bonds

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla 

 BODY:
HAVE rising interest rates piqued your interest in the bond market? Not a bad idea for some portfolios, perhaps. But don't jump in until you have a handle on the elusive costs of buying bonds.
A broker from New York's W. J. Nolan & Company made the mistake of cold calling to pitch Ginnie Mae bonds to a reporter recently, and hidden charges were the last thing he wanted to discuss. 
 "Mrs. Antilla, I'm working on a strategy for investing in Ginnie Maes -- I don't know if you are familiar with Ginnie Maes," he began, adding that they were paying a guaranteed rate of return of 7.5 percent to 8 percent a year. Ginnie Maes are pools of mortgages backed by the Government National Mortgage Association, which provides a Government guarantee against default and eliminates credit risk. Still, the securities' value fluctuates with interest rates.
What, the reporter asked, were the commissions on such an investment?
"Commissions?" he replied. "O.K. Let's say you buy a $50,000 bond. There is no commission or fee or sales charge or anything like that."
Not the whole truth, the reporter thought. Bond brokers make their bucks on the price "spread" between what the brokerage house pays for a bond and the marked-up price paid by the buyer. This spread varies, depending on the firm, the customer and the size of the purchase.
"No costs at all?" came the disingenuous question.
 "What I earn, and what my company, W. J. Nolan, earns, is built into the price," he replied. "We might buy $50 million of bonds at the wholesale price, if you will."
W. J. Nolan might go to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, he continued, and pay 99 cents on the dollar for a bond and then sell it to the customer at 100 cents on the dollar. So the brokerage firm's profit is "already in it," he said.
(Never mind that Ginnie Maes are not traded there.)
"So what if I bought a $50,000 bond from you this morning," the reporter said. "With no commissions, I guess what you're saying is that I could sell it right back to you for $50,000?"
Well, not quite right, came the answer. The bond would be subject to "market risk" if the investor were to sell it six months later, he said.
"But I'm asking you what would happen if I sold it immediately," the reporter countered.
"It would depend on how rates were moving a couple hours later," said the broker, who identified himself as Terry Fortunate.
"What if I sold it two minutes later?" the reporter asked, exasperated that the broker would not acknowledge that the bond would immediately be worth less as a result of the broker's markup. "Or what if another customer were selling the same bonds at the very same moment?"
More runaround ensued.
"It would depend on the price we'd be getting for the bonds," Mr. Fortunate said when pressed to respond. Besides, buying bonds "is not like calling up a firm like Quick & Reilly and paying a stock commission," he said, not "when you're a principal owner, as we are."
"But I thought you said that you went to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange to buy and sell bonds for your customers," the reporter said, wondering why the broker was now suggesting that the firm was selling bonds from its inventory as a principal owner. If the bonds were already in-house, there would be no uncertainty from waiting to get an exchange price.
When the reporter called back later in the week to say the broker would be included in an article about bond commissions, Mr. Fortunate said he would refer the matter to a senior member of the firm. In a subsequent call, William Nolan said that his broker was not "cold calling," or making a sales pitch to someone who had expressed no interest, because the reporter had made a query to Nolan while working on a previous article nearly two years ago. It was a "recycled lead," Mr. Nolan said.
Fair enough. But what of the matter of markups?
Jay Goldinger, a bond broker at Capital Insight in Beverly Hills, Calif., said that investors should specifically ask a bond broker about his sales credit on a prospective purchase. And "if he says he doesn't know, he's lying," Mr. Goldinger said.
Expect a generous sales credit of 1 to 2 percent of the purchase price, or "anything they think they can get away with" in the case of a naive investor, Mr. Goldinger said.
 And if the broker balks repeatedly at the question, consider buying those bonds elsewhere.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges After Report Shows Economy Is Slowing

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar surged against the German mark and other leading currencies yesterday after a report showed the American economy was slowing.
For many traders, the rally confirmed a belief that the dollar was finally rebounding from a seven-month slump that took it to a post-World War II low against the yen and a 20-month low against the mark. 
 "The dollar is clearly bottoming," said Marc Chandler, director of research at Ezra Zask Associates, a Norfolk, Conn., hedge fund with $180 million under management.
The dollar rallied yesterday after the Commerce Department revised the gross domestic product for the second quarter up slightly, to an annual rate of 3.8 percent from 3.7 percent, far less than most analysts had expected.
The smaller-than-expected revision suggested that the United States economy was not growing fast enough to increase the inflation rate; higher inflation would erode the value of interest-bearing investments like Government bonds. Prices of United States Treasury securites rose sharply yesterday.
Currency analysts and traders often watch the performance of the Treasury market for clues about demand among overseas investors for American assets. Those investors must buy dollars to purchase American stocks and bonds.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5773 German marks from 1.5423 marks on Thursday. The move of 3.5 pfennigs was the dollar's largest one-day gain against the mark since Jan. 9, 1992.
The dollar rose to 100.67 yen from 99.65 yen, rising above 100 yen for the first time in more than a week.
The speed with which the dollar rallied caught many traders off guard, analysts said. The currency jumped in part because many traders who had sold dollars for marks and yen earlier, hoping to buy them back at a lower level later, had to purchase dollars today to limit their losses.
"The dollar was like a freight train today," said David De Rosa, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. "There was no stopping it. I imagine there were a lot of people who were unpleasantly surprised."
In other currency trading in New York, the dollar settled at 5.4002 French francs, up from 5.2860 francs on Thursday; at 1.3335 Swiss francs, up from 1.3025 francs, and at 1,598.50 Italian lire, up from 1,563.50 lire. The British pound tumbled to $1.5278.

HEADLINE: Barton Biggs Is Burying the Bear

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
For a living, Barton M. Biggs predicts market booms and busts around the globe. Sometimes he even causes them.
Mr. Biggs, the chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management, is one of the most venerable seers on Wall Street. If he says, as he has in recent years, "Put money in emerging markets," plenty of institutional investors do so -- and a boom is born. 
 Mr. Biggs is looking particularly prescient right now. Late last year, he predicted that short-term interest rates would rise and cause trouble for securities markets around the world. Sure, that seems obvious today, but at the time, stocks were soaring in the United States, and many market gurus were forecasting the best of all possible years in 1994.
All of which explains why investors may be heartened to hear that Mr. Biggs is a good deal more optimistic now than he was then. In an interview last week, he said that he expected stock markets to rally -- perhaps very soon.
"It would be typical of the orneriness of the market for there to be a strong upsurge around the world next week, because all the great money managers will be at the watering holes of the upper class, and they don't want the week before Labor Day disturbed," he said wryly.
Such quips are typical of Mr. Biggs, whose bulletins and travelogues are widely read and quoted, even by those who disagree with him.
But he has substantive reasons for saying stocks are ready for a rally. Many markets got pounded in the first half of the year, and many investors have suffered enormous losses in derivatives, bonds and some emerging markets. "This was not just a minor summer squall; it was a serious bear market," Mr. Biggs said, "and it would not be surprising to get a good recovery from that." In addition, many professional investors remain gloomy, which in the topsy-turvy world of Wall Street is considered a positive sign.
Similarly, the malaise on the political front may not be all bad. Although Americans may be dismayed by the gridlock in Washington, Congressional inaction is probably good for the stock market, Mr. Biggs concludes. "I think it's pretty clear we are not going to get a health care plan, and whether you like it or you don't, it is really a tax increase, and the market does not like tax increases," he said. "The market is beginning to think the Republicans will have a significant victory in the '96 elections, and that Clinton is fading badly, and the market thinks those things are bullish."
The economics are favorable, too. "Basically, slow growth and low inflation around the world are bullish for long-term financial assets, particularly stocks," he said.
Which markets does he favor? He likes American stocks, particularly small-capitalization companies in the emerging growth category. (He would avoid cyclical stocks, however, and says "bonds are boring.")
But his favorites are the smaller Asian stock markets, which he says "will be the best place in the world to be for the next five years." In particular, he recommends Thailand, Indonesia and Hong Kong, citing dramatic growth prospects and relatively cheap prices. All three markets have fallen significantly this year.
Not everyone shares his enthusiasm for investing in what used to be known as less-developed countries and are now called emerging nations. Small positions in emerging markets may be suitable for large institutions, but "for individuals to have more than a toehold is fraught with risk," said Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates in Greenwich, Conn., who recently published a book on global investing. "I don't think we really understand these markets very well." he added.
Mr. Biggs does not play down the risks of emerging markets. These investments, he said, are "only for the brave; you've just got to accept the fact that they will be volatile."
A market losing his favor is Tokyo, which he recently cut to a 20 percent portfolio weighting, from 30 percent. He still wants to have significant exposure there, but is losing confidence that corporate earnings will take off.
Mr. Biggs has been swayed by some Morgan Stanley colleagues, who point out that although Japanese companies have been through a depression and deflation and have restructured and cut costs, they have not cut employment. Corporate earnings, consequently, may increase by only 25 percent a year, instead of the 70 percent that Mr. Biggs once expected. Big American companies would love to have that kind of earnings growth, but then, big American companies' stocks trade for roughly 20 times their earnings. Japanese stocks trade for more than 80 times earnings.
He is also cautious about Brazil, where stocks have soared more than 75 percent this year. Positive political and economic developments have already been factored in, he said. "I'm worried that if there's any kind of bad news in Brazil, you could have a very, very sharp drop in both the currency and the markets."
Because of such risks, big institutions cannot bet too heavily on small stock markets. Right now, Mr. Biggs is suggesting that they put 22 percent of their portfolios in emerging markets. But individuals, he suggests, should consider putting as much as half their holdings there.
"I don't mean widows and orphans," Mr. Biggs said, "but for the aggressive individual who can afford to take some risk, the conventional heart of danger is the safest place."

HEADLINE: HUD Plays Too Rough

 BODY:
Last year a neighborhood group in Berkeley, Calif., protested the conversion of a local motel into a shelter and treatment facility for recovering drug addicts and the mentally disabled. Before they knew what had hit them, members of the group were under investigation by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, accompanied by demands for their mailing lists and all their writings about the project.
There were threats of fines and jail terms. Last week HUD finally dropped the investigation, after finding no violations. 
 HUD conducted its investigation under the 1968 Fair Housing Act, as amended in 1988. The Fair Housing Act protects housing rights of the disabled, including the mentally ill, drug addicts, alcoholics and those suffering from AIDS. It is a worthy law that tackles the nation's most persistent form of racial isolation -- housing segregation.
Nevertheless, HUD's muscular defense of the groups protected by the law, particularly its strong-arm tactics, interfered with a community's right to raise legitimate questions about how, why and where the Government chooses to place its social-services facilities. Not all Americans object to social services simply because they want them in somebody else's backyard. HUD has been operating without clear distinctions between legitimate protest and discrimination, and it needs to make them.
Under the Fair Housing Act it is unlawful to "coerce, intimidate, threaten or interfere" with any person's exercise of fair housing rights. It is also potentially unlawful to harass people on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, handicap, familial status or national origin.
As Roberta Achtenberg, Assistant Secretary of HUD for fair housing and equal opportunity, explained this week in The Washington Post, "the First Amendment does not protect a landlord or neighbor who employs intimidation or verbal abuse to discourage someone from moving into housing because of his race, religion or disability."
Placement of facilities that house and serve society's most troubled citizens is the subject of emotional debate almost everywhere. More affluent neighborhoods may simply want to keep out populations that demand a lot of social services; but some neighborhoods, particularly those that are politically and economically weak, may legitimately fear an overconcentration of social-services facilities and an influx of troubled populations.
Under present rules, neighborhood groups that raise these questions or stage formal protests have to answer to HUD, which is conducting 32 such investigations across the nation. No group should be allowed to use intimidation or harassment to keep out needed facilities, but onerous Federal investigations of neighborhood groups that are exercising their rights of protest and free speech can also constitute intimidation and harassment.
HUD should therefore set clear standards of conduct before an investigation of any private group is triggered -- excluding from retaliation, for example, legitimate forms of citizen protest like circulating petitions. It should also apply uniform rules to all investigations, with the broadest consideration for free-speech rights.
The debate over where to place public facilities for the troubled and disabled needs to be as open and wide as possible. HUD should not use strong-arm tactics to stifle it.

HEADLINE: After a Lull, Stocks Come Roaring Back

 BODY:
Tentatively, but then with increasing assurance, investors are returning to the stock market. With a 51-point surge in the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday, they bid up stocks for the largest one-week gain in 19 months.
Until this week, the stock market had been stagnant at best. But now, stock investors have become encouraged by stabilizing bond prices, a rising dollar and, above all, a more optimistic picture of a sound, low-inflation United States economy. 
 It will take a few more weeks to confirm whether this week's rally marks a rekindling of the powerful surge that was halted abruptly on Feb. 4, when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates. But some analysts say this is the real thing.
Business Day, page 35.

HEADLINE: A Neighborhood In Waves

BYLINE: By Verlyn Klinkenborg; Verlyn Klinkenborg is the author of "The Last Fine Time," a social history of a Buffalo bar.

 BODY:
HISTORIANS OF CITIES ARE OFTEN FOOLED BY the endurance of buildings. The camera loves buildings because they conform to the camera's idea of standing still, of not flinching, of acting natural. When you look through the photographic archives of a city like Buffalo -- a galvanic giant not so long ago -- what you frequently see is a crowd of humans smeared in motion across the foreground, while in the background the buildings stand tall, resolute, confiding. It's easy to imagine a neighborhood -- the Lower West Side of Buffalo, for instance -- as though it were mainly a stockpile of buildings, an architectural shoreline of sorts. Into it flows a "wave" of people, marked by ethnic background or economic class. The wave leaves a high-water mark on the neighborhood and then it recedes, making room for another wave. The only thing that remains in focus is the buildings. What is human is averaged out in the motion of the wave.
You get at one kind of truth with that kind of history -- like driving through Buffalo on the New York State Thruway, hoping to make Cleveland by nightfall. But in a living neighborhood there is never only one kind of truth. 
 In 1939, when he was 30, Milton Rogovin opened his optometry practice on Chippewa Street in Buffalo, near the edge of the Lower West Side. That was a time when Buffalo's neighborhoods still seemed to have the temporary ethnic coherence historians and politicians love. The East Side was largely Polish; the Lower West Side was largely Italian. But if you approached the neighborhoods not ward by ward but house by house, you would have found something completely different, an almost unmappable complexity of people and purposes. As in most cities, then and now, what made the neighborhoods in Buffalo was not where you came from but where you hoped to end up.
"I came mostly for the trade union people," Rogovin told me not long ago. "I was a product of the Great Depression and what I saw and experienced myself made me politically active." When I asked him if he thought of his photography as explicitly political, Rogovin said, "I like to photograph people with problems." He purchased a used camera in 1942 but did not become serious about photography until 1958, when he began taking photographs in storefront churches on the East Side of Buffalo. A collection of those photographs was published in Aperture in 1962, with an introduction by W. E. B. Du Bois.
By the time Rogovin began taking photographs on the Lower West Side in the early 1970's, the neighborhood had become one of the poorest and most ethnically diverse in Buffalo. To the west lay the waterfront, an old industrial center, and to the east lay the antiquated mansions of Delaware Avenue. Italian homeowners had begun to sell out in the early 1960's, and hundreds of houses had been pulled down in the name of urban renewal, leaving behind a place of which Rogovin said, "There was a tremendous amount of potential on the Lower West Side, and it was just rotting away."
Rogovin was invited into the Lower West Side neighborhood by his patients, who introduced him to their families. Before long, he had become a familiar figure on the street. "For the first six months," Rogovin has said, "there was real uncertainty. They thought I was the F.B.I. or the welfare department. But I would take a picture and then give a print to the person. Soon people were saying, 'Have the old man take your picture and he'll give you a photograph of yourself.' I let them select the place. I never told them what to do. Because of the nature of the area, I seldom asked them their names."
Some of the photographs Rogovin took on the Lower West Side in 1973 and 1974 were published in a collection of his work called "The Forgotten Ones" (1985), which included photographs taken in Mexico, Chile and Appalachia. In the early 1980's, Rogovin's wife, Anne, urged him to go back to the Lower West Side, as she did again in the early 90's. They tracked down Rogovin's former subjects by going to a street corner with a box of photographs. "People would gather round and I'd show them the pictures. They would tell me who had OD'd, or was in jail; who had moved away, or had split up; and where I could find the others who continued to live there." What Rogovin has captured is a still-life record that seems to move nonetheless, a history of the human form as it evolves over three decades.
In these moving photographic sequences, it is not the buildings of Buffalo that endure, but the people. This is an utterly different kind of urban history. The neighborhood is not an architectural shoreline, and nothing human has been averaged out. Here is the full weight of time and trouble, and something almost indomitable besides.

Joseph Marchese, 20
The first picture was at my baptism. My grandmother was 80 at the time; she turned 100 this year. She lived in Sicily most of her life, then moved to Toronto 30 years ago to be with my uncles and aunts. She's still there now, but she lives in a nursing home. Sometimes she tries to trick you. She'll call my dad up and say, "I'm dying, I'm dying." She does it to get you to go visit, but she's really fine. My dad goes at least once a month. All of my children have a copy of the picture, and they have all had the same kind of picture done for their own children. All of my children have copies of these three photographs, too.

I was poor, working for my uncle -- my father died when I was a little kid. I was happy here, so I stay here. I have never gone back. My wife and I, we always stay together. We don't believe in divorce where I come from. Matrimony is matrimony forever. There is no secret. I don't like change. It's too late, I'm too old now.

My father is the flip side of what I'm doing. I was pretty young when he went to jail. The last time I saw him was when he was dying of a brain tumor. There was nothing they could do for him and he died in prison. A guy took me under his wing and started training me as a carpenter. I've worked as a carpenter for the past eight years. We used to live in the fruit belt -- that's on the Lower East Side. My mom got us out of that ghetto. She was the one that raised us. Pretty proud of her. She's a lady foreman in construction -- the first one in her union. Life's shaky, but we keep banging away at it.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Foxwoods' Expansion Plans Trouble the Region

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THESE are unsettled times in southeastern Connecticut. Electric Boat and related arms industries in Groton and New London eliminated more than 8,000 jobs. And the Mashantucket Pequots are buying up land for expansion with profits from their Foxwoods gambling casino, while patrons and 9,000 employees clog local roads 24 hours a day.
The next six months promise to be even more unsettled if the Federal Government approves plans for a second gambling casino by the Mohegan tribe in Montville across the Thames River from Foxwoods and lets the Mashantuckets annex a large parcel of land. 
 Foxwoods has eased the unemployment problem by hiring hundreds of laid-off armament-industry workers. And it has given the region's moribund real estate market new heart by buying hundreds of acres and dozens of houses through local brokers.
But the Mashantucket tribe's appetite for property, and their ability to hold it free of taxation and local use controls -- worries residents of Ledyard, where the casino is situated, and North Stonington and Preston, where the tribe has bought land. Since the casino opened in 1992 the tribe has accumulated almost 4,000 acres in the three towns and contracted to buy more, said William R. Haase, Ledyard's Town Planner.
Of that total, almost 1,200 acres of the original reservation, where the casino and two hotels are situated, are in a Federal trust -- commonly called annexed -- under the terms of the Mashantucket Pequot Indian Land Claims Act enacted in 1983. Trust lands are exempt from taxes and the jurisdiction of zoning, environmental and other municipal bodies. The remaining tribe-owned acreage is subject to taxes and local oversight.
"This is of tremendous national consequence," said Richard Blumenthal, the State Attorney General, "staking the towns and cities, land use, tax revenues and local control against the desire of Indian tribes to expand the geographical areas of their reservations and thereby enhance their gaming operations."
"We oppose annexation so long as the towns take that position," he said. "All we can do is appeal to Federal authorities who have ultimate decision-making power and vast discretion."
He said he suspected that there were officials within the Department of the Interior who favored annexation, and that Bruce Babbitt, the Secretary of the Interior, was "seeking to strike a balance."
Lawyers for the tribe and the towns declined to comment on the situation while negotiations were proceeding.
Madeline Jeffery, president of the 275-member North Stonington Land Alliance and a founding member of the recently formed No Annexation Not One Acre citizen's group, said annexation was unacceptable.
"It's a loss of the democratic process," she said. "Normally we could go to the Selectmen or the Planning and Zoning Commission when we object to a proposed development. But here we are dealing with a 'sovereign government.' "
At issue are 247 acres in Ledyard and North Stonington, for which the tribe applied for trust status early last year. It plans to join thatwith 1,000 acres of a former Boy Scout camp it bought and build a park, possibly with an Asian theme.
The application, perceived by many residents as opening the door to a cascade of future annexations, prompted a joint referendum last November. Out of a three-town population of 26,800, there are 13,795 registered voters; 4,034 voted against annexation, 1,020 for it.
Though the vote carries no legal weight it provided an impetus for Mr. Babbitt to refer the matter to mediation by the Conflict Management Group of Cambridge, Mass., a nonprofit organization that has so far been unable to resolve the issues.
"PLANS for the park are misunderstood," said Jackson T. King, Jr., legal counsel to the tribe. "We are talking about water gardens, Chinese architecture, quiet places for meditation, not the Ferris wheels and carnival atmosphere that people envision."
"We have just bought an additional 375-acre site," he continued, "containing a silica mine that we will close, and a hiking trail system that we will preserve and enhance for the public and guests of Foxwoods. People should look at what we have done and how we are stewards of the land."
To offset tax losses from annexation the tribe offered each town $1 million a year for five years and negotiation at the end of that period. But Joyce Elias, tax assessor for North Stonington, said that this approach ignored basic principles of valuation.
"Unless there is a calculated formula you are only getting today's value in future years," she said. "And if the theme park goes in, the homes near it will become worthless to buyers other than the tribe." As the tribe hires more and more people the towns will become bedroom communities for the casino, she predicted.
This analysis may already explain in the listless market for commercial and industrial development, which officials in the area are hoping will replace the military-oriented industry.
"With an increased reliance on a gaming economy, it is not likely that major companies will site a new plant or distribution center in the middle of an environment that is generally regarded as negative for employee families," said William M. Newman, broker and appraiser with Connecticut Commercial Realty in New London.
"We are probably going to see the development of retail and service businesses, shopping centers, nightclubs, motels and restaurants, in anticipation of increased traffic into the area," Mr. Newman said.
That process has begun on Route 2, the main artery leading to the casino from Hartford; from Massachusetts via I-395 and from Rhode Island, New York and coastal Connecticut via I-95. Gas stations, shopping strips and restaurants on Route 2 are sprucing up and motels are doing well.
But four new traffic lights have been installed on the eight-mile stretch of Route 2 in North Stonington, from Exit 92 of I-95 to the casino, to regulate the increased traffic. The 57-square-mile town, with a population of 5,000, previously had only one set of traffic lights, which converted to a blinker in winter.
"North of the casino," said Richard Martinez, planning administrator for the state's Department of Transportation, "toward Hartford, there were 7,000 cars clocked daily in both directions in 1990; in 1993 there were 21,500. South of the casino to North Stonington there were 7,200 cars in 1990; in 1993 there were 18,500." His department is conducting an 18-month study of options for widening Route 2.
"Unfortunately for people who live on roads where traffic has increased," said Stanley Steinberg, a Ledyard real estate broker, "their home prices have decreased, and selling them will be difficult." Conversely, home and condominium sales in the region have risen 15.4 percent over last year, and prices have increased by 2.4 percent, according to The Commercial Record, a Connecticut business weekly.
"It's the tribe's right to buy land," said Ms. Jeffery, "but annexation would change our lives forever.
"Why can't we live peacefully together as we have for generations?"

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Why Pay To Insure A Rental?

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
RENTERS, including the thousands of students going back to school these days, should be aware that one of the classic mistakes is to discount the importance of household insurance.
O.K., so they don't have Aubusson rugs or Cartier jewelry. But they may have expensive computer and other electronic equipment, VCR's, boom boxes, sports gear and so forth, which together may also be worth thousands of dollars. 
 Still, slightly less than half of all tenants bother to protect their personal belongings and furnishings with insurance, according to industry estimates, with younger people particularly lax.
Barbara Wick, senior vice president with Condominium Insurance Specialists of America, based in Arlington Heights, Ill., puts the figure as low as 25 percent in ongoing surveys that her company has taken in buildings that it manages.
"After a major fire or water loss it can be quite tragic," she said.
Yet unfortunately, in New York State, the number of insured renters is likely to shrink even more. Last December the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal issued an opinion letter stating that owners of rent-stabilized apartments could not require a tenant to buy renters' insurance as a condition of being granted a lease. The opinion was offered in response to an inquiry from a Bronx law firm that represents apartment owners.
Although it may have made sense for people who really do have little of value, it sends an unfortunate message to everyone else because a tenant policy is one of the great insurance bargains.
"I was quite shocked at how low the premiums were compared to auto or medical insurance," said Jackson Peng, owner of the Asia Restaurant on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, after shopping for renters' insurance a few years ago.
For example, a basic policy from State Farm Insurance that offers $20,000 of coverage with a $250 deductible plus $100,000 worth of personal liability costs just $84 a year for a renter in Westchester County and $140 in Manhattan (one of the highest-cost areas of the country). This type of policy also covers home-based computer equipment up to $5,000. USAA, a company based in San Antonio that specializes in covering military and former service personnel and their families, has a tenant protection plan costing $169 a year in New York (with no differential by location) that insures $20,000 worth of belongings, with a $100 deductible. It also includes $100,000 of personal liability and replacement cost coverage. This means it will pay to replace, say, a 10-year-old TV set, not just provide the cash equivalent of the TV's value at the time of the loss.
Still, tenant policies are continually dismissed as unnecessary, usually in the mistaken belief that the landlord can be held responsible for virtually everything that might go wrong.
"If water gets into the apartment or there's a fire or a robbery, it doesn't necessarily mean the landlord was negligent," said Carla Vel, a vice president at Kaye Insurance Associates of Manhattan.
Ms. Wick, the other insurance specialist, was so convinced of the same need that she made sure her 27-year-old daughter in student housing carried a renters' policy. So does her 25-year-old son.
Indeed, say experts, even when the landlord can be charged with negligence, it could cost more than it would probably be worth to hire a lawyer to fight the case.
Further, the liability portion of the policy, a relatively new phenomenon in renters' insurance, is something that many people should find comforting in these litigious times.
"What if you're the one who lets the bathtub overflow and you get sued by your downstairs neighbor," asks Ms. Vel. "Or you're walking along the street and poke someone in the eye with your umbrella." Some off-premises losses can be covered, too.
The typical renters' coverage is known as an HO4. It can either be written in a comprehensive form for "all risks" or for "named perils" only, the latter being about 20 percent cheaper because the losses it covers are more limited. But named perils should cover fire, theft or water damage, the primary hazards for a renter.
How much coverage you need depends, of course, on the value of your belongings. "The question you have to ask yourself is: 'How much can I stand to lose?' " said Mr. Peng, the restaurant owner.
Mr. Peng also reasoned that in an urban area like New York City theft was a particularly acute possibility. So it did not pay to scrimp. He pays $280 a year for $30,000 worth of coverage with a $200 deductible.
More and more renters are also making sure they get replacement cost coverage since the premium for this benefit, if it's not automatically included, is usually no more than an extra 10 percent.
But how do you make a reasonable estimate? The best way, say insurance experts, is to take a detailed inventory of all furnishing and personal belongings. And most insurance companies and independent agents will provide a worksheet as a guide through the process.
Using the worksheet also prompts the applicant to include items that might be overlooked, such as collectibles, said Wendell Wardell, product planner and development manager at State Farm.
It may also alert the renter to the need for separate coverage for individual items of value if they do have some of those jewels or expensive art work. The Pengs, for instance, also took out an off-premises rider that helped them when Cynthia Peng had her handbag stolen in a midtown hotel two years ago.
But not every rental situation is necessarily acceptable. As with auto insurance, it's difficult to get coverage if you've had a history of multiple claims on past rental policies.
State Farm, for example, tends to exclude anyone who has had more than three or four theft claims during the prior two years. It also examines the condition of the rental structure and may exclude buildings that are poorly maintained or have antiquated mechanical systems, such as inadequate wiring.
So it even pays for a landlord to take the necessary steps to make sure that renters' insurance will be available to a tenant, since it's in their interest to promote policies that avoid law suits, too.
Indeed, despite the New York State regulators' position, actually requiring a tenant to do so is something that lawyers increasingly advise landlords. It helps clarify, immediately, that there is a limit to any landlord's responsibilities. And this, in turn, helps prevent the owner from getting embroiled in endless arguments and prolonged litigation later on, too.

HEADLINE: How Tyson Became the Chicken King

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: SPRINGDALE, Ark.

 BODY:
Don Tyson, the chairman of Tyson Foods and America's chicken king, had the flushed look of a kid caught sneaking a peek at an X-rated videotape. Two other company executives also appeared mildly embarrassed to be discovered huddled around a television at the sleek headquarters building, where Andy Warhol competes for wall space with mounted marlins.
"Oh, uh, we're just watching a commercial for, uh, Butterball turkeys," muttered Mr. Tyson as one of the other men reached quickly to shut off the television. "Gotta be going anyway." 
 Only after the boss departed did one of the participants confess. They had been watching a videotape called "The Clinton Chronicles," an 83-minute, innuendo-filled attack on President Clinton that contains inflammatory allegations about Mr. Tyson's relations with his fellow Arkansan in the White House.
Tyson Foods Inc. is the world's largest poultry producer and processor, but its name has been in the headlines more often lately because of its ties to President Clinton and his Administration.
First came the disclosure that Tyson's general counsel had guided Hillary Rodham Clinton's unusually profitable trading in cattle futures. Then the Justice Department recommended appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate whether Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy violated the law by accepting plane rides, lodging and football tickets from Tyson.
In a sure sign things are not going well, Tyson's troubles wound up in a David Letterman late-night monologue. In a jab the other night at Mr. Espy's flights, Mr. Letterman deadpanned: "Good news, ladies and gentlemen. President Clinton today announced that the Tyson chicken company will be flying American combat troops to Haiti free."
The folks at Tyson are not laughing. "It's time-consuming and tiresome," groused the 64-year-old Mr. Tyson recently between bites of garlic chicken at Herman's Ribhouse, his favorite restaurant in nearby Fayetteville. "I could be doing something productive."
The poultry business is not nuclear power or airlines. But it is highly regulated, from state laws restricting truck weight to Federal inspectors who work alongside employees in plants. This means a company Tyson's size gets plenty of opportunities to brush up against the politicians who set policy and the regulators who enforce it.
"We don't make the system," said Archie Schaffer 3d, Tyson's director of media and government affairs, "but we have to play in it.'
And Tyson is a big player. From a one-truck business started by Mr. Tyson's father in the Depression, the company mushroomed from its Arkansas roots into a global empire through market innovations and a hardball acquisition strategy. It ranks 110th on the Fortune list of America's 500 largest companies, with $5.2 billion in sales projected for this year. It sells 6,000 food products in 57 countries, from fresh chickens to taco fillings. And it has made Don Tyson a very wealthy man, worth an estimated $800 million.
 
 
'Grow-or-Die' Philosophy
 Now, the company faces a risky new challenge as it tests the next phase of Mr. Tyson's "grow-or-die" philosophy. Tyson's business acumen -- as well as its political firepower -- is trained on the fishing industry, where the company hopes to replicate its success with chickens. The record is dismal so far, but no one familiar with the company is ready to write it off.
"Time will fix Tyson's seafood business and bring it into the operating story of the company," said John C. Bierbusse, an analyst with A. G. Edwards in St. Louis.
So far, the story of Tyson has been the story of chicken. Driven by health concerns and lower prices, Americans nearly doubled their chicken consumption in the last 20 years. Chicken surpassed beef as the most popular main course in the American diet. So businesses grew and consolidated. What was once a small regional industry run by families is now a true agribusiness in which 20 companies control 79 percent of production.
As the dominant company, Tyson slaughters 29 million chickens a week, producing twice as much chicken as second-ranking ConAgra and nearly three times as much as Frank Perdue's Perdue Farms. Tyson chicken shows up in 88 of the top 100 restaurant chains, in everything from McDonald's Chicken McNuggets to KFC's new rotisserie gold, both of which Tyson helped develop.
Tyson is the leading chicken supplier in Japan. This year, it will ship 300 million pounds of chicken to Russia, mostly leg quarters which are not as popular in the United States. Pursuing its next bonanza, Tyson executives were in China last week seeking Government approval for poultry ventures there.
In its drive to dominate the "center-of-the-plate" protein business, the company is now the nation's second-largest producer of hogs and is expanding its beef processing capacity. To complete the menu, Tyson bought the largest at-sea fishing processing fleet, Seattle-based Arctic Alaska Fisheries, in 1992.
But this month the diversification drive stung the company twice, raising questions about whether Tyson is overreaching. First, plans to grab a big share of the turkey industry failed when WLR Foods, the second-largest turkey producer, rebuffed a hostile bid led by Mr. Tyson himself.
 
 
Tyson's First Write-Off
 Then Tyson took the first major write-off in its history because of troubles at Arctic Alaska. The $205 million charge against earnings in the quarter that ended June 30 left the company with a per-share loss of $1 for the period. Still, investors are confident that most of Tyson's problems in the fishery business are behind it. Its stock price has remained steady in the $24-a-share range.
When the company started out, it had no financial cushion to absorb errors. John Tyson, a produce hauler from Kansas, was driving through the small Ozark Mountain town of Springdale in 1930 when his truck ran out of gas. He stayed, began hauling fruit for local orchards and branched out to chickens. Soon, he was delivering poultry throughout the Southeast and the Midwest.
As business grew, Mr. Tyson found that growers sometimes did not have enough birds to keep him busy. So he bought a hatchery and produced baby chicks for the growers. By the late 1940's, Mr. Tyson had added a farm, a feed mill and growing houses, pioneering the concept of vertical integration in the industry.
His son left the University of Arkansas in his senior year to join his father in 1952. Don Tyson became the company's president in 1966, three years after it went public. By that time, he was already responsible for a major breakthrough.
The poultry business had always been cyclical. In 1965, Mr. Tyson sought refuge from the boom-or-bust cycles by inventing Rock Cornish game hens, named for the cross breeding of two types of chicken.
Nothing more than young female chickens under two pounds, Mr. Tyson sold them to markets as specialty items for 50 cents each, a higher profit than chickens sold by the pound and a price that was not tied to daily fluctuations.
Mr. Tyson took over as chairman of the company after his father and stepmother were killed in an accident in 1967, when their car was struck by a train. A replica of John Tyson's office in the corporate headquarters contains a clock stopped at the time of his death. Much of what the son has done since is a variation on the game hen theme of extracting more value from the basic product, chicken.
 
 
Time for Sale
 "It was pretty much Don's vision that fueled the company," said Mark A. Plummer, an analyst at Stephens Inc. in Little Rock. "He saw that if you added more convenience by further processing the chicken, consumers would pay for it."
Processed chicken was Tyson's biggest boom. They debone it, marinate it, cut it into pieces, press it into patties, roll it into nuggets, bread it, batter it, cook it and freeze it. In return, processed products command a premium price over fresh chicken.
"We're really selling time along with quality and convenience," said Mr. Tyson over lunch at Herman's, where the chicken on the menu -- garlic, barbecued or Cajun -- was from Tyson. "We produce it and you assemble it."
Modern processing plants are a far cry from grabbing a chicken by the neck and whacking off its head. Live chickens empty onto a conveyor belt that leads to a darkened room, where workers hang them upside down from U-shaped shackles on an assembly line. The birds are stunned with an electric shock, their throats slit by machine and they move through boiling water to loosen the feathers. Machines massage off the feathers, eviscerate and wash the birds inside and out, and slice them into pieces.
Seventy birds a minute move down the line, the maximum allowed by the Department of Agriculture. Government inspectors work alongside Tyson employees, inspecting chickens as they move toward the breading, cooking and freezing operations.
Nothing is wasted. Feathers, heads, blood and internal organs are collected and sent to a Tyson rendering plant to become ingredients in chicken and cattle feed and pet food. Chicken feet, called paws, are shipped to China for use in soups and appetizers.
A few years ago, Mr. Tyson noticed a surplus of gizzards, since fewer birds were sold with innards. He thought he could earn some money by finding a use for them. And the gizzard burger was born.
"Gizzards are high in protein, so we ground 'em up and added hamburger flavor," recalled Mr. Tyson. "The price was a third to a half what hamburger cost."
Gizzard patties were first marketed in the Watts section of South-Central Los Angeles. They were a flop. Undeterred, Mr. Tyson made use of his legendary Arkansas connections.
"I figured we'd try a captive market," he said. "I called a man I knew in the prison system. He agreed to serve gizzard burgers to the prisoners. Well, the first time they served them, he called me up and said, 'Don, if we try to serve'em again, these prisoners are gonna riot.' "
Laughing loudly, Mr. Tyson added, "You know, you could almost eat those gizzard burgers."
Along with more than 60 poultry, beef and pork processing plants nationwide, Tyson operates 24 feed mills, 35 hatcheries and 36 fishing and processing ships. Through its Mexican food line, Tyson is one of the nation's largest tortilla makers.
But chicken still dominates, accounting for $3 out of every $4 of the company's sales. Processed chicken accounts for 71 percent of those sales, with fresh and chilled pieces and whole birds making up the rest.
 
 
Close to the Edge
 Tyson revenues have increased sevenfold in the last decade and profits have risen from $18.1 million in 1984 to a projected $200.1 million this year. About half of the growth has come from internal expansion. The other half came by acquiring more than 20 other companies.
In an industry where companies are often highly leveraged, Tyson regularly plays close to the edge. Its debt-to-capital ratio of 45 percent reflects the company's aggressive financial stance. So far, Tyson has come up a winner.
The biggest acquisition -- and the biggest win -- was the 1989 purchase of Holly Farms for $1.5 billion. Holly was the second-largest chicken producer behind Tyson and it had been set to merge with ConAgra. Mr. Tyson unleashed a bitter, two-year fight and finally prevailed in a battle that demonstrated his dogged determination to maintain industry dominance.
"We had to have Holly," explained Mr. Tyson. "If ConAgra had bought Holly, they would have been No. 1.
Being No. 1 carries more than bragging rights in the food business. The biggest companies get the most shelf space in supermarkets and the most clout with big customers such as restaurant chains and the growing wholesale club market.
Tyson's tactics have won it admirers and critics in the industry. Earlier this year, when Tyson went after WLR Foods, the turkey producer in Broadway, Va., it employed a full media blitz accusing WLR management of putting their jobs ahead of shareholder interests in rejecting the bid of $30 a share for stock selling around $20. But shareholders rejected Tyson five times.
"I admire a lot of what I see about the Tyson company, but I don't agree one bit with the way Don Tyson continued his hostile takeover attempt of our company," said James L. Keeler, president and chief executive of WLR.
Despite its bare-knuckle demeanor, Tyson maintains a homespun atmosphere reminiscent of another Arkansas entrepreneur, the late Sam Walton. All Tyson executives, including the chairman, wear the same khaki uniform, with their first name stitched on the shirt. Anyone who refers to their 54,000 co-workers as "employees" instead of "people" is fined a quarter.
 
 
Corporate Myth
 Part of this corporate populism is the myth that the wealthy Mr. Tyson lives simply in the modest house he built 30 years ago. In fact, he spends about two weeks a month on his 62-foot boat fishing for marlin from Mexico to Africa. His trophies dot the company headquarters, topped by the head of a 1,100-pound black marlin. He drives a jet-black, $45,000 Range Rover and owns homes in Fayetteville, Little Rock, England and Baja, California.
Mr. Tyson and his wife, Jean, have been separated for two decades, but this year he built her a 7,000-square-foot limestone house on 33 acres just down Johnson Road from the corporate headquarters.
As the empire has grown, so have efforts to protect it. That means courting politicians and contributing to campaigns. Mr. Tyson routinely makes his Baja house available to the Arkansas Poultry Federation for fishing junkets by legislators. The company's political action committee, called Typac, has contributed $99,800 to candidates for Senate and House seats in the 1993-94 Federal election cycle.
Two years ago, Mr. Tyson, family members and company executives gave $29,000 to Mr. Clinton's presidential campaign, and Mr. Tyson was favored as one of the few corporate executives to speak at Mr. Clinton's pre-inauguration economic summit in Little Rock.
Along with airplane rides, meals and lodging for Mr. Espy and a companion, Mr. Tyson and company employees contributed $6,000 to help retire the campaign debt of the Agriculture Secretary's brother, Henry, who lost a bid for Congress in 1993.
It was the same year the Agriculture Department shelved work on new poultry inspection regulations. Only after congressional pressure did it resume the work this year. Mr. Espy has denied engaging in any misconduct and Tyson officials say they support stricter inspections and were not trying to influence him.
Tyson is counting on political help to recover from its uncharacteristic stumble in the fish business. Many in the industry scoffed that Tyson overpaid when it bought Arctic Alaska for $212 million. Then the market collapsed for surimi, the imitation crab and lobster meat that is Arctic Alaska's biggest product. Prices plunged to 50 cents a pound from $2 after the Japanese reduced their purchases. In addition, the Russian Government has refused to allow Arctic Alaska boats to fish its waters, something Tyson had counted on.
 
 
Grand Strategy
 "It still fits our grand strategy of being a center-of-the-plate protein provider," said Leland E. Tollett, Tyson's chief executive and president.
Tyson officials believe success lies partly in revamping management of fish harvesting in the Pacific Northwest. Under the current system, appointed management councils determine the size of the catch and set the season. Tyson wants a quota system, which would divide the annual catch into shares. Companies could leisurely fish their shares, lease them or sell them. By ending the current race for fish in a short season, the process would be safer and more efficient, Mr. Tyson said.
Smaller fishermen oppose the change. They argue it would give Tyson an unfair advantage by allowing it to purchase or lease other shares -- and monopolize the fish industry the way it has chicken.
To get its views across, Tyson hired Alaska Governor Walter Hickel's personal attorney, along with a top lobbyist. However, the final decision will be made in Washington, where some Alaskans fear Tyson wields more influence.
"Tyson felt they are not getting a fair shake in the Pacific Northwest and they want to shift things back to Washington," said Dennis Phelan, a lobbyist for interests opposed to changing the system.
To lobby on fish-related issues, Tyson recently hired Ralph Everett, a senior staff member of the Senate Commerce Committee, and Glenn R. Delaney, who worked on the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee.
The efforts have begun to pay some dividends, although quotas face a bitter fight. On Aug. 4, Senator John Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, introduced a bill to strip the management councils of much of their power, a move supported by Tyson.
Senator Breaux received $4,000 in contributions from Mr. Tyson and other company executives in his last race and Mr. Delaney used to work for him. Senator Breaux said he talked with Mr. Delaney, but he said the bill was aimed at ridding the council system of conflicts of interest, not helping Tyson.
Mr. Schaffer said, "All we want is a fair and safe system for managing the fisheries."

HEADLINE: Population Growth Is Anything but Harmless

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Surely you published Julian L. Simon's "Population Distraction" (Op-Ed, Aug. 21) only because of his prominence during the Reagan-Bush years, not for its "facts" or the validity of his position. Mr. Simon remains stuck in the now thoroughly discredited theory that rapid population growth is harmless. 
 Before 1980 there was indeed no correlation between population growth in developing countries and economic development. After 1980, however, yearly income growth was 1.23 percent in the 41 developing countries with below-average population growth, whereas in the 41 with faster population growth, average yearly income fell by 1.25 percent. This relationship held true everywhere.
Common sense belies Mr. Simon's theory. In sub-Saharan Africa, with minimal access to family planning, children younger than 5 total twice the number of adults 20 to 24 years old, four times the number of those 40 to 44 and 10 times the number of those 65 to 69. The population has a 23-year doubling period, per capita food production is falling, illiteracy is the norm, and malnutrition is rampant. The work force is so debilitated by AIDS and overwhelmed by dependents that saving is almost impossible. The entire continent produces less than the Netherlands.
Mr. Simon belittles the Cairo population conference and would have us do nothing. Happily, Congress disagrees. Though reducing total foreign aid appropriations for next year, it increased population assistance by 18 percent.
 
JOHN R. BERMINGHAM
Pres., Colorado Population Coalition
Denver, Aug. 24, 1994

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Interior Secretary Endures Storms From All Directions

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
INTERIOR SECRETARY BRUCE BABBITT has been fighting forest fires this summer, donning a yellow fireproof shirt and taking up a shovel in hot spots from the Colorado Rockies to the Washington Cascades. He says he enjoys staring down a wall of flames.
Fires may actually be a relief compared with the heat Mr. Babbitt has faced from the two extremes in the debate over how to manage nearly 500 million acres of public land. In Wyoming last month, Mr. Babbitt surprised opponents when he showed up at a barbecue and ranchers' rally against his policies. Beef was on the spit, but the grill was hottest under Mr. Babbitt. Speaker after speaker ridiculed the 56-year-old Interior Secretary. Through it all, he chatted and swapped stories with the crowd, as if he were just another cowboy. 
 On the other side of the land-use divide, some environmental leaders say they have all but given up on Mr. Babbitt, calling him the kind of names that seldom find their way into organic farm monthlies. The man whom the Wilderness Society heralded as "our Babe Ruth" when he was appointed last year is now viewed by some members as something closer to Bob Uecker.
Mr. Babbitt, a third-generation Westerner from a prominent Arizona ranching family, says he relishes the heat. Recently, after four hours' give-and-take with Western senators who are fighting to hold on to century-old subsidies for mining, grazing and timber interests, he came away looking refreshed. "I love it," said Mr. Babbitt, who picked up part of his debating skills from the priests at the University of Notre Dame, where he was student body president. "Bring 'em on."
But if Mr. Babbitt remains unbloodied in his fight to change the way America's vast public domain is managed, some of his major policy initiatives are in tatters. He came into office vowing that 1993 will be the year of reform on public lands.
Yet his plan to raise grazing fees paid by the ranchers who run livestock over 280 million acres of public land was stymied first in the Senate, where it was filibustered to death, and later in the West, where vocal and occasionally militant opponents packed hearings run by their allies in the Senate. A small increase in grazing fees, barely above the level paid 15 years ago, will go into effect next year, Mr. Babbitt now says.
But this is not enough for people who waited through 12 years of Republican administrations to get some changes in the grazing policies. "The year of public land reform turned into the year of public land retreat," said Jeff DeBonis, the head of a group of Federal employees who favor more environmental changes in the agencies that govern Federal land.
Mr. Babbitt made a big splash in trying to end the 1872 mining law, which allows companies to take billions of dollars in gold and silver from public lands without paying anything in royalties. The law's biggest beneficiaries are foreign-owned companies, which dominate mining in the United States. But a bill to overhaul the law, passed by a 3-to-1 ratio in the House, is now stalled in the Senate, where some Westerners have again threatened to filibuster.
His biggest fight, over reauthorization of the Endangered Species Act, will come next year. Mr. Babbitt has recently appeared at press conferences with the leaders of the timber and sugar industries, heralding their cooperation in his effort to show that saving creatures in peril is not the Rush Limbaugh nightmare its opponents describe. But courting the business leaders may not be enough to stave off a run at the act, which is considered the most powerful environmental law on the books.
"Babbitt made a real blunder in trying to take on the grazing, mining and timber industries all at once," said Phil Hocker, head of the Mineral Policy Center, which tracks mining. "So now the Republicans see this as a way to score political points against the Democrats."
Western senators, emboldened by the success in stalling grazing and mining reforms, say Mr. Babbitt is conducting "a war on the West," and that the Democrats will pay dearly for it in the next Presidential election. Mr. Clinton took 7 of the 11 Western states in 1992.
The vast majority of Westerners, says Mr. Babbitt, are with him, and he points to polls showing that in most Western states up to 80 percent of the people want mining and grazing laws to change. Ranchers and mining employees make up less than 1 percent of all workers in the West, and he says they have painted a distorted picture of what he is trying to do. Indeed, opponents are hard-pressed to point to a single thing he has accomplished which is directly hurting them.
Just as James G. Watt helped to galvanize the environmental movement against him when he was Ronald Reagan's Interior Secretary, Mr. Babbitt is a fund-raising draw for the extraction industries.
"Babbitt is helping us raise a lot of money," said Barbara Grannell, the director of People for the West, a group supported by mining, ranching and logging interests. "What Bruce Babbitt is about is control. He's trying to control how people use the land and water."
Environmentalists are in a deep funk. "There is a good chance he has lost control of the agenda," said Jon Roush, president of the Wilderness Society. "The people who oppose him are people who want it all, and they are accustomed to getting it all."
The same criticism has been made of environmentalists, who tend to desert political leaders at the first sign of compromise. Supporters of Mr. Babbitt say he has had little, if any, help from President Clinton, who early on traded away a stiff grazing-fee increase to win Senate votes on his economic policies. Twice, the President has dangled Mr. Babbitt's name as a possible Supreme Court nominee, but has made few other public mentions of him or his efforts.
 
Casualties of Office
 The job itself has inherent conflicts, and a high casualty rate. One long-ago Interior Secretary collapsed of a nervous breakdown 13 days into the job, and another, Albert Fall, was convicted in the 1920's Teapot Dome scandal of accepting a bribe to lease an oil reserve and was sentenced to prison.
Mr. Babbitt may be most effective from the bully pulpit, using the same tool that one of his conservationist heroes, Teddy Roosevelt, used. He has made strong speeches about national parks, saving wild places such as the California desert and keeping the Federal Government out of the dam-building business.
"Under my watch, the National Park Service is not going to be in the hotel business," he said earlier this summer, siding with critics who feel the parks have become too cluttered by commercial establishments. He recently evoked Teddy Roosevelt, saying a supporter had urged him to do what Roosevelt did in 1907, when he infuriated the timber industry by creating large forest reserves. One goal which Mr. Babbitt may actually be able to reach is a bit more modest. He says, simply, that he is determined to become one of the first Interior secretaries to finish a four-year term.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt suited up with firefighters near Truckee, Calif., earlier this month. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: Best of Enemies;
Castro, the Man With Few Cards, Always Winds Up the Dealer

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
HIS country may be crumbling around him, its economy reduced to ruins and its people so disgusted with their situation that some have marched in the streets of Havana this month, openly demanding his ouster. But for all his problems at home, Fidel Castro still retains a remarkable ability to bedevil the United States and to transfer the burden of his own domestic failings to the adversary he has fought with such gusto and relish for more than 35 years.
In what has become a rite of passage for every American President since Eisenhower, Bill Clinton is now learning that lesson the hard way. The internal crisis that began less than a month ago with boat hijackings and a riot in Havana has quickly been transformed into a crisis of American foreign and immigration policy, with the United States now forced to provide temporary refuge at places like the Guantanamo Bay naval base for the more than 16,000 disenchanted Cubans intercepted as they headed for Florida aboard rickety rafts. As was the case during the 1980 exodus from the port of Mariel, Mr. Castro, playing a weak hand with consummate skill, is now dictating the course and tempo of events while Washington, with far more resources at its disposal, struggles to respond. 
 "Everything that he is doing today is consistent with what he has always done, which is to be creative with his limited options," said Tad Szulc, who wrote the biography "Fidel: A Critical Portrait" with the Cuban leader's cooperation. "He has been doing this for a living for 35 years, and realizes he has only one card to play, the weapon of the refugees. He needs the breathing space and knows that the only way to get it is to force the Americans into a dialogue."
If anything, Mr. Castro seems energized by his clash with a young, untested President, whose foreign policy staff includes many of the same officials who were also involved in Mariel. In eclipse since the collapse of the Soviet bloc five years ago, his image tarnished by reports of Cubans going hungry and the collapse of the health and education programs that were the proudest achievements of the Cuban Revolution, the Maximum Leader is back on the front lines and in the international limelight again, leading the efforts to quell internal discontent and cut the yanquis down to size.
Mr. Castro comes well-equipped to the latest confrontation with his "closest of enemies," as Wayne Smith, former head of the United States Interests Section in Havana, describes the United States-Cuba relationship. He is known to be an avid viewer of CNN on the satellite dish that was Ted Turner's gift to him a decade ago, and, Mr. Szulc said, not only sees that Mr. Clinton has his hands full with domestic legislation and with Bosnia, Korea and Haiti, but knows how to use that knowledge to his own benefit. He is also well aware that the United States, given its values and domestic political pressures, cannot afford to send back the "anti-social elements" he is encouraging to leave, even though Mr. Clinton has reversed the longstanding policy of automatically granting asylum to fleeing Cubans.
"Fidel is a shrewd student of United States society, institutions and government," Jose Luis Llovio Menendez, an ex-Cuban official, wrote in "Insider," an account of his 17 years in the revolutionary elite. He said Mr. Castro "understands the limitations on a President's power to act in many critical circumstances. This knowledge informs his every strategic maneuver."
As Mr. Castro's oldest associates tell it, that has always been the case. "He knew from the beginning that to be a great man he had to confront a great power," Carlos Franqui, one of Mr. Castro's earliest comrades in arms, said in an interview. In a letter written in June 1958 while still in the Sierra Maestra fighting the Batista dictatorship, Mr. Castro said of the United States that "when this war is over, a much longer and larger war will begin for me: the war I'm going to wage against them. I realize that this will be my destiny."
More often than not, of course, Mr. Castro has found the United States only too happy to oblige that ambition. Ludicrous assassination schemes, the botched Bay of Pigs invasion and diplomatic campaigns aimed at isolating him internationally all added to his revolutionary luster, remaining propaganda fodder for Havana long after the United States pledged, as part of the solution to the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, not to use force to overthrow Mr. Castro.
Occasionally, however, Washington has shown itself able to defuse challenges Mr. Castro has manufactured. In September 1965, for example, in an immigration crisis handled so deftly that it has been largely forgotten, Mr. Castro announced that any malcontents were welcome to leave from the port of Camarioca. Over the next month, more than 5,000 Cubans took to sea in small vessels of every type, straining the ability of the Coast Guard to intercept and assist them.
The Johnson Administration, preoccupied with Vietnam and fearing a tragedy in the Straits of Florida, quickly proposed an open-ended refugee airlift if Mr. Castro would call a halt to the exodus. He accepted the offer, and the ensuing "freedom flights" lasted into the 1970's, bringing more than 200,000 Cubans to the United States with virtually no fanfare or any real political cost for either side.
"That is the model Cuba likes for migration, and Castro said as much" last week in a rambling speech on Cuban TV, said Lisandro Perez, director of the Cuba Research Institute at Florida International University. "He wants an escape valve that is orderly and drawn out and not very splashy." This time, Mr. Castro's call for high-level negotiations was rejected, though the Administration said yesterday it would like to quickly resume mid-level talks on migration with the aim of stemming the flow of refugees.
In fact, though Mr. Castro likes to portray American policy toward his revolution as one of unrelenting hostility, the record indicates otherwise. All nine presidents since the days of Eisenhower have sought to take the approach recommended by then-Vice President Richard Nixon as he emerged from his Washington office with his arm around the Cuban leader after they met there in April 1959: "We're going to work with this man."
Mr. Nixon himself would later negotiate an anti-air-hijacking agreement with Mr. Castro. And under President Ford, Secretary of State Henry Kissinger said he saw no reason for "perpetual antagonism between Cuba and the U.S." In 1975, the United States even voted with the majority at the Organization of American States to end sanctions against Cuba, and under Jimmy Carter, an even broader initiative was launched.
 
The Same Pattern
 But Mr. Castro unilaterally abrogated the anti-hijacking agreement after blaming the United States for the bombing of a Cuban airliner. The Ford initiative collapsed when Cuban troops were sent to fight in Angola's civil war. As for the Carter Administration's efforts to reduce tensions between the two countries, they were answered with Mariel.
Despite those bitter experiences, however, Ronald Reagan was able to put aside his aversion to Communism and reach accords with Mr. Castro on migration and the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Africa. "Each and every one of these Presidents came to the conclusion that an important aspect of his Castro crisis required negotiations," said Jorge I. Dominguez, a Cuba expert at Harvard's Center for International Affairs.
With Mr. Clinton, the Cuban leader's behavior thus far has followed much the same pattern. "Every time an American President takes office, Castro starts by throwing bouquets," said Mr. Franqui, who fought in the Sierra Maestra with Mr. Castro and wrote "Family Portrait With Fidel" after breaking with him. "But at a certain moment, he always provokes a problem."
In the current crisis, Mr. Castro has repeatedly said his ultimate objective is the lifting of the economic embargo that the United States has maintained on trade with Cuba for more than 30 years. But the embargo has also worked to his benefit, not only because he can blame it for Cuba's economic ills but also because it is easily circumvented, and an American offer to discuss ending the embargo in return for political reforms might well put Mr. Castro in a difficult spot.
"I have always believed he is more afraid of openness than isolation," Dr. Perez said. Lifting the embargo "would allow him greater options for trade, yes, but he doesn't have any money to buy anything. It wouldn't really multiply the possibilities of trade, but it would bring in a flood of ideas and dollars, which are dangerous, and deprive him of a political tool."
Or as Mr. Nixon put it in a book published just before his death this spring, "the plain fact . . . is that after 35 years of Castro's rule, the hard line against him has failed to get rid of him." With the Communist bloc gone, "our best service to the Cuban people now would be to build pressure from within by actively stimulating Cuba's contacts with the free world," Mr. Nixon concluded.
No matter what the outcome of his umpteenth clash with Washington, Mr. Castro plans to stick around. In Colombia three weeks ago, he compared himself to the Great Liberator of the Americas, Simon Bolivar, and vowed to keep on frustrating "those who want to see me away from all this."
"Revolutionaries never abandon the battlefield," he explained. "Revolutionaries do not go into retirement as long as their services and efforts are required."
