LENGTH: 2437 words

HEADLINE: The rage for the real

BYLINE: By Joan Duncan Oliver 

 BODY:
Save for the occasional flurry -- Elsa Peretti's "Diamonds-By-The-Yard" at Tiffany's in the 1970's; Paloma Picasso's killer rocks at the same store in the early 80's; the sale of the Duchess of Windsor's fabled jewels at Sotheby's in 1987 -- real jewelry as fashion news has been all but moribund for decades.
But last March, the influential English designer John Galliano, who shows in Paris, chose to accessorize his fall collection with important pieces borrowed from such venerable French jewelers as Rene Boivin. When Galliano repeated the performance in New York in June at Bergdorf Goodman, with diamonds from Van Cleef & Arpels, fashion antennae started whirring. Editors who had felt ho-hum about the real stuff started giving it more than perfunctory attention. After several seasons of severe, accessory-less style, somehow the real stuff began to look right. 
 "Real jewelry is a sign of the new glamour," was Galliano's explanation. "There's a resurgence of elegance. Women have lost interest in hiding behind shapeless clothes and again want to celebrate beauty and femininity."
Darting among the models backstage at Bergdorf's, a puckish figure in red leather pants and a tail coat, Galliano tweaked and tucked and managed to make the pedigreed jewelry look almost cheeky. He slipped a 12.5-carat diamond earring into the bodice of a pink satin fishtail dress, turned a $200,000 diamond bow into a hatpin, jabbed a $28,000 camellia brooch onto a Persian lamb muff. "Diamonds should be worn irreverently," he says, "such as on the ankles, or back to front. Or like a pair of jeans."
Then there was Marc Jacobs, the street-smart New York designer, whose show was the talk of the fall collections. He accessorized his clothes with diamond earrings and scatter pins he had designed himself. With his little paveed letters and numbers, you can flash your name and phone number across your chest, if that's your thing. "I like diamonds worn with a throwaway attitude," Jacobs says.
Meanwhile, the House of Chanel, legendary for its high-fashion costume jewelry, has come out with its first precious jewelry since the 1930's. Introduced last year in Paris, it is due here in October.
And Tiffany's is planning to launch a small but important gem missile of its own (see " 'Juicy' Jewels," page 52).
W hat's happening now is a shift in attitude. There's a new kick to getting dressed: it's playing dress-up. Like the little tweed suits, slinky evening dresses and Mata Hari makeup around this season, fine jewelry taps into past images of glamour. After a couple of sober years, fashion's back to the pursuit of pleasure. Diamond sales last year topped $12 billion, an all-time high. What better than real flash to celebrate the sheer fun of being decorative? The mid-90's sense of values isn't how big or how much or how old, but how delicious and how good.
 Questions of value loom larger in periods of economic uncertainty. In 1932, at the height of the Depression, Coco Chanel, already established as queen of the faux, stunned Paris by mounting an exhibit of platinum and diamond pieces (they weren't for sale), ostensibly to benefit the foundering jewelry industry. "At a time of financial crisis," she said to explain the gesture, "in every aspect of life there appears an instinctive craving for authenticity."
The idea is right on target now. When costume jewelry may cost thousands, yet ruby rings are hawked on QVC, there's an undeniable pull toward value. "If you're going to spend $1,500 anyway," says Jean Appleton, the founder and director of the Jewelry Resource Center at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York, "then you think, 'I might as well buy something real.' "
And something else is happening. The "trophy wife," on whom a man could hang material evidence of his success, is phasing out. Working women are buying jewelry for themselves. "Even women married to men who want to do the giving have gotten the message across that they want to be involved in the choice," says Edward J. Landrigan, president of the New York jeweler Verdura.
For some women, of course, precious jewelry has never lost its luster. Witness the success of Verdura, which is reissuing the jewelry of Fulco di Verdura and Suzanne Belperron, two influential designers from the first half of the century whose work had slipped into obscurity.
Just as fake furs are stirring up a fur revival, costume jewelry, with its crash and splash, is credited by many experts with helping to bring back the real. "The most effective costume jewelry has its genesis in real jewelry, much of it from the 30's and 40's," says Landrigan. "It was bold, and there was a lot of exciting jewelry then."
When Landrigan took over the company in 1984, Fulco di Verdura's work was known to the general public mainly through Kenneth Jay Lane's costume jewelry knockoffs. Landrigan dusted off the Verdura archives, containing thousands of designs.
A charming and soigne Sicilian duke, whose family was chronicled in "The Leopard" by Giuseppe di Lampedusa, Verdura was as much a part of cafe society as most of his clients. He got his start from Chanel in the 20's, creating her signature enameled Maltese-cross cuffs. Like Chanel, Verdura preferred gold and colored gems to platinum and diamonds, and thought big "important" stones on their own were vulgar. (He reportedly referred to diamond solitaires as "swimming pools.") From the time he set up shop in New York in 1939, fashionable women found his mad artistry an antidote to the Art Deco jewelry then in vogue -- and far more suitable for daytime wear. There were real seashells dipped in precious and semiprecious stones; gold looped and twisted into ropes and swags and sailor's knots; fantastical animal and flower brooches. "Verdura broke all the rules," says Landrigan. "He made jewelry out of sea glass: the blue was milk of magnesia bottles; the green, 7-Up. He used big, chunky beads in pinks and blues, mabe pearls and Russian emerald beads. They weren't gem-quality, Colombian emeralds, so they didn't cost hundreds of thousands of dollars."
In 1991, Landrigan acquired the sketchbooks of the Parisian designer Suzanne Belperron, along with exclusive rights to sell the jewelry made from her designs. Belperron, who was born in 1900, two years after Verdura, worked steadily from the 1920's until her death in 1983. But she was so reclusive that it was only with the auction of the Duchess of Windsor's jewelry that Belperron's name and work came to light.
She gave no interviews and refused to sign her pieces. (They are recognized today by the maker's mark, Darde et Fils; the new pieces are stamped with her name, to distinguish them.) Known to a stylish "underground," she is sometimes called the "JAR" of her day. (JAR is Joel Arthur Rosenthal, another famously inventive Parisian jeweler, American by birth, who works out of his tiny shop, JAR's, off the Place Vendome. He, like Belperron, sees clients only by appointment and by referral.)
Belperron's talent ripened early. Just 23 when she went to work for Rene Boivin, she was instrumental in establishing the look of his jewelry house, before leaving a decade later to form a partnership with the pearl dealer Bernard Herz. Her life is veiled in mystery -- she burned her papers before she died -- but there are stories: that she was Herz's lover for many years; that she was in the French Resistance during World War II. In any case, when Herz was sent to a concentration camp, Belperron put the firm in her name and carried on. After the war -- Herz died in the camp -- she took his son, Jean, who had been a prisoner of war, into the business as her partner.
Her clientele stretched from Colette to the avant-garde designer Elsa Schiaparelli to Grace Kelly, and to such celebrated men as Charlie Chaplin, Gary Cooper, Fred Astaire and Frank Sinatra. Except for Colette (Belperron reportedly broke her usual policy to make "house calls" to the aged writer), they all trooped off to Belperron's small shop in the ninth arrondissement, on the rue de Chateaudun, for the jeweler's equivalent of couture fittings.
"I'm not surprised Schiaparelli was a client," says a woman who knew them both. "There would have been a meeting of the minds there. Neither one was a traditionalist." In 1935, Schiaparelli was photographed by Vogue wearing Belperron jewels with her Venetian blackamoor costume for Daisy Fellowes's Bal Oriental. "Incredible accessories" is how the magazine described them.
Unlike Verdura, Belperron never socialized with clients. "Nobody ever got on a first-name basis with her," a former customer recalls, though "she had a perfectly charming personality, a lovely smile." Black-haired, elegant, Belperron always wore black and, before it was fashionable, long fingernails painted dark red. Meeting with a client, she often sketched while talking. Then she'd say, "But let me refine this a little." Later, after the client had gone, she'd spread out gems on her worktable or on the floor to study their effect at a distance.
Each piece was one-of-a-kind. Belperron's sketchbooks -- some 4,500 drawings, more than 800 of them brooches -- don't even cover the extent of her output. The range of motifs is vast, from stylized natural elements -- a butterfly, a bunch of grapes, a fiddlehead fern, a conch shell -- to gutsy abstract forms drawn from her far-flung travels. "You can practically hear the tribal drums when you look at her work," Landrigan says.
Like Verdura, Belperron mixed precious stones and humbler materials. She was among the first to sink gems directly into rock crystal, quartz and chalcedony, devising nearly invisible settings that played up the colors and sensuous forms. The finished pieces -- a crystal and diamond starfish, for example, or a chalcedony flower with articulated petals -- are not quite like what anyone else was doing, or has done since. "People are finally understanding that jewelry can be a work of art," Landrigan says.
When a pair of Belperron's wavy scroll-motif platinum and diamond cuffs from the 30's came up for auction last April, "half the audience was waiting for those bracelets," says John Block, an executive vice president at Sotheby's and director of the jewelry and precious objects department in New York. They
sold for $222,500 -- nearly three times the high estimate of $80,000.
The sapphire, diamond and blue chalcedony pieces that Belperron made for the Duchess of Windsor look as modern today as 60 years ago. "It's a 90's sensibility," says Marion Fasel, a jewelry historian and co-author with Penny Proddow of "Hollywood Jewels" (Abrams) and of a forthcoming history of diamond jewelry styles. "When a woman isn't going to feel comfortable wearing a large emerald on the street, she's certainly going to feel comfortable wearing a large chalcedony, because it doesn't scream 'precious jewelry,' yet it has the sparkle of diamonds and sapphires, and it's well crafted."
With security such an issue now, jewelers are more tight-lipped than ever about their clients. Those in the know, however, are aware that women regularly mentioned in the society columns are wearing Belperron and Verdura. There are ways around the security problem. Those Hermes and Armani scarves draped around fashionable necks may be covering an important brooch. Brushing aside the scarf ever so slightly, the wearer can show her pin to those she knows will appreciate it fully. "It's a bit of theater, that scarf," says Landrigan. "But it works."
Meanwhile, at the old, established jewelry houses, the workrooms are as busy as ever. At Harry Winston one recent morning, the head designer, Ambaji Shinde, was checking progress on a rush order: a pair of drop earrings and a necklace designed around five colossal emeralds brought in by a client from the Middle East. "This is the only company where we can play," he said, in his quiet, courtly manner. "Nobody else has these stones."
For 32 years Shinde has been creating pieces with some of the world's most impressive gems. In his small upstairs office, out of sight of the customers, he paints detailed watercolor designs with the delicacy of an Indian court miniaturist. Having begun his career in Bombay after India's independence, when maharajahs were selling off their jewels by the drawerful, Shinde is used to turning major stones into works of art. When the company president, Ronald Winston, presented him with an exceedingly rare green diamond -- at 8.09 carats, the world's largest -- Shinde made several sketches. "One was a flower," he says. "But then I thought, 'Why not a peacock?' " The resulting brooch, reminiscent of a turban pin, has articulated vanes that wiggle and rows of sapphires, emeralds and colored diamonds surrounding the big green gem.
With a price tag of $3 million, such artistry eludes most jewelry wearers. But on a more modest scale, fine-jewelry sales are up across the country, notes Stephen Magner, vice president in charge of precious jewelry at Neiman Marcus. Not only are diamonds on the upswing, but estate jewelry, too, is selling well, especially Art Deco. "The old look is now a fashion statement," Magner says.
It also signals a sense of permanence, a yearning for substance. "People see enormous integrity in those pieces," says Ralph Destino, the chairman of Cartier. "Some of the allure -- the attractiveness, the provenance -- of old pieces has shaped ideas about what jewelry today should be. The attitude is: 'If I can't have yesterday's heirloom, I can buy tomorrow's.' "
But for all the lofty explanations for precious jewelry's resurgence -- the ups and downs of hemlines, taste or the economy -- fashion has its own goofy logic. The best justification for the real may be the simplest: "The reason I chose diamonds," says John Galliano, "is that they make me smile."
 
'JUICY' JEWELS
 
Tiffany's latest collection of "gems" takes its cue from some unlikely sources. "I think the whole look of America is changing," says the company's senior vice president and design director, John Loring. "Cartooning is the most important influence on a generation brought up on pop culture." For them, much of today's jewelry "is too linear and dry," he says. His solution? What he calls "juicy jewelry," with the curvy shapes and plump profiles that make cartoon characters so appealing. "Things have to be fun in this day and age," Loring says. All the pieces are in matte-finish 18-karat gold with pearl or colored-stone accents. Even more fun are the prices: $725 to $1,400. -- JOAN DUNCAN OLIVER

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

Nat West Announces Plans To Expand Into the Bronx
 Under pressure from a community action group that questioned its commitment to the inner cities, Nat West Bank announced last week that it would expand into the Bronx, opening several branches beginning next year. 
 The announcement came after the group, Inner City Press/Community on the Move, tried to block Nat West's purchase of two banks in New Jersey on the basis of the Community Reinvestment Act, which compels banks to lend in the communities they serve. The organization said Nat West had not done enough business in the Bronx.
The first Bronx bank will open by July 31, near 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, said Donald P. Schwartz, senior vice president of Nat West.
Nat West said it hopes to be part of a revitalization of the South Bronx. "We're getting in on the ground floor of an area where there will be a lot of opportunities," Mr. Schwartz said.
 
Owners of Merchants New York To Open Blues Club on Eighth Ave.
 The owners of Merchants New York, the cozy bar-restaurant across the street from Barneys downtown at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street, are opening a new blues club this week at 73 Eighth Avenue, between 13th and 14th Streets.
The owners, Andrew Emmet and Ibrahim Merchant, along with William Gilmore, who owns two blues clubs in Chicago, will open Chicago B.L.U.E.S. on the site of the former jazz club Zanzibar.
"We've painted the walls midnight blue, revamped the sound system and dirtied the place up a bit," Mr. Emmet said. "Other than that, there wasn't too much to be done."
The new club will have no food service, just "lots to drink," Mr. Emmet said. "Merchants is upscale, but this will be a little bit downscale since it is the blues."
The club will open Wednesday night with Big Time Sarah and the B. T. Express.
 
Course Offers Business Advice To Spanish-Speaking Women
 The American Woman's Economic Development Corporation will be offering a "Start Your Own Business" course in Spanish starting in the fall.
"Many Latino women are intimidated about being taken seriously in the business world," said Maria Salcedo, a counseling director at the nonprofit group and a founder of the new curriculum.
"They are not only going to get the training with us, but they will get the reassurance they need that a Latino woman can start her own business," she said.
The cost of the program is $125 and runs for 10 three-hour sessions at the organization's offices at 71 Vanderbilt Avenue, between 45th and 46th Streets. For information, call (212) 692-9100.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JACKSON HEIGHTS;
Amid the Houses, Bodegas Grow in Queens

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
In the city's quieter neighborhoods, entrepreneurship often spills over into residential streets. Amid row houses and single-family homes, a bodega or auto-repair shop appears suddenly, peeking out of an illegally converted garage.
The unauthorized conversion of houses into businesses is a particular problem in neighborhoods with high concentrations of recent immigrants from countries where setting up shop at home is common practice. 
 And among them Corona, stands out. Thought by many to be the home of the fictional Archie Bunker, and a symbol of white parochialism in the 1970's, Corona accounts for almost half of the establishments closed in Queens in the last 18 months. And Queens accounts for almost 75 percent of the investigations in the city.
The problem has grown acute in the last five years, said Mary Sarro, district manager of Community Board 3, which covers East Elmhurst, Jackson Heights and northern Corona, areas that have seen a great influx of Hispanic and Asian immigrants in the last decade.
While immigrant entrepreneurs have revitalized the neighborhood, the trend has also meant zoning violations. Houses are altered, additions wedged between buildings, oddly transforming streetscapes and changing the lives of residents who have to coexist with a furniture manufacturer or beauty parlor.
"It's a free country, but they don't realize you can't do whatever you want," said Ms. Sarro, who estimates that there are about a dozen such places operating in her district, most of them in northern Corona.
On 98th Street, near 37th Avenue, five garages are squeezed between an apartment building and a row house. On an otherwise quiet residential street the other day, a deafening sound came out of a welding shop housed in two of the garages.
In the other three, Carlos Torres worked on a Chevrolet Celebrity and Volkswagen Jetta out of a makeshift auto-repair shop. With little space inside, the cars' rears jutted out onto the sidewalk. Mr. Torres charges $25 to fix a car's shocks or brakes, far less than the going rate.
Until last year, he said, he worked at a nearby shop that paid him only $300 a week, so he and his brother Richard rented the garage to set up their own business. Mr. Torres, 36, said he knew it was illegal, but he did not have the money for a legitimate auto-repair shop in a commercial zone. Back home in Ecuador, he said, he would have faced no such problems. "You can buy a house and open a shop in the backyard," he said. "There's no problem. At the end of the year, you pay little tax. That's why I love my country.
"I love this country, too," he quickly added. "But there you can relax more."
The City Council passed a new law 18 months ago to make it easier to padlock such businesses. Before that, officials said, many people opened illegal businesses in residences with the intention of staying for two or three years: the time it took the city to close them.
A bodega on 93d Street and 31st Avenue was closed last week, only four months after residents complained. Like many other illegal bodegas, this one was a squat concrete structure, 20 feet by 20 feet. Maria Valerio, who lives on the first floor of the adjoining row house, said her husband, Manuel Gomez, built it two years ago in the space reserved for parking and had been operating it since then.
Andre Wimberly, 31, who lives across from the bodega, said some residents had complained because teen-agers milled around the store, drinking beer and urinating outside. "But it wasn't that bad," he said. "I could just cross the street and get a soda." NORIMITSU ONISHI
 
 
There Is a Law
 The padlock law passed by the City Council in March 1993 makes it possible to shutter businesses operating out of residences if they are found to be a public nuisance. That is easier to do than proving them to be hazards to the community, the prior requirement.
Since then, department inspectors have investigated 357 complaints in the city; 257 were from Queens. In most cases, said Vahe Tiryakian, a Buildings Department spokesman, the complaints prove unwarranted. Fourteen businesses have closed or been closed after being notified; 16 more closed before the city obtained permission to padlock them. Of the 30, 21 were in Queens, more than half in Corona and Jackson Heights.
Under the new regulation, a judge in the Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings, after weighing evidence from all parties, submits a recommendation to the Buildings Commissioner, who may order the building closed. The process now averages six months, though it can take up to 10.
"Because we are in effect taking away someone's property, it has to be done seriously and carefully," Mr. Tiryakian said. N.O.

HEADLINE: This Nanny's Life

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
SHE seems like the dream nanny. She has 10 years of experience, a sturdy and serene manner and a spotless record (always punctual, never been dismissed, never had an emergency on the job). She can monitor a carriage-bound infant, riffle through the racks in a clothing store and carry on a coherent conversation at the same time. She knows the playground circuit, the American Museum of Natural History and the pizza parlors on Broadway like the back of her hand. She wants to be paid on the books.
And yet, come September, Jan S. will be looking for a job. 
 "When you get settled in with a family, it's hard to have to move," said Jan, a 37-year-old Guyanese grandmother whose demeanor masks a quick sense of humor. "But that's the way it is. Nothing is forever."
She knows that for a fact. She has had eight different jobs in those 10 years, not counting some part-time baby-sitting she did as a newly arrived immigrant. She has seen the four corners of Manhattan from behind the handle grips of every conceivable style of stroller. All but two of her jobs have lasted six months or less, because the parents left the city or, in one case, decided to stop working. Her latest employers, an Upper West Side couple who hired her in April, delivered the bad news a couple of weeks ago. They're moving to Westchester County.
Jan and the city's untold numbers of nannies know well what it's like to care for someone else's child day after day, wiping noses and drying tears, changing diapers and washing clothes, filling formula bottles and fixing sandwiches. It is a business arrangement in which love is an essential ingredient, but so is money, where the hours are long, the thanks sometimes minimal and the attachment to the child great (though the parents can be another story).
It is also an arrangement interwoven with issues of class and race, issues that Jan tends to brush past on her way to all those baby-sitting jobs and, ultimately, a better life.
"I had my own home, and you come here and it's totally different," she says. "But you come here for a reason."
Jan, who asked that her full name not be used out of her and her employers' concern for privacy, has spent plenty of time awash in her own tears, yearning for the two daughters she left behind in Guyana when she first emigrated. Once they joined her, she struggled to raise them as a single parent in an unfamiliar city. She has sustained herself with hard work and religion, always believing that she did the right thing. And as good as she is, she and the other nannies all over the city -- descending in threesomes into Riverside Park, parading along the Promenade in Brooklyn Heights -- live with the constant worry that the lure of the suburbs, the maturing of the children or the ambivalence of working parents will leave them, the nannies, looking for work all over again.
 
COMING TO AMERICA
 "I should consider myself an Irish nanny," Jan said with a lilt and a laugh, "because I'm very lucky with The Irish Echo. I really believe in The Irish Echo."
She has found three jobs, including her latest one, through The Echo, a weekly paper whose front pages are filled with news of Irish sports and politics but whose back pages are a gold mine of classified ads placed by and for baby sitters here in New York. Most of the time, the unemployed are from the Caribbean, although there are usually some Irish candidates in there, too. "Reliable and conscientious" were the key words in Jan's ad, placed (out of courtesy) by her last employer.
Jan was born not on the Emerald Isle but in Guyana, one of 10 children. Her family, which traces its ancestry to India, owned a farm near Georgetown, the capital, and she began her working life selling oranges, tangerines, scallions and other produce at a little stand there. "Coming here, the work was not the problem," she said. "It was just that you had to work under someone."
Her parents taught her their Hindu faith, and she still goes to a temple in Queens when she can, surrounded by others who pray and bring offerings of fruit. She fasts once a week, usually on Thursdays. Married at 16, she gave birth to a daughter when she was 17, and another followed two years later.
She sensed, though, that Guyana was not the place for her and her family. Despite the lush beauty of the countryside, inflation was rife and prices out of kilter with reality. When she and her husband divorced, she decided to join an exodus that has made the Guyanese one of the fastest-growing immigrant groups in New York. (Frank S. Vardy, chief demographer for the Department of City Planning, estimates that there are now 100,000 Guyanese in the city.)
"In our village, actually, all of them are here," said Nora Singh, a nanny from Goedfortuin, on the western coast of Guyana, watching the little boy she cares for clamber in and out of a sandbox in Riverside Park. "In every home, one member comes here and then sends for the others."
Jan was the first of her immediate family to leave. In 1983, "all alone," she said, she bought a plane ticket to Toronto, where she had relatives. She moved to New York in 1984. The word from other Guyanese she met here was, look for a baby-sitting job.
"A couple of years ago, we were all basically housewives," she said, describing her family as middle-class in Guyana. "You come here, you get baby-sitting."
 
GOING TO WORK
 Jan's first job was a live-in position in New Jersey, the kind most nannies hate. "They were nice people, but you had to wait until they finished eating before you could eat," she said. "And I had to sleep in the basement. It scared me so much that now I can't ever rent a basement apartment. They had fixed it up, but when you go down to the basement, it's just you and you alone."
She lasted six months. She quit when she landed her first full-time, live-out job, caring for a newborn boy on East 29th Street. Since then, all of her jobs have been with newborns, and all of the children, by coincidence, have been boys.
"To be with a kid when they're young, well, they grow with you and it works," Jan said. Once, when she was between jobs, an agency sent her to a house where the children were older. One of them, a little girl, spat on her, and she has never forgotten it.
All this time, she was missing her daughters, whom she had kissed goodbye and left with relatives when they were 7 and 10.
"It was very hard," she said, shaking her head. "I went through my lonely days, my crying days, my depressed times. I called them, but it was not enough." In her anguish, she turned to religion, she said, and showered affection upon the little boys she took care of.
In 1986, Jan went home to Guyana to get her green card, and her daughters, who by then were 10 and 13 years old.
"When I saw them, I was so overwhelmed that I was there with them," she recalled. "My feelings were so numb." Sometimes she thinks of that period as her three lost years. "But I had to do what I had to do. It was for them because the country was getting hard. I said, I have to do something positive for them."
After she returned to New York with her children, her bosses decided to move to Westchester. With the burdens of single parenthood on her shoulders, she then held a series of short-term jobs -- two months with a family on Bleecker Street, four months on West 74th Street (they went to Westchester), six more months in an adjoining building on 74th (they moved to Connecticut), then three months with a family where the mother finally decided to stay home.
Loving, and then leaving, a series of children, Jan says, has never been a problem, though each new job means adjusting to a fresh set of employers.
"That just comes naturally," is the way she explains it. "I need to work, and I love kids and all my jobs were with wonderful people."
 
THE GOOD JOB
 Then Jan finally got the job that offered her a rare combination of stability and personal growth. This was in 1990, when she was hired by a woman she calls Denise to care for her newborn son. She stayed for four and a half years, which perhaps was the best part, not having to look for work every few months.
"I started at $310 a week, working 8 A.M. to 6 P.M., five days a week," she said. "She had someone cleaning as well, every other week. Then I asked her if I could do the cleaning. By the time I left her, I was making $425 a week, with the cleaning.
"They were wonderful. In a year, I didn't ask for a raise. The first year, they gave me a bonus of one week's pay. The second year, it was two weeks, and when I left, they gave me $1,000."
There was money, and there was caring. If she worked late, she got overtime -- $10 an hour, in addition to her salary. "And she sent me home in a cab," Jan recalled. "She always had my best interests at heart."
By most nanny standards, Jan had hit the jackpot. "Employers don't like to pay," thundered a nanny who was holding forth one recent afternoon from a bench in Riverside Park's Henry Neufeld Playground, where sculpted elephants as plump as Gerber babies spray water from their trunks. "When I demand that I be paid properly, I say to my employer, I am Class 1 baby sitter. I am not just any baby sitter."
Once her son started school and she only needed a sitter part of the day, Denise paid for Jan, who had abandoned high school for marriage and motherhood, to take a high-school equivalency course. Everything was glorious, Jan said, until earlier this year, when the family moved to Boston.
Still, she has kept in touch, with cards and letters. When the family visits New York, she goes to their hotel to say hello and sometimes, to baby sit, too.
"We got so much attached and so close," she said. "Whenever they come here, they call me."
 
A DAY IN THE LIFE
 Jan's day begins in Jamaica, Queens, at 5:30 A.M., when she rises to get herself ready for work. She dresses in child-resistant clothes -- a T-shirt and skirt or jeans -- and adds lipstick and understated earrings.
She's on the subway by 6:30 or so, for a commute that takes at least an hour, riding with her eyes closed to seize a last bit of rest. If she is tired during the day, she can doze while the baby is napping.
She took her latest job at a cut in pay -- for $7.50 an hour, with hopes of a raise to $8 -- but since the job is ending, that raise isn't likely. Because she is paid on the books, income taxes and Social Security are deducted from her pay, and she is entitled to workers compensation, disability and unemployment insurance.
Jan's day revolves around the baby's needs. But she says her employers, a lawyer and a therapist, don't mind if she shops for herself sometimes while wheeling him around. She straightens up their apartment as if it were her own, plumping chair cushions and packing away toys. "When I'm at work, I feel like I'm home," she said. Recently she cooked some curry, so her employers could sample Guyanese cuisine.
Few baby sitters like to hang around the apartment all day. The other day, Jan took the baby to the Museum of Natural History, where, though he is only a few months old, she said he appeared to enjoy watching other children run and shriek past the gemsbok diorama and the big whale. When they are out together, she is the steady hand that guides him through the city, responding to the tiniest noise from his end of the stroller, quick with bottles, hats and Pampers to keep him content.
Often she meets up with a friend, another Guyanese baby sitter whom she has known for the last six years. "We always go together," she said. "You need someone to interact with, to let your day go by."
Together they check out the wares at stores like Kids Are Magic, a clothing and toy shop on Broadway near 83d Street. When it was so hot this summer, they would head for the big Barnes and Noble nearby, not for the story hours but "because it was cool."
How does Jan feel about being a paid, substitute parent for someone else's child?
"We are there during the day," she said. "That's the way you look at it. I have my hours that I work, and when I'm done, I'm done."
Most days she's done by 6, then back on the swaying, rumbling subway for the long ride home to the three-bedroom apartment she shares with her elder daughter, who recently gave birth to Jan's first grandchild.
On the subway the other afternoon, a man with a deformed arm approaches her for money, but she doesn't give. She is not sure what he will spend it on.
She lives beyond the last stop of the F train, and when she emerges from the station she sees the sun-scorched, low-rise streetscape of eastern Queens. There is a nameless car service nearby that advertises, "Ladies Feel Safe." There is the Midland Grocery, where one can buy American and West Indian foods. An OTB branch near the station is crowded with local horse players, all eager for a break.
Jan's daughter meets her near the subway station with a sleepy granddaughter in tow. "Hellooooo," Jan coos, taking the baby in her arms and flashing a brilliant smile. "How are you today?" And to her daughter: "Where's her hat?" Then the three generations set off down the sidewalk together.
 
THE BAD JOB
 Nearly every nanny, it seems, has a bad-job tale to tell. Often it is that first job, living in. Sometimes it is a matter of the parents' attitudes toward child care. Jan always has an eye out for that kind of thing.
"I had an instance earlier this year," she said, "and I told the mom I couldn't stay there. She was in her 40's, and she was very nervous about her son. She wanted things done a certain way. She said she'd seen kids in the street, sitting in their strollers looking depressed. After two weeks, I told here I don't think this is going to work."
More common, though, are parents who just don't know how to treat a nanny. Jan has a friend who was hired to take care of twins. "Every morning when she goes in, she has to clean 17 bottles and then fill them again," she said. "When the babies are sleeping, she has to do the cleaning. She has to do the ironing. And this is for $325 a week. She sat down one day to take her coffee and her bagel. The minute she got up, her boss said, 'Bibi, can you clean the bathroom?' "
Bibi is looking for a new job, too, Jan said.
Rhonda Allayn, another veteran nanny, plans to go back to Barbados in two years.
"Please," she said, sitting on a playground bench in Riverside Park while the child she cared for drew with colored chalk on the pavement. "I've had enough of this."
Her first job seven years ago, as a live-in maid on Long Island, lives fresh in her mind.
"I worked 16 hours a day for $200 a week," she said. "That was no money. You had to clean the whole house, and the house was humongous. And you had to wear a pink or blue uniform with buttons down the front. The day I was ready to leave was the day they fired me. I was going home. There was no way I was going to be a slave."
Ms. Allayn progressed to four more jobs, all of them live-out. But now she is studying interior design. She also wants to write a book about her nanny experiences.
"A lot of Caribbean women come here without knowing anything," she said. "They're very strong and very spiritual, so you wouldn't find them committing suicide. They come and they love and they nurture. It's hard for them to have children and leave them and come here and love someone else's children."
Perhaps even in the worst jobs, there is an ultimate benefit: "What we all feel is that if we can cultivate some kind of tolerance, maybe the next generation won't be so racist," Ms. Allayn said. "Maybe they'll remember when they grow up that they had black nannies who loved them."
 
LOOKING TO THE FUTURE
 In the inevitable next round of interviews, Jan will be looking for someone with whom she senses an affinity. "If you get a click, you know it's going to work out," she said. "After a while, they just leave me alone. If I had a boss who was on top of me all the time, I don't think it would work."
After all this time, Jan seems to be doing more screening herself than worrying about whether she'll be hired. She certainly has enough references. "I am a very successful baby sitter," she said, "and I know what I'm doing. I know I don't have any problem getting a job."
Like some of her peers, Jan doesn't see herself doing this forever.
"Baby sitting is a wonderful job," she said, "but I need more benefits and more stability in a job."
Since her current job is just 35 hours a week, Jan is studying accounting -- also Denise's idea -- at a Queens business school. At some point, she hopes to switch to a corporate environment, starting out at the bottom if necessary. And "my goal for next year," she said, is to buy a house, instead of paying $850 a month in rent.
And she is taking driving lessons. "I'm working on my driving," she said. Learning to negotiate city streets and to parallel park might come in handy in her next career.
 
 
Wait One Minute. She Was My Nanny!
 Anne G., an Upper West Side mother of two, became suspicious when her son, who normally played only with boys, started being invited on play dates by a girl in his first-grade class. As it turned out, the play dates were her baby sitter's interviews for what turned out to be her new job. It had all been engineered by the other mother.
"She sent her nanny out to look for a new nanny," is how Anne explains her encounter with nanny-poaching, a phenomenon that, while hardly epidemic, has become one of those things that parents whisper cautiously about these days, another layer of apprehension in the already anxious child-care experience.
"There are a lot of women out there who, I don't know how they sleep at night," said an Upper East Side working mother whose nanny was hired away last spring by someone she knew from her child's school. "It was the most stressful and anxiety-ridden time of my whole life. My daughter had a hard time, because she missed this person, who had lived with us, and I had a new baby in the house."
Not only was Anne worried that her son would feel rejected when he saw the nanny, whom he loved, taking care of another child, the tussle dredged up other conflicts, particularly the working- vs. stay-at-home-mother debate. (The other mother was a lawyer.)
"I think she felt entitled to the best person possible, because she worked," Anne said. "And she made me feel that because I was a housewife, I didn't really need help."
After the nanny quit, Anne tried to negotiate.
The other mother said, "If you think this is going to cause problems, I won't hire her," Anne recalled. "And then I sort of obliquely threatened her with the peer pressure thing. I said everyone else I had talked to about this was horrified." But the nanny was already lost. "It had totally poisoned our relationship," Anne said.
Despite many parents' apprehensions, Nancy Kolben, executive director of Child Care Inc., a nonprofit resource and referral center, thinks some of this happens indirectly. Many people approach a nanny they know to ask if she has any friends, she said. When talk turns to salary, that can act as a trigger for a baby sitter to switch, though other factors, like loyalty and job satisfaction, also come into play.
Ira Weissman, a placement counselor with the Pavillion Agency, which specializes in household workers, says he sees nanny-poaching more often in the suburbs, where there is a demand for nannies who drive. In the city, he added, housekeepers are more often stolen. "People will walk into the kitchen during fancy dinner parties and offer them more money," he said. "It happens all the time." CONSTANCE L. HAYS
 
 
Nannies to Day Care: a Primer
 Q. What are the options for child care in New York and what do they tend to cost?
A. Generally speaking, having a baby sitter at home is the most expensive form of full-time care. At a rate of $7.50 an hour, or $300 for a 40-hour week, a family would spend $15,600 in salary. Its advantages are that the child is at home among familiar things, can keep his or her own routine, and a parent's long or erratic hours can be accommodated. The disadvantages are that care givers are unregulated, absences are disruptive and parents must rely on their own judgment for hiring, evaluating and dismissing employees, which can be painful.
The city also has 2,520 licensed group day-care centers, which are regulated, give a parent more than one care giver to depend on and allow a child to play with others his or her own age.
In a related but separately regulated category is family day care, in which a person takes care of between three and six children, usually in a home. Family day care providers must register with the New York City Department of Health. There are 5,387 such centers in the city, said Steven J. Matthews, a department spokesman.
Group day care is a fine option for many parents, although demand exceeds the supply, says Toni Porter, director of the Center for Family Support at Bank Street College of Education. In 1989, there were 166,927 spaces available in part-time and full-day programs for children under 6. The city's standards are among the most rigorous in the nation, she said, with high adult-to-child ratios and high staff-education requirements. Last year, families paid an average of $6,800 for full-day care for preschoolers and an average of $10,600 for infants.
There are disadvantages: frequently inflexible hours (many close by 6 P.M.); closings for holidays and vacations, and the unwillingness of some centers to accept children under 6 months of age.
Underground, or unlicensed, day care also exists, and often is not a bargain.
"There are countless illegal family day-care centers," Mr. Matthews said, adding that officials often do not find out about them until there is a problem, like a fire or an outbreak of food poisoning.
For parents who cannot afford private day care, the city has 370 subsidized centers operated by the Agency for Child Development and 169 Head Start centers. For information, call (718) 260-2000.
Q. How can you tell if someone will be a good baby sitter or day-care provider?
gfleadinA. You can't discern everything from the interview. But the following guidelines are offered in a pamphlet available from Child Care Inc., a nonprofit resource and referral service in Manhattan. (Call [212] 929-4999, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. weekdays).
According to the pamphlet, a care giver should: Have a warm, positive personality and appear to enjoy being with children; be attentive to smiles as well as cries; be flexible, patient and understanding; respond quickly to a baby's physical needs; understand different stages of development, and value parents as experts about their children.
Many experts also advise spending time with a baby sitter and the child before making the job official. And occasional surprise visits aren't a bad idea either, to see how things are going when the parents are assumed to be far away.
Q. Is it illegal to hire someone who does not have a green card (a residency permit for the United States, which can lead to citizenship)?
A. Yes, if they have no other documentation, under the 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act. No, as long as the person has a separate document known as work authorization, experts say. Some employers sponsor immigrants for citizenship, which means they can hire them while waiting for the application to be approved, a process that can take 10 years, said Martha Davis, senior staff attorney for the NOW Legal Defense Fund.
Q. What are the tax rules when it comes to paying a baby sitter?
A. Social Security deductions must be made from their paychecks, and the employer must match the amount withheld (the rate is 7.65 percent of salary). Federal, state and local taxes can also be withheld if the baby sitter desires (the alternative is for the employee to pay them independently when filing the 1040 tax return). The employee must fill out Federal tax forms, listing the deductions they wish to take, and you, the employer, must file tax-reporting statements and payments at the end of each quarter.
Employees who work more than 40 hours a week are also entitled to workers compensation, which helps pay medical bills and gives them cash if they are injured on the job and cannot work; disability insurance, which covers work-inhibiting illnesses or injuries sustained off the job, and unemployment insurance, which entitles them to collect a percentage of their pay should the job end.
Baby sitters who are still awaiting their green cards but who log 40 or more hours per week are nonetheless entitled to Social Security payments (if they have a Social Security number) and workers' compensation benefits.
Of course, while it is illegal, many nannies want to be paid off the books, to avoid taxes, and many employers comply.
Q.How much do you have to pay a nanny.
A. Under New York law, household workers (regardless of legal status) are entitled to the Federal minimum wage of $4.25 per hour. After 40 hours, also according to state law, they are supposed to get one and one-half times that hourly wage for every hour they work. Prevailing rates in the city range from $6 to $9 per hour.
Q. Do live-in workers get more or less money?
A. For live-in employees, the cost of room and board may be deducted from the minimum wage, but are not to exceed $1.45 per meal, $1.80 per day for lodging and $3.40 per day for an apartment. They also do not get overtime, but are required to be paid at least $6.37 per hour after the first 44 hours worked in one week.
Q. Can you require a baby sitter to work around the clock, 365 days a year?
A. No. Under New York law, household workers are entitled to one full day off per week. They are also entitled to 30-minute meal breaks. Holidays and vacations are up to the employer, but experienced employers point out that paying for holidays and vacations earns good will with employees.
Q. What makes a good day-care center?
A. Look for the same attributes in the staff members that you would look for in a baby sitter. The center should be safe for babies at various developmental stages, have plenty of indoor and outdoor space for active play, be clean (especially where diapers are changed or food prepared), have age-appropriate equipment and toys in good condition, and offer space for quiet time and napping. Ask to see permits from the Department of Health. C.L.H.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Connections, Connections

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
IT'S just after 10 A.M. and John R. Fratianni and his team are brainstorming.
Their client is an independent filmmaker, Ayoka Chenzira, whose movie, "Alma's Rainbow," will soon be released on video. The problem: how to draw attention to her film, which has been showing at one small Harlem theater since June. 
 One woman narrows her eyes. "Maybe we could get into the schools, publicize it to kids, hit our target audience that way," she suggests.
Mr. Fratianni frowns. "Dealing with the school system -- it's going to be a painfully slow process," he says.
Another woman leans in. "I have a friend who's a schoolteacher. All you need is one person on the inside, right? Bypass the system," she says, to approving nods around the table.
This is clearly not the conversation of TriBeCa movie executives. The office -- a cramped, second-floor conference room -- overlooks the teeming sidewalks of Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. And the strategists, who pepper their conversation with phrases like "guerrilla financing," and "bootstrap equity," are soon on to their next client, a cash-poor Caribbean bodybuilder from Flatbush who desperately wants to market his own line of power juices.
Here, in a sense, is a frontier of economic development in New York -- not the courting of large corporations or manufacturers but the effort to help small entrepreneurs, many from minority communities and most with fewer than 20 employees.
Mr. Fratianni and his team are among the leaders of a rapidly expanding program that aids ambitious small business owners who have been hindered by cultural isolation and neighborhood redlining policies. The program, called the Business Outreach Center Network, builds business connections, helps position products and lines up loans to fuel startups and expansions.
The program follows a nationwide trend toward small entrepeneurs.
"This is part of a tremendous shift in the entire framework of economic development," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "It's very important for New York City, because these types of businesses have by and large been neglected by policy makers until recently."
He added that New York's often balkanized communities are only now beginning to fully realize that their small business interests are the same. "And I know of nothing more powerful than capitalism to overcome ethnic cleavages," he said.
The nonprofit network was created four years ago by Orthodox Jewish leaders in the close-knit community of Borough Park, Brooklyn, to help small business owners there, many of them Yiddish-speaking Russian immigrants, get on their feet or expand thriving young businesses.
It started with the help of $4 million in city, state and Federal grants. Connected by computer, the network now has seven offices around the city -- in Borough Park, Flatbush, Chinatown, the largely Hispanic neighborhood of Hunts Point in the Bronx, in minority areas of Far Rockaway and Staten Island and on West 116th Street in Harlem. Next month it plans to open an office in Bridgeport, Conn.
The program sheds light on the forces that constrain small entrepreneurs. For example, a Chinatown business owner's spotty English and distrust of big banks keep him from getting a loan to expand his store. A counselor who speaks his Cantonese dialect helps him put together a business plan and then finds a bank or other loan program that is likely to give him the money.
Ethnic divisions often work against economic self-interest. Counselors put together business partners from areas whose residents rarely communicate or whose ethnic groups have sometimes been hostile -- a meat distributor from Hunts Point and an exporter from Chinatown agree to find new markets in Taiwan, or a Jewish business finds that its services are needed by a group of black Muslims, for example.
"What most of these businesses need is just someone to hold their hand for a little while," said Paul Chernick, director of operations for the Council of Jewish Organizations, and the man who came up with the idea for the network. "There've been precious few places they can go to."
Tom Lam, who co-owns an audio parts distributorship in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, said he came to the network in Chinatown after he and his partner tried to negotiate a loan. "We took one look at what you have to do to get it and we put the application away," he said recently, on a visit to his business counselor, Vicky Cheng, on Canal Street.
"By the time we got through, we wouldn't need the loan," said Mr. Lam, who was born in Hong Kong. "We would be out of business." But with Ms. Cheng's help he found that much of the $90,000 in speakers, receivers and other stereo parts he had in inventory could serve as collateral.
"Tom speaks English very well and even used to work for a bank," said Ms. Cheng. "There are many others in Chinatown who were raised to think that a bank is only a place where you put your money. To borrow other people's money is something we have to work to make them comfortable with."
The network has now served more than 1,000 businesses, with about half of its active clients having been open less than six months. It has drawn up formal agreements with dozens of service organizations around the city -- ranging from banks and accounting firms to business colleges and government agencies -- to make them aware that it will be sending business owners their way for money or technical help.
"The time was ripe for an invention like this," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "There's been no real infrastructure out there to help small businesses of this kind and so somebody finally got the bright idea to help it develop an infrastructure of its own."
The network is just now beginning to have the capability to connect two merchants, or lead a buyer to a seller, a service that officials hope to expand dramatically as its information becomes more sophisticated and neighborhoods learn to work together.
In one recent successful case, Bernard Samet, the co-owner of Great Neck Party Rental on Long Island, originally went to the Borough Park network office for help with an expansion loan, which he received.
But in doing so he also found out that the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque in Central Harlem, the sponsors of the newest network site, needed to rent a large canvas tent and 1,000 folding chairs for an outdoor speech. The deal was struck early this month, for a reduced rate, and Mr. Samet is negotiating another, larger deal with the mosque that could help him in paying off his loan.
"I have to say I don't think I had ever set foot in that part of Harlem before the day I went to set up the tent," Mr. Samet said. "But before you know it, we were happily ever after. We needed each other, you know? A tent's a tent and a chair's a chair."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hanif Shabazz, left, and Dr. Khalil A. Khaliq, co-directors of the Harlem Business Outreach Center, meet with Bernard Samet of Great Neck Party Rentals at the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque in Harlem. Mr. Samet will rent a tent and folding chairs to the mosque. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
A License to Sell

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
MICHAEL J. CORTES serves those who only stand and wait.
He works as New York State's first and only authorized license plate salesman. His sales territory is confined to the blocklong lobby of the motor vehicles office on Worth Street in lower Manhattan, where he plies the captive audience of motorists shuffling along in the serpentine lines. 
 The notion of a state employee actually helping the public may shock weary Worth Street veterans who remember the agency as a hopeless Marxist bureaucracy modeled after both Karl and Groucho.
But in the 1990's, the agency is reinventing itself. Now it extols customer friendliness, lower costs and revenue growth. Innovations include toll-free numbers and an express office at 34th Street and Eighth Avenue with almost instant service.
Officials say they have even succeeded in shrinking the geologic waits at the Worth Street office. Although the lines are typically down to 30 minutes or less, they have not been totally eliminated -- fortunately for Mr. Cortes.
"On good days, I average 20 plates," he said recently, strolling along his beat. That may not seem like much. Even the idea of a license plate salesman sounds superfluous. After all, the law requires vehicles to have plates, as the waiting line attests. So why does anyone need to hawk them?
The answer is that the products Mr. Cortes sells are not standard-issue, white-bread plates with the Statue of Liberty. Instead, he offers new customized varieties with a choice of colored emblems for nine New York sports teams and 11 regions of the state, with the borough or county name.
After this year's hockey championship game, the motor vehicles had Stanley Cup commemorative plates ready to order the very next morning. Since the program started in March 1993, Mr. Cortes estimates he has sold 5,000 plates. Because they yield extra fees, his sales have added more than $300,000 to the state treasury -- earning him an in-person thank you from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Jean Rosenthal, the program's director, said, "It's a win-win situation that gives people a fun way to express themselves that's higher class than bumper stickers."
As a salesman, Mr. Cortes's gimmick is that he really doesn't have one. He offers information in an amiable, factual, low-key fashion. Standing and talking all day requires comfortable shoes, and he said, "I keep fully stocked with cough drops and throat lozenges.
"I developed my own approach. I walk up and down the line and talk to everybody who gets on it. When I tell them they can have plates with the county name or sports team of their choice, their eyes light up."
His routine pitch: "See the new-style plates -- sports teams and regional plates. You can get them now, today." While talking, he extends his right hand and adroitly flips through sample plates. "Yankees, Knicks, Rangers, Mets. Check this out: the Stanley Cup limited edition." His right hand fans out leaflets. "Brochures are free. You can order anything in the brochure."
When someone nibbles, Mr. Cortes, 27, follows up with facts on the fees, which plates are available on the spot and which ones are mailed in three weeks. (All plates are made by inmates at Auburn state prison.) When people decide to buy, he takes them out of line -- a small bonus -- and escorts them to a cashier's window.
"I'm very much interested in getting a set," said James Chambers, a tugboat captain. "It's wonderful. Anything that promotes the city is great." Another interested man lamented that he had limited cash. A check or Visa card would do, Mr. Cortes said, but the man didn't have those, either. Mr. Cortes chuckled: "That's a nice watch. Maybe you can work something out."
Although custom plates are catching on -- 67,000 out of 10 million sets statewide -- many people are still unaware of them. "I never knew about it -- I didn't know you could do this," Iakovas Patestas of Queens said as Mr. Cortes help him order plates with the city skyline and his wife's name, Angie.
With the help of sales agents like Mr. Cortes, officials hope custom plates will eventually corner a tenth of the market. "We'd like to clone Michael," said Mr. Rosenthal, who hopes to have Mr. Cortes train people at other offices around the state. "Manhattan is our highest office in sales, and I know for a fact that he is responsible for almost all of that."
Besides selling plates, Mr. Cortes acts as a roving trouble-shooter. If you're on the wrong line, he points you to the right one. If you don't have the right form, he will help get it. If your paperwork is in order, he reassures you. That additional contact and friendliness also sell more custom plates.
Richard C. Diaz, the office manager, said: "We were looking for somebody with the right personality. We put Michael out there because he showed us something, a certain quality of niceness. He's just exceptional, and it shows in his salesmanship."
Just two years ago Mr. Cortes, a Manhattan resident, was unemployed, having lost his job in the recession. In 1992, the motor vehicles agency hired him as a cashier. Then he volunteered for the selling job "because it was something different."
Unlike business salesmen, Mr. Cortes earns no commissions. Some grateful customers offer tips, which he declines. Lazaro Pigueiras of Manhattan, who bought Giants plates, paid him a compliment not often heard in the lobby in years past: "He's a very good guy and knows how to do his job."
Besides sports and regional plates, a proliferating new category is made up of plates advertising, and sold by, special groups -- St. John's alumni, Korean War veterans, hypnotherapists, ham radio operators and others.
Prices vary. Replacing regular plates with sports plates on a typical car costs $39.50 plus an extra annual fee of $25. Adding personalized letters or numbers -- a "vanity" plate -- raises the cost to $68 and the annual fee to $50. So far, custom plates have produced $3 million statewide.
Not everyone on line spends the extra money. Some are even dubious of Mr. Cortes. "They think I'm here doing something crooked," he said, "but I show them my I.D." One man scoffed at the plates for giving free advertising to sports teams and said, "They should be paying us to use them." Mr. Cortes smiled and said, "Tough crowd today."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael J. Cortes, New York State's only authorized license plate salesman, shows his wares at the Department of Motor Vehicles. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "CUSTOM PLATES: Logos to Go "
 The customized license plate for New York City depicts a classic skyline vista: the Brooklyn Bridge against the backdrop of Manhattan skyscrapers.
"Women tend to go with the regional plates -- they like the designs," said Michael Cortes, who sells license plates for the state.
Another option is plates with sports logos, which Mr. Cortes's informal market research shows appeal mostly to men. "The Yankees are doing well, and the Knicks are still selling like hotcakes," he said.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2396 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Multilevel Concept;
New Stores Make Shopping A Many-Tiered Experience

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
NEARLY 20 years ago, Selma Weiser, who owns the Charivari apparel chain, was walking down a Paris street and fell in love with a store.
"It had mezzanines and staircases, lots of different selling levels that you could see from the street," recalled Jon Weiser, Mrs. Weiser's son and now Charivari's president. "Mom thought the store was a visual kick." 
 No matter that this kind of layout went counter to the retailing wisdom of the day: that only in department stores would customers travel between floors to buy full-priced merchandise. Charivari rented a store on 72d street and Columbus Avenue, pulled out the floor, relocated the pipes, and built a hodgepodge of upstairs, street-level and basement selling floors.
"When we did it, even our landlord was shocked," Mr. Weiser recalled. "Today, everyone loves it. It's like a playground for grownups, and it's still one of our most profitable stores."
Why retell this ancient history now? Because throughout Manhattan, operations as diverse as Duane Reade drugstores and Calvin Klein are opening multilevel stores. And brokers keep pointing to Charivari and the handful of other, older success stories to reassure the new clients that they are not making a terrible mistake.
"Retailers have it in the back of their heads that customers just won't go up or down to buy," said Richard Evans, a vice president at the retail brokerage New Spectrum. "But they no longer have much choice."
Indeed, many retailers, particularly high-priced designers who want to showcase their entire lines, have discovered that they either cannot find, or cannot afford, large enough street-level stores to accommodate the merchandise they want to display. Their problem has been welcome news to landlords, many of whom are finding that second floors and basements that they could barely give away are turning into valuable retail assets.
"I can't tell you how many owners have started to call their basements 'shopping concourses,' " said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum.
Owners and their agents readily own up to that. "We used to throw a basement in free when we rented a store," said Joseph J. Sarno, an associate director at Cushman & Wakefield who represents several buildings. "Now we actually market basements as full selling space."
The multilevel bonanza is particularly evident on chichi Madison Avenue, where huge stretches on which stores were once confined to eye-level space have been converted to multistory retailing. On the east side of Madison between 69th and 70th Streets, three multistory stores -- Fila, Madison Avenue Bookshop and Clifford Michael -- all have second-floor selling areas that are easily seen from the street. And now that visual effect is about to be echoed by the high-fashion stores one block south.
Valentino is about to start selling out of the second floor above its store between 68th and 69th Streets. Versace, its next-door neighbor, is also expanding to the second floor. Tse Cashmere recently moved onto the block as a multilevel store. Max Mara will be anchoring the block with a multilevel store on the northeast corner of 68th and Madison.
William Wagner, an independent broker who represents most of the buildings on the block, says he has another two-story retail lease out for 821 Madison, a vacant building on that same block. "Any landlord with half a brain is going after multilevel stores," Mr. Wagner said.
The economics work in everyone's favor. Retailers accustomed to paying $250 a square foot for ground-floor space in a chic area can get the second floor for $50, the basement for $15. Even though landlords are actually renting less space -- retailers generally cut deals for "usable" space, as opposed to "rentable" space, which includes useless nooks and crannies -- they are still coming out ahead, in that they would never get $50 a square foot from office or residential tenants.
"WE'VE recommended to many landlords that they rethink their second floors as retail," said Richard Seligman, a senior managing director specializing in retail at the Edward S. Gordon Company.
The list of new multilevel stores is formidable. Brioni of Italy has leased a retail condominium in the Four Seasons Hotel, at 57 East 57th Street, that combines basement and street-level selling space. Calvin Klein will open a 20,000-square-foot, three-level store at 654 Madison, on 60th Street, next spring. Warner Brothers, the Gap, Crate and Barrel, Chanel, Armani, Brookstone, Prada -- all have gone the multilevel route.
And brokers report more deals in the works. Virginia M. Pittarelli, a senior managing director at KTR Retail Services Group, says she is about to close three deals for multilevel stores, all for designers opening their first New York stores and wanting to display their entire lines.
"They know they will not get the same sales at an upper or lower level that they get on the street floor," Ms. Pirrarelli said. "But they also know that if they want to be on a really good street there is not enough space at street level to carry a full product line."
Even where space is available it is rarely affordable for any but the most deep-pocketed retailers.
Stephen Werther could probably have found 4,300 square feet of ground-floor space in the East 80's for Portico Kids, the two-level children's store he opened at 1167 Madison Avenue, near 84th Street, last year. Instead, he took 800 square feet on the ground floor and 3,500 square feet above that.
"Sure, I'd rather sell on one floor, but it was simply more cost-effective to take second-floor space," Mr. Werther said.
Sellers of low-priced merchandise, who rely on high volume to justify their fixed costs, are in an even worse economic bind. They know their sales will drop in a multilevel store; but they are simply unable to carry lavish street-floor rents.
Take Duane Reade, the fast-growing drugstore chain. Bruce Weitz, its chief executive, lists a litany of what's wrong with multilevel stores: They are expensive to build and to staff; they make it hard to spot when a floor person should be deployed to help a customer, or when customers should be routed to less crowded cash registers; they require extra security.
And they are a merchandising nightmare for a business that relies heavily on impulse buyers -- people who come in to fill a prescription or buy a tube of toothpaste and then pick up various sundries that catch their eye. In a multilevel store there's often an entire floor of wares that a hurrying customer won't see.
"Nothing sells as well when people have to walk up or down stairs," Mr. Weitz said.
Yet a dozen of Duane Reade's 50-or-so New York stores operate on more than one level. For those stores, Mr. Weitz's choice was clear: Either open on more than one level or don't open at all.
"Take the Empire State Building," Mr. Weitz said, referring to one of Duane Reade's multilevel sites. "Do you really think a discount drugstore could find or afford 8,000 square feet of street-level space there?"
Such rhetorical questions aside, some retailers still go through design hoops to avoid multilevel selling. Last year Smith & Hawkins, an outdoor furnishings and plant retailer based in Berkeley, Calif., was looking to open a 7,000-square-foot store in New York. Ms. Petarelli, its broker, tried to persuade its managers to open a multi-level store. They refused.
This spring Smith & Hawkins will open on one level at 394 West Broadway in SoHo. It will have an extended selling porch in front, a selling balcony attached to the rear windows -- and with all that, it will still have just 4,200 square feet of selling space.
"They had just heard too many scary stories about the problems of multilevel selling," Ms. Petarelli said.
Joel Fisher, the 9 West Group's senior vice president for real estate and store planning, also shuns more than one selling level. By year's end, 9 West will have 15 shoestores operating in New York, 10 of them opened since 1992. Each does all its selling on the street-level floor.
"New York City customers are limited in time, they want to get in and get out," Mr. Fisher said. The huge saving in rent attained by venturing off the ground floor becomes less attractive, he notes, when one factors in the additional sales staff and security needed with a second level.
Multilevel stores can indeed be expensive to build and run. They require staircases or elevators and fancy interior designs to entice people in from the street. When they entail converting office or storage space to selling space, they require a change of use certificate from the New York City Buildings Department. And the department will not issue such a certificate unless the space conforms to the requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act.
That alone has kept some landlords from marketing off-grade space for retail. "A lot of owners don't want to let an inspector into their buildings," said one retail broker who insisted on anonymity.
And the physical, financial and regulatory problems pale in comparison to the sheer sales problem of getting customers to move up or down. Multilevel retailers have found that out the hard way.
When Mr. Werther opened Portico Kids, he put impulse items -- lamps and pillows and books and such -- on the ground floor and higher-ticket furniture items upstairs.
"It took us six months to realize that no one was going upstairs, because no one realized what else the store sold," Mr. Werther recalled. Mr. Werther rearranged the store so that the downstairs is a "snapshot of what the upstairs is about," with at least one piece of each kind of merchandise it carries. Sales, he said, have picked up considerably.
"It took a year for word of mouth to really generate business," he said. "If we'd been on one level it would have taken a month."
SIMON PEARCE had an even worse problem at the 5,000-square-foot glassware and furniture store it opened on 59th Street between Park and Madison Avenues in October 1992. Four-fifths of the store's selling space is in the basement, with no natural light and unspottable from the street. That configuration almost spelled disaster for the store. Floor-to-ceiling window displays made it hard to see the staircase from the street. And from inside, a huge walnut display unit hid the staircase from many angles.
"Our downstairs was one of the best-kept secrets in New York," recalled Lisa Schorr, the store's manager.
In the last year Ms. Schorr removed the display unit and the tall window displays. Like Mr. Werther, she changed the merchandise mix so that the street level offered a sampling of wares that could be found downstairs. And she charged one staff person with greeting all customers who walk in and apprising them of what's downstairs.
Ms. Schorr says that sales between January and August of this year were 75 percent higher than in the same period of 1993.
"I'd still like a second floor better than a basement, and I'd like a one-level store best of all," she said. "But you really can persuade customers to go downstairs."
Of course, some buildings are just better suited to multilevel stores than others. That's certainly true in Rockefeller Center.
Kate D. Coburn, Rockefeller Center's vice president for retail, just leased a two-story store at 630 Fifth Avenue, at 51st Street, to Movado, a seller of high-priced jewelry that is moving from a one-level store on Madison Avenue and 57th Street. Ms. Coburn is certain that it was the nearly 50 feet of window exposure that came with the store that clinched the deal.
"If you're talking 20-foot frontage and no great windows, a multifloor deal just isn't easy to make," she said.
Other Rockefeller Center buildings are on a steep grade, so a store can have two "street-level" entrances that in fact lead to different selling floors. That's the sort of space Brookstone, the upscale giftware comapny, has taken at 620 Fifth Avenue, at 50th Street. The store has a 6,000-square-foot selling level on one "street" floor, an additional 2,000 square feet on the other and tall windows that overlook the skating rink.
"This space, whether it's technically second floor or not, makes a major statement," said Michael Hirschfeld, president of the Hirschfeld Group and Brookstone's broker.
Retailers occupying less architecturally enhanced space are trying hard to avoid the mistakes that Simon Pearce and Portico made the first time around.
Take Prada, the Italian store known best here for its handbags. It has rented 12,000 square feet on four floors at 28 East 70th Street, where it will combine retail and wholesale sales and administrative offices.
"They didn't go ahead with the deal until the architects they flew in from Italy assured them they could get the customer flow they wanted," said New Spectrum's Mr. Evans, who negotiated for Prada.
DATAVISION, a big computer retailer, recently rented 2,000 square feet of retail space at 445 Fifth Avenue, at 39th Street, as well as the 12,000 square feet of commercial space above it. They will show samples of their wares on the first floor, and carry their full stock on the second.
"This gives them enough affordable space to go up against CompUSA across the street," said Faith H. Consolo, a vice president at Garrick Aug Associates, who helped broker the deal.
Many fashion retailers are taking more of the mini-department-store approach, stocking, say, suits on one floor, accessories on another and shoes on a third, so that customers must travel up or down to complete the "look."
In the high-end, service-oriented stores, the same salesperson stays with customers from the time they walk in, and literally leads them up or down the stairs.
Retailers with truly diverse product lines are setting up stores-within-stores. Calvin Klein, for one, is opening a three-level, 20,000-square-foot store at 654 Madison Avenue, at 60th Street, next spring. The entire street-level floor will be devoted to its mainstay women's fashion collection. The upper level will be devoted to the men's collections, while the lower level will feature the Calvin Klein Home collection.
"The store will provide the context for the quintessential modern idea of luxury," Mr. Klein said when he announced his plans in June. Presumably, luxury in the pared-down 90's includes traveling between floors.
