HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: What Went Wrong? How the Health Care Campaign Collapsed -- A special report.;
For Health Care, Times Was A Killer

BYLINE: By Adam Clymer, Robert Pear and Robin Toner 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
This article was reported and written by Adam Clymer, Robert Pear and Robin Toner.
In March 1993, two months after his inauguration, President Clinton appealed to Robert C. Byrd, the presiding officer of the Senate, to let national health insurance legislation be considered as part of that summer's budget bill. 
 It was, at first glance, a move of remarkable hubris, a President elected with 43 percent of the vote expecting Congress to allow him to rearrange one-seventh of the American economy under the streamlined, fast-track procedures of a budget bill.
But it reflected the concern of the President and his allies that his power would never be greater than it was in his first months in office, that what was hard then would be supremely difficult a year later, and that a window was open, perhaps only fleetingly, to pass a major health care bill.
Senator Byrd, ever the parliamentarian, demurred -- the rules could not be bent, he said, that way and that far. And Mr. Clinton, before long, was distracted by economic struggles, the North American Free Trade Agreement, Whitewater and foreign crises, and the window began to close.
The Clinton health care plan became the captive of events, and politics, and an enormously complicated process headed by two figures making their debuts in national policy making -- Hillary Rodham Clinton, the impassioned First Lady, and Ira C. Magaziner, the cerebral policy guru and friend of Bill Clinton.
As the Administration and its Congressional allies take a brief vacation and try to gather strength for one last push on health care, some reflect on that moment in the spring of 1993 and see it as emblematic of lost time, lost opportunities, lost confidence.
There were many mistakes and misjudgments that surrounded the campaign to achieve universal coverage: The Administration assumed that a 43 percent electoral plurality was a mandate for a tremendously complicated overhaul of a system as sensitive as health care. It showed a continuing uncertainty about how to deal with Republicans, and an overly combative political approach. It even assumed that when the public said it favored fundamental change in health care that it meant the kind of change the policy analysts wanted.
But on all sides, from Clinton allies like John Rother of the American Association of Retired Persons to foes like John Motley of the National Federation of Independent Business, to sometime allies and sometime foes like Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, there is agreement on one thing: Delay was a fundamental error, the crucial stumbling block to passing legislation.
Consensus stops there. Even now there are disputes over whether some slight chance for a broad bill remains, or whether the realistic choice ahead is between slim change and none.
Though unfinished, the history of health care legislation is a striking measure of the complexity of legislating major change in an era of intense partisanship, with a public that distrusts Washington as never before, a campaign technology applied to whipping around voters' opinions, and news reports that emphasize conflict, not explanation.
The simplest measure of partisanship is that just one Republican in Congress, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, ever backed Mr. Clinton's bill. In the House, moderates were told bluntly by Republican leaders not to offer amendments that might make legislation easier to pass.
Bob Blendon, a public opinion scholar at the Harvard School of Public Health, said of the Administration: "They misread the mandate, read it much too broadly. Since people are very cynical about government and the President only had 43 percent of the vote, they wanted reform, but they wanted something easy to understand, something that did not look as threatening as the Clinton plan. The Clinton White House read it as much too broad in terms of trust in President and Mrs. Clinton."
Whatever trust there was came under tremendous assault. Lobbyists for every conceivable interest that could be affected by any version of legislation swarmed over the Capitol. And to influence the public, more than $50 million was thrown into advertising, most by opponents and much of it simply false.
And newspapers and television failed to cut through the din and educate people, said Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School at the University of Pennsylvania. Instead, they merely elevated public skepticism.
"Everything the press did appeared to engender cynicism," she said, citing a study that she and a colleague, Joseph N. Cappella, plan to present next Saturday to an American Political Science Association convention in New York. When the news emphasized controversy, she said, "That undermined the public sense that there was any agreement on what the problem is."
But only two or three years ago, it seemed there was a vast, historic consensus bubbling up from the grass roots, a hunger for sweeping change in the nation's health care system.
 
 
The Campaign
Did the Democrats Misread the Signs?
 Throughout the 1980's, business, labor, economists and a wide array of public policy analysts had grown increasingly alarmed over the rising costs and the expanding gaps in the health care system. But in the rough recessionary politics that brought the Democrats victory in 1991 and 1992, the issue became a populist crusade.
In 1991, the Democrat Harris Wofford won the bellwether Senate race in Pennsylvania with a promise of health care reform, signaling the power of the issue with an economically anxious middle class.
A year later, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska built his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination around the promise of universal coverage. (Two years later, he was among the Senators arguing for an incremental approach.) Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, another candidate for the nomination, began talking in New Hampshire meeting halls about restructuring the health care marketplace.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas did not campaign on the issue as hard as some of his rivals did, but it fit neatly with his overarching campaign promise: to look after the forgotten middle class and use the Government to improve the economy and ease their lot. By the summer of 1992, Atul A. Gawande, a young Harvard medical student who had previously worked on health issues for Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, came on board the Clinton campaign. His task was to help flesh out Mr. Clinton's health plan and defend it from Republican attacks.
Mr. Clinton and his allies were trying hard to redefine the Democratic Party away from traditionally liberal approaches to domestic policy; they were almost inevitably drawn to the ideas of managed competition. Though still largely theoretical, the concept relies on market forces, not government, to hold down costs and expand access to health insurance. Mr. Gawande, now back in medical school, recalled on Saturday that in a series of meetings in the summer of 1992, "Clinton was very clear about his interest in managed competition and that he had no interest in a broad-based tax."
Vagueness is often a virtue in the politics of health care, and there were some who argued that Mr. Clinton should keep it vague. But by the end of the summer, he was being accused by the Bush campaign of being just another tax-and-spend, big-government Democrat when it came to health care in an eerie precursor of the Republican attacks to come.
"We had to repel it by saying here's the details of our plan," Mr. Gawande recalled. So the Clinton campaign prepared a major health care speech for the fall campaign.
Delivered in Rahway, N.J., at the offices of Merck & Company, the pharmaceutical giant, the speech committed Mr. Clinton to universal coverage, achieved by requiring employers to pay for their workers insurance.
This was enough for a Presidential campaign; Mr. Clinton enjoyed the benefits of being for health care reform without the downside of explaining how, exactly, it would be paid for, without the Congressional Budget Office passing judgment on his financing, without a fully engaged debate on all the contentious specifics of remaking the health care system. But without that debate, the Clinton forces may have made a dangerous miscalculation. They came away with a clear conviction that the public was sending a message in this campaign: do something big about health care.
But were they?
Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who also works for the Health Insurance Association of America, said on Saturday, "People overread the data in 1992. Almost half of Americans said they wanted a radical change in the health care system, but in Washington that was interpreted to mean something these people did not mean."
Mr. McInturff said that when he followed up in focus groups, asking people exactly what they meant by radical change, "they said: 'if I lose my job, I don't want to lose my coverage. I don't want it to cost so much.' "
The pollster added: "What they were really talking about was portability. So what in Washington was considered incremental change, was to people out in the country radical."
But to the first Democratic Administration in 12 years, and to its euphoric allies, remaking one-seventh of the American economy was just the kind of challenge they craved.
 
 
Early Days
From a Promise To Deep Secrecy
 In the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton had promised to guarantee health insurance for all Americans while cutting the Federal budget deficit in half within four years. In the transition from his election on Nov. 3, 1992, to his inauguration on Jan. 20, 1993, he received unwelcome news suggesting that those goals might be irreconcilable.
His transition team told him that it would be nearly impossible to expand health insurance coverage in his first term without big tax increases or Draconian controls on health costs. His advisers fought among themselves over whether deficit reduction or universal health insurance had higher priority.
At her confirmation hearing, Donna E. Shalala, then the nominee for Secretary of Health and Human Services, said that money saved through cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid would be used to finance coverage for the uninsured, not to reduce the Federal budget deficit. In fact, Mr. Clinton and Congress decided that deficit reduction should come first.
Recalling the period between Election Day and Inauguration Day, Stuart H. Altman, an economist at Brandeis University who advised the President-elect, said this weekend: "During the transition, Clinton's total preoccupation was either with his economic program or putting his Cabinet together. Health care took a back seat. We got no guidance."
On Jan. 20, 1993, Americans heard the sparkling poetry of Maya Angelou, celebrating "the pulse of this new day." Five days later, the President appointed his wife to head a Task Force on National Health Care Reform with a clear mission: writing legislation "to be submitted to Congress within 100 days of our taking office," that is, by April 30.
 
'A Highly Formalized Process'
 It soon became clear that this was no ordinary process for developing policy. "We're in this big time," Secretary Shalala, a member of the task force, said in an interview on Jan. 25. She declared that the Administration would "corner the market" for health policy experts by recruiting the best ones to work in Washington.
Dr. Shalala was immediately upstaged by Mr. Magaziner, the coordinator of the task force, who designed the policy-making process with a zealous attention to detail and a deaf ear for politics and public relations. In his first public appearance, on Jan. 28, he told the Washington Business Group on Health that the 12-member task force would do its work through "a highly structured process, a highly formalized process."
The real work was done by the staff of the task force, which grew larger every week. Ultimately, with more than 500 people, the staff was bigger than 99 percent of all businesses in the United States. The staff was organized in 15 "cluster groups" studying such issues as cost controls, coverage, benefits, long-term care and ethical foundations of the new health care system.
To check on the progress of the cluster groups, to synthesize their work and to narrow the options, Mr. Magaziner scheduled a series of seven "tollgate" meetings from Feb. 10 to May 3. Confidential working papers from the task force show that "decisions on key issues" were to be made by the end of March, but the panel fell far behind schedule.
In an interview over the weekend, Mr. Gawande, the leader of one cluster group, recalled: "The tollgate meetings were open, free-for-all sessions. We sometimes went till 2 in the morning, and still felt that we were shortchanging each issue."
Mr. Gawande's recollections help explain why the proposals that emerged from the task force ran into a political buzzsaw.
"Politics was not a major part of our task," he said. "That was what the President and the First Lady and their political advisers were supposed to be dealing with. We were there to pull together options for them.
"The options were more difficult to narrow than people realized. The tradeoffs over who will pay and how generous the benefits should be, these are ultimately political decisions."
Health care experts in the Government and in private industry said, half in jest, that the task force was a huge seminar to educate Mr. Magaziner.
"Ira was the dominant player," Walter A. Zelman, a senior White House health policy adviser, said Saturday. "I never knew the extent to which the decisions he made were a result of conversations he had with others," like the President or Mrs. Clinton, "or whether he was making the decisions on his own."
Insiders say Mr. Magaziner and Mrs. Clinton reinforced each other's tendencies to seek idealistic solutions. They shared a perception that, as Mrs. Clinton said in May 1993, "too many people have made too much money" providing health care and insurance.
In an interview tonight, Mr. Magaziner defended his work. "The final decisions that we needed from the President in order to be able to finalize the policy were indefinitely postponed, and we didn't get them until after Labor Day because of the focus on the economic package," he said. "I don't think there was any choice. If the economic package did not get passed, the country would have been worse off."
Illustrating the problem, Mr. Magaziner said: "We set up our communications room at the end of May, and it was basically taken over by the economic team. We got it back at the end of August."
In hindsight, people who worked for the task force say its organization and secrecy planted the seeds of trouble for the President.
The policy experts developing proposals for universal coverage, a comprehensive package of health benefits and Federal subsidies for poor people, rarely spoke to the fiscal experts. The task force deferred the discussion of costs. Experts on mental health and long-term care argued for a richer and richer package of benefits without knowing how much it would cost.
 
Meeting, but Not Listening
 Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Magaziner met with many outside groups, but did not confide in them. After one such meeting, in March 1993, Dr. Quentin D. Young, chairman of Physicians for a National Health Program, which represents 6,000 doctors, said, "It was a magnificent exercise in pseudo openness."
In the crucial months from January to September 1993, Administration officials, especially Mr. Magaziner, alienated potential allies in Congress. Representative Pete Stark, a California Democrat who heads the Ways and Means subcommittee on health, said: "They came over and saw us all the time, but ignored what we said."
Some lawmakers had urged the President to submit only a statement of principles; others wanted details. In the absence of a detailed proposal from the White House, Mr. Stark said, "we were paralyzed."
Last month, long after the task force went out of business, the Clinton Administration was still defending the secrecy of its operations in Federal District Court here. In retrospect, Mr. Zelman said, "it probably wasn't worth the secrecy."
 
The Strategy
Planning Falters As Crises Appear
 Last Sept. 22, President Clinton went before a joint session of Congress. Overcoming a malfunctioning Teleprompter, he gave a compelling speech.
"Tonight we come together to write a new chapter in the American story," he declared. "This health care system is badly broken and we need to fix it.
"At long last, after decades of false starts, we must make this our most urgent priority: giving every American health security, health care that can never be taken away, health care that is always there."
The speech, and the succeeding weeks, had been planned like a long political campaign. There were interviews with television anchors and newspaper columnists by the President and the First Lady, "Health Care That is Always There" buttons, different "messages" for different weeks and an immense commitment of Presidential time -- a promise of five weeks on this issue.
At first the signs seemed favorable. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, offered hope for bipartisanship and played host to Mrs. Clinton. Senator Chafee, with 23 Republican co-sponsors for a different approach to universal coverage, requiring individuals to insure themselves, basked in her tributes.
And Mrs. Clinton captivated and dominated her audience when she testified before five Congressional committees starting on Sept. 28, recalling heart-rending stories of health care problems, praising members of Congress for their insight and deflecting the rare episodes of hostility. The Clinton program had been smoothly launched.
But, like a new battleship that slides down the ways, it still wasn't ready for action. The bill itself was not ready to be introduced until Oct. 27. Lloyd Bentsen, the Secretary of the Treasury, refused to testify on Capitol Hill before he was surer of the numbers. Four days before the President's speech, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, foreshadowed the obstacles he would present later when he called the Administration's numbers "fantasy."
Dubious about the Clinton proposal or even whether there was a health care crisis, Mr. Moynihan would emerge from time to time. His hearings were a fascinating intellectual excursion into health care and related issues, but it was late June before he was ready to write legislation.
 
The Big Delay
 But the most immediate problem was not in Washington, or even in the United States. On Oct. 3, 12 American soldiers on a peacekeeping operation in Somalia were killed and scores were wounded or missing in an exchange with a Somali faction. Americans were horrified to see pictures of a dead soldier dragged through the streets of Mogadishu.
The President turned back from a health care trip to California and turned his focus abroad. Other foreign policy problems erupted in Haiti and Bosnia, the North American Free Trade Agreement was in trouble, and it was December before Mr. Clinton was again heavily focused on health care.
Mr. McInturff, who was polling for the already hostile Health Insurance Association of America, said this weekend: "We were doing daily tracking from Sept. 22 on, and awareness of his plan was going up. Support for the plan was going up." But on Oct. 3, Mr. McInturff said, it stopped.
Administration officials see that diversion as critical to the selling campaign. But the dream of five weeks of uninterrupted Presidential time was just another unrealistic hope, another imperfect translation from the campaign mode to governing.
Moreover, the Administration's likely allies were not out cheering. They expressed only qualified approval, or said they had to wait. It was in this period that Washington first began to notice the insurance association's television commercials of a couple named "Harry and Louise" who voiced doubts about the details of the Clinton program, starting with requiring people and employers to join health insurance purchasing alliances. The audience was never national, and Professor Jamieson of the University of Pennsylvania has cast some doubt on the ads' effectiveness, but they rubbed a nerve here.
 
Shifting Focus
 In a campaign posture, the Clinton Administration resisted inquiries about how the alliances would work. Instead it wanted to talk about what it called the six principles of the President's program: "security, simplicity and savings; choice, quality and responsibility." In Mr. Clinton's Sept. 22 speech, it had taken longest to explain "simplicity."
For all the talk of conducting this effort like a campaign, which put Republicans on their guard about the depth of the commitment to cooperation, there was often only feeble follow-through. In September, Mrs. Clinton promised Congressional leaders that the Administration or the Democratic National Committee would find small businessmen in every Congressional district who supported required payments by employers. It was months before that effort was even begun, after the other side's argument was firmly planted.
 
The Lobbyists
Strong Foes, Uneasy Allies
 In the beginning, almost nobody wanted to be cast as an opponent of health care restructuring. But by the end of 1993, when the vague promise of a health care overhaul had been turned into the 1,342 pages of the Clinton plan, it was difficult to find out-and-out supporters of the President's proposal.
In February of this year, the Business Roundtable, representing about 200 of the nation's largest companies, rebuffed the Clintons and threw its support to a more modest rival plan. This was devastating to the Administration, which had counted on such companies to offset the opposition of the small-business lobby.
"You are not going to reform one-seventh of the American economy without business support and Republican support," Tom Downey, a former Congressman who is now a lobbyist, said in an interview this weekend.
Many advocates of health care restructuring were perplexed by the position taken by big business. After all, they had reasoned, big corporations generally paid for their workers' insurance -- and what they paid also subsidized health care for millions of people who were uninsured. For years, business executives had complained about the soaring cost of health care.
But many corporate executives had a visceral reaction to the complexity of the Clinton plan and the expansion of Federal authority that Mr. Clinton was proposing. They said they could control costs much better than the Government could, and they feared that under the Clinton plan they would lose the right to tailor health benefits to their employees' needs.
 
Small Business to the Fore
 With big business sidelined, the National Federation of Independent Business had a clear field. Mr. Motley, chief lobbyist for the 600,000-member federation, said his organization made two early strategic decisions about how to block Mr. Clinton's proposal to require employers to help buy health insurance for their workers.
First, the federation decided that the best way to fight the "employer mandate" was not to seek public sympathy for small business, but to play on public fears that jobs would be lost if employers had to absorb added insurance costs. Second, it concluded that the campaign would be won or lost out in the country, not in Washington.
"We did everything we possibly could do from a grass-roots standpoint," Mr. Motley said.
The Administration's biggest tormentor, after small-business lobbyists, was probably the Health Insurance Association of America, which began running television advertisements ridiculing the Clinton plan in September 1993. The "Harry and Louise" commercials featured a couple agonizing over details of the Clinton plan in exchanges like this one:
Louise: This plan forces us to buy our insurance through these new mandatory Government health alliances.
Harry: Run by tens of thousands of new bureaucrats.
Louise: Another billion-dollar bureaucracy.
Professor Jamieson of the University of Pennsylvania said the available evidence suggests that "the ads had a negligible impact on the public" and were intended primarily to influence opinion makers in Washington and New York. But Mr. McInturff, the pollster who analyzed the commercials for the insurance industry, says they did influence the public.
In any event, the Clintons' criticism of of the advertisementsprovoked far more public interest in them than Harry and Louise would ever have commanded on their own.
The supporters of Clinton-style health care legislation proved no match for the groups opposing Mr. Clinton. Citizen Action, a consumer group, says that political action committees formed by insurance companies, doctors, hospitals, drug companies and others in the health care industry contributed more $26 million to members of Congress from January 1993 to last May.
The core of support for universal health insurance was a broad coalition known as the Health Care Reform Project, founded in September 1993 by groups like the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the American Academy of Pediatrics, the Catholic Health Association and the American Association of Retired Persons.
These groups staunchly supported the principles and goals of Mr. Clinton's plan, but expressed varying degrees of enthusiasm for its details. Many groups, including the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said they supported both the Clinton plan and proposals for a Canadian-style "single payer" system of national health insurance financed by the Government. Those two proposals are very different and, in many ways, contradictory.
Moreover, Mr. Clinton's allies continually qualified their support by expressing concern about specific parts of his plan. Labor unions worried that Mr. Clinton was going to tax some of the benefits they had won in collective bargaining. Doctors specializing in internal medicine supported much of Mr. Clinton's plan, but objected to the proposed cutbacks in Medicare and to the idea of Federal limits on private health insurance premiums.
In view of these reservations, Mrs. Clinton said, the Administration's allies, the proponents of universal coverage, "cannot possibly have the intensity that the negative forces have."
 
 
The Committees
An Issue Is Lost In the Labyrinth
 In his State of the Union Message on Jan. 25, 1994, President Clinton waved a pen before Congress and threatened to veto any health legislation that did not guarantee insurance coverage for all Americans.
By then, health care reform had made its way from a vague buzzword on the campaign trail to a scholarly treatise to a sprawling piece of legislation scattered over five major Congressional committees. It was in those committees that the most byzantine stage of the health care struggle began, a stage that lasted until the Fourth of July weekend -- long past all the self-imposed deadlines, long past the time when anyone expected a grand health care compromise to emerge.
The struggle for universal coverage began to collapse in the committees. Again and again, members tried to reach consensus on how to cover everybody without antagonizing the small-business lobby. But they always ran up against the same problem: without an employer mandate or a broad-based tax increase, how could they pay for it?
 
'You Can't Go That Way'
 Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, was usually the man who delivered the bad news -- to committees, to rump groups, to the ad hoc gatherings that wrestled one after another with the same insoluble issues.
"Each individual group would think they'd discovered a new route to China," said Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington and a member of the Ways and Means Committee, in an interview this weekend. "And they'd go down to Bob Reischauer, and he'd say, 'No, boys, you can't go that way. It's all ice up there.' "
Most of the committee leaders tried hard to muscle a bill through. Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, the chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, offered one compromise after another. But his committee deadlocked.
Mr. Motley of the National Federation of Independent Business said that Energy and Commerce was ripe for his lobbying -- heavy with members from rural states that are dependent on small business. "We can reach out and touch them a lot easier," Mr. Motley said. "States like Kansas are set up perfectly to maximize the impact of business owners."
Representative Cooper, who had his own health care plan that relied on market forces to expand coverage instead of a mandate, said on Saturday that the issue may have been destined to stall in the committees.
"I think you had committee chairmen who were for the Canadian health care system, who were to the left of Clinton," he said. "And you had the average House member who was way to the right of Clinton, and the President's proposal -- the Ira Magaziner proposal -- satisfied no one."
The two most liberal of the five committees -- Education and Labor in the House, Labor and Human Resources in the Senate -- reported out versions of the Clinton plan. But despite a quarter-century of determined advocacy by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, chairman of Labor and Human Resources, nobody expected those committees to produce the vehicles for floor debate. The committee that most prides itself on this kind of heavy lifting, the House Ways and Means Committee, was hindered by the loss of its chairman, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, who gave up the chair when he was indicted in May on corruption charges.
"He is the strongest member of the House of Representatives in terms of driving a consensus," Mr. McDermott said. "I don't think it would have been a consensus I would have liked every piece of, but there would have been a consensus reached that would have been ready for the floor."
Ways and Means soldiered on under the acting chairman, Sam M. Gibbons of Florida, producing a bill that attained the necessary 20 Democratic votes on the committee to keep the process going. But by that point, the Republicans were essentially opting out of the process and Democrats were beginning to wonder where it was headed.
In the Senate Finance Committee, another place where a grand compromise might have emerged, there was instead weeks of false starts and jabs at the Administration from Senator Moynihan, the committee chairman.
Health care, of course, was the kind of issue that the committee system was intended for, demanding great expertise, months of close-in work. But in the end, it seemed to overwhelm the lawmakers.
"This issue got away from everybody," said Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, a member of the Ways and Means Committee. "It got away from all of us. And I don't think anybody anticipated the amount of resources that would be marshaled against it."
 
 
Summer
The Mitchell Plan Runs Into a Snag
 Universal coverage was undergoing redefinition when Congress came back to work on July 11. The 95 percent figure was in the air, and soon it was to be in the bill the Administration supported, the plan put forward on Aug. 2 by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader.
His plan was to use subsidies for the working poor, and especially their children, to push coverage rates up. But if it did not rise to 95 percent, from the current 85 percent, by the year 2000, a fall-back plan would go into effect, requiring employers to pay half the cost of their workers' premiums unless Congress found a better way.
Mr. Mitchell assembled the bill from the work of the Senate Finance Committee and Labor and Human Resources Committee, as well as from his own ever-shrinking idea of what would pass. But his narrowed hopes of what the Senate might adopt alarmed House Democrats.
Three days earlier, their leaders proposed a bill requiring employers to start paying 80 percent of workers' premiums, beginning in 1997, and expanding Medicare to cover the unemployed and others without a paycheck in the household. But with Mr. Mitchell apparently retreating, House Democrats were even more reluctant to go out on a limb and take the political risks in voting for something the Senate might undo.
The Senate started debating the bill on Aug. 9, and Mr. Mitchell promised six-day-a-week sessions until it was finished. But in two five-day weeks, Republican stalling tactics prevented any important votes. The majority leader was not sure he had the votes, but the opposition was not sure he did not.
Senator Dole and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, both 1996 Presidential hopefuls, led the attack. Mr. Gramm's zeal in proclaiming Mr. Clinton's hopes "a dead body," was predictable, but Mr. Dole's partisan antagonism was not, for he had worked closely with Senator Chafee in drafting his universal coverage bill. Now he was opposing any taxes and offering slim subsidies, and insisting that the President move in his direction.
Nor was that the only distraction Mr. Clinton's allies faced. Senator Chafee was now leading a bipartisan band of about 20 senators that called itself the "mainstream coalition." It proposed more coverage than the Dole bill and more deficit reduction than the Mitchell bill. Some members of the coalition insisted that it had to be their plan or nothing; others were more willing to bargain.
But Mr. Mitchell had no time for bargaining as the bitter partisanship of the House debate on crime legislation sloshed over to the Senate last week, and he had a four-day fight to pass what is normally a politician's dream, a $30.2 billion anti-crime bill in an election year.
The crime bill dispute complicated health care efforts in the House, too. Representative Cardin, the Maryland Democrat, said on Saturday that if the dispute "had been off the screen, I think we would have had a chance" to start assembling votes.
But between that problem and waiting for the Congressional Budget Office to analyze the leadership bill and rival approaches, the House never even took up the health care measure, which it had first planned to finish by Aug. 12, and then by Aug. 19.
Finally, hoping that a cooling-off period might help, Mr. Mitchell sent the Senate home last Thursday night, insisting he would be earnestly negotiating with the mainstream group for two weeks and promising that the Senate would go back to the health care debate on Sept. 12.
 
Two Degrees of Optimism
 Mr. Chafee expressed optimism this morning, but he conceded that if anything passed it would not provide universal coverage -- "not if by 'universal' you mean 100 percent or 95 percent."
Mr. Mitchell, who is retiring from the Senate this year and who passed up a Supreme Court seat to achieve a last legislative triumph in health care, took a longer view. "I really believe that we will get this done, if not all this year, in time, if for no other reason than it is so necessary," he said in an interview on Friday. "Democracies tend to respond to crises afterwards more so than before them."
To Mr. Chafee, the hope for insuring another 15 million or so Americans and making other changes in health insurance practices that were once scorned as "incremental" rests on the willingness of the President and his allies "to abandon 'mammoth steps' and recognize that "we had better be cautious."
There is general agreement that Mr. Clinton would have got closer to his goal if he had acted faster, before the opposition had mobilized and his own standing had weakened. But beyond that, even perfect hindsight produces no consensus on what could have been done to bring the nation closer to the universal health care it seemed to want 11 months ago.
Dr. Drew Altman, president of the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation and an advocate of universal insurance, said on Saturday: "You were always dealing with a fundamental underlying dynamic: the American people want change as long as it doesn't cost them too much or affect them too much personally. The problem wasn't Harry and Louise. The problem was us."
 
CHRONOLOGY
 
November 1991 -- Harris Wofford, a Democrat running for the Senate from Pennsylvania, wins an upset victory with a campaign that centered on health care, demonstrating the issue's political power.
 
February 1992 -- In the New Hampshire primary campaign, Bill Clinton call for employers to provide health insurance for their workers or to pay a tax to enroll them in a public program.
 
Feb. 6, 1992 -- President George Bush unveils a health proposal that would give tax credits or tax deductions he says would make medical care affordable to every American. Congress never takes up the plan.
 
Sept. 24, 1992 -- Bill Clinton offers an revised version of his universal health care proposal under which employers would have to buy insurance for their employees, the Government would guarantee coverage for the unemployed, a new entity composed of consumers and providers of health care would establish national limits on health spending, and small businesses could band together to buy insurance at a discount.
 
Jan. 25, 1993 -- President Clinton appoints his wife, Hillary, to head a panel to prepare legislation.
 
PUB-DATE: March 8, 1993
 
Sept. 8, 1993 -- The Health Insurance Association of America finances commercials portraying a suburban couple, "Harry and Louise," fretting over proposed health care restructuring.
 
Sept. 22, 1993 -- Mr. Clinton outlines his health insurance plan to a joint session of Congress. Under the plan, most Americans would obtain coverage through large regional purchasing groups called health alliances; employers would be required to pay 80 percent of premiums for their employees; universal coverage would be achieved by 1999.
 
Oct. 6, 1993 -- Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, introduces a health proposal that would require no employer payments and would rely more heavily on market forces to keep health care spending under control. A similar bill is introduced on Oct. 21 in the Senate by John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana.
 
Oct. 27, 1993 -- The President delivers his plan to Congress.
 
Jan. 25, 1994 -- In his State of the Union speech, Mr. Clinton vows to veto any proposal that would not provide coverage for everyone.
 
Jan. 31, 1994 -- The nation's governors issue a unanimous call for Congress to pass a health bill this year, but they cannot agree on whether employers should be required to pay any of their workers' insurance costs.
 
Feb. 2-4, 1994 -- Despite last-minute lobbying by the President and Mrs. Clinton, the Business Roundable, representing about 200 of the nation's largest companies, endorses Representative Cooper's plan. The United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers say they cannot support the Clinton plan.
 
PUB-DATE: March 15, 1994
 
PUB-DATE: May 31, 1994
 
June 1994 -- Three committees adopt bills generally based on the President's proposals. On June 28 the chairman of another, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, acknowledges that it is hopelessly deadlocked over employer payments.
 
PUB-DATE: July 2, 1994
 
PUB-DATE: July 19, 1994
 
PUB-DATE: July 29, 1994
 
Aug. 2, 1994 -- Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine proposes legislation that he says will achieve coverage of 95 percent of all Americans by the year 2000 through voluntary measures and subsidies.
 
Aug. 4, 1994 -- The President says that Senator Mitchell's bill meets his requirements.
 
Aug. 9, 1994 -- Senate begins debate on health care legislation.
 
Aug. 11, 1994 -- a battle over the Administration's crime bill keeps the house from taling up the leadership health bill. A bipartisan group in the House introduces a bill that would offer billions of dollars in subsidies to help the working poor buy health insurance without raising taxes or requiring employer payments.
 
Aug. 17, 1994 -- House Democratic leaders say the Congressional Budget Office has not completed its analysis of legislation and acknowledge they have no clear idea when the House can resume its work.
 
Aug. 25, 1994 -- The Senate recesses until Sept. 12 and the House adopts its schedule.
 
Aug. 26 -- Congressional leaders and White House officials all but concede that there is no chance of passing universal health insurance legislation this year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Garden Sale
 Viacom agreed to sell its Madison Square Garden sports and entertainment empire to a partnership of Cablevision Systems and ITT, but many analysts said the purchase price of $1.075 billion in cash would far exceed what the Garden properties -- including the New York Knicks, New York Rangers and MSG cable network -- are actually worth. [Page A1.] 
 Analysts and investors have been scratching their heads ever since ITT was identified as a serious bidder for one of the entertainment world's most glamorous properties. But to many, ITT's deal clouds the vision of the company's future. [D1.]
There is little mystery about why Cablevision Systems was intent on acquiring the Garden. It has made sports programming -- especially of New York sports -- a central pillar of its growth for nearly three decades. [D8.]
The reactions by two of New York State's highest officials demonstrated how differently politicians have assessed the sale. Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell pronounced the deal flawed, while Gov. Mario M. Cuomo hailed it. [D8.]
Bob Gutkowski could soon be out as president of Madison Square Garden. [C3.]
 
The Economy
American businesses in increasing numbers are turning away from the pension plans that have provided retirement income for millions since the Depression. Instead, they are asking workers to pay for and manage their own retirement plans -- and, left on their own, Americans are not doing a very good job of it. [A1.]
By publicly challenging the views of Alan Greenspan, his boss, on the mission of the Federal Reserve Bank, the agency's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, may have sparked a dispute that could lead to clashes over policy on interest rates. News Analysis. [D1.]
 
Companies
In a quiet decision in June, the Patent and Trademark Office handed Microsoft a significant victory by reversing itself and tentatively approving the software giant's application for trademark protection for the word "windows." [D1.]
Investors in a failed Prudential Securities partnership have been offered a deal that raises legal and ethical questions. Baker & McKenzie, the law firm, will try to recover their money. But a portion of any recovery must be reinvested in the partnership and at least 10 percent must be turned over to its general partner -- a Baker & McKenzie client. [D2.]
The struggle for control of Olympia & York Developments' U.S. subsidiary grew more heated when the administrator for the bankrupt Canadian parent ordered the removal of two prominent executives from the board of the American unit. [D5.]
 
The Media Business
Thanks to Fox Broadcasting's raid on network affiliates, nearly everything about broadcast television in Phoenix, the nation's 19th-largest market, is about to be turned upside down. [D1.]
It's not easy competing with HBO. But Steven Hewitt, in charge of original programming for Showtime Networks, says he intends to have fun trying. [D6.]
With a fortune in reruns at stake, the prime-time crown is far more than a status symbol. Bill Carter: Television. [D6.]
Paper magazine, a self-described hip harbinger of change, has a campaign with a shifting theme. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Today's Columns
Alan Greenspan is not going to be mean to investors anymore, much of Wall Street now believes. And if that belief persists, last week's surprising stock rally could have a considerable way to go. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
A technology consultant has devised an eight-speed auto transmission with no extra gears for greater fuel economy. Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Bosnian Serbs Cast Ballots on Peace Plan

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Bosnian Serbs voting in a referendum today appeared certain to confirm their rejection of an international peace plan for Bosnia that their leadership has portrayed as a recipe for military defeat and economic ruin.
Diplomats and United Nations officials said that a relentless campaign by the Bosnian Serb news media seemed to have assured an overwhelming defeat for the plan. The proposal, drawn up by the United States, Russia, Britain, France and Germany, would require the Serbs to give up about a third of the territory they hold in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 
 The first results from the referendum are expected within 48 hours of the closing of 82 polling stations where Serbs cast ballots on the second and last day in the territory they control. Although organizers of the vote said almost a million people had cast ballots, international observers argue that the population of the Serb-held areas -- about 70 percent of the former Yugoslav republic's land -- has fallen to about 700,000 at most.
President Clinton has warned that if the Serbs persist until Oct. 15 in their rejection of the plan, he will ask the United Nations Security Council to lift the arms embargo on the mainly Muslim Bosnian forces so they can fight the Serbs more effectively.
But Britain and France, which have troops in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia, argue that peacekeeping and ending the arms embargo are incompatible. Military analysts fear that if the peacekeeping force withdrew, the better- armed and better-organized Serbs could defeat the Government forces.
As the voting was held today, Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia arrived here for talks with Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, over the recent rift between the Bosnian Serbs and their patrons in Belgrade.
Because the landlocked Bosnian Serbs have been dependent on financial and logistical support from Belgrade throughout 28 months of war, there were signs of a potential breakthrough this month when Serbia cut off road and telephone communications with the Bosnian Serbs because their leaders rejected the peace plan.
Western diplomats said Mr. Kozyrev would offer a mild easing of an international trade embargo against Serbia, including the possibility of opening the airport and readmitting Serbia to world sporting events, if Mr. Milosevic agreed to effective international policing of the border between Serbia and Bosnia. "We are no longer talking about toughening or imposing extra sanctions on Belgrade," Mr. Kozyrev said. "The task is the opposite: to lift certain sanctions to show clearly to the Serbs that every step in the right direction by Belgrade will be met by a corresponding, positive reaction from the side of the world community."
His statement underscored the sharp turnabout by the five-nation group that drew up the latest peace plan, which would allocate 51 percent of Bosnia to the Muslim-led Government and 49 percent to the Serbs. Rejection of the plan by the Bosnian Serbs was supposed to lead to tighter sanctions on Serbia, as well as increased world military pressure on the Serbs in Bosnia.
Instead, a new policy of squeezing the Bosnian Serbs by using an unlikely ally -- Mr. Milosevic -- appears to have been adopted while an easing of sanctions against Belgrade is under intense review.
His country is economically and psychologically exhausted by more than two years of a debilitating embargo, and another winter of isolation would be difficult to endure. Moreover, officials close to the Serbian President say he is convinced the peace plan can be used as a first step toward resolving the central problem posed by Yugoslavia's disintegration: substantial Serbian minorities in Bosnia and Croatia.
 
A Difference of Outlook
 But while Mr. Milosevic's stand against Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, now seems serious, it is by no means clear that the Serbian President will accept the political embarrassment of allowing international observers on Serbia's border with Bosnia or that he can restrain the Bosnian Serbs.
The Serbs of Serbia and the Serbs of Bosnia have different histories, the former having freed themselves from the rule of the Ottoman Turks much earlier, and their differing sensibilities have now been strained by more than two years of fighting in Bosnia. A life-or-death conflict for the Bosnian Serbs has become a dreary, somewhat distant and increasingly meaningless war for many of the people in Serbia.
The Bosnian Serb army has become more self-reliant and is now highly organized and well equipped. Over time, the Bosnian Serbs argue, the long border between Serbia and Serb-held parts of Bosnia is certain to become porous once again.

HEADLINE: THE GARDEN SALE: THE PROGRAMMING;
Cablevision's Craving for Sports

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

 BODY:
Although he is nowhere near as famous -- or as noisy -- as cable television impresarios like Ted Turner, there is little mystery about why Charles F. Dolan was so intent on acquiring Madison Square Garden.
As the chairman and chief executive of the Cablevision Systems Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest cable operator, Mr. Dolan has made sports programming -- particularly of New York sports -- a central pillar of his company's growth for nearly three decades. 
 The deal would give Cablevision sweeping control over sports in the local market. The company not only would own the New York Knicks and New York Rangers, but would also still be televising the New York Mets, New York Islanders, New Jersey Nets and New Jersey Devils on Cablevision's Sportchannel cable network and the Knicks, Rangers and New York Yankees on the MSG Network.
Indeed, so sweeping would that control be that the New York State Attorney General, G. Oliver Koppell, plans to open an antitrust investigation.
"Until now, you have had two cable stations that vigorously competed to carry New York sports teams," Mr. Koppell said in an interview yesterday. "After this acquisition, you'll have only one, and you'll have essentially no competition. You will also have no competition for viewers. The viewers will not have a choice."
At a news conference yesterday announcing the deal, Mr. Dolan said: "The advice we have is that we are in good shape on antitrust. The way we are doing it is making the games available to a maximum audience. The object is to give the games maximum circulation and to have them be presented in ways appropriate to specific interests of the public."
Based in Woodbury, L.I., Cablevision has 2.5 million subscribers in 19 states. But 1.4 million of those subscribers are concentrated in and around the New York metropolitan area, with most of the rest clustered around Boston, Cleveland, Chicago and a few other cities.
Largely because Cablevision's systems are grouped tightly together around common television markets, Mr. Dolan was a cable industry pioneer in signing up sports teams like the Knicks and Rangers. (He subsequently sold rights to those two teams, which he would regain as part of the deal announced yesterday.)
For Cablevision over the years, the formula has been both simple and successful: build or buy systems that together make up a big market, achieve economies of scale that allow the systems to sign crowd-pleasing local sports teams, and then attract subscriber revenues that make it possible to finance more growth.
Cablevision now owns eight regional sports networks, including Sportschannel New York, and it operates two national sports services -- Prime Network and Newsport -- in partnership with the Liberty Media Corporation, a part of Tele-Communications Inc.
Though hardly operating on the scale of John C. Malone, the powerful chief executive of Tele-Communications in Denver, Mr. Dolan has quietly but consistently been quick to seize on new technology and new ideas.
In 1961, when cable television was still in its paleolithic era, he started by delivering multiple-channel programming to hotels in Manhattan. Four years later, he built a fledgling cable network for residential customers and soon became the first person in the cable industry to strike deals with professional sports teams.
In 1967, he reached an agreement to carry the Knicks and Rangers on cable in New York and developed what is now Sportschannel New York. In 1978, he was the first cable operator to strike a deal with Major League Baseball, winning rights to carry the Yankees and the Mets.
Mr. Dolan sold his Manhattan system to Time Inc. in 1973, in exchange for several systems on Long Island. Those systems formed the nucleus for what is now Cablevision Systems.
In addition to expanding his cable systems, Mr. Dolan also started Home Box Office, the movie channel, which is now also owned by Time Warner Inc. Cablevision, through its subsidiary Rainbow Program Holdings, currently owns another movie channel, American Movie Classics, as well as a cultural channel, Bravo, and a 24-hour local news channel called News 12 Long Island.
 
Tripping on the Triplecast
 There have been some mistakes. The biggest was the Triplecast, Cablevision's joint venture with NBC to offer the 1992 Olympics on pay-per-view television. Under that plan, viewers would get three channels of full-time Olympics coverage. But the project failed to get much interest, and Cablevision lost about $50 million on it.
Cablevision's Sportschannel lost rights to Yankee baseball in 1988, when the MSG Network won a bidding battle. Many financial analysts criticized MSG at the time, saying it had overpaid with its $486 million deal for rights to Yankee games through the year 2000. Now those rights are Cablevision's to make or lose money on.
The company's core business has been sound, though the company has accumulated $10 billion of debt over the years to finance its growth. Last year, Cablevision reported a net loss of $57 million on revenue of $666 million. But its operating cash flow -- earnings before depreciation, amortization and interest -- was $252 million. In the cable industry, cash flow is considered a better measure of strength than profits or losses.
 
A Merger Candidate
 Last year, when the telephone and cable television industries were caught in a frenzy of merger talks, Cablevision Systems was one of the most-sought-after companies. U S West Inc., the regional Bell company based in Denver, and Time Warner were believed to have been active suitors, as well as the Southwestern Bell Corporation. Shortly after the Bell Atlantic Corporation shook the industry with an agreement to buy Tele-Communications, many industry experts predicted that Cablevision would be sold to a Bell company within a few weeks or months.
That never happened, however. Investment bankers say Mr. Dolan held out for a high price. And after the Bell Atlantic deal collapsed in February, the merger mania subsided quickly.
Now it is Mr. Dolan on the acquiring side, in a deal that -- if it goes through -- suddenly makes him the most powerful sports programmer in the nation's largest television sports market.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sumner M. Redstone, let, Viacom's chairman, announced yesterday the $1.075 billion sale of the Madison Square Garden properties to ITT and Cablevision Systems. At the news conference were Rand V. Araskog of ITT, Charles F. Dolan of Cablevision and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: U.S. POLICY;
U.S. Promises to Respond If Castro Offers Reforms

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Seeking to defuse the refugee crisis with Cuba, the Clinton Administration offered some carrots to Fidel Castro today to encourage him to undertake democratic reforms.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said that if Mr. Castro took meaningful steps like allowing free elections, the Administration would respond in a positive way. 
 "If he moves toward democracy in a tangible, significant way, we'll respond in a carefully calibrated way," Mr. Christopher said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
Mr. Christopher declined to say what these responses might be. But after he spoke, several State Department officials said the Administration might ease -- but not eliminate -- economic or travel restrictions against Cuba if Mr. Castro allowed more freedom of expression or free elections.
 
Not Seeking Castro's Ouster
 In what several officials said was an effort to reduce the rancor of the exchanges between Washington and Havana, Mr. Christopher also said the United States was not specifically seeking Mr. Castro's departure.
"What we seek is peaceful, democratic change," he said. "That's our goal. Whether that involves Mr. Castro or not is really up to him."
Although many Republicans and Cuban-American groups are urging President Clinton to demand Mr. Castro's departure, several Administration officials said it would be unwise to demand his ouster because that could cause the Cuban leader to take a vindictive approach to the refugee crisis and other matters.
Mr. Christopher, who cut his California vacation short last week to deal with the Cuba crisis, sought to portray the Administration's policy as a reasonable, middle course between what he described as two extremes -- those seeking warlike measures and those willing to scrap the trade embargo.
He said the Administration was not contemplating a naval blockade, stating that "it can lead toward confrontation; it's an act of war." Those who advocate a blockade, like some Cuban-American groups, are advocating "extreme positions," he said.
Last Sunday, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, suggested that the Administration might look at a blockade as a way of stepping up pressure on Havana.
Mr. Christopher denied that the Administration's policy was being driven by domestic politics, even though Florida officials, Cuban-American groups and some Administration officials have said Mr. Clinton's decision to tighten sanctions against Havana was a response to Cuban-American pressures.
In television appearances today, Mr. Christopher and other officials sought to put to rest skepticism that the Administration would discuss subjects other than immigration at the talks scheduled later this week with Cuban officials.
The United States and Cuba agreed to limited talks on immigration after Mr. Clinton rejected Mr. Castro's call last week for high-level talks on a range of subjects, including the trade embargo.
"Migration is at the core of what we have to talk to Cuba about," Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." "We're not going to negotiate broader questions."
Mr. Tarnoff said the United States was not interested "in cutting a deal" with the Cuban leader. "What we want him to understand is that he has to deal with the Cuban people," he said. "The United States is not an intermediary between Castro and his people."
 
Isolate Castro, Floridian Says
 Also appearing on "Face the Nation," Senator Connie Mack, a Florida Republican, agreed that the Administration should not engage in broad negotiations with Mr. Castro. "It would be like throwing him a lifeline," he said. "It's not what we should be doing. We should be attempting to further isolate this man."
Mr. Mack said the Administration should consider blockading Cuba if Mr. Castro continued to let Cubans flee to the United States.
On the same program, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, said "I can't think of anything more foolish" than a blockade, asserting that it would isolate the United States.
Mr. Dodd, chairman of the Senate's Subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere, backed the idea of broad negotiations. "No one wants to see this Government perpetuated," he said. "But to suggest somehow that we're just going to allow this situation to persist without trying to find some common ground or resolve these issues diplomatically and politically seems awfully naive and awfully myopic."
Administration officials said they were encouraged by a report in the Cuban Government newspaper Juventud Rebelde that Mr. Castro would prohibit children and adolescents from leaving Cuba on unsafe rafts and boats.
"We are interested in safe, legal and orderly migration, and that's what we want to encourage," Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, said in an interview. "If Cuba wants to discourage emigration that is illegal and dangerous for Cuban citizens, we think that makes sense."

HEADLINE: U.S. Puts Off Any Decision On Haiti Issue

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's plans for a possible invasion of Haiti have been put on a slower track by the Cuban refugee crisis and a myriad of diplomatic doubts and problems. But the preparations for a showdown with Haiti's military rulers continue, senior Administration officials say.
An invasion to restore the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, would not take place until after the Cuban crisis is resolved and perhaps not until after the November elections in the United States, some Administration officials say. 
 While the delays have raised some concerns in the Pentagon about readiness, in a larger sense no one in the Government seems to mind. The Administration hopes that the threat of an invasion makes the reality unnecessary. In that light, keeping the wheels of preparation moving, however slowly, has taken on a special importance.
 
'No Timetable Has Been Set'
 "No one ought to assume that there's been any decline in the urgency of dealing with the situation," said Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff. "No timetable has been set, but I can assure you that we are moving to increase the pressure."
Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch are to attend a meeting of Caribbean defense and foreign ministers in Kingston, Jamaica, on Tuesday, where the ministers are expected to support an invasion of Haiti.
At least five countries, including Barbados, Jamaica and Belize, are expected to contribute a total of about 200 troops to the 15,000-member, largely American invasion force. The Caribbean troops would not be in the first wave, State Department officials say.
American assurances aside, members of Father Aristide's government-in-exile express deep concerns that time is slipping away and that the position of the Haitian rulers is growing stronger.
 
'Not So Serious'
 "We have not been walking forward toward a solution and we are impatient that things are standing still," Claudette Werleigh, Father Aristide's Foreign Minister, said in a telephone interview. "The military in power is hearing a message that they have more time and they shouldn't worry. They really believe the international community and the U.S. are not so serious or so eager to intervene as the message seems to be sent and to be received."
There are many signs of this go-slow approach, which Administration officials acknowledge but attribute more to summer vacations and diplomatic snarls than to lack of interest.
A mid-level United Nations envoy, Rolf Knuttson, is in the Dominican Republic now to arrange a meeting between senior United Nations officials and the Haitian junta, but no one is certain if the generals or their aides will even meet with Mr. Knuttson. "If a senior-level meeting happens it will be to persuade the military to step down," said Ahmad Fawzi, a United Nations spokesman. "We may offer them a boat or a bike or a plane to leave, but there will be no negotiations."
 
Giving Sanctions a Chance
 Defense Secretary William J. Perry and Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have argued for giving sanctions as much time to work as possible. But an 88-member international observer force that is supposed to monitor the enforcement of sanctions along the porous border with the Dominican Republic has been mired in bureaucratic wrangling, and is still days away from setting up.
American and Canadian observers say they are ready to go, but Argentine troops are still waiting for approval from the Dominican Government.
Sanctions have had an overall "wrecking" effect on the already weak Haitian economy, a State Department official said. Since July 1, inflation has sapped the value of the Haitian currency, the gourde, by 58 percent, the official said, and gasoline is selling at about $9 a gallon, its highest levels since January.
But the wealthy elites and military rulers still seem largely insulated from this pressure. The Cuban crisis has led the Navy to reduce the number of ships enforcing the trade embargo from 10 to 6, including two foreign vessels, allowing the elites to rebuild their smuggling networks.
 
Questions of Readiness
 Pentagon officials worry that the delay is complicating questions of military readiness. Two Navy warships, the Wasp and the Nashville, with 1,800 marines, are steaming off Port-au-Prince. "At some time soon, we won't be as ready, and we'll have to gear up training again," said a senior Pentagon general. "It's getting close to that now. We'd have to go back into a honing phase."
But a delay will also give the United Nations more time to win commitments from other nations to join a peacekeeping force that would follow up an invasion. The United Nations has approached more than 40 countries, but only 10 have committed to send about 2,000 of the 6,000 militia and police that would be part of United Nations-directed "second phase."
And it could extend the chances that a carrot-and-stick approach of tough sanctions and inducements to depart might persuade the junta that seized power in 1991 to step down. "If in the next two weeks there's evidence that an envoy mission can be the fig leaf the military needs, that will change the urgency to get a multinational coalition," said a senior American official.
Indeed, the urgency to use military force will remain low if the flow of Haitian refugees stays a trickle and the harassment of foreigners "stays off the front pages," said the American official.
Invading Haiti before resolving the Cuban crisis poses huge risks. While some Administration officials argue it would send Fidel Castro a strong message, other experts say it would only inflame tensions.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Clinton Administration officials say that despite Washington's focus on Cuba, preparations are continuing for a showdown with Haiti's military. To show their resolve against any American-led invasion, the Haitian military has been holding parades with volunteers for a militia in Port-au-Prince. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Whitman Starts Four-State Campaign for G.O.P.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman held more than her share of the spotlight this weekend as she began her first major political tour outside New Jersey. While she was preparing to try to boost the campaigns of Republican candidates in four states, she heard herself being praised as a possible Vice Presidential candidate on the Republican ticket in 1996.
Mrs. Whitman's tour was intended to offer testimony that cutting taxes and reducing the size of government were good politics as well as good business. She added that she wanted to see Republicans pick up the seven seats needed to take control of the United States Senate, a change she said would protect states like New Jersey from expensive Federal mandates. 
 But she did not close the door on speculation about a spot on the next national Republican ticket, saying only that such talk was premature.
"I'm a new governor," she said, during a news conference at a small women-owned business in the heart of this city's downtown area. "I've only had the job for eight months and it's a little early to say something as dramatic as that."
 
'She Has Lots of Potential'
 At her first stop, to support the United States Senate campaign of John Ashcroft, former Missouri Governor, the press release prepared by the Ashcroft campaign said he was being endorsed by "a potential V.P. nominee." Doreen Torgerson, communications director for the Ashcroft campaign, said the description was her idea and not that of Mrs. Whitman's staff.
Both Mr. Ashcroft and Senator Christopher Bond of Missouri pointed to Mrs. Whitman's efforts in New Jersey as a model for the type of fiscal policy they favor.
Senator Bond, who has known Mrs. Whitman since 1960 when he attended Princeton University with her brother, Webster B. Todd Jr., met the Governor at the airport and said her visit was significant. "She's a Republican governor, a woman governor and she has lots of potential," he said. "She's doing a good job in New Jersey and is being watched closely by national party leaders."
Mr. Bond revealed another reason for his invitation to Mrs. Whitman: He needed fresh faces for his series of summer barbecues. "You have no idea how tough it is to attract some media attention in St. Louis on a Saturday," he said.
The cocktail reception and barbecue was held at a private home in Ladue, an affluent St. Louis suburb. Pat Fusselman, executive director of the Missouri Republican Party, said the 100 guests contributed about $40,000 to the state party.
 
Reviving Rollins Dispute
 While the Missouri stop appeared to go smoothly, Mrs. Whitman faced controversy in Texas, the second leg of her weeklong trip, even before she landed today. Democrats were trying to revive the criticism stirred up last year when Edward J. Rollins Jr., her campaign manager, said that he had pledged money to black clergy members if they would refrain from urging their congregations to vote for Gov. Jim Florio, her rival.
Mr. Rollins later recanted his story under oath and Mrs. Whitman steadfastly maintained that no such activity took place. But on Thursday Joe Cutbirth, the spokesman for the Texas Democratic Party, called on Republican candidates to "distance themselves from -- rather than embrace -- the racially insensitive politics that Mrs. Whitman represents."
Mick Voines, a spokesman for United States Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Texas Republican, said in an interview, "The Texas Democrats are in desperate political shape and grasping at any straw."
Mrs. Whitman said she was surprised and disappointed that some black ministers in Texas appeared to support the Democratic message. "Don't they realize that hurts their own communities?" she asked. "If people keep bringing this up, someone is going to believe that black ministers took bribes, and that's not true. Nothing, absolutely nothing, happened."
Mrs. Whitman was returning a political favor to Senator Hutchison, who went to New Jersey last year, when she agreed to campaign in Houston, Austin and San Antonio on Monday. But today she is campaigning for George W. Bush, the son of the former President, who is running for Governor against the Democratic incumbent, Ann W. Richards.
 
'Proven It Can Be Done'
 Karen Hughes, communications director for Mr. Bush, said Mrs. Whitman's staff contacted the Bush campaign and offered to have the Governor make some campaign appearances with Mr. Bush. "It turned out to be a good idea," Ms. Hughes said, "because Mrs. Whitman is a fiscal conservative and budget-cutter who has proven it can be done, and, like George Bush, wants to strengthen the juvenile justice system."
Mrs. Whitman is scheduled to campaign in Arizona for Fife Symington, who is running for re-election as Governor, and later for Gov. Pete Wilson of California before returning to New Jersey on Friday.
Dean R. Armandroff, executive director of the New Jersey Republican State Committee, said Mrs. Whitman's trip grew out of invitations picked up at Republican Governors Association meetings, as well as a desire by Mrs. Whitman to pay back party leaders for help she received during her campaign. In addition, the state party wants to get the Governor and her tax-cutting message around the country, he said.
 
'Other Balls in the Air'
 The New Jersey Republican Party raised the $15,000 to pay for Mrs. Whitman's trip and Mr. Armandroff said it was only the beginning. "We're planning another trip to the Midwest and a tour of the East Coast from New England to Florida before the November election," he said. "And we have other balls in the air."
Brendan T. Byrne Jr., the New Jersey Democratic chairman, said it was not surprising that Mrs. Whitman was using her new celebrity.
"It's not unusual," he said. "You go around the country building chits and denying that you have any national ambitions." But Mr. Byrne said that one thing puzzled him. "She seems to be campaigning for everybody but Haytaian," he said. "She's not raising money in her own backyard."
Garabed Haytaian, the Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, is running against the Democratic incumbent, Frank R. Lautenberg, for United States Senate. Mr. Haytaian has strongly supported Mrs. Whitman's income-tax and budget cuts and a Haytaian campaign aide said talks were under way with the Whitman staff about how to best help him.

HEADLINE: THE GARDEN SALE: THE POLITICS;
State Officials Split on Antitrust Aspects of Garden's Sale

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Two of New York State's highest officials reacted in sharply different manners yesterday to the announcement that the ITT Corporation and Cablevision Systems had agreed to buy Madison Square Garden. Where one saw antitrust concerns, the other saw secure local ownership.
While Gov. Mario M. Cuomo praised the deal, New York State Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell immediately pronounced it flawed. He said that because Cablevision would gain sweeping control over television sports coverage in the New York market, there were significant antitrust concerns, and he announced that he planned to open an antitrust investigation. 
 "You already had great concentration of control and here you eliminate any competition whatsoever," Mr. Koppell said. "At least now, there's an overall competition right now between the networks over the packaging, the entire packaging of sports," he said, referring to the local competition between the Garden's MSG Network and Cablevision's Sportschannel.
But if the Cablevision acquisition proceeds, he said, "you have the owner of the venue, the owner of the teams and the owner of the access to the viewers all in one person."
With the deal, Cablevision will not only own the Knicks and Rangers, but will also televise the Mets, Nets and Devils on its Sportschannel pay-cable outlet and the Knicks, Rangers and Yankees on the MSG Network.
Mr. Koppell said his office had jurisdiction to enforce both New York and Federal antitrust laws and could sue to block the purchase.
Governor Cuomo took a sharply different position. Mr. Cuomo attended the news conference in which the companies announced the transaction and hailed the sale as one that would place the renowned New York City landmark, Madison Square Garden, in the secure hands of companies committed to the city.
"Who owns the Garden is very important to us," he said. "We were eager to see New Yorkers who are vested here, who have ties here, because that gives you more influence with them. If they're from out of town you have no hold on them. So I'm a lot more comfortable with these guys than with someone else."
The other bidder for the Garden, Liberty Media, is based in Denver.
Mr. Cuomo added that he had no antitrust concerns about the deal and said that he was not troubled by suggestions that the price paid by the buyers could ultimately lead to higher rates for households that subscribe to the MSG cable network.
The different postures may represent the varying strategies of the two men to gain the spotlight in an election year.
Mr. Koppell, a former state assemblyman who was named interim Attorney General by the State Legislature in December, faces a hotly contested race in the Democratic primary next month in a field of four major rivals. And Mr. Cuomo, also a Democrat, faces a tough re-election campaign in which his stewardship of the state has been the target of criticism from various aspirants, including State Senator George E. Pataki, his leading Republican rival.
"Their different views on the deal reflect the difference in the offices they hold," said Norman Adler, a political consultant. "The Governor's job is to bring home the bacon and build the economy of the state. The Attorney General is supposed to be a watchdog, seeing that consumers are safeguarded. And they're simply trying to position themselves to be seen by voters as doing their jobs well."
The Madison Square Garden purchase is not the only business deal Mr. Koppell has questioned on antitrust grounds. He also opposed the proposed merger of R. H. Macy & Company and Federated Department Stores, saying that the combination would decrease competition in the New York department store market.

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Off 14.6% in July

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools fell 14.6 percent, to $344.75 million, in July but remained above the level recorded in the same month last year, a trade group reported yesterday.
The Association for Manufacturing Technology said machine tool orders were down from $403.65 million in June, but were 39.2 percent higher than orders in July 1993. Orders for the year so far totaled $2.49 billion, 23.6 percent higher than the $2.02 billion in the corresponding period last year. 
 "Even though there was a 15 percent decline in orders during July, it's interesting to note that this is the highest total for that month since 1979," said Albert W. Moore, president of the association, which is based in McLean, Va.
Machine tool orders are considered a gauge of future economic activity because an increase in orders indicates that manufacturers believe future sales will rise. The monthly report covers metal-cutting and metal-forming machine tools, which are used to make goods from household appliances to aircraft engines.
Domestic orders fell 10.6 percent, to $321.7 million, in July, from $359.85 million in June. They were 39.4 percent higher than the July 1993 level. Export orders fell 47.4 percent, to $23.05 million, in July, from $43.8 million in June. They were up 36.4 percent from a year earlier.
Machine tool shipments in July fell 32.5 percent, to $250.6 million, from $371.3 million in June. But they rose 5 percent from the level of July 1993.
The July machine tool order backlog totaled $1.76 billion, up from $1.67 billion in June. The backlog for July 1993 was $1.5 billion.
