HEADLINE: A Split Over Fed's Role;
Clashes Seen After Vice Chairman Says Job Creation Should Also Be a Policy Goal

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 28

 BODY:
By publicly challenging the views of his boss on the mission of the Federal Reserve Bank, the agency's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, touched off a dispute that could lead to clashes over policy on interest rates, many economists said over the weekend.
Speaking at the Federal Reserve's annual conference here on Saturday, Mr. Blinder called for central banks around the world, including the Fed, to set interest rates so as to pursue low inflation and low unemployment. 
 In the past, however, the agency's chairman, Alan Greenspan, has called for an interest rate policy that focuses on low inflation alone.
Though the disagreement is largely theoretical now, it makes it likely that the nation's two top central bankers would take different positions on interest rates if unemployment rose. Who wins will affect the interest rates that Americans pay on credit cards, car loans and home mortgages.
Unemployment in the United States, which was at 6.1 percent in July, was already so low that Mr. Blinder said a further drop might stoke inflation, which has been running at nearly 3 percent annually. The Federal Reserve has already raised short-term interest rates five times this year, and Mr. Blinder has endorsed those moves.
But economists here predicted that if unemployment rose, Mr. Blinder would be more reluctant than many of his colleagues to raise rates further, producing clashes about policy.
"He does have a different approach and a different opinion," said Richard B. Berner, the chief economist at Mellon Bank.
Mr. Greenspan told a Congressional panel on Aug. 10 that he favored legislation to set zero inflation as the Federal Reserve's sole goal. But Mr. Blinder said this afternoon that the Federal Reserve should pursue the multiple goals set forth in current legislation, which include low inflation and maximum employment.
Mr. Greenspan also said in his testimony on Aug. 10 that any employment gains from allowing inflation to rise were "ephemeral." Yet Mr. Blinder said today that he did not believe that and interest rate increases to control inflation could hurt employment for a year or two.
Mr. Blinder said he agreed with Mr. Greenspan that in the long term -- which he defined as 5 to 10 years -- inflation and interest rates could not be used to hold down unemployment. Still, he characterized his disagreements with Mr. Greenspan as not serious.
 
Chairman on Vacation
 Mr. Greenspan attended the conference from Thursday through Saturday, but went on vacation today and could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Blinder is President Clinton's first appointee to the Federal Reserve Board and one of several candidates to become the next chairman in early 1996, when Mr. Greenspan's term expires. Mr. Greenspan was appointed by President Ronald Reagan in 1987 and reappointed by President George Bush in 1992.
Aspirants to the chairmanship have historically talked tough about inflation and played down the importance of unemployment in an effort to reassure financial markets that they will not allow inflation to rise. That temporarily creates jobs but makes the fixed interest payments on bonds much less attractive.
Several economists here said Mr. Blinder's remarks suggested that he was willing to force his colleagues to confront the social problems created by higher interest rates even at a possible cost to his career. Asked about that in an interview this afternoon, Mr. Blinder said, "I am not going to play to the gallery and I'm going to say what I think." He declined to discuss his future further.
 
View on Employment

Mr. Greenspan has contended that employment issues should be left to the free market and that unemployment will remain low if prices stay stable and companies are confident that they can invest in job-creating new factories and equipment without fear of inflation.
Mr. Berner of Mellon Bank said Mr. Blinder's comments on Saturday were unlikely to have a strong effect on financial markets on Monday. While Mr. Blinder has spoken strongly about a need to focus on reducing inflation since he joined the Federal Reserve Board, he took some of the same positions that he defended today while he was an economics professor at Princeton University. Many on Wall Street think his true views remain those from his academic days, Mr. Berner said.
But other private economists expressed surprise that Mr. Blinder's views had not changed more since he joined the Fed, which, like the Supreme Court, tends to mold the people who serve on it.
Mr. Blinder said on Saturday that even if unemployment were high he would prefer slow to rapid changes in interest-rate policy. "How could I as a central banker argue against gradualism?" he said. "I won't."
Representative Stephen L. Neal, a conservative Democrat from North Carolina, said Mr. Blinder's stance risked higher inflation. "That's exactly what got us in trouble in the late 1970's, the idea that we can fine-tune the economy," he said in a telephone interview from his home in northern Virginia.
But Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Budget Committee and has long criticized the Fed for insensitivity to the unemployed, praised Mr. Blinder today in a telephone interview from Tennessee. "I am greatly encouraged that we have a member of the Federal Reserve now that understands that the Federal Reserve is charged not only with controlling inflation but also with managing the economy to create jobs," he said.
Mr. Blinder sought to assuage some of these concerns in his speech on Saturday. He pointed out that one explanation of the high inflation in the 1970's was that central banks were slow to raise interest rates. While he did not specifically endorse this explanation, he said that if world oil prices rose sharply and American economic output fell, "then it's the duty of the central bank to contract aggregate demand" through higher interest rates.
Mr. Blinder's comments appeared to anger some colleagues, who discussed his speech at a barbecue Saturday night at the end of the conference. One senior Fed official who insisted on anonymity called Mr. Blinder an "outlier" -- an economics term for a point on a graph that is far removed from the other points.
Thomas Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, said in an interview today that he believed Mr. Blinder's remarks on Saturday were consistent with an emphasis on stable prices. But, he added, "I think stable prices are the primary goal."
Unlike several other central bankers here, Mr. Blinder spoke without a prepared text, and his comments were much more blunt than those of his colleagues. In an interview after the speech, he said he was not aware that Mr. Greenspan had publicly endorsed the idea of setting a single target for the Federal Reserve of fighting inflation.
Mr. Blinder took a very different position from that of Mr. Greenspan in what may be the single biggest dispute in monetary economics: whether unemployment can be reduced by allowing higher inflation. Mr. Blinder said the trade-off, known as the Phillips curve, existed for periods of up to a few years. Mr. Greenspan told Congress this summer that the Phillips curve "is dead," except for periods of time so brief as to be unimportant.
Some economists contend that the Federal Reserve has deliberately tried to discredit the Phillips curve to avoid taking responsibility for the unemployment that its interest rate increases can cause as purchases of houses and cars decline, prompting builders and auto makers to lay off workers.
Congressional Democrats amended the Federal Reserve Act in 1978 to require that the central bank pursue "maximum employment, stable prices and moderate long-term interest rates."
Representative Neal has introduced a bill, supported by Mr. Greenspan, that would replace this language with a requirement that the Fed pursue zero inflation. Because of opposition from other Democrats, the bill has never emerged from the House Banking Committee, which oversees monetary policy, and is unlikely to do so soon.

HEADLINE: Crime Fighters Draw A Line in the Grass

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
What convinced Deborah Forde was her scar, the one left by muggers who violently ripped a gold chain from her neck while she was jogging in Prospect Park last year.
For Dante Jordan, it was the memory of having his bike stolen at knife-point. Suzann Bassil simply wanted a little independence. She likes to cycle and does not want to wait for her boyfriend to get off work to accompany her. 
 The three are among 450 Brooklyn residents who have agreed to be on the lookout in Prospect Park as they go about their recreation, carrying phones that dial directly to 911 and wearing vests that identify them to other park users.
 
 
On Rollerblades, on Foot
 The program, begun last week, springs from the success of neighborhood watch groups in which people from the same block band together to fight crime. The volunteers in the new program represent a diverse lot of Brooklynites, coming from various corners of the park -- from Crown Heights to Park Slope -- and different jogs of life.
There is a doctor and a milkman, a retired bird watcher and an unemployed hospital worker. There are bankers, nannies and scrappy teen-agers. Most do not know each other, and they often share very little outside of their love of the park.
Their motivations differ, too. Some have had bad experiences in the park, and are carrying the phones principally to protect themselves. Others have grand dreams of guarding their neighbors from evil. "I want to protect New Yorkers," said Norman Weissman, 50, after dropping by the 78th Precinct to pick up his phone.
And many said that they had seen news reports of the killing of a teacher in the park last year, and of rapes this year, and felt that being armed with a phone and a sense of responsibility, they had at least a psychological edge over those who come to spoil their place of peace.
 
The Last Frontier
 "It's not costing me anything," said Mr. Jordan, who rides his bike in the park daily, now with his phone. "If there is something I can do to make life better for everyone else while feeling safe doing what I love to do, which is ride my bike, why not?"
 For New Yorkers, the local park is often the final frontier in the urban showdown against crime. Though they will step over crushed crack vials on their streets, scurry past vagrants who sleep or shoot up on their stoops, and pay cab fares to avoid the subway at night, they seem unwilling to surrender their right to stroll in their park.
"When you go into a public park, you go in there anticipating freedom," said Barry Tindall, director of the National Recreation and Park Association, an advocacy group for park planners in Arlington, Va. "It's your free time. You've chosen to be there and you let your guard down. And when you feel your space and your body is violated in that time, the feeling is horrendous."
The volunteers in Prospect Park are not trained, nor are they obligated to alter their activities: skating, cycling, sunbathing, strolling, walking dogs, baby-sitting, or just enjoying the park. The idea is simply to be around and alert should trouble find its way into the park.
On Friday night, Paul Kim and his fiancee, Maureen Brogan, both medical students, took their nightly constitutional, zipping twice around the park on Rollerblades. Miss Brogan, 27, sported the bright blue vest, while Mr. Kim wore the black fanny pack that stored the phone. They received smiles and a wave or two from other visitors, but found no use for the phone.
 
 
No Flood of Calls
 All of the dozens of volunteers interviewed said they had not yet needed to call 911, and the police confirm that they have not yet received any reports, but all agreed that the volunteers' presence gives other park visitors a sense that they are somehow more secure.
"This was something that the community needed," said Mr. Kim, 26. "I have a fiancee using the park and I would like it to be safe for her and other women."
Although at 525 acres Prospect Park is smaller than Central Park, it can feel larger and more remote. It has a single drive and no transverse roads, and its 90-acre meadow is shadowed by forest and foliage rather than skyscrapers, giving it the distinct feel of a country hideaway.
Since 1980, the administrators of the park, which was designed by Calvert Vaux and Frederick Law Olmsted, have worked to restore its 1800's grandeur, said Tupper W. Thomas, the park's current administrator. Partly because of those efforts, the park now attracts about 6 million people annually, up from just 1.7 million in 1980.
 
 
Shadows of a Teacher's Death
 On a sunny day this week, when the park was hardly full, the specter of menace seemed almost unimaginable. Rollerbladers whizzed by. A couple sat kissing on a picnic bench. A German shepherd, startled by a lone walker, barked until his owner smacked him lightly on the head and scolded, "Hey, you don't own the park."
But it was in the middle of a similar sunny day last June that Allyn Winslow, a 42-year-old drama teacher, was shot to death as he tried to escape three teen-agers who were trying to steal his new mountain bike.
Last week, in an indication that park-goers may be getting more vigilant, a group of people grabbed and subdued a sex offender who the police say was trying to kidnap a 9-year-old girl, also in the middle of the day.
Cases like these, which have increased in recent years in Prospect Park, are what led the Police Department to approach people earlier this year and ask them if they would carry the cellular phones while in the park between 5 A.M. and 9 P.M.
To the Police Department's surprise, nearly everyone they approached was eager to participate. "I expected to get the minimum," said Sgt. Joseph Lavelle, the "Safe Parks" coordinator for the 78th Precinct. "But instead, we got the maximum."
The program, along with a smaller one in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem, is a pilot that the department hopes to expand to all city parks by next spring. The precinct has already enlisted 450 volunteers, and by late yesterday, had distributed about 200 phones, which were donated by Nynex and Motorola.
 
 
At the 78th Precinct
 Every night last week, the precinct filled after work with volunteers coming to collect their fanny packs, and with other neighborhood residents looking to sign on.
"A friend told me about this," said Ms. Forde, 24, the switchboard operator who lost her gold chain to muggers as she was jogging last year.
Ms. Forde, who lives in Crown Heights, was left with a scar on her neck, but she went right back into the park. "When that happened," she said, "people saw but there was nothing much they could do. There were no phones around."
Unlike many of the volunteers, Suzann Bassil has no children, and she does not consider herself a particularly altruistic sort. Rather, she is enraged by the idea of not being able to venture into the park without fear. "I want to ride my bike alone," she said. "Who wants to wait around for somebody? It becomes tedious."
With that, she grabbed her fanny pack and left the precinct to go home and get ready for a night of peaceful solitude in the park.

HEADLINE: New Wave From Southeast Asia Is Hitting New York Real Estate

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

 BODY:
They seemed to come out of nowhere -- a powerful group of Hong Kong billionaires who appeared in June to revive Donald J. Trump's troubled Riverside South project with millions in cash and a promise to finance the multibillion-dollar development.
But while the names of the new investors were largely unknown here, the size and power of their move into New York came as no surprise to brokers familiar with the recent influx of overseas investment. 
 Over the last two years, a surge of money from Hong Kong and Southeast Asia has swept into the city's battered real-estate market in a variety of high-profile deals. Drawn by bargain prices and a market that offers a haven from the turmoil of speculation in the Far East, those investors, largely ethnic Chinese from Hong Kong and Singapore, have bought some of the city's choice properties.
And while the deals have been modest in number, their size and scope has brokers predicting that the new Asian investors could become the deal makers of the 1990's, driving the real-estate market as the Japanese did in the 1980's, and the Canadians and the Europeans did in the 1970's.
"Ten years ago, it would have been unheard of," said Mr. Trump, who had never dealt with Hong Kong or Southeast Asian investors before the Riverside South deal. "There's a great deal of money and a great deal of expertise in the Far East, and they're beginning to spread their wings."
The Riverside South project is the most notable of the new Asian investments in New York, but in its shadow have been other deals, including the sale of the 1,000-room New York Palace Hotel to interests from Brunei for $202 million in November, the 561-room Hotel Millenium to Singaporean investors for $75 million in February, and an older, 1.1-million-square-foot office building at 40 Wall Street to a Hong Kong group for $8 million last May.
While Asian investors have also bought property on the West Coast, from mini-malls in Los Angeles to sprawling residential and commercial projects in Vancouver, British Columbia, many investors have focused on New York because of its supply of quality buildings and its stature in international trade and finance.
"Chinese firms have just begun to look internationally," said Edmund Yu, president of Kinson Properties, which purchased the Wall Street building for the company's Hong Kong owners. "They figure it is time to come out, and now they have the capital to play with the big boys."
European, Canadian and Japanese companies still have by far the largest holdings of all foreign investors in New York, but the new investors have begun to alter the nature of the market, as Asian companies open offices here to search for potential investments and local brokers learn the ways of doing business with companies from Hong Kong and Southeast Asia.
"Millions are flowing out of Hong Kong now," said Peter Friedman, president of the New York commercial real-estate firm of Peter R. Friedman Ltd. "Two years ago, they weren't even on the scope. This year, they're going to be number one."
The entry of the new Asian investors has been fueled by an enormous buildup of capital in the Far East, much of which was initially invested in Asia and is only now being turned toward the United States.
 
Most Dynamic Area
 For the last decade, the regional economy of China, Hong Kong and Southeast Asia has been the most dynamic in the world. And while Japan still languishes in a recession, economic growth elsewhere in Asia is expected to increase by more than 7 percent next year, nearly triple the pace projected for the United States, according to estimates from the International Monetary Fund.
Like many Asian investors, Mr. Yu said, the owners of Kinson Properties began their forays into real estate by buying in areas they were most familiar with -- in their case, Hong Kong and China. In China alone, the company has invested up to $1.5 billion since the late 1980's, Mr. Yu said.
The company's New York purchase was small in comparison, but was done in part to establish an overseas base, an important consideration for many Hong Kong companies in preparation for the transfer of the British colony to Chinese control in 1997, he said.
Another reason, Mr. Yu added, was that for many Hong Kong investors, buying into New York has become cheap.
Back in the 1980's, top-quality office space in New York went for as much as $500 a square foot. Today, sale prices in the volatile Hong Kong market have risen to about $1,200 a square foot, while New York prices have fallen to about $150 to $200 a square foot for prime office buildings, a level that he believes is as low as it will ever go.
Kinson Properties bought the older building at 40 Wall Street for $7 a square foot, although it has required extensive renovation that will likely push the final cost to around $50 a square foot.
"The differential is just too much," Mr. Yu said. "There is a huge price disparity. They can't understand why people would sell at that price."
The prices in New York in the 1990's dropped substantially from the preceding decade, when Japanese investors helped push the market to high levels.
From 1984 to 1990, the total value of Japanese-owned real estate in New York State, most of which was invested in the city, jumped from $800 million to over $10 billion, according to figures from the Federal Bureau of Economic Analysis.
But after the flurry of buying through the late 1980's, new Japanese investment has dropped off. Investment from the Middle East, Canada and Europe also has slowed from the heady pace of the late 1980's.
Although the Japanese buying led to warnings about the selling of America, the actual Japanese share of the city's real-estate market is small. At best, Japanese companies -- the single largest group of foreign real-estate investors -- own only about 3 percent of the $2.7 trillion in commercial real estate in New York City, according to figures from the real-estate firm of Cushman & Wakefield.
 
Driving the Market
 While their share was small, they represented a significant portion of new investment and were able to drive the prices of the market.
In a similar fashion, brokers in New York say that the new Asian investors have the potential to assume a powerful position in the market. They have concentrated their investments in hotels and properties in financial trouble, which has often allowed them to buy at favorable prices.
The value of property owned by Asian companies, with the exception of those from Japan, is below even 1 percent of all commercial property, according to figures from the Bureau of Economic Analysis.
But at least for the moment, they are striking some of the biggest and most prominent deals.
"Right now, I would guess they are dominating about 50 percent of the buying power in the market," said Darcy A. Stacom, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield who represented the buyers in the 40 Wall Street sale. "If they're willing I could see them eventually matching the share of the Japanese."
One of the largest real-estate purchases in New York City last year was made by the Amedeo Hotels Limited Partnership, which bought the New York Palace Hotel on Madison Avenue for $202 million. The company is owned by the royal family of Brunei, an oil-rich sultanate on the island of Borneo.
 
Quarter of the Action
 The hotel purchase alone accounted for nearly a quarter of the $874 million in commercial property sales in the city last year, according to figures from Cushman & Wakefield.
This year, the attention has been focused on the agreement to build the Riverside South project between Mr. Trump and a group of Hong Kong investors that includes the New World Development Company, headed by Y. T. Cheng and his son, Henry, and the Shui On Group, headed by Vincent Lo.
The Riverside South project covers 75 acres on the Upper West Side of Manhattan along the Hudson River, from 59th to 72d streets.
The $2.5 billion project had been languishing until the arrival of the Hong Kong investors, who purchased Mr. Trump's $250 million debt on the land for $90 million and made a commitment to finance the construction of Riverside South.
Mr. Trump said he had never dealt with investors from Hong Kong or Southeast Asia before, but on this project he found himself facing offers from four Asian companies -- two from Hong Kong, one from Singapore and one from Malaysia. He added that he is currently working with yet another Hong Kong group on a separate commercial and residential development.
Despite the size of the recent investments from Asia, some brokers here caution that the new generation of overseas investors are different from the Japanese and may never become as influential.
 
Extremely Selective
 Jack A. Shaffer, managing director of international sales for the New York real-estate firm of Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, said the new Asian investors had been extremely selective, picking off properties that are selling at bargain prices. Whether they will continue buying as the market moves upward is uncertain, he said.
In addition, the investors have plenty of opportunities in their own backyards, particularly China, where returns can be far higher.
"You've got to remember that they have alternatives," he said. "The major sales in greater New York are coming out of Southeast Asia, but what will happen in the future isn't really that clear yet."
But Paul Chan, the New York representative of the Glorious Sun group from Hong Kong, said he believed the big purchases of the last two years are only the beginning of a larger movement of capital from Asia. His own group spent $32 million on a block on condominiums at Worldwide Plaza, an office and residential development on West 50th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.
Mr. Chan said the crowded Hong Kong real-estate market and the unpredictable nature of real-estate investment in China made New York an appropriate investment for companies seeking a larger international presence.
Even if investment from Hong Kong and Singapore ultimately fades, he added, there are many investors from Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and potentially the biggest player of all, China itself, who are set to enter the fray.
"All the big investors are out there looking," he said. "Just looking at the economic potential of China, I am very confident of investment here in the future."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The Mood Improves On Wall St.

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan is not going to be mean to investors anymore. Or so much of Wall Street now believes.
And if that belief persists, and if confidence grows that the economy and corporate profits will not suffer greatly at the current level of interest rates, the stock rally that surprised Wall Street last week could have a considerable way to go. 
 "I think the next move the Federal Reserve will make will be to reduce interest rates, not to raise them," said Byron Wien, the chief American equity strategist for Morgan Stanley, discussing one reason he expectsthe next big move in stock prices to be up.
 
Data Foster New Mood
 The belief that the Fed, headed by Mr. Greenspan, would not need to raise rates again, after the surprisingly large move on Aug. 16, has been reinforced by a series of economic figures during the last two weeks that pointed to less robust growth.
The new mood helped push the Dow Jones industrial average up more than 125 points, or 3.4 percent, to 3,881.05 last week. All major stock averages are now at their highest points since March.
The happiness with the Fed is in sharp contrast to the mood that has generally prevailed after the previous rounds of credit tightening, beginning in February, which sent bond prices down sharply. But this time, the bond market has reacted reasonably well. Bond prices are generally a bit higher than before the latest Fed move, and short-term interest rates, which are set by the market, have fallen.
 
'Best of All Worlds' Is Seen
 "We really have the best-of-all-worlds scenario here, for the economy and the stock market," says one enthusiastic economist, Edward Yardeni of C. J. Lawrence. He says the evidence indicates the economy is growing in a way that will increase corporate profits without pushing up inflation rates.
In the stock market slump that followed the earlier Fed tightenings, it was professional money managers who showed the most concern. "Individual investors have kept the faith," noted Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Co.
While stock mutual funds have seen the rates of inflow slow from the heady days of earlier this year, investors are still putting money in them, even while money has slowly drained out of bond mutual funds. Corporate insiders have also been buying their own stocks in larger volumes than normal. What has been new in recent days is that professionals now seem to be showing more willingness to invest in stocks.
There is, of course, much more to the stock market rally, which has seen the Dow rise 7.1 percent since late July and left it just 2.4 percent below the peak it set on Jan. 31, a few days before the Fed's first tightening. Signs that the dollar is beginning to strengthen -- it climbed back to more than 100 Japanese yen on Friday -- have begun to draw some European interest, brokers say. There is encouragement about corporate profits, and a strong surge of takeovers.
And there are signs that the prevalent speculation just before the rally was against the stock market. Part of the story of last week's rise was a scramble that occurred as a money manager lost some money on an options trade that had been intended to make money unless the stock market took off quickly.
"The lore says the market always goes down while the Fed is tightening," said Mr. Wien, adding that as stocks traded in a narrow range recently, a lot of money was bet on the thesis that the next big move would be down. When share prices began to leap last week, a lot of those speculators had to buy stocks quickly to cut losses.
There is no guarantee that last week's rally will have any follow-through, and some recent precedent to suggest that it won't. Last week's move in the Dow was the best weekly gain since the week that ended on Feb. 5, 1993, when the Clinton Administration was just getting going. In that week, the index leaped 132 points, or 4 percent. But in the next two weeks the index gave up 120 of those points.
Still, the supply and demand outlook for the market seems to have improved, Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates, a market analysis firm, said. The calendar of new equity offerings is relatively light, reflecting the concern that had gripped many investors until the last two weeks. And the supply of available shares has been depleted by a growing amount of corporate purchases of their own shares -- buybacks -- and of others' shares -- mergers.
That reflects the fact that corporate profits -- and available cash -- seem to be rising at a good clip. Thomas Doerflinger, an investment strategist at Paine Webber, says he expects operating earnings of the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 to rise 16.6 percent this year and 10.1 percent more in 1995. "It is difficult to identify a major sector whose earnings will be down next year," he said.
That would not be true if the economy began to falter. But with other economies growing, Wall Street seems inclined to believe that the economy will avoid both serious inflation and recession, with the economic expansion continuing until 1996.
The consensus is that the Fed, at worst, will stay on the sidelines until after the November election, and that if there is to be one more tightening, that will be the last one. Many think there will be no more tightenings at all.
The change in atmosphere regarding the Fed is traceable in part to the fact that it chose to raise by half a percentage point both the Federal funds rate, the rate banks pay on loans to one another, and the discount rate, the rate banks pay to borrow from the Fed. The consensus forecast had been for a smaller increase in the Federal funds rate and no change in the discount rate.
"People said, 'Wow, the Fed is really serious and maybe this is all they will do,' " Mrs. Cohen said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Yesterday Was Just Perfect for a Ball Game

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
YANKEE STADIUM was like a morgue yesterday. The sun was shining brightly, the field was gorgeous with the manicured grass as green as a pool table, the tan infield dirt was smartly raked. It was a perfect day for a ball game. The first-place Yankees, according to the schedule, were supposed to be playing the Texas Rangers, in the heat of a pennant race. But Yankee Stadium yesterday was as silent as a cadaver.
Except for the soft whir sprinkler system that is run by computers in the stadium basement and which pop up for a time first in right field, and then behind third base, and somewhere else after that, the playing field, the broad, wondrous sweeping diamond, was empty. No runners, no hitters, no one to err. 
 Like the stands. Like all of the 57,545 stark blue seats in the ball park. From the box seats to the grandstands to the bleachers that curve down from the familiar Gothic facade of the roof. Empty. No cheering. No booing. Nothing.
If someone had been held captive in a cave for the last few weeks and was released to see a ball game here and didn't know anything about the strike -- the dispute between the major league owners and the players that is now in its 18th day -- he might have wondered: Had he arrived too late and the game was over? After all, cigarette butts remain in the aisles, and peanut shells, and flattened paper cups. Or maybe there had been a bomb scare, and everyone evacuated. Surely something weird had occurred.
It was reminiscent of a recurring dream that Mickey Mantle had shortly after his retirement. He dreamed of going to a game and not being allowed in. That there were locks on the gates. And he heard his name announced as the next batter. It was a sad dream. A kind of nightmare. For baseball fans now, this, too, is a bad dream come true.
No one there to buy a hot dog that is advertised on a sign in the grandstand. No one to hail a vendor for a Slurpee, as seen on another sign in the outfield. There was no crack of the bat. No smack of a fastball into the catcher's plump mitt. No one to stretch in the seventh and wail "Take Me Out to the Ballgame."
The skeleton crew in the Yankee office was off yesterday. The space in the parking lot reserved for George Steinbrenner's limousine, and those for the cars of his pinstriped employees, was vacant. Only a couple of security men and an engineer were on the premises, to keep things in working order in case someone turned the season back on.
Across the street from the ball park and under the elevated train tracks on River Road, Stan's Sports Bar and Grill is shuttered down. Discount Dugout is closed. As is Baseball Land. Only Stadium Souvenir is open, but the proprietor, Abdul Al Sacahi, says business is dead.
"Very slow, they wreck my business," he said, as a train rumbled over head. He held up a slip of paper. "Here, this is my bill for the rent. $4,500. I can't pay it. Maybe have to close up next week. They told me they don't know when strike will be over. They told me maybe next month. Maybe next year. Have you heard anything?"
No one knows, unless it's the owners. And they are gagging themselves.
On the other side of Yankee Stadium is Macombs Dam Park, with a sign above a handball court that reads, "We Do Care. New York Yankees Neighborhood Project 2." There is also a basketball court and a ball field. Games were on both.
The basketball court was a center of controversy earlier in the season when Richard Kraft, the Yankees' vice president in charge of community relations, was forced to resign after supposedly telling a magazine reporter that kids hung "like monkeys" from the rims.
"Most of us don't try to hang from the rims," said Abe Johnson, one of the Sunday morning players, who works in computers for Smith Barney. "We like the rims straight. But maybe one or two of the younger kids was trying to imitate the pros."
How did he feel about the major league situation? "Baseball is commercialism," said Johnson. "And I think there's greed on both sides. But I majored in economics, and I know it's likely that the owners have two sets of books."
At the ball field, there was, unlike the big white structure across the road, a ball game in progress. It was a kids' game between the green-and-white uniformed Rosado Design team and the red-and-white NatWest nine.
"I told you to swing only at strikes, Irvin," said a coach to a player.
"It was a strike," said the player.
"It almost hit you in the head -- how can you call that a strike?" said the coach.
Another hitter lined a single. "Way to rip, Jacob!" came a shout from the bleachers.
The players were playing on a field with grass up to their ankles. A Stadium groundskeeper could have done wonders in minutes.
"It's a shame," said Dennis Centeno, the NatWest coach. "One of my kids could get hurt because you can't see the holes in the field."
It was a hot day under the sun. There were two water fountains nearby, but both were broken. "My players are thirsty and there's nothing to drink, so I have to run to the store to buy them juice," said Centeno. "I know the Yankees have a sign that says they care. But how much?"
One player wondered if any Yankees were in the park. "What's wrong with you?" said a teammate. "Do you think they're playing dominoes? It's a strike!"
Some around the Stadium thought the owners right, some the players. Like some editorial writers, some thought neither was right. But if, in America, one side, the players, are seeking only to maintain their position of being paid for what they can command in the open market, what's so wrong?
In Yankee Stadium now, the water fountain in the dugout was dusty. The railings in the vacant stands sparkled in the sunlight. But all that bespoke of baseball were the silent monuments in center field. The ghosts of Ruth and Gehrig and DiMaggio and Mantle.
It was a perfect day for a ball game. But all was still. Like a morgue.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two and a half weeks into the strike, Yankee Stadium, the big ball yard in the South Bronx, remains empty. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Nonmusicals, New York Is Still The Field of Dreams

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Robert Falls, the artistic director at the Goodman Theater here, was talking about New York and its current, difficult-to-define place in the American theater universe.
"There's no doubt the whole romantic notion of Broadway as a place to open a play does not apply anymore," he said, giving voice to a widely held view that the most glamorous commercial-theater venue in the world is no longer hospitable to nonmusical dramas. "It's been completely usurped by the regionals." 
 Yet, he acknowledged, Broadway aside, New York is still the place where plays go for the imprimatur of quality (or at least commercial viability) necessary for a life beyond its original production. Indeed, in recent interviews that focused on the relationship between theater in New York and elsewhere in the country, executives at several institutional theaters here and on the West Coast said that in spite of the rise of the regionals in recent years, New York still exerts its primacy over what appears on stages nationwide.
 
The Press, Talent and Theaters
 One reason, of course, is that New York is where the most influential press is.
A second is that New York is where much of the talent is. All the large regional companies, and many of the small ones, look to New York to cast their shows. Many artistic directors of regional theaters have substantial New York directing credits, including Mr. Falls (whose "Suburbia" is now completing a summerlong run at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center) and Daniel Sullivan of the Seattle Repertory Company ("The Sisters Rosensweig" on Broadway and "The Merry Wives of Windsor" in Central Park), to name just two among many.
A third is that New York is still where the heart of the commercial theater is, Off Broadway as well as on. Plays like David Mamet's "Oleanna," first produced at the Orpheum Theater Off Broadway, and now Edward Albee's "Three Tall Women" (which may be produced this season at the Steppenwolf Theater Company here) are the latest proof that a celebrated New York run, even in an out-of-the-way theater, can translate into a long life in other cities. Theaters all over the country fill their schedules with shows that have proved to be hits in New York. And though none of the directors interviewed said they chose their productions with the prospect of moving them to New York, all acknowledged that the revenue their productions can generate if they get there is extremely gratifying.
 
'At the Big Table'
 "Everyone dreams of the oil well," said Gordon Davidson, the artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, "the benchmark being 'A Chorus Line,' " the show that generated millions of dollars for the New York Shakespeare Festival.
Jack O'Brien, the artistic director of the Old Globe Theater in San Diego, said, "You have to be able to play cards at the big table."
Mr. O'Brien, the director of the current Broadway revival of "Damn Yankees," which originated at the Old Globe, added: "Something like 'Damn Yankees' used to be the exception. Now it's what you have to bring to the table in order to survive."
As a result, if New York City is no longer the source, the place where all theater starts, it has become more of a hub, the place where everything checks in before heading elsewhere. It's a rare play -- Jane Martin's "Keely and Du" and Pearl Cleage's "Flyin' West" are current exceptions -- that makes the rounds of American theaters without stopping in New York.
"I'm trying to think of the last time we sent something somewhere else but New York," said Mr. Falls, who is the director of "Suburbia," Eric Bogosian's new play, which opened not at the Goodman, but at Lincoln Center at the Newhouse . "It's been a long time, I'll tell you."
 
'New York Is Always the Goal'
 He finally came up with Scott McPherson's "Marvin's Room," which in 1990 moved to the Hartford Stage after opening at the Goodman the previous year. But that show turned out to be on its way to New York. After Hartford, it went to Playwrights Horizons, and then on to a commercial run Off Broadway. Since then it has been everywhere.
"New York is always the goal," Mr. Falls said. "You'd like to say that the regional theaters have usurped that, but no. If 'Suburbia' had been produced at the Goodman, I don't think there would be as many theaters clamoring to produce it as there are now."
Stephen Eich, the managing director of the Steppenwolf Theater Company here, agreed that New York was still the prime economic force in the theater, but he portrayed its role in the relationship between it and the regionals as less benign, more of a monster that needs to be fed.
The empty theaters on Broadway, he said, in spite of the forbidding economics of producing plays there, have turned Broadway producers particularly ravenous. During the last several seasons, Steppenwolf has sent three productions to Broadway -- "The Grapes of Wrath," "The Song of Jacob Zulu" and "The Rise and Fall of Little Voice" -- with varying degrees of critical acclaim. None have made their money back, even though "Grapes" won a 1991 Tony for best play. The theater had far better luck with such previous shows as "Orphans" and "True West," plays that moved to Off Broadway theaters and then went on to longer lives.
 
'So Weird Out There'
 "The productions we've taken to New York lately have been drawn to New York by interest from New York," Mr. Eich said. "And the atmosphere is so weird out there. There's maybe a kind of desperation. That it's so barren out there has maybe warped perspective."
He couldn't help adding, however: "It's not like we wouldn't consider it again."
Mr. Davidson, who founded the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles in 1967, remembered that during the 60's, the decade in which the regional-theater movement took hold, the shows produced outside New York were largely lesser works by the greatest playwrights.
"I would say, somewhat sarcastically but not entirely, that a typical regional-theater season had one Shaw, one Shakespeare, one Chekhov, one Arthur Miller and one Tennessee Williams," he said. "And whenever possible you did a play that had fallen into the public domain, so you didn't have to pay for the rights. In those days, if I called an agent and said, 'Do you have any new plays?,' they'd laugh at me, or send me stuff rejected by all the Broadway producers."
Now, of course, he said, the opposite is true, with the larger goal being to develop new works and send them off into the world for the most prosperous possible lives.
"Very few plays are perfect," Mr. Davidson said. "They either need more work, or they need the Good Housekeeping seal of approval." The latter, he said, is what New York provides.
The current production at the Taper is "The Waiting Room," a new play by Lisa Loomer, about the exploitation of women by men and medicine.
"I don't know if it will be a success," he said, in an interview conducted while the show was in previews. "But if it touches an audience, I will try and see it gets around. My main concern is prolonging life for a play. Going to New York will help that."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gordon Davidson, Mark Taper Forum, L.A. -- 'Everyone dreams of the oil well.' (Steve Goldstein for The New York Times); Jack O'Brien, Old Globe Theater, San Diego -- 'You have to be able to play cards at the big table.' (Ken Howard for The New York Times); Robert Falls, Goodman Theater, Chicago -- 'New York is always the goal.' (Cynthia Howe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Speak Louder on Rights in China

 BODY:
Commerce Secretary Ron Brown, now in China with an entourage of U.S. executives, is being spared the personal humiliations showered on his Cabinet colleague, Warren Christopher, last March. Those spring tantrums achieved their goal of convincing the Clinton Administration to drop all human rights conditions for China's tariff privileges. Though Mr. Brown yesterday promised to raise human rights concerns with his hosts, he has made it clear that commerce is his priority.
Beijing is showing its appreciation by upgrading the Commerce Secretary's protocol status to "Presidential envoy." But on matters of substance, China has given the Administration little to show for its human rights retreat. 
 Mr. Brown arrived amid reports that Qin Yongmin, who protested against China hosting the 2000 Olympic Games, has been beaten and mutilated in a prison labor camp. Wang Dan, a student leader in the Tiananmen Square movement, was briefly detained Saturday after weeks of surveillance. Wei Jingsheng, China's leading democracy activist, who was harassed during Mr. Christopher's visit, soon after disappeared into the labyrinth of China's penal system and has not been heard from since.
As for Mr. Clinton's original human rights conditions, progress went into reverse the day the President changed his policy. As The Times's Patrick Tyler reports, China has continued to round up democracy, labor and religious activists, including some it had previously released, like Mr. Wei. It has broken off talks with the Voice of America over jamming of its broadcasts and dropped discussions with the Red Cross about humanitarian visits to prisons. China has also toughened its terms for talking to Washington about proliferation issues.
This tough-minded behavior should come as no surprise. While Beijing always reacts badly to public pressure, it never concedes anything when it believes there is no penalty for refusing.
How can the United States now recover its human rights credibility? One way would be for Mr. Brown to persuade American businessmen to adopt a voluntary code of conduct, which would assure minimal labor standards, restrict business cooperation with political surveillance activities and prohibit dealing with suppliers that use prison labor.
Another would be to begin loosely linking progress on particular U.S. grievances to relevant aspects of the official U.S.-China relationship. For example, progress on Voice of America broadcasts could be linked to the frequency of ceremonial visits by high U.S. officials, progress on proliferation to military cooperation and progress on prison labor exports to Chinese membership in the World Trade Organization. Perhaps other links could be found that would make Beijing more eager to permit Red Cross visits and release prominent dissidents.
These loose linkages need not insist on perfect performance, merely good-faith efforts measurable by results. Meanwhile, none of the new links should be interpreted to preclude actions that directly serve obvious American interests, such as holding high-level talks on North Korea.
If Mr. Clinton is at all serious about defending human rights in China, Cabinet officers like Mr. Brown need to use their private meetings to convince Chinese leaders that the quality of their relations with the United States will in part depend on how they treat their own people.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Cuban Overture

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Will the principle that guides Clinton Administration domestic policy also be applied to foreign affairs?
The bedrock principle, as it has evolved from Bunker Hill to the White House bunker, is this: Don't run until you see the whites of their eyes. 
 Using this key, readers of prognosticatory harangues in this space were able to discern beforehand the passage of the Republican-deporked crime bill, as well as the President's sudden willingness to let Congress go home to mull over ever-less-toxic health legislation.
Now let us apply it to the mini-crisis precipitated by Fidel Castro. Like Marshal Foch at the Marne, with his center giving way and his flanks collapsing, the nemesis of modern American Presidents has dispatched from his teeming shores the refuse Communism made wretched.
Castro used this technique of immigration aggression and dissident-dumping on Jimmy Carter successfully 14 years ago. In 1994, however, the U.S. President properly chose to defend our border.
The determined Clinton reaction set hard-liner hearts to racing. He interdicted the pitiable raft armada at sea; he reversed a policy that automatically granted Cuban economic refugees the asylum of the politically persecuted; he turned Guantanamo into a Cuban colony under American protection; he tightened the embargo of three decades by cutting off the flow of hard currency sent in by relatives in the U.S.
That's a vigorous response to aggression, at once harsh and humane and expensive, the foreign-policy equivalent of a 1,400-page comprehensive health plan. Now comes the reaction to his swift reaction.
Democratic accommodationists, led by Chris Dodd in the Senate and Lee Hamilton in the House, argue that Clinton is playing to Castro's hands by martyring him. They would go along with the dictator's demands for normalization of relations.
Republican hawks like Senator Richard Lugar, forgetting that the Reagan arms-race stressing of the Soviet system helped bring down Communism in Russia, also want to do business with Castro. They see Cuban Communism's demise in a wave of trade and tourism and cultural exchange, although that approach hasn't quite worked in China.
Everybody worries about riots in the holding pens, led by Castro's implanted provocateurs, which would cast Americans in the role of Israelis abusing Palestinians in camps.
Mr. Clinton, observing the charge of the detenteniks begin, does not yet see the whites of their eyes. Instead, he feels the heat from the Cuban-American community, led by stalwart anti-Castroists, and worries about losing the State of Florida to a Republican tide if he caves in too quickly.
That is why we see "mid-level" talks beginning, limited "strictly" to the topic of immigration. In time, these will escalate to upper-level exchanges at the U.N. or Guantanamo, or semi-private intercessions under a cigar smoke screen (Jimmy Carter's bags are packed), on what our diplomats will call "a wider range of bilateral concerns."
Before allowing Castro to extort an end to the embargo in return for taking back his refugees, however, Mr. Clinton needs to show some muscle elsewhere (the equivalent of his firm stand against assault weapons in the crime bill).
This suggests the October Non-Surprise, the multinational, multicultural, multimedia invasion of Haiti, with air cover by CNN, with the Congressional Black Caucus in the second wave to take the surrender, and with a nice boost in the polls for Mr. Clinton before Election Day.
Then, with the eyes of his Congressional and editorial critics getting close enough to show their whites, Mr. Clinton will declare Mr. Castro to be a new democrat, whose promises of "market socialism" mean the end of Communism in our hemisphere. End of embargo, end of refugee problem, and a revived dictatorship in Cuba for Castro, who logically expects to outlast Mr. Clinton in office.
As an unreconstructed interventionist and human rightsnik, I root for our military ouster of the Haitian junta and a continued squeeze on Castro until Cuban patriots do their duty.
But if the Clinton foreign policy is bottomed on the same principle that undergirds his domestic politics, then we can soon expect to be singing "Sand in my shoes, sand of Havana . . ."

HEADLINE: PENSION CHANGES RAISING CONCERNS

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
American businesses in increasing numbers are turning away from the pension plans that have provided retirement income for millions since the Depression. Instead, they are asking workers to pay for and manage their own retirement plans -- and, left on their own, Americans are not doing a very good job of it.
For decades, the American private pension system has been dominated by plans that promise a steady benefit check from the company to the worker from retirement to death. But, with astonishing swiftness, these plans are being overtaken by 401(k) plans, which require workers to put in their own money for retirement and make their own decisions on how to invest it. 
 More than 40 million Americans now have a 401(k) plan, up from hardly any 15 years ago. Yet many workers are not setting aside enough money in such plans, they are poorly investing what they do save and are frequently turning to these retirement accounts to cover everything from medical bills to houses to cars.
The result, some say, is a crisis in the making. As corporate paternalism is replaced by employee self-reliance, millions of Americans could be left with insufficient retirement savings.
"For many retirees, the money won't be there, and this will have a direct effect on most Americans' standard of living," said J. Carter Beese Jr., a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission who specializes in 401(k) plans. "A lot of participants in 401(k) plans are not doing a good job. They are not investing well and leagues of them may be retiring at subsistence levels from their 401(k) plans. That has tremendous implications for the economy."
The number of workers under 401(k) plans is expected to continue to grow sharply, while the number of workers in traditional plans falls. Already the more than 40 million Americans in 401(k) plans exceeds the 36.5 million in traditional plans. And the number of traditional pension plans has fallen by 40 percent, to 99,000, in the last four years, while the number of 401(k) plans has grown 12 percent, to 609,000.
 
Onus For Investing Changes With Plans
 At many large companies, a 401(k) is a supplement to an existing pension plan, but many of these companies are expected to limit their pension benefits and ask workers to rely more on their 401(k) programs.
Typical of Americans juggling future needs against current ones in their retirement plans is Richard Wimmer, a Chicago lawyer. With three children, Mr. Wimmer has used his plan for a loan to buy a car. But he knows it comes at a price. "I try to take loans only when the markets are bad so I don't hurt my investment returns," he said.
The 401(k) plan, named after a section in the Internal Revenue Service code that created it, has been around since 1978. In such a plan a worker puts a percentage of his or her pretax earnings into an investment account, where the money grows tax-free until retirement. Most 401(k) plans offer an array of investments, mostly mutual funds.
The 401(k) differs from the traditional pension plan in some basic ways. A traditional plan is paid for by the employer. A 401(k) plan is paid for primarily by the worker, though some companies offer a small additional contribution.
A traditional plan guarantees that the company will pay a monthly check, based on what the worker earned, from the time he or she retires until death -- however long that might be. By contrast, a 401(k) plan provides one lump sum, the size of which is determined by the amount the worker saved during his working years and how well he invested it.
In the late 1980's the 401(k) became more popular as employers sought a low-cost way of offering retirement plans. And workers like them also, for the fact that they can watch their investments grow -- in contrast to pension plans, where the dollars multiply invisibly. In addition, unlike corporate pension plans, which require that workers stay for five years to receive future benefits, the 401(k) allows workers to leave for another employer at any time and take the money with them.
For many small employers, the choice often comes down to offering a 401(k) plan or nothing. For about 16 million Americans, mostly at smaller companies, the 401(k) is their sole retirement plan. With half of the American work force lacking any retirement plan, the 401(k) looks good.
"The cold, hard reality of 401(k) plans is that the companies used to pay for retirement plans and now the worker does," said Roger Hurtog, chief executive of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a leading money management firm. "In a corporate plan, you were assured of a retirement payment. Now it is totally up to you. Workers have lost, big time."
Added Eric Russell, a director at the Frank Russell Trust Company, an investment counselor: "401(k) plans are not all they are cracked up to be. They offer employers a way to get off the liability hook for pension plans. And the people these plans are designed to help don't understand the magnitude of responsibility they've been handed. Until they understand this, 401(k)'s won't work."
 
Scaling Back 'Dinosaur' Plans
 Traditional pension plans, of course, are still alive and well at large corporations, especially those with unionized workers. And there is overlap: fully 97 percent of large corporations offer not only a traditional pension plan but also a 401(k) plan, according to a Greenwich Associates survey of 1,100 such companies.
Still, only about 15 percent of all American workers have the luxury of two plans, according to the Labor Department. And while many large corporations are not eliminating their pension plans, the trend is toward limiting them, by reducing benefits or capping cost-of-living increases, for example, and improving the 401(k) plan.
"Corporate pension plans will be dinosaurs," said David Ball, a Washington lawyer who served as an Assistant Secretary of Labor in the Bush Administration. "They will still be around. But no one is creating any new ones, and gradually their significance will diminish."
For instance, at the Dayton Hudson Corporation, a large retailing company, the pension plan has recently been scaled back to cap payments for the highest-paid workers, and the 401(k) plan has been improved with a bigger matching contribution.
"Corporate pensions are the last vestiges of paternalism," said Fred Hamacher, vice president of compensation and benefits at the company. "Workers are having to do more for their retirement on their own. We've tweaked our formula slightly more toward the 401(k)."
"There is a very distinct shift," said William Hubert, manager of corporate benefits at the Polaroid Corporation, which has two plans, but is contributing more to its plan that includes a 401(k). "The company can't do it all. It's no longer realistic to expect to work for 30 years and then retire comfortably for 30 years on a corporate pension. Today, we have to share, and there is much more emphasis on encouraging the worker to save for himself."
 
Not Enough Money And Bad Investing
 Some companies, mostly small ones, have replaced their traditional pension plan with a 401(k) plan. Other young companies are choosing 401(k) plans over traditional pension plans. One example: Tellabs Operations Inc., a telecommunications equipment manufacturer in Lisle, Ill. "We're a young company, with a young work force," said David Southard, the company's director of human resources. "We decided to let them make their own retirement decisions."
As an employer, the Federal Government is also part of this trend. In 1984, it made its pension plan less generous and expanded its 401(k) plan. That arrangement now covers the more than half of Federal workers who were hired since then.
But as 401(k) plans grow, concerns mount. Too few workers, especially young and lower-income workers, are putting away enough money. And higher-paid workers -- those who earn more than $64,000 a year -- who may want to put aside more money cannot because of Federal limits. What is more, at all income levels, people are making bad investments and pulling out too much money for loans.
In contrast to the professional money managers who invest for a traditional pension plan, many workers continue to shun stocks, the investment that has best outpaced inflation during the last 50 years. Instead, many favor lower-yielding investments like money market funds that may not provide enough for their future needs. Or, workers buy the stock of their own company -- in spite of exhortations to diversify their holdings into a broad array of investments.
For example, 80 percent of all new dollars flowing into Texaco Inc.'s 401(k) program, which has 18,000 employees, go into either Texaco stock or money market funds. While these may seem safe in the short run, they are the riskiest choice in the long term, providing neither diversification nor protection against inflation. Only about 20 percent of the Texaco dollars go into an array of mutual funds that investment professionals say are better suited for retirement planning.
At the Xerox Corporation, nearly 60 percent of the $1.5 billion of employees' 401(k) money is invested in bond investments, often with low yields. And 70 percent of the 401(k) money at Public Service Electric and Gas Company in Newark is in a low-yielding guaranteed investment contract, a form of annuity. These investment decisions came in spite of programs at Texaco, Xerox and Public Service Electric and Gas aimed at educating employees about wise investments.
And employers report that conservatism has nothing to do with salary or schooling. For instance, even Michelle Varnhagen, a Senate staff member giving advice on the nation's pension policies, has most of her 401(k) money in a cautious Treasury-bill fund. "It's hard to find the spare time to think about how to invest my money," Ms. Varnhagen said.
 
 
Withdrawals Deplete Workers' Nest Eggs
 Equally troubling is the tendency of workers to pull money out of their 401(k) plans -- either as loans or as outright withdrawals. More than 38 percent of workers switching jobs took money out of their 401(k) plans and spent it, according to the Employee Benefits Research Institute. And the demand for loans from 401(k) accounts has been so strong that some companies, including Public Service Electric and Gas and Texaco, have had to limit loans to two per worker.
"Probably most disturbing is the large number of people who make withdrawals from their 401(k) plan for frivolous things, like buying a car," said Richard Quinn, director of corporate benefit planning and services at Public Service Electric and Gas.
Some argue that the loan provisions should be eliminated. "Why should our tax system subsidize people who use their 401(k) money to buy boats and cars, and that's what they are doing," said Robert Wuelfing, president of Access Research, an investment advisory firm.
Others, however, have more pressing reasons for the loans. For instance, Sandra Smith, a sales supervisor at a Baltimore insurance agency, took out a loan on her 401(k) account this year to pay her daughter's medical bills and to cover moving expenses. "I needed the money now," Ms. Smith said. "I'm 28 years old and far from my retirement years. I didn't think that taking a little bit today would hurt at retirement."
And rates of participation among lower-paid workers and young workers are disturbingly low. At the Marriott Corporation, only 35 percent of the company's hourly workers put money in the company's 401(k) plan, compared with 70 percent of management employees. "The hourly workers often don't have enough money to put aside," said Deborah R. Iwig, a personnel vice president at Marriott.
As a result of these trends, many are painting a bleak picture for the future. If workers lack enough money to retire, they may refuse to. To cut their work forces, many corporations may then have to pay their older workers more to get them off the payroll.
"If there is not enough money in 401(k) plans, a lot of workers will stay working," said Howard Fine, a partner at Hewitt Associates, an actuarial firm. "And the fact that people are living longer means they may have to retire later, or that others will have to be taxed more to cover them."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 30, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about changes in retirement plans misspelled the surname of a top executive at the money management firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. He is Roger Hertog. The article also misstated his position. He is the president, not the chief executive.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Advice That Employees Often Ignore"
 
START EARLY: Start participating in the plan as early as possible. The earlier you start, the more you will have for retirement. Plan ahead by estimating how much you will need for retirement.
 
CONTRIBUTE TO YOUR LIMIT: Invest as much as you can afford, up to the annual limit, to take full advantage of the tax benefits and any employer match.
 
DIVERSITY: Maintain a diversified investment program that includes stocks for growth, bonds or guaranteed investment contracts for income, and short-term money market-securities for safety. Your company stock should not represent the bulk of your stocks because a single stock is riskier than a diversified portfolio.
 
GO FOR GROWTH: If you have a long time until retirement - more than 10 years - and can accept moderate risk, place primary emphasis on common stocks, which have historically provided superior returns. They are the best inflation hedge over the long term. Avoid being too conservative.
 
HOLD THE COURSE: Maintain your investment program throughout up and down cycles of the stock and bond markets. You'll do better than by trying to time the markets.
 
DON'T UNDERESTIMATE INFLATION: If you are approaching retirement, you should still have growth potential in your plan to guard against inflation after you retire. Even a 4 percent rate of inflation cuts the purchasing power of a dollar in half over 20 years.1

HEADLINE: Change Begins at Home In Hamilton Fish District

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 23

 BODY:
For as long as anyone can remember, a Hamilton Fish has represented the mid-Hudson River region in Congress. The family traces its conservative roots to the nation's birth.
This year, with the incumbent Hamilton Fish having decided not to seek a 14th term in the House of Representatives because of poor health, the dynasty may end. If it does not, there will still be a major change. The Hamilton Fish currently seeking the seat, the incumbent's son, is a Democrat. 
 Last week, Hamilton Fish Jr. received his father's endorsement in the Sept. 13 primary. Representative Fish has declined to back any of his seven fellow Republicans in that primary.
Two other Democrats are seeking their party's nomination.
 
Changes in District
 New York's 19th Congressional District, once heavily Republican, is much more balanced since the 1990 redistricting that extended its southern border deep into Westchester County. All of Putnam County and parts of Dutchess and Orange counties make up the rest of the district, which now encompasses 113,400 registered Republicans, 91,200 Democrats and 87,000 unaffiliated voters.
The first Democrat to seek the Congressional nomination was Dennis Mehiel of Armonk, a businessman and a former chairman of the Westchester Democratic Party.
Mr. Mehiel, who has contributed $250,000 to his own campaign and expects to raise an additional $300,000 to pay for radio and television ads, took aim at Mr. Fish in one of his first television ads.
"Hamilton Fish Jr. owned a magazine that printed anti-Semitic articles and said, 'Hey, don't blame me. I'm only the publisher,' " the ad said.
 
Article by Gore Vidal
 The magazine was The Nation and the 1986 article, by Gore Vidal, attacked the publisher, Norman Podhoretz. Mr. Mehiel said that the article "portrays Jewish-Americans as not owing their first loyalty to America, the country of their citizenship, perpetuating a charge that has been leveled against Jews over the centuries."
The charge of anti-Semitism created a stir in the district, with the backers of Mr. Fish saying that the article was not anti-Semitic and that it was fair comment in a journal of opinion.
"Negative campaigning is offensive and turns off voters," Mr. Fish said. He added, "The voters in this district will reject the message and the messenger."
Mr. Fish, who no longer publishes The Nation, is now a senior adviser to Human Rights Watch, which monitors 70 governments around the world to enforce compliance with human-rights standards.

 
Shift to Economic Issues
 Although the Mehiel ad is still being shown, he and Mr. Fish are focusing on economic issues in the district, particularly the widespread layoffs among white-collar workers.
Mr. Mehiel campaigns on a platform of economic renewal and job creation. He says he worries that young college graduates and those trained for other jobs "cannot raise their own families where they grew up" and he proposes Federal tax credits for job creation.
Mr. Fish favors Federal assistance in expanding new technologies and exploring new global markets, as well as simplifying the paperwork required of business and easing of credit.
This is not the first time that Mr. Fish, who lives in Garrison, and Mr. Mehiel have faced each other politically. They lost a three-way primary for the 20th Congressional District in 1988 to Nita M. Lowey, who went on to defeat the Republican incumbent, Joseph J. DioGuardi.
 
A Change of Plans
 The third Democrat seeking the nomination, Neil McCarthy of Lewisboro, was the party's nominee in 1992, losing to Representative Fish. Mr. McCarthy, a lawyer and former Federal prosecutor, had not intended to run again, but he changed his mind, an aide said, with Representative Fish's decision to retire.
He has the support of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. and uses house parties and small gatherings to raise money and gain political support. "My campaign is more grass roots and door-to-door than Mehiel, who has the money, or Fish, who has the name," he says.
The Republican contenders include Mr. DioGuardi, who moved into the 19th District to run for the seat being vacated by Mr. Fish. Describing himself as the most conservative candidate in the race, he urges voters to "Re-elect DioGuardi" and says his old 20th District included 200,000 Westchester residents who are now in the 19th.
Mr. DioGuardi, an exuberant campaigner, advertises himself as "the only certified public accountant to have been elected to Congress."
 
Party Worker Running
 The Republican slate includes one woman, Sue W. Kelly of Katonah, who works in a hospital as a patient advocate. She said she has been "involved for 14 years in the Republican Party, helping to put people in office." Now, she said, "I've decided to run for myself." She expects to spend $300,000 on the primary campaign.
"I'm not running as a politician, nor as a woman," she said, "but as a person caught in the same economic trap as everyone else in the region."
Guy Parisi, a Chappaqua lawyer who has long been active in Republican Party ranks, was the choice of the Westchester party chairman, Anthony J. Colavita. But despite such support, the party convention in June was unable to reach a consensus, throwing the decision into a rare Republican primary.
Mr. Parisi, a former village justice and Albany lobbyist for Westchester County, has the advantage of enlisting party loyalists to help reach the Republicans who vote in primaries.
 
Four Veterans in Race
 Four of the Republican candidates have military credentials. One is a nine-term Assemblyman, Glenn E. Warren of Fishkill, a Marine helicopter pilot in Vietnam who was shot down three times. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross twice. His political base is in Dutchess County.
Paul W. Bucha of Somers, a graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point, which is in the district, won the Congressional Medal of Honor in Vietnam. He says he has been involved in international finance, marketing and real estate for 15 years.
John Flanagan Jr., of Brewster, is a brigadier general in the Air Force Reserve, as well as an author, lecturer and consultant. He flew 300 missions in an unarmed spotter plane in Vietnam and was awarded the Silver Star. He is a faculty member in transportation management at St. Francis College and St. John's University in New York.
He says jobs and crime are the major issues in the district, favors military intervention in Haiti to "restore democracy," and says he offers the financial knowledge of a businessman, the vision of a professor, the leadership of a military officer and the objectivity of an author.
Another candidate, Joseph M. Corrigan of Wappingers Falls, has devoted his campaign almost entirely to the issue of servicemen missing in action in Vietnam. A former marine, he has played a role in negotiating for their release, acting as a link between Hanoi and Washington.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 1, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the Congressional race in the 19th District in New York State referred incorrectly to Norman Podhoretz. He is the editor in chief of Commentary magazine, not a publisher.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
