HEADLINE: Home Health Care Is Gaining Appeal

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
Cheryl Corrins pulls up to the brick, split-level house of Margaret Savinis, 93 years old, a widow for 54 years and a long-retired cook. Mrs. Savinis waits cheerfully at the head of the dinner table in a nightgown and robe, in front of a centerpiece of daisies that a great-grandchild brought from his wedding.
"I come three times a week," Mrs. Corrins says, "and the nurse comes the other days. I give her a shower and once a week shampoo her hair. Take her pulse and blood pressure. Change the dressing on her ear." 
 Mrs. Savinis has skin cancer that has spread from her right cheek to her ear. To treat her, Mrs. Corrins slips on thin plastic gloves and lays out a white cloth, a cleaning solution, cotton swabs and gauze pads. She drains the lesion on her patient's ear and replaces the bandage. Then she dabs ointment on Mrs. Savinis's shoulder to relieve a burn from radiation treatments. "She's an angel of mercy, I tell you," Mrs. Savinis says.
 
Fastest Growing Job
 Mrs. Corrins, 39, is in demand these days, visiting four or five patients a day in Pittsburgh's southeastern neighborhoods. The growing demand for home care has made home health aide the fastest-growing occupation, in terms of percentage, among all those monitored by the Government, and it has helped make health care, over all, the nation's fastest growing provider of jobs.
Even without taking into account whatever success President Clinton has in trying to overhaul the health care system, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts that the number of home health aides will soar to 827,000 by the year 2005, compared with 347,000 in 1992.
Home health care is one of the few growing occupations that offer workers with only a high school diploma wages approaching those of the manufacturing jobs that the nation has been losing. With training, regular retraining, Medicare accreditation and 13 years on the job, Mrs. Corrins earns $11.13 an hour, plus health benefits and 29 cents a mile for use of her car. Registered nurses earn about $17 per hour for home care, which more of them are providing.
 
No Layoffs
 Mrs. Corrins's employer is the Home Health Agency, a part of South Hills Health System, a private provider that starts aides at $9.56 an hour. It requires two years' experience, usually at nursing homes or hospitals. It also requires aides to pass a 50-question, multiple-choice test on medicine, nutrition and psychology.
The work is secure. The agency's executive director, Cathy Frasca, said that in 31 years in business "we have never had a layoff."
Home health care is growing because the old and infirm prefer their homes to institutions, said Val J. Halamandaris, president of the National Association for Home Care in Washington, a lobbying group.
In Mrs. Savinis's case, home is with her daughter, Irene Pascuzi. "I wouldn't give up my mother for all the money in the world," said Mrs. Pascuzi, a widow. "She'll never be put in a nursing home."
 
Underlying Economics
 The aging of the population also contributes to the demand. So does technology that allows patients at home to have services like intravenous feeding and chemotherapy. But the most important reason may be economic.
A day in a hospital costs about $1,500, so both the Medicare bureaucracy and private insurers push hospitals to release patients sooner. Patients can go to nursing homes, where daily costs start at about $250 and can top $500, or they can go home.
For Mrs. Corrins's patients, the usual home visit, which takes one to two hours, costs $55 if the patient pays and $52.41 if Medicare pays, as it does for 90 percent of the South Hills agency's more than 3,000 patients. The agency charges $100 or more for visits by nurses and specialists.
While home health care is less expensive than nursing home care, the Government currently helps only elderly people who are acutely sick or people who are very poor, and it tends to drive them into nursing homes. Medicare, the Federal insurance program for the elderly, pays for home aides for people who require the attention of registered nurses or other professionals. The coverage usually runs up to 90 days after the person is released from a hospital.
 
Prohibitive Costs
 Although some patients remain ill enough to keep their Medicare coverage for home health aides for years, most lose it as their conditions stabilize because their conditions are no longer deemed acute. Many private insurance companies offer home health care coverage, but the cost is prohibitive for most people.
A patient without private insurance who still needs care but who loses Medicare coverage can pay for an aide, can turn to relatives for help or can move to a nursing home. The patient or a private insurer pays the nursing home bills until the patient's savings are nearly exhausted. At that point, Medicaid, a Government program for the poor, will pick up the bill, provided the patient stays in a nursing home.
South Hills, whose aides make 320,000 visits per year, is one of the largest of the nation's 6,500 home health agencies certified by Medicare. More than 6,000 home health agencies are not certified by Medicare; they usually charge lower fees because they are not subject to Medicare standards, and their aides' training may be less rigorous. Their lower prices are attractive for people who want home care but who cannot get coverage for it, either through Medicare or private insurance.
In traveling from home to home, a home health aide provides help for an array of problems as Lillie Munnell, 39, a South Hills aide for five years, did when she visited patients on a recent morning.
 
Patients in Need
 First she saw a 73-year-old woman with diabetes, high blood pressure and arthritis in her knees, ankles and toes. She is so obese that open sores have formed in the folds of her waist, and she cannot bend to treat blisters between her toes.
Then Mrs. Munnell went to the home of Charlotte Gaupp, 86, who has osteoporosis, emphysema, a swelling of unknown cause in her abdomen and poor hearing and eyesight.
Mrs. Gaupp looked chipper. Five-feet-one and trim, she played forward on her high school basketball team, she said, and she gets around unassisted. But she prefers to stay in her chair, where she watches television and eats her Meals on Wheels.
Like all South Hills aides, Mrs. Munnell was trained by a number of health professionals, and a nurse accompanies her once a month on visits to patients. She cannot give injections or do anything else considered invasive. But she takes vital signs and specimens and gives shaves, baths and showers, back rubs and enemas. She cleans catheters, hearing aides and artificial eyes, applies bandages and topical medications and looks for signs of new ailments. She has learned to move patients from beds to shower stools without throwing out her back and to change beds with patients in them.
 
Taxing Compassion
 But there are also emotional dimensions to the work of aides.
One of Mrs. Corrins's patients taxes all of her training and compassion. George Kostek, 64, who is called Buck, retired from his job as a steel company welder when he was 42. A diabetic, he had to undergo a kidney transplant. His wife, Jean, 64, retired from her job as a secretary four years ago to care for him.
His second kidney functions perfectly, she said, but little else does. Mr. Kostek has lost his left leg and the toes on his right foot. He has pulmonary disease. A stroke three years ago left his left side partly paralyzed. He has lost the sight of his left eye, and despite laser surgery, he is nearly blind in his right. He can no longer read or watch television. A new ailment, narcolepsy, is terrifying Mrs. Kostek. "He passes out on me for no reason at all," she said.
But Mr. Kostek wants to stay where he is, and Mrs. Kostek intends to keep him there. "I don't have much of a life," she said, "but I wouldn't have much of a life if he was in a nursing home because I'd be there all the time." Her relief comes at night -- when her husband sleeps soundly, straight through -- and during the two visits a week from Mrs. Corrins.
 
A Mischievous Smile
 "Hello, Bucky," Mrs. Corrins said, coming into a room where Mr. Kostek lay in his motor-controlled hospital bed. At her greeting, his face glowed with a mischievous, untroubled smile.
Mrs. Corrins put an arm across his shoulders, took his blood pressure, soaked his face with a warm, damp towel and shaved three days of stubble. Then she prepared to bathe him.
"She makes him so comfortable," Mrs. Kostek said in the kitchen. "See how calm he is in there? When I try to give him a bath, it's like fighting."
Mrs. Corrins and her husband, a mechanical engineer, have three children, a daughter, 14, a son, 12, and a daughter, 1. "My son had leukemia," she said. "He had 15 radiation treatments, and he's been off for three years. It was a gift. Now I can deal with this."

RAISING MATH AND SCIENCE REQUIREMENTS
In two weeks, New York City high schools will begin an ambitious effort to raise the math and science requirements for nearly all its students. But there are so many hurdles -- from a lack of money for books and teacher training, to concerns about the readiness of most ninth graders for such a change -- that many parents and teachers believe the new requirements will be nearly impossible to meet. A1. 
 A similar plan to raise standards was undertaken four years ago in Brooklyn. B4.
 
STUDY CHALLENGES STEREOTYPE OF POOR
Challenging the stereotype of the poor as single mothers on welfare who soak up more and more tax dollars, a new study has found that only one in four poor households in New York City is headed by a single parent and that spending on welfare, when adjusted for inflation, has declined by 20 percent since 1975. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
VILLAGE JEWELER IS FOUND SLAIN
Alfonso Albrizio was a fixture in Greenwich Village for 35 years, partly because he operated a jewelry store that became a favorite of celebrities, but mostly because of his generous heart. That ended when a man raced out of Mr. Albrizio's shop, C'est Magnifique, with a steak knife in his hand. The knife was covered with blood. On the floor inside lay the 79-year-old Mr. Albrizio, dead, his throat slashed. B3.
 
NEW IDEAS ON SUBWAY SHOOTING
Investigators looking into last week's shooting of a transit police officer are exploring the possibility that the city police officer who mistakenly fired on his plainclothes colleague was himself wounded either before he opened fire or while he was shooting. If that is true, said an official, then the city officer, Peter Del-Debbio, might have believed he was under attack. It might help explain why he continued to fire once the plainclothes officer had crumpled to the ground. B3.
 
12 DEATHS ARE LINKED TO TAINTED HEROIN
After finding 12 people dead of drug overdoses in Manhattan in the last 5 days, the police said that the deaths may have been caused bycontaminated heroin sold on the Lower East Side. B4.

A group of Hispanic elected officials endorsed the Rev. Al Sharpton in his campaign to unseat Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. B4.

In a campaign growing ever nastier, Herbert London called State Comptroller H. Carl McCall an extremist and questioned his participation in a 1972 political convention for blacks. B5.
 
A STORM AT FIRE ISLAND'S NUDE BEACH
In the old days, Lighthouse Beach on Fire Island was for the birds. No one can say, exactly, when the nude sunbathers discovered it. But it made sense that they chose the quiet stretch of seashore to be left alone. Who thought they would have company? But they do, lots of it, including children. Problems? And how. Our Towns, B5.

HEADLINE: Sidetracking Rights, U.S. Aide Pursues Business in China

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, leading a high-level business delegation to China, has agreed to take human rights off the public agenda so he and the American corporate executives traveling with him can open a new era of "commercial diplomacy" in the world's fastest growing emerging market, American officials said today.
As the first Clinton Cabinet member to visit China since the President separated human rights concerns from trade policy, Mr. Brown has publicly avoided any statement about the deterioration of human rights conditions over the last three months or about the security clampdown that has coincided with his arrival. 
 A senior official traveling with Mr. Brown said tonight that the Commerce Secretary would undertake only "private representations" to China's top leaders about continuing rights abuses.
"Commercial engagement" is one aspect of the Administration's new human rights policy, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "One strand of human rights policy is private representations."
Tonight, Mr. Brown was able to announce the first success of his business mission. The American power-generation giant Westinghouse signed a $140 million agreement to provide the steam turbines for a 700-megawatt electrical power plant in Jiangsu Province.
Westinghouse's chief executive, Michael Jordan, is a member of Mr. Brown's delegation.
Pitney Bowes and International Business Machines sealed contracts today worth about $20 million each, delegation spokesmen said.
Mr. Brown's first full business day in Beijing included a friendly session with Prime Minister Li Peng, who greeted his American guest by saying: "We have waited a long time for you to come to China. I hope that your current visit will provide impetus for friendship and cooperation of our two countries."
In remarks carried on national television, Mr. Li also told his American visitor that China was willing to discuss human rights, but only on the basis of "mutual respect." Western diplomats say, however, that the high-level dialogue between Washington and Beijing on the fate of thousands of religious and political detainees in China remains suspended.
A senior official traveling with Mr. Brown and insisting on anonymity later said the Chinese were not so friendly when the talks got down to the dispute between Washington and Beijing over the terms and conditions for China's entry into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Chinese officials were said to have taken a tough line against American insistence that China revamp some of its protectionist tariff and currency rules as a condition of entry.
Mr. Brown began the day by addressing a breakfast of the American Chamber of Commerce in Beijing, telling dozens of business managers based here that "commercial diplomacy allows the United States to pursue our economic agenda of creating jobs by increasing exports and bringing down barriers."
By the end of the day, Mr. Brown had signed a set of agreements to expand the United States-Chinese Joint Committee on Commerce and Trade.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE POLICY;
U.S. WILL PROPOSE REDUCING BARRIERS TO CUBA MIGRANTS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration plans to ask the Cuban government to halt the exodus of boat people in return for an offer by the United States to relax its immigration rules and grant residency visas to more than 20,000 Cubans a year.
During the last year, the United States granted residence visas to only 2,700 Cubans. The low number has caused Mr. Castro to complain that it was far below the legal ceiling of 27,845 Cubans that the Administration is authorized to admit. 
 Last week, Mr. Castro asserted that the failure to grant more visas to Cubans has helped cause the mass exodus of Cubans aboard rickety rafts and boats.
Today, as the weather cleared in the Florida Straits, the flow of refugees increased again, and scores of Cubans took to their boats in the hope of being rescued by the United States Coast Guard. [Page A10.]
The new Administration offer was being prepared in advance of talks scheduled for Thursday with Cuban diplomats in New York intended to resolve immigration issues and ease tensions over the refugee cisis created when the latest exodus of Cubans began early this month.
The Administration's plan represents another twist in its immigration policy toward Cuba, this time in the form of bending immigration laws to make it easier for Cubans to enter the country legally.
For instance, it plans to grant entry to cousins and grandparents of Cuban-Americans and grant refugee status to some Cubans even if they do not meet the strict standards for asylum.
Under existing rules, the parents, children, spouses and siblings of naturalized Americans can qualify for visas, but cousins do not.
According to several officials, Attorney General Janet Reno plans to use her emergency powers under the immigration laws to raise the number of Cubans admitted each year to the legal ceiling.
To help reach the ceiling, she is also expected to allow some or all of the 19,700 Cubans who are on a waiting list for visas to jump the line and receive visas this year. Some of those Cubans, many of them brothers and sisters of Cuban-Americans, have been waiting for visas for 10 years.
Several Administration officials said they hoped that this new offer would win Mr. Castro's approval and put an end to the refugee crisis, in which the Coast Guard has picked up more than 18,000 Cubans in the Straits of Florida since Aug. 1.
"We think the Cubans need to control illegal departures and we need to facilitate legal departures," said a White House official.
Mr. Castro has long pushed Washington to expand legal immigration from Cuba, partly because it would help serve as a safety valve for discontented Cubans to leave the island.
In 1984, the Reagan Administration agreed to grant visas to up to 20,000 Cubans a year. Immigration laws that went into effect in 1990 raised the ceiling to 27,845.
"We are going to recommit to that number and be more precise about how to get to those figures," a senior Administration official said.
The officials said that Ms. Reno and Doris Meissner, the Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, are developing additional ideas to be presented Tuesday at a White House meeting on how best to raise the number of Cubans accepted each year to the ceiling.
 
Fear of Favoritism
 The United States and Cuba agreed to meet on immigration after the Clinton Administration requested the talks to resolve the current refugee crisis. Mr. Clinton has steadfastly refused to discuss topics other than immigration at Thursday's talks even though Mr. Castro has called for negotiations on a wide range of subjects, including the 31-year-old trade embargo against Cuba.
One fear that Administration officials said they have about their new offer is that other ethnic groups like Chinese-Americans or Haitian-Americans will protest that the Cubans are being granted preferential treatment. The Immigration and Naturalization Service currently has a list of 3,442,000 foreigners awaiting visas, some of whom have waited for 10 years.
Still, one senior Administration official said, "For 30 years, we've been treating Cubans differently from everyone one." Under the Cuban Adjustment Act of 1966, the Administration welcomed all Cubans who arrived on American shores. But on Aug. 19, Mr. Clinton, fearing a flood of Cuban refugees, ended that policy and decided to send Cubans intercepted at sea to the naval base at Guantanamo Bay.
A senior State Department official said, "I've been assured that whatever steps we take regarding Cubans will in no way delay the admission of anyone else."
 
Castro's Response Unknown
 Administration officials acknowledged that they were unsure whether Mr. Castro would agree to stop the exodus of rafts in response to the proposal.
Still, there was hope that Mr. Castro would accept the offer because it might earn him some goodwill with the United States, perhaps encouraging the Administration to discuss easing economic sanctions.
"If he wants a debate in this country on Cuba policy, he has to act responsibly," said a senior Administration official.
Another factor that could push Mr. Castro to accept the offer, officials said, is that he must recognize that the flotilla of fleeing Cubans is sabotaging his efforts to entice Western tourists and investors.
In return for the offer to increase legal immigration, the Administration also wants Mr. Castro to take back 226 refugees being held at Guantanamo Bay who have asked to return to Cuba.
The list of 19,700 Cubans awaiting visas includes 10,900 brothers and sisters of American citizens, 5,100 spouses and unmarried children of permanent resident aliens and 3,000 married sons and daughters of American citizens.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Picks Business Editor

 BODY:
John M. Geddes, a former national news editor of The Wall Street Journal, has been named the business editor of The New York Times, Joseph Lelyveld, the executive editor, announced yesterday.
Mr. Geddes, 42, will preside over a planned expansion of The Times's business news coverage. 
 "He's an editor who thinks strategically and starts with a keen sense of our strengths and opportunities," Mr. Lelyveld said.
Since March, Mr. Geddes has been the president and chief executive of BIS Strategic Decisions, a 300-employee market research firm.
He has also been a principal in Friday Holdings L.P., which bought BIS Strategic Decisions late last year. Friday Holdings is a media investment group formed in 1993 by Norman Pearlstine, the former executive editor of The Wall Street Journal.
As business editor of The Times, Mr. Geddes succeeds William Stockton, who is working on special projects for the executive editor.
Mr. Geddes, who graduated from the University of Rhode Island in 1974 and earned a master's degree in business journalism from the University of Wisconsin in 1976, was a general assignment reporter at Reuters and Dow Jones before being transferred by A.P.-Dow Jones to Bonn in 1978.
He joined The New York Times as an economics reporter in Germany later that year.
Mr. Geddes returned to Dow Jones in 1980 to open The Wall Street Journal's Bonn bureau. He became deputy managing editor in 1982 and helped start The Wall Street Journal/Europe, the paper's Brussels-based European edition. He was later named managing editor of the edition.
He became an assistant managing editor of The Wall Street Journal in New York in 1985 and led teams that redesigned The Journal as a three-section paper. He became the national editor in 1992 and was responsible for The Journal's inside news pages and Marketplace section. He resigned in 1993 to join Friday Holdings.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 17.80 as It Strives for 3,900 Level

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For a moment yesterday morning, the Dow Jones industrial average leaped nearly 30 points, before falling back and closing at 3,898.85, up 17.80 points.
The advance yesterday marked the third time in four sessions that the blue-chip index has risen, aided somewhat by stable bond prices and a steadying dollar. 
 The relatively modest rally was also the first time since mid-March that the Dow came close to 3,900, and it renewed talk among investors of another assault on a Dow of 4,000, perhaps as early as this week.
But the rise yesterday, coming after last week's surge of 125.65 points, may signal a period of husbanding the market's gains in the usually quiet week before the long Labor Day weekend.
 
Economic Reports Due
 Two sets of Government economic data scheduled for release this week, factory orders and unemployment claims, could also dampen traders' enthusiasm and thwart any significant advances. Any signal in those data of emerging inflation could erase the advances of last week, which were based on an optimistic picture of a sound economy with low inflation.
"Mostly the Dow had a nice rally last week and is now in a consolidative position," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at Kemper Securities Inc.
Amid the generally rising tide, there were some notable stocks. Eastman Kodak agreed to sell its nonprescription drug business, which includes Bayer aspirin, to SmithKline Beecham for nearly $3 billion. Kodak's stock rose 1 3/8, to 50 3/4, while American depository receipts of SmithKline rose 1/2, to 31 1/2.
First Financial Management, a data management firm in Atlanta, said it planned to join in the bidding for Western Union Financial Services, a leading supplier of money orders and wire transfers. First Financial stock rose 1/2, to 61 1/4. Western Union's parent, New Valley, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, does not trade.
Nextel, the most active stock, at 9.5 million shares, was a big loser. The provider of specialized mobile radio service, which is akin to cellular phone service, could not complete alliance talks with MCI Communications and Comcast. Nextel's stock fell 5 1/4, to 25 1/4.
ITT was also a big loser. The stock market had judged that ITT and its partner, Cablevision Systems, had overbid for Madison Square Garden in a combined offer valued at more than $1 billion. ITT shares dropped 4 1/8, to 82. But Cablevision shares, by contrast, gained 3/8, to 58.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell, and its yield rose to 7.49 percent, from 7.48 percent on Friday. The dollar stayed above 100 Japanese yen and remained above postwar lows. Still, it fell to 100.02 yen, from 100.67 yen on Friday, but rose to 1.5776 German marks from 1.5745 marks.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was less than normal with 266.3 million shares changing hands, or much less than this year's average of 286 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered decliners, 1,237 to 903.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.79 point, to 474.59, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 0.27 point, to 763.21. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.46 point, to 261.28, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.9 points, to 451.46.
Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 19 rose, led by Eastman Kodak and Union Carbide, which rose 1 1/4, to 33 3/4.
Of the 500 stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 275 rose, led by AT&T, which gained 5/8, to 55 3/8, a rise that might have been connected to the failed MCI-Nextel deal.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Prices Flat Despite Inflation Fear

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday after commodity prices rose to their highest level in more than three weeks, raising inflation concerns among some investors.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 4/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.49 percent, from 7.48 percent on Friday. 
 Economic reports are scheduled for release every day this week. The main event is Friday's release of the August employment report, which for months has been the economic indicator that has moved the market most. Traders said many investors would wait for that report before making investment decisions.
Bond prices fell after the Commodities Research Bureau index of 21 commodities rose slightly, according to James Kenney, head trader at Prudential Securities. The index rose 1.14 points, to 232.02.
While the rise was small, it was enough to push the index to its highest level since Aug. 4, when it reached 232.45. Higher commodities prices cause investors to worry about inflation, which diminishes the value of fixed-income securities such as bonds.
Higher oil prices also raised concern about inflation. The crude oil contract for October, the most active contract, rose 49 cents, to $17.63, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
At the same time, the dollar fell 0.65 yen, to 100.02 yen. A weaker dollar discourages overseas investors from holding financial assets denominated in dollars, like Treasury bonds.
The dollar's retreat "killed off the rally here," said Bruce Hillyer, a trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "We're still just locked onto the dollar."
The small moves in other markets were enough to stop bonds from extending an advance on Friday in part because activity was light ahead of the Labor Day weekend, traders said.
"Because of the volatility in the foreign exchange markets and oil prices and C.R.B. and other things, the optimism of Friday seems to be somewhat reversing itself," said Robert G. Alley, chief fixed-income investment officer at AIM Management Group, who oversees $3 billion in investments.
Earlier, bonds rose amid speculation that the Federal Reserve may buy as much as $4 billion in Treasury securities this week. Bond firms generally bid up prices when they know they have a ready buyer of a large block of securities.
The Fed is expected to execute the "coupon pass" today or Wednesday, Steven Saslow, executive managing director at HSBC Securities, said. That could lift Treasuries, he said.
In a coupon pass, the Fed buys securities for its own account to ease a seasonal shortage of reserves in the banking system. Without the buying, short-term interest rates would be higher than the central bank wanted. A pass does not signal a change in interest rates.
Bonds were not affected by a Government report showing that personal income rose a half percentage point in July, as expected. Spending rose two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said. Both income and spending rose for the third consecutive month.
The report is "consistent with the economy remaining on a moderate growth trend," said David Cohen, an economist at MMS International in San Francisco.
"We're pushing the economy toward capacity," Mr. Cohen said. A higher inflation rate is bound to develop if the current pace of growth keeps up, he said.
On balance, the August employment report "probably will be negative" for bonds, said Robert McGee, chief economist at Tokai Bank. "All the indicators suggest the labor market remains quite strong," he said.
Yet the Government's reports will not reflect an economy so robust that bond yields will fluctuate much from 7.5 percent, where they have been for 11 weeks, Mr. McGee said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Incomes Rose 0.5% Last Month

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
The income of Americans rose moderately but more rapidly than consumer spending did in July, the Government said today in a report that indicated that economic growth was slowing.
The Commerce Department said today that income climbed for the sixth consecutive month, advancing five-tenths of 1 percent, while spending rose for the third consecutive month, but by just two-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Disposable income -- income after taxes -- also rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month. Both income and disposable income had risen one-tenth of 1 percent in June. Income last fell in January, by six-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Series of Increases
 Consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of economic activity, has advanced five of the last six months. But the July rise was less than the gains of five-tenths of 1 percent in June and six-tenths of 1 percent in May.
Today's report points to an economy that is shedding momentum, at least partly in reaction to a series of five increases in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve this year, analysts said.
"There is no overheating here," said Paul Boltz, an economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. "The bounce-back in income was impressive. Income growth is easily exceeding inflation."
The July figures for spending and income generally were in line with analysts' expectations.
The combination of incomes and spending meant that Americans' savings rate -- savings as a percentage of disposable income -- was 4.1 percent in June, up from a revised 3.7 percent the previous month. The Commerce Department had previously put the savings rate for June at 4 percent.
Wages and salaries, the most closely watched component of income, increased $15.3 billion in July after a $5 billion rise in June.
Government wages and salaries rose $1.6 billion in July, after declining $1.5 billion the previous month because of a drop in buyouts for Government employees.
Spending on long-lasting items declined 1.1 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $579 billion as car buying slowed.
"Consumers have become more cautious about making significant commitments such as cars," said Sung Won Sohn of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "The trend has been established in both housing and autos."
Spending on nondurable goods, like food and fuel, rose three-tenths of 1 percent, to $1.393 trillion, and spending on services was up four-tenths of 1 percent, to $2.648 trillion.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The booming personal computer industry defies economic gravity.

BYLINE: By John Markoff 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
THE personal computer boom just won't quit. Wall Street analysts expect a new sales surge to drive up computer companies' stocks during the second half of the year.
In June a number of Silicon Valley insiders were quietly betting that Apple Computer Inc. was about to take a fall. The rumors were that huge cutbacks in orders for disk drives signaled that the computer maker, based in Cupertino, Calif., was sitting on a sizable inventory. 
 But Apple, the world's second-largest PC maker after Compaq Computer, confounded the skeptics with strong third-quarter results. Now it looks as though Apple and much of the rest of the industry are headed for an unusually strong second half.
Apple's stock, which lost 37.5 cents yesterday to close at $35.375 on Nasdaq, has risen this year but is still 3.125 points below its year's high set in March. Some analysts say it could rise as much as 20 percent by the end of the year.
As educational institutions place their computer orders for the new school year, late summer is proving to be a time of strength, and it is likely to be followed by a strong-looking Christmas season for both Apple and its competitors. "The personal computer is becoming a stocking stuffer," said John T. Rossi, an industry analyst at Robertson Stephens & Company.
The PC industry's remarkable strength is bucking broader trends. Economists predict that the economy's strong growth since the fourth quarter of 1992 will moderate in the second half of the year.
"Over all, consumer spending has been very strong," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities. But, he said, sustained growth of the economy above 3 percent will probably not last. "I would imagine the economy will start to slip as we move into 1995," he said.
Besides Apple, both Compaq and Hewlett-Packard are showing remarkable strength. The PC business at Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., has grown about 100 percent this year over last, David Wu, a computer industry analyst for S. G. Warburg, said. Compaq, based in Houston, has grown increasingly bold, telling analysts that it believes it can raise its market share to 30 or 35 percent by 1996, in part by cutting prices. Compaq now has a 14.3 percent share of the computer market, according to Dataquest, a market research firm. Its stock gained 12.5 cents yesterday to close at $39.875, and its year's return has shot up 122.86 percent.
Earlier this month Compaq cut prices on some systems by as much as 22 percent. Indeed, Compaq's target is largely I.B.M., which responded last week by cutting prices up to 27 percent.
I.B.M., however, seems to be the one PC maker that may miss out on the end-of-the-year sales surge. Although the company briefly took the No. 1 spot in PC market share last year, it has since stumbled to fourth place behind Packard Bell, and its United States PC revenue declined in the most recent quarter. International Business Machines lost 50 cents yesterday, closing at $69.50.
Wall Street analysts predict that in the December quarter, PC purchases could exceed 20 million, setting a quarterly record, in large part because the home PC market is projected to grow to about 16 million in 1994, from 11 million in 1993. Indeed, more than half of all home PC sales for the year are expected to come after Sept. 1. "The new personal computers have all the attributes of classic consumer electronics products -- color, sound, stereo, fun and games," Mr. Rossi said.
The surge is not limited to home PC's. Intel will ship its top-of-the-line Pentium microprocessors in the fourth quarter and that should drive down prices for business-system buyers who have been waiting to upgrade.
Pentium-based systems are falling below $2,000, spurring demand, according to Andrew J. Neff, a PC industry analyst at Bear, Stearns.
He said in a recent newsletter that falling prices for PC's would finally spur the consumer market in Europe, which has been largely dormant compared with the United States.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Report on German Economy Strengthens Dollar vs. Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly higher against the German mark and most other European currencies yesterday after an influential report on Germany's economy suggested that interest rates there might fall.
The dollar advanced initially against the Japanese yen in Asian and European trading on optimism for progress in trade talks between the United States and Japan. Also helping the dollar was an American economic report showing that personal income rose moderately last month, providing little evidence of new inflationary pressures. But much of the strength faded later and the dollar ended lower against the yen. 
 Foreign exchange traders described activity as light, with a financial holiday in London reducing the volume. The slow trading might have exaggerated the dollar's moves in either direction.
In late New York trading, the dollar brought 1.5776 marks, down from its high for the day of 1.59833 marks but higher than 1.5745 marks at the close of trading on Friday.
The dollar also fetched 100.02 yen in late New York trading, down from 100.67 yen on Friday.
 
Weakness in the Mark
 Traders said much of the activity focused on weakness in the German mark after the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Germany's central bank could lower key interest rates there to stimulate the economy without accelerating the inflation rate. Lower interest rates in Germany would lessen the attractiveness of mark-denominated investments.
"After that news we started buying the dollar," said Zlatko Glamuzina, senior trader at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia, an Italian bank.
He said the strength in the dollar intensified as traders who had speculated on weakness in the dollar after its big run-up last week scrambled to buy dollars to cover their short sales. Once the dollar surpassed 1.59 marks, however, dollar sellers moved in.
"It turned into an overbought situation when we went over 1.59 marks," said Peter Dembinski, senior trader at the New York office of Bank Julius Baer. He said the dollar "probably could consolidate around these levels."
Early in the day, the dollar gathered strength against the yen after the Japanese Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, said he was confident that Japan and the United States would solve their trade disputes through negotiations. The dollar has tended to weaken on rumors that those negotiations could falter and strengthen on word that they might succeed.
Meanwhile, the British pound rose to $1.5366 in New York, from $1.5315 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Jobs Versus Inflation at the Fed

 BODY:
Alan Blinder, recently appointed vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board by President Clinton, called last week for the Fed to use monetary policy to bring down unemployment from temporarily high levels. That prescription put him at odds with Chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony to Congress that the Fed cannot control employment and ought to focus only on inflation. The difference at first blush seems stark: one man worried about jobs, the other about prices.
Mr. Blinder's declaration may have been designed to enhance the likelihood that the White House would elevate him to the Fed chairmanship when Mr. Greenspan's term expires in early 1996. But the statement should have come as no surprise: he preached the same doctrine as an academic and before Congress. Indeed, it is Mr. Blinder's dovish stance on inflation that made him an attractive appointment to a White House that desperately seeks to create jobs. 
 The dispute is real, but easy to exaggerate. Mr. Greenspan, too, is worried about jobs, which he believes are best created by wringing inflation completely out of the system. Both economists agree that the Fed cannot drive unemployment below current levels, about 6 percent of the labor force, without doing damage. According to both men, if the Fed were to pour money into labor markets that tight, wages would rise and drag prices and interest rates along. Eventually the Fed would be forced to stamp out the rising inflation by changing course -- clamping down on the money supply and thereby throwing the economy into a job-destroying recession.
Yet there are circumstances that could bring the differences between the two to the surface. Suppose, for example, that inflation rose above current levels while unemployment climbed toward 7 percent. Mr. Blinder would probably advocate pushing down interest rates in an attempt to spark investment spending and, therefore, more jobs. But Mr. Greenspan would argue that Mr. Blinder's policy would backfire because bond markets can anticipate that the Fed is about to trigger higher inflation and therefore demand higher interest rates, the opposite of the result Mr. Blinder intended to achieve.
The important point, however, is that their policy prescriptions are unlikely to prove greatly different in practice. Neither economist is a zealot. Mr. Greenspan has skillfully steered the economy along a path of non-inflationary growth by guiding monetary policy, no matter what he tells Congress, with an eye on employment as well as prices. Mr. Blinder says he is an inflation dove, slow to raise interest rates to combat inflation, but he voted to raise interest rates earlier this month even though inflation rates remain very low.
Mr. Blinder was able to do so without jeopardizing jobs because he recognized that unemployment was hovering around 6 percent, which is about as low as the economy can sustain over the long haul. Had the Fed refused to intervene with higher interest rates, inflation would almost surely have picked up by the end of the year.
When Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Blinder summarize their theories of intervention in the economy, neither sounds convincing. Neither Mr. Greenspan's sole focus on inflation nor Mr. Blinder's willingness to worry about inflation only after the economy hits capacity is a complete answer. But Mr. Blinder is surely right that the Fed must be concerned about employment, and it does not hurt for the nation's assembled bankers and economists to be reminded of that.

HEADLINE: Redlining Under Attack

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
While the Justice Department's settlement with the Chevy Chase Federal Savings Bank of Maryland was the first of the Clinton Administration's attacks on redlining to gain wide notice, it represents only an early salvo in a multifronted assault. Both the Department of Housing and Urban Development and an interagency committee of banking regulators are working on broad new Federal requirements for more lending to minorities, and the costs will likely be spread among all borrowers, banking specialists say.
A stricter regime on mortgage discrimination has long been a goal of many Congressional Democrats, and Clinton Administration officials have called for progress, not paperwork, on the issue. But the pragmatic case for an aggressive approach hinges on the assumption that mortgage discrimination is widespread. And on this point, some economists are raising serious questions. 
 Most of the analysts who are dubious about the assertion that redlining is a fact of life make their argument on the ground of economic efficiency.
George J. Bentson, a specialist in financial regulation at Emory University, finds it implausible that banks would pass up any chance to issue mortgages that could be sold for a quick profit in the securities markets. "There is no evidence of significant discrimination in mortgage lending," he said.
Others, including Lawrence J. White, a former Federal bank regulator who teaches economics at the Stern School of Business at New York University, worry that using statistical patterns to infer discrimination -- the general mode of proof in such matters -- will induce lenders to allocate funds by racial or neighborhood quotas rather than by creditworthiness.
"Such targeting is bad public policy because it wastes capital," Mr. White said. "If we are going to subsidize lending for social purposes, it ought to be done explicitly and with Government money."
But other analysts question the statistical patterns as well.
A recent study by David Horne, an economist at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, concludes that the seminal redlining study, conducted by Alicia Munnell, a former economist at the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston who is now a deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, was fatally flawed. His analysis of the data shows no discrimination at all.
Redlining -- avoiding banking in low-income neighborhoods -- and discriminating by race are forbidden by a host of Federal laws. Under the Fair Housing and Equal Credit Opportunity acts, the Justice Department in the last two years has reached settlements with banks in Mississippi, South Dakota, Massachusetts and, earlier this month, in the greater Washington area.
In the past, redlining cases involved charges that that lenders unfairly rejected loan applications. In the Washington-area case, the department said that Chevy Chase Federal Savings, with $5 billion in assets, was guilty of refusing to market itself in minority neighborhoods. Chevy Chase strenuously denied the allegation and said it had settled to avoid costly litigation. Under the settlement, the savings and loan will offer loans to minority applicants that will cost it $7 million in subsidies and open new branches and mortgage offices in poor neighborhoods.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development is working on a new lending code, to be published next month, that will ask the 2,900 members of the Mortgage Bankers Association to pledge that they will aggressively seek business among minorities. And Federal bank regulators, including the Federal Reserve and the Controller of the Currency, are drafting tough regulations against redlining under the authority of the Community Reinvestment Act.
These battles should prove easier to win than antidiscrimination initiatives in employment, education or housing. For while the banking industry may quietly lobby against greater social regulation, banks are reluctant to resist publicly -- and for good reasons.
For one thing, bank regulators have enormous discretion in ruling on applications for mergers, the opening or closing of branches and expansion into new financial services. And they have the obligation to consider a bank's responsiveness to community needs in evaluating these applications.
Then, too, banks are loath to fight high-profile battles against discrimination charges because of the bad will it generates. That could explain why of the antidiscrimination cases investigated by the Clinton Justice Department all have been settled out of court, said James D. McLaughlin, a spokesman for the American Bankers Association. Similar logic could be used to account for the apparent compliance of the industry with the lending code the housing department is negotiating with the Mortgage Bankers Association.
 
Plan Will Be Voluntary
 The agreements between the department and individual lenders, which will include dollar targets for minority-area lending and statistical analyses to measure compliance, will be voluntary. But according to The American Banker, a trade publication, the financial trade associations are telling their members that signing up will buy them friends in high places.
Much of the pressure for a tougher enforcement effort stems from data collected under the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act of 1990. The data show that black and Hispanic applicants are two to three times more likely to be turned down for a mortgage than whites.
Those data, however, have been criticized by the banking industry for what they do not show. Race, it is argued, is correlated with employment and financial assets -- information that should legitimately be considered in evaluating loan applications. So in 1992 the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston decided to fill in the missing pieces.
The Boston Fed's effort, led by Ms. Munnell, looked at a large random sample of mortgage applications in the Boston area. The researchers included data on employment, age, family stability, neighborhood stability, personal debts, credit histories and size of requested loans compared with house values -- all of which might have explained why nonwhites were rejected in disproportionate numbers.
 
Explanation in Part
 These factors do, in fact, explain part of the discrepancy. Even so, the researchers concluded that black and Hispanic applicants with equal qualifications were 60 percent more likely to be turned down by lenders. Highly qualified applicants, black or white, had no trouble getting credit, saidLynn E. Browne, one of the study's authors. The problem came with marginal applicants; bank loan officers apparently proved more willing to work with white clients to find offsetting factors that would open the credit window.
The Boston study and its conclusions have had enormous influence on regulators' views. Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve, called it "the most comprehensive statistical analysis of lending patterns by race that has ever been conducted."
But in an article published this spring in the F.D.I.C. Banking Review, Mr. Horne, the F.D.I.C. economist, took another look at the Boston Fed analysis. He concluded that adding yet more information relevant to loan decisions -- for example, the availability of cash for closing costs -- wiped out three-quarters of the discrimination found in the Boston Fed's study. What's more, Mr. Horne said, if one eliminates data from two minority-owned banks that actively solicited business from marginally qualified blacks, the evidence of discrimination vanishes entirely.
With or without evidence, what is the harm to increased vigilance? The answer, economists argue, depends on whether lenders respond by funneling capital into unproductive projects.
While bank regulators have apparently rejected formal statistical tests as a standard for judging compliance with the Community Reinvestment Act, banks can certainly use numbers to ward off the regulators. And the H.U.D. guidelines will reportedly ask lenders to pledge to lend minimum amounts in minority neighborhoods.
 
Impact of Incentives
 It is possible, of course, that the incentives will only make lenders more aware of the profit opportunities in neglected areas. The consequences of such lending, said Geoffrey Tootell, a co-author of the Boston Fed study, "may be less inefficient" than current lending decisions colored by bias.
But it is also possible that banks will find that the path of least political resistance is simply to shovel enough money into minority projects to make the regulators go away. "These costs would then be passed on to creditworthy borrowers of all races," Mr. Horne said.
That is why Mr. White of New York University would rather see socially motivated investments made with public funds -- say, through community investment banks. "If we are going to push money around," Mr. White said, "I'd rather the decisions be transparent and the results open to public scrutiny."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 31, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An economic analysis in Business Day yesterday about the Clinton Administration's efforts to curb mortgage discrimination misstated the current position of Alicia Munnell, the former chief economist at the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston. Ms. Munnell is now the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy, not the deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget.

HEADLINE: How U.S. and Russia Can Reduce Nuclear Peril;
Steadfast on Smuggling

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Nuclear Black Market" (editorial, Aug. 22) charges that the Clinton Administration has been giving nuclear smuggling only "fitful attention." Far from it. The Administration has identified stemming the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction as one of its key security priorities. We have worked at the highest levels, and with our allies, to coordinate strategies for controlling the spread of nuclear material. 
 Preventing diversion of fissile material is part of our overall strategy to reduce the risk of nuclear proliferation. We have long cooperated with German authorities on reported nuclear-smuggling cases, and they are keeping us informed of their investigation of last week's case.
Through the Nunn-Lugar program for the safe disposition of nuclear weapons in the former Soviet Union and other programs, the Defense and Energy Departments and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission cooperate with Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan to account for, control and protect nuclear materials.
Louis J. Freeh, Federal Bureau of Investigation director, has been in touch with his counterparts to improve law enforcement cooperation with European states affected by smuggling. The Customs Service is working with the Russians to facilitate information sharing, leading to joint investigations.
To help reduce excess stockpiles, the United States contracted with Russia to purchase power reactor fuel blended down from 500 metric tons of highly enriched uranium from dismantled weapons. And Vice President Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin signed an agreement to shut down the last three Russian plutonium reactors by 2000.
In July, President Clinton achieved agreement with the leaders of the Group of 7 leading industrial nations and Russia to cooperate in preventing nuclear smuggling. Secretary of State Warren Christopher spoke with his European colleagues last week to reinforce this agreement, and we are aking steps to facilitate the exchange of nuclear-smuggling data.
The Russians understand the importance of this issue and have been forthcoming in cooperating with us and other countries in combating this threat, as demonstrated by their agreement with Germany. We expect that this subject will be an important topic at the September summit.
Nuclear smuggling will continue to receive the serious and high-level attention it deserves, using a coordinated strategy and drawing on the expertise and talents of senior United States officials.
 
LYNN E. DAVIS
Under Secy. of State, Arms Control
& International Security Affairs
Washington, Aug. 25, 1994

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
For a China Boycott

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
On just one issue, President Clinton, American business and the Chinese Communist leadership have taught the people of the United States three nasty lessons.
The issue is human rights. It is a pallid phrase for what it means: freedom, or at least some surcease, from torture, forced labor and deprivation of the right to speak and worship as we are moved. 
 The question now is what Americans can do, as individual members of a free society, to override their instructors. The answers stare at us: stockholder action, and boycott.
President Clinton taught his lesson by betraying promises he made with his mouth while campaigning and with his pen after election -- to use higher tariffs on Chinese goods to pressure Beijing into human rights relief for Chinese and Tibetans.
Thus he taught the world that his word on human rights cannot be trusted, even when he puts it on paper. Since this is an issue that touches the whole world, the cause of wars throughout modern history, it is a matter of moment and danger.
How can Mr. Clinton preach human rights in Cuba as a reason for the embargo, and be believed, after reneging on a pledge to use a much milder economic weapon against China's greater tyranny?
How can he denounce ethnic cleansing in the Balkans and close his mouth and heart to Beijing's moving Chinese into Tibet and Tibetans out of their homes -- a continuing atrocity almost a half-century old?
The second lesson, from American business, is that Chinese and Tibetan blood and pain do not count on the bottom line. American business in China sups eagerly with the Devil. American executives, a planeload, are now at table, ushered in by Secretary of Commerce Ron Brown to make deals, without reference to human rights.
When the issue was higher trade tariffs, the China trade said no and won. Then human rights supporters in Congress suggested targeting only products of the industrial empire of the Chinese Army. Mr. Clinton and U.S. business said no -- and won.
Now human rights groups ask business for a code that would show some smidgen of interest about labor conditions in China. From the Administration and business, no action.
Writer, haven't you learned that business is business? Sure, but I learned at school and at home to kind of admire America, so it was just hard for me to believe right away that so many U.S. businesses would be so cold and so craven.
Lesson three. Beijing taught us that the Clintonian and business argument that more trade would mean more human rights in China was false.
Human rights groups and American correspondents report that persecution of dissidents and clergymen has increased pointedly since Mr. Clinton dropped the tariff threat.
The Chinese Communists are creating a system in which controlled capitalism and tyranny work together -- familiar from Hitler to Saddam. Spare us Washington's pout of innocence.
But if Washington and American business do not care that their country and companies help finance torture cells, what can an individual American do about it?
Two things, together. Use the stockholder's right to demand a rights code for every U.S. business investing in China. It worked on South Africa.
And in combination, boycott across the board: shoes, toys, tools and the thousands of other exports to the U.S. that give Beijing its $30 billion annual trade bonus from America.
The China lobby, the Administration and even some human rights people will say it will just get Beijing mad; forfend. But cutting down that huge trade advantage even by some annual billions will be the first economic pressure for human rights applied to China by Americans.
Beijing will at last face the choice between easing oppression and seeing its essential trade balance wither.
Combined with stockholder pressure on American corporations, backed by American labor and preached in American churches and temples, a boycott could buy some liberty for persecuted Chinese dissidents, workers and clergy.
One sure thing: It would show more rights achievement than today's appeasement policy. That stands at zero, and getting lower.
The boycott would be an act of individual conscience, the answer to the old question: But what can just one person do? At least we would not be wearing stained clothes, and that would be good.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: New Game for Pequots: Party Politics

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 29

 BODY:
The Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, having earned millions from the gambling business at its Foxwoods casino in Connecticut, is investing its profits in a new game: politics.
As the November elections approach, Pequot money is flowing across the country in abundant and increasing amounts, to Albany and Hartford as well as Des Moines and Sacramento. And virtually all of it is going to Democrats.
In just the last few months, the tribe -- whose roughly 300 members are expected to earn about $600 million from the casino this year -- has given $100,000 each to the Democratic Party organizations in New York and California and $50,000 to the state party committee in Iowa, all at the direction of national party leaders. It has pledged $250,000 for other state campaigns still to be named. And with total donations of $315,000 over the last two years, it has become one of the single largest contributors to the Democratic Party's National Committee, joining the ranks of huge corporations like Time Warner and big unions like the National Education Association.
What all this means, for the Pequots and the Democrats, is an open question.
Lobbyists and lawyers for the tribe say that Democrats have been good to the Pequots, and American Indians generally, and that across a broad spectrum of issues, from health care to education, the tribal council believes that the Clinton Administration is on the right track. Local Democrats helped the tribe gain Federal recognition in the 1980's -- an old debt that can now be repaid -- and Mr. Clinton held an American Indian summit at the White House in April that was viewed by the Pequots as symbolically significant.
And while some critics grouse that the tribe is only furthering its economic interests as the owner of a huge gambling enterprise, there is little evidence of a Pequot agenda.
The Republican National Committee has offered no comment on the donations or the tribe. Democratic officials in the states getting money say they have had no contact with the tribe, and in the states closest to the casino -- Rhode Island and Massachusetts -- where the tribe would presumably have the keenest interest in influencing debate about gambling, the Pequots and Democrats say there have been no contributions at all.
But people in both parties say that the tribe has found a quick way to become a player in the game of politics. While the size of contributions to individual candidates is limited, the tribe can give as much as it wants to the state and national parties, gaining the maximum good will from party leaders.
"I would imagine that all they're trying to do is expand their influence," said State Senator James T. Fleming, a Connecticut Republican and an opponent of casino gambling. "As long as it's legal, I don't see anything wrong with it."
In Connecticut, the tribe formed a political action committee in July that could under state law give unlimited amounts to candidates. Tribal lawyers said they were also considering forming a national PAC.
Earlier this month, Carrie Saxon Perry, a former Mayor of Hartford and a Democratic candidate for the State Senate, held a fund-raiser at the casino, on the tribe's reservation in Ledyard. Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, a third-party candidate for governor, plans to do a star turn there next month, at a $250-to-$500-a-ticket fund-raiser in a hotel ballroom.
 
Expanded Lobbying Efforts
 The tribe has expanded its lobbying efforts, too. It opened a Washington office this year, and a in Hartford this spring its largess surpassed even that of Stephen A. Wynn, the Las Vegas casino developer who has spent millions in Connecticut over the last few years to try to end the Pequots' monopoly on casino gambling in the state. The Pequots paid a Hartford public relations company $210,000 through mid-June, compared with the $152,000 spent by Mr. Wynn on lobbying, according to the State Ethics Commission.
Experts in American Indian affairs said that many tribes have long had political action committees, and that political contributions have gone up in the last few years. But the Pequots, if only by their grand scale of doing things, still get the attention.
And like all of their previous efforts to test themselves and their newfound economic sovereignty -- from the expansion of land claims to the development of a Pequot legal code -- the new flexing of political muscle is also sparking anxieties about where the tribe is going and what it will do when it gets there.
A lobbyist for the tribe, Charles J. Duffy, said that those "sensitivities" had led the tribal council to take what state elections officials say is an extraordinary step: the Pequots will limit contributions to local candidates from its new state PAC, even though it does not have to.
Mr. Duffy said the tribe would consider donations to Democratic and Republican candidates, but will hold donations to the same maximum allowed for business PACs, which can donate only up to $5,000 to a gubernatorial campaign and $500 to an individual state legislative race, with a $100,000 cap on all contributions.
"We don't want people who are averse to the tribe to be making egregious claims about what the tribe is doing and what it intends to do," Mr. Duffy said.
That has not stopped people from questioning, however, why a small tribe would ship its money so far from home.
"It is my belief that any sound-thinking person would ask why, in this case, an Indian nation would send a significant donation to a political party or elected official in another state," said State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Westchester County Republican who asked this month for a Federal investigation into the Pequots' $100,000 contribution to the New York Democratic Party.
Mr. Spano, an advocate of casino gambling in New York, said in a letter to the United States Attorney General, Janet Reno, that the State Legislature's defeat in July of an amendment legalizing casinos came within days of the tribe's donation, and that the appearances and timing were questionable, though he had no direct evidence of any wrongdoing.
Chris McNeil, a tribal lawyer who heads the Washington lobbying effort, said the Pequots had had absolutely no contact with New York Democrats, and that the state committees that have received money were all suggested by the Democratic National Committee as places where Democrats could use extra help this year.
"There's no connection," Mr. McNeil said, referring to the gambling issue in New York and the tribe's contribution.
Still, party officials in Iowa and California said that even though the Pequots' national political agenda is vague, their ability to write big checks has not gone unnoticed.
 
Keeping Track of Friends
 Mike Monasmith, a spokesman for the California Democratic Party, said the money had come with no strings attached, but that, if only to protect itself, the party always knows who its friends are.
"We are sure to make sure we know where they money is coming from," Mr. Monasmith said.
In Iowa, Democrats said the Pequots had asked for nothing in exchange for their $50,000 donation.
"We have some good Congressional races and a good chance of knocking out a Republican governor, but how that ties in to the tribe's agenda, I'm not certain," said Ron Parker, a spokesman for the Iowa Democratic Party. "We have no contact with the Indians."
Here in Connecticut, where the tribe clearly does have an established agenda -- to keep non-Indian gambling operations out of the state -- politicians said they hoped the new Pequot PAC would be low-key about any kind of loyalty pledge.
"It should not be a single-issue PAC and I don't think it will be," said Edward L. Marcus, the Connecticut Democratic Party chairman. "I'm not sure that would make too many candidates all that comfortable."

HEADLINE: Researchers Find a Diverse Face On the Poverty in New York City

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Challenging the stereotype of the poor as single mothers on welfare who soak up more and more tax dollars, a new study has found that only one in four poor households in New York City is headed by a single parent and that spending on welfare in the city, when adjusted for inflation, has declined by 20 percent since 1975.
In fact, the report, released yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission, found that Medicaid, not welfare, had been the prime engine of growth in public spending on the poor in the city, particularly in the exploding costs of medical care for the disabled and the elderly poor. 
 In 1992, the most recent year studied, expenditures by the city, the state and the Federal Government for Medicaid in New York City amounted to $10.2 billion, far more than for any other antipoverty program and about three times as much as the total spending on welfare and food stamps combined.
The authors of the study say the results raise questions about whether government spends too much on medical care as compared with food, shelter and other basic needs. Runaway health care costs and eroding welfare benefits have skewed spending toward the elderly, and away from children in poor families, they say.
Citing United States census figures, the researchers noted that nearly one-third of the city's children lived in poverty in 1990, while 13 percent of the elderly were poor.
"Certainly the elderly are taking up the lion's share of the poverty spending," said Philip Thompson, an assistant professor of political science at Barnard College. He conducted the study with Charles Brecher, research director for the budget commission and a professor of public administration at New York University.
The budget commission, a nonprofit city government monitoring group that usually focuses on financial matters, decided to venture into the poverty debate after the 1992 riots in Los Angeles. The commission's trustees decided that the riots showed the dangers of ignoring the dispossessed, said Ray Horton, president of the commission.
The portrait of the poor that emerges in its report, "Poverty and Public Spending Related to Poverty in New York City," is a varied one. One-quarter of poor households were headed by single parents. Another quarter were headed by an elderly person, one in five consisted of single adults, one in six were headed by a disabled adult and one in eight by a couple.
"I certainly would have guessed a larger portion of households were single-parent families," said Mr. Brecher, who had previously specialized in the financing of city government, not in poverty. "The extent to which different kinds of households were represented among the poor was news to me."
The researchers also report that the poor are ethnically varied, though clearly minorities are disproportionately represented. Among poor households, 31 percent were headed by blacks, 28 percent by non-Hispanic whites, 20 percent by Puerto Ricans, 14 percent by others of Hispanic heritage and the balance by people from other minorities. Almost half the poor households headed by an elderly person were those of non-Hispanic whites.
 
Variance Among Boroughs
 The profile of the poor varied widely by borough. In the Bronx, which has the city's highest concentration of poor people, more than one-third of the poor households were single-parent families. In Manhattan, the largest group of poor households -- 30 percent -- consisted of single adults. In Queens, households headed by the elderly made up the largest group, representing 26 percent of the poor.
The study noted that government cash payments to the elderly lifted most out of poverty. In 1990, the poverty rate among households headed by the elderly would have been 63 percent without Social Security and other cash benefits. With those benefits, only 21 percent were classified as poor.
But a negligible number of poor families were lifted above the Federal poverty level by welfare payments. Because welfare is so politically unpopular, lawmakers in New York State and elsewhere in the country have refused to increase welfare payments to keep up with inflation.
As a result, between 1970 and 1992, the inflation-adjusted dollar value of welfare benefits in New York City declined by 30 percent, to $2,206 per person, according to the report. In 1992, overall spending on welfare in the city was 20 percent lower than in 1975 after adjustment for inflation, while the number of families on welfare increased by 6 percent during the same time.
Like many others who have studied the growing phenomenon of homelessness among families, Mr. Thompson suggests that the declining value of welfare payments to poor families is closely connected to their inability to pay the rent.
 
New York Is Typical
 Despite the Dickensian contrasts of wealth and poverty in the city, the study also found that the New York metropolitan area was about average nationally in the proportion of its households that were poor -- 11.7 percent. The diversity of the city's poor people was also mirrored in the national data.
Mr. Brecher said he had assumed that all social problems were different or worse in the New York area, and was surprised that it was actually quite typical in most ways.
The researchers did find, however, that poverty in the New York metropolitan area is more concentrated in the city than in every other large metropolitan area except San Antonio, making the contrast between city and suburb more pronounced than in other parts of the country. More than two-thirds of the New York metropolitan area's poor population live in the city itself.
In 1992, the city spent $4.8 billion of its own money on the poor, about 28 percent of all locally financed spending, the commission found. Each year from 1970 to 1992, the proportion of local spending devoted to the poor ranged between 25 and 29 percent.
From 1985 to 1992, the city-financed portion of Medicaid spending more than doubled, to $2.1 billion, about 45 percent of total city-financed spending for the poor.
The rapidly rising city spending on Medicaid highlights the importance of the city's push to have the state take over local Medicaid costs, Mr. Brecher said.
