HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE NEXT WAVE;
Cuban Refugees Resume Exodus Despite Warnings

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 29

 BODY:
After a lull over the weekend, scores of Cubans launched fragile boats and rafts from beaches along the coast today, heading for international waters in spite of American warnings that they would not be permitted to enter the United States.
One after another, and then by the dozens, rafts began appearing in the water in front of Havana's oceanfront, known as the Malecon, and a few miles east at Cojimar, which has become the main launching point for those who want to escape from Cuba. Many of the Cubans had been camping on the beaches for days, waiting for the weather to improve.
Trucks also began arriving, depositing people who had come from Alamar in the east and Pinar del Rio in the west, 120 miles away. The trucks carried boats that the refugees had been building at their homes. Because of the current in the Florida Straits, the coast around Havana is the best launching area for the mostly unpowered boats.
Hundreds of well-wishers lined the beaches near Havana as the exodus resumed.
 
A Weather Predicter
 No one has been able to predict the flow of refugees, but the weather has been one prognosticator, even better than pleas by Fidel Castro or President Clinton.
Indeed, there has been less science and method involved in how many people have left than there has been strong emotion, including anger at Cuba's economic deterioration and impatience to get on with what everyone knows is a perilous journey.
[Despite the ample evidence that the number of Cubans leaving was rising sharply, relatively few were picked up by the Coast Guard. As of 10 P.M. Monday, 253 Cubans had been intercepted, up from 84 on Sunday. Last week, in the first rush, the Coast Guard picked up 13,600.]
"Tell my mother that I have gone and that I am very happy," Marbel Betancourt Gonzalez said just before she jumped into the turquoise waters of Cojimar to scramble onto a rubber and wooden raft with 10 others. Miss Betancourt, who had slept on the beach for nine days waiting for her journey, turned to face the crowd of hundreds of people piled on a crumbling sea wall, and with tears in her eyes she waved and blew kisses.
It is impossible to predict how many Cubans will leave in this wave, but today's activity indicates that the United States policy to deny them automatic asylum will not keep many people at home.
In fact, some of the Cubans say there is an urgency about leaving now.
Two brothers, Felipe and Jesus, came from Pinar del Rio, about 125 miles west of Cojimar, to leave from Cuba in a boat that they had assembled by soldering together pieces of aluminum, then painting it over with tar and padding the inside with plastic foam.
"We're afraid Mr. Castro is going to say, 'No more,' so we have to leave now," Jesus said. "We came here because this is the closest point to the United States, and it is a good place to launch a boat."
The brothers also said that on their stretch of the coast the Government's coast guards still seemed to be patrolling the waters. At Cojimar, there were only a few soldiers in camouflage uniforms, and they did not seem to bother the people leaving.
 
First Boat Leaves
 The first boat to leave this morning from Cojimar was a tidy contraption of rubber and wood. It, too, had come on a truck, and it had a wooden rudder and a bow made of aluminum, with lines of thin rope on its perimeter for its passengers to hold onto and a jaunty red yachting flag atop its rough-hewn mast.
One by one people boarded the boat, as hundreds of well-wishers gathered on the littered beach to see them off. A festive atmosphere pervailed. Vendors were selling tamales and guanabo turnovers. The only ones not laughing were the six women and nine men who pushed off, rowing at the direction of an older man who was clearly their captain.
Some people were dispensing advice. One man told a would-be refugee how to judge how far his raft was from tankers that navigate the straits. He told him to hold his hand out in front of him in a fist, with his thumb sticking skyward, and to close one eye. "If your thumb covers the whole tanker, then he's 10 miles away," the older man told the younger one.
Some carried good-luck charms on board. One boat had the Virgin of Charity on its bow. One refugee tried to take his dog on the raft, but the animal ran down a dock away from him.
Ramon Perez Lara, who is 61, was at the beach helping his son Sergio, who would be making about his 30th attempt to leave. The two men personify the debate about whether it is better to abandon Cuba or to stay and make it better.
Mr. Perez fought in the revolution. His family grew tobacco and corn on their small parcel of land, but the inequities of life before Castro's rule left the countryside poor of many things Cubans now have, he said.
"I learned to read and write after the revolution," he said proudly.
But his son, Sergio Lara Caras, has felt let down by the revolution. He made his first attempt to try to leave Cuba on a home-made boat five years ago, when he was 29, and he has been trying ever since. Twice he was picked up by Soviet tankers and turned over to the Cuban authorities.
He has been in prison three times for his so-called treasonous crimes, and has served as long as eight months. He has gotten as far as 35 miles out to sea, far short of the 90 miles to Florida.
"Castro has turned my struggle into something political by saying I am betraying the country," Mr. Lara said. "But it is only economic. This country does not have opportunities for me anymore. Because I have been arrested for trying to leave, I cannot get the kind of work that will help me have a life."
With tears streaming down her face, Berta Serrano Belot waved from the beach to a raft carrying her oldest daughter, 30, and her youngest son, 18.
"For a mother this is the biggest pain in my entire life, to see my children leaving," said Mrs. Serrano, holding a granddaughter's hand.
Another daughter's husband was also on the boat, along with others from their town of San Miguel del Padron, about a three-hour bus ride from here. They had come to Cojimar as a family 12 days ago, and had camped on the beach.
They spent their days scavenging for bits of lumber and other material to build their boat. They bought what they needed with the money they got from selling many of their possessions back home. They had only a few pesos each day to buy bread.
But finally today, those who wanted to go were on their way.
"I never thought my children would abandon me, but the ruin this country has fallen into has created such misery and hunger that it has forced them to go," Mrs. Serrano said, her voice trembling.

HEADLINE: Luxury Car Fight Turns Uncivilized

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Some blame the sport-utility vehicles, others the higher income taxes on the very wealthy. Some claim "90's values" have made the rich self-conscious, while still others argue that fears of health care cost-cutting have made doctors miserly.
Whatever the reason, the luxury car market, roughly defined as cars costing more than $25,000, or about 13 percent of car sales in the United States, is in turmoil, and the calfskin gloves have come off. 
 No longer do the luxury marques attract customers by simply coughing politely and drawing attention to their burled walnut. These days, the once genteel divisions are publicly taking potshots at each other, and even competing -- heavens! -- on price.
Amid the din, they are rushing to develop less expensive cars, build new plants and branch into new models like fancy trucks and roadsters in a bid to catch up with their customers' rapidly changing tastes.
"We're in a dogfight," said John O. Grettenberger, the vice president for General Motors who is general manager of its Cadillac luxury division, adding a bit archly: "Some of the competition has gotten down to a level that I would never want to see at Cadillac." The reason, he said, is simple: "Everyone's got a lot of cars."
Within the luxury segment, in which buyers perhaps most closely identify cars with the nationalities of their makers, the momentum has shifted. As a category, imports are doing well. But after big losses to the Japanese in the late 1980's, the Germans and Swedes have gained back some ground, while some of the Japanese -- in particular Toyota's luxury division, Lexus, and Honda's luxury division, Acura -- have struggled.
Sales of luxury cars in the United States are up by 4 percent over last year, but they are lagging behind the rest of the robust auto market. In particular, sales of cars costing more than $35,000 are slack, for several reasons. Conspicuous consumption, the luxury car makers grumble, is out. Further, most luxury cars' price tags are too high for executives made anxious by widespread corporate restructuring.
As a result, less expensive cars with all the options but no luxury badge, like the new Mazda Millenia and the forthcoming Toyota Avalon sedan, are drawing buyers who in the past might have paid $40,000 for a little more prestige.
The most unexpected blow to luxury sales, however, has been the popularity of four-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicles like the Jeep Grand Cherokee and the Ford Explorer. That shift has been a boon to the Big Three auto makers, because they make the most sport-utilities.
Such vehicles, auto industry analysts say, remain decorous enough for country-club parking lots, while carrying a rough-and-ready, back-to-nature cachet. It does not hurt their appeal that these vehicles cost less than most luxury cars.
Sales of luxury cars tend to be the most profitable for the auto makers, so the slow pace hurts. In reporting its second-quarter earnings last month, G.M. said slower-than-expected Cadillac sales had undercut the results.
 
'A Captive Audience'
 The Big Three are still searching for a way to halt the slide in their share of the luxury market. Both Cadillac and the Ford Motor Company's luxury division, Lincoln-Mercury, have had little success attracting younger, more affluent buyers.
"Their focus has been on a captive audience -- the same captive audience for 20 years," said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, a consulting firm in Rutherford, N.J.
Hit hard by the last recession, older luxury buyers remain more pessimistic about the economy than younger Americans, according to Cadillac's research. Many are retired, so low interest rates have bitten into their incomes. And Cadillac has found that its older buyers are uncomfortable with leasing, which importers have successfully used to prop up their sales.
Lexus, whose sales and market share have slipped this year despite a jump in July, appears to be a victim of its success at shaking luxury buyers' habits. Many auto makers scoffed in the mid-80's at the idea of a Japanese luxury auto maker, but Lexus quickly proved that customers would flee the traditional luxury marques for cheaper competitors of equal or superior quality.
"People are less hung up on marque," said Maryann N. Keller, auto analyst with Furman Selz in New York. "Lexus educated them."
 
A Climb in Prices
 It also educated the German auto makers. "When it came to price and value, we were a little out of whack," said Michael J. Jackson, executive vice president for marketing, service and sales of Mercedes-Benz of North America.
But Lexus's prices have climbed steadily, partly because of the strength of the Japanese yen. BMW and Mercedes reacted by lowering or at least maintaining some prices. They also became more sensitive to Americans' tastes -- dampening road noise, for example, and adding cup holders.
"The industry has had five years to try to match Lexus," said George E. Borst, the group vice president for Toyota who is general manager of the Lexus division, in a meeting with reporters here last month.
But, he acknowledged, "Our products are priced above where the market is." Customers want luxury cars priced at or below $35,000, he said. But 60 percent of the Lexus models cost more than that.
As the 1994 model year comes to an end in September, the lowest-priced Lexus, the ES300, costs $31,200 -- 19.3 percent more than its introductory price of $29,250 in 1992, according to an analysis by Ms. Jacobs. During the same period, the price of the lowest level Mercedes -- the C class -- has risen 2.2 percent, to $29,900, from $29,250, even though Mercedes introduced an all new version for 1994.
 
'Water Over the Dam'
 To help buyers over the initial price hurdle, Lexus dealers are running advertisements that stress the resale value of the cars. While luxury advertising has traditionally eschewed negative attacks on the competition, one of the new Lexus ads shows a Mercedes atop a dam.
"European luxury owners are good sports about the high cost of owning their cars," the commercial begins. "To them, it's just water over the dam."
The ad goes on to claim that because of its high resale value, a Lexus LS, priced at $51,200, costs at least $14,000 less to own over five years "than most European competitors in its class."
Mr. Borst predicted that vigorous cost-cutting and new products would restore the Lexus price position before long, and no one is counting Lexus out of the market. But some of Mr. Borst's competitors are clearly relishing his predicament, and they are not above delivering the occasional jab at his product line.
"They're very competent cars, no doubt about it," said Victor H. Doolan, president of BMW of North America. "But are they very exciting cars? I don't think so, and I think the market agrees with that."
In addition to fiercer competition from each other, luxury marques are trying to fend off an even stiffer challenge from outside their ranks: the sport-utility vehicle market. "A lot of the people who moved up into S.U.V.'s are people whose logical next purchase would have been a luxury car," Mr. Borst said.
 
A Move to Practicality
 Further, some luxury car owners are switching their allegiances. Gary Chefetz, a 37-year-old business consultant in Edison, N.J., recently traded in a Mercedes roadster for a Jeep Grand Cherokee with leather seats.
"It's got all the features of a luxury car and all the abilities of a car of this type," he said of the Jeep. After the snows of last winter, he decided he wanted a more practical, four-wheel-drive vehicle.
"It's not an insult to Mercedes," he added. "They don't have a competing product. If they did, I'd probably buy it."
Mercedes is scrambling to halt further defections by building a plant in Tuscaloosa County, Ala., to start producing what the company calls an "all activity vehicle" by 1997. Lexus is weighing the idea of a luxury sport-utility, but Mr. Borst said it would not have one before 1996.
By buying Rover Group of Britain earlier this year, BMW acquired the auto maker's popular line of off-road vehicles, including the new Discovery, with a base price of less than $30,000. Free to focus on its car lineup, BMW is planning to produce a new two-seat convertible roadster at a plant it is building in Spartanburg, S.C.
Even without luxury sport-utilities, the German and Swedish auto makers have made strong gains in sales and market share this year.
 
A Sleek Sedan
 Sales of Volvos, for example, have shot up almost 20 percent in 1994, as the company has recast its image to draw younger buyers. Volvos lost sales in the late 80's, as customers came to perceive them as safe but dull cars for people long on children or short on imagination.
Further, because they lacked front-wheel drive, the cars dropped off the list for those faced with the prospect of fishtailing through snowstorms.
But in late 1992, Volvo introduced a relatively sleek sedan, the 850, with an in-line five-cylinder engine driving the front wheels. The 850, with a base price of about $26,000, is also available as a wagon and now accounts for about 55 percent of Volvo's sales.
BMW's sales are also up substantially -- 12 percent for the year. The company has gained back share since the beginning of the 1990 model year, when it began paying closer attention to Americans' tastes.
Moving away from the brooding tones preferred by its home market, BMW began offering brighter colors, both inside and out. Also in deference to American tastes, it added touches of wood and began installing seats with wrinkled, rather than taught, leather.
But its most aggressive action came in pricing. For the 1990 model year, for example, the price of the 535i sedan, its midsize model, fell to $41,500, from $43,600. Since then, BMW has tried to limit price increases. Five years later, in the 1995 model year, the 535i has been replaced by the 540i, priced at $42,750.
"There was a change in values from the 80's to the 90's," Mr. Doolan of BMW said. "People are not just buying status."
Or, at least, they're not willing to pay quite so much for it. Mr. Doolan expects strong sales in the low- to mid-luxury range, but, he said, "I don't see a lot of growth over $50,000."

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE PEOPLE;
In Crisis Over Cuba, Moderates and Castro Supporters Cry Out to Be Heard

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 29

 BODY:
In meetings with the White House and in large demonstrations here, the message heard from Cuban exiles has mostly been the same: no negotiations with Cuba, out with Fidel Castro.
But heard less often are voices from other parts of the broad political spectrum among the exiles, voices often overwhelmed by the political and economic power wielded by conservative groups opposed to any dealings with Mr. Castro. They are the voices of other representatives of the Cuban-American community who advocate talks with the Cuban leader and oppose harsh measures like a naval blockade of the island, saying they want to avoid further hardship for those in Cuba. 
 The spectrum includes moderate Democrats who seek a negotiated transfer of power in Cuba, Cuban-Americans involved in humanitarian aid, and Castro sympathizers.
Moderate groups here say they are hopeful that mid-level meetings this week between the United States and Cuba about the refugee crisis will lead to broader discussions. They say tough measures like the economic embargo, which has been in effect since the Kennedy Administration, have failed to bring about democratic reforms in Cuba and that change can only come through negotiation.
 
'Bringing Democracy to Cuba'
 "I hope that the talks go beyond immigration," said Alfredo Duran, a Miami lawyer and former state chairman of the Democratic Party who last year helped form a coalition of "moderate and progressive" business executives, academics and other professionals, the Cuban Committee for Democracy.
"There's no question right now that the only way rafts are going to be stopped is when Castro stops them, but that's not going to resolve the ultimate problem of bringing democracy to Cuba," Mr. Duran said.
Most of the Cuban exiles share the goal of moving the Cuban Government toward democracy. But while the conservatives lobby for punitive measures to remove Mr. Castro from power, the moderates accept Mr. Castro for now. Trying to get rid of him, they say, would only lead to civil war or an American invasion.
Some of the exile groups that take a softer stance, like the Cuban Committee for Democracy, were formed within the last two years, partly because of the election of the first Democratic President in 12 years and partly because Cuba's economic troubles have put the country in a position to seek alternatives to Communism. But so far, the Clinton Administration seems to have consulted mostly with conservative Cuban leaders on ways to deal with the influx of refugees.
 
Warnings of Angry Reaction
 Most prominent among these leaders is Jorge Mas Canosa, a wealthy businessman who is chairman of the Cuban American National Foundation and one of four representatives of Miami's Cuban community who met with President Clinton in Washington two weeks ago. Foundation officials staunchly oppose discussions on issues other than immigration, and have warned of an angry reaction among Cuban exiles in Miami if more comes to pass.
Some experts now say that the exclusion of a wide range of views in meetings between the White House and exile leaders is another indication of how hastily the Clinton Administration's policy on Cuba was put together. After the President met with the exile leaders, he cut off cash remittances to Cuba and limited travel to the island by relatives in the United States.
"There's a large constituency that still does want to send money to their families, who wants to travel to Cuba, and at the White House there wasn't somebody there who said, 'I'm sorry, I disagree,' " said Lisandro Perez, director of the Cuban Research Institute at Florida International University. "These are usually newer immigrants who don't have the power or the money to be in political circles."
Last week, White House officials broadened consultations and met in Miami with about 70 people representing about a dozen civic groups as well as government agencies to explain the new policies and gather local reaction. Among the Cubans in the group, however, no one advocated a dialogue with Cuba, said Jeff Eller, a White House spokesman who was in Miami for the talks. He said he did not know why other groups were not included.
 
Crashing the Meeting
 The omission so frustrated Eddie Levy and Xiomara Almaguer, who head another group that advocates negotiations, the Cuban American Defense League, that they decided to crash the all-day meeting at Miami Dade County College. Ms. Almaguer said some of the Cuban participants walked out when she began to speak.
"Everybody there was from the far right," said Mr. Levy, who also heads Jewish Solidarity, a group that sends food and medical supplies to Jews in Cuba. "If they want to listen to Cubans, they have to listen to more than one sector of the community."
Mr. Mas, of the Cuban American National Foundation, insisted that the President solicited a broad range of exile views. The group that met with Mr. Clinton included Maria Elena Torano, a Democrat who worked in the Carter Administration and now heads a management consulting and environmental services company; Cesar Odio, the Miami city manager, and Luis Lauredo, another Democrat and businessman who is coordinating Florida's preparations for the upcoming Summit of the Americas.
But Mr. Mas said there was no reason to involve those who advocate talks with Mr. Castro.
"This type of people are an insignificant minority in Miami," he said. "They reflect the opinion of the Cuban Government."
 
Petition Drive to Open Talks
 The political spectrum in the exile community does include organizations that support Havana. Last week a group of them began a petition drive in Miami and other cities with large Cuban populations, demanding that the Clinton Administration rescind its policy of detaining refugees and its ban on travel and monetary aid, and open talks with the Cuban Government.
Andres Gomez, national coordinator for one of the groups, the Antonio Maceo Brigade, said the United States had encouraged immigration from Cuba for the last three decades and was morally responsible to continue accepting Cuban refugees.
"I don't know whether that is its purpose, but the current policy is a policy of war," he said. "There has never been any indication that the Cuban Government makes concessions under pressure."
Nicolas Rios, the publisher of a monthly magazine on Cuban issues who visits Cuba frequently to meet with Communist Party workers, said, "The intelligent thing to do now is to give Mr. Castro an exit." He contends that by now the Government in Havana will be willing to negotiate "everything."
 
Looking for Alternatives
 Many of those advocating conciliation say they are just looking for alternatives to 35 years of hostility between Cuba and the United States. If the United States is willing to normalize relations with Communist countries like North Korea, he said, why not Cuba?
"The cold war is over," said Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, a former political prisoner and president of Cambio Cubano, an exile group that advocates talks with Cuba and lifting the economic embargo.
But Mr. Lauredo, one of the Democrats who met with Mr. Clinton, said the only way Cuba can become a democracy is with Mr. Castro's departure.
"There have been several attempts at negotiations in the past by Latin American leaders intervening with Castro to open up the system, and we've gotten absolutely nowhere," Mr. Lauredo said. "I believe sanctions would put more pressure on him."
As the United States deals with the influx of Cuban immigrants, some Cuban exiles here concede that they are at a loss for answers. Raul Rodriguez, an architect who is active in Cuban-American affairs, said Mr. Castro is "an unreliable negotiator" who would not keep his word, but he was reluctant to call for drastic action to bring down the Cuban leader.
"The only incentive for people to arise against Castro is to make it a fair fight," he said. "Making them more impoverished than they already are won't make them better soldiers to bring him down."
"Besides, what will be left after a civil war?" he asked. "The losers will be the Cuban people."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

HEADLINE: CUTS IN MEDICARE ARE ON THE TABLE, BUT PERIL IS SEEN

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
Even while spurning most of President Clinton's health care plan, members of Congress have eagerly accepted one part of the original proposal, which would take money from Medicare and Medicaid to help finance health insurance for people without coverage.
The President's dream of universal health insurance appears to be dead in this Congress. But his proposal to set stringent limits on the growth of Medicare and Medicaid is very much alive in the more modest proposals still being considered in the Senate and the House. 
 The prospect of such cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid, in the absence of new benefits, alarms many beneficiaries, doctors and hospital executives, though Federal budget officials say the two programs are growing at unsustainable rates.
Lawmakers from all political camps, including Democratic and Republican leaders of the House and the Senate, rely heavily on savings in Medicare and Medicaid to pay for efforts to expand coverage.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said, "If health care reform is not enacted this year, it is as close to a certainty as there can be in the legislative process that there will be a cap on Medicaid and Medicare enacted next year."
But experts on health policy say the proposed cutbacks could have adverse effects. While the cutbacks are aimed primarily at doctors and hospitals, not at beneficiaries, the experts say that if Federal payments are reduced, doctors will probably become even less willing than they are today to care for patients on Medicare or Medicaid.
Moreover, they say, many doctors and hospitals that accept such patients will make up the lost revenue by increasing their charges to patients with private insurance. Businesses and labor unions have long complained about such cost-shifting because they pay the extra costs.
Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for 32 million elderly and 4 million disabled people, pays doctors an average of 59 percent of what private insurers pay, and the gap has been widening, according to the Physician Payment Review Commission, a Federal panel that advises Congress on payment of doctors.
Paul B. Ginsburg, executive director of the commission, said most of the health care bills pending in Congress would further increase the gap in fees paid to doctors by Medicare and by private insurers.
Medicaid, the Federal-state program for 33 million low-income people, pays doctors 47 percent of what private insurers pay. Many doctors refuse to take Medicaid patients because the fees are so low.
Several authoritative studies suggest that most Medicare beneficiaries have good access to medical care, but that there are problems for some groups, including blacks, Hispanic Americans, people who are disabled and those who live in rural areas and inner-city neighborhoods.
 
'Beginning of a Problem'
 Dr. John M. Eisenberg, chairman of the Physician Payment Review Commission, said: "The problems in access to physicians' services for Medicare beneficiaries are just below the surface. People in areas underserved by doctors, members of minority groups and poor people already have the beginning of a problem. This should be a red flag."
Vic Rosenthal, staff director of the Minnesota Senior Federation, a consumer group with 35,000 members, said that "it's difficult to find doctors who are willing to take Medicare patients" in some rural areas of Minnesota, and added, "Our big fear is that if you cut Medicare, there are likely to be fewer physicians willing to participate in the program."
In addition, Mr. Rosenthal said, the premiums that elderly people pay for private insurance to supplement Medicare may rise. The supplementary insurance, known as Medigap, pays medical expenses not covered by Medicare. There will be more such expenses if Medicare pays less, he said, so "cuts in Medicare will drive up the cost of Medigap policies."
The Congressional Budget Office said the President's original health care proposal would have cut the projected growth of Medicare by $103 billion, or 9 percent, over five years. The bills offered by Mr. Mitchell and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, would save slightly more.
While lobbyists for the elderly do not like such cutbacks, they were willing to accept them as part of a plan to restructure the health care system and to control health spending across the board. Many of the comprehensive proposals discussed this summer would have provided new benefits for the elderly, including coverage of prescription drugs and long-term care. But such benefits are less likely to be included in the more modest bills that Congress will consider when it returns from its summer recess on Sept. 12.
Mr. Clinton also proposed to limit private health spending by setting a cap on the annual growth of private health insurance premiums. Mr. Gephardt would set annual limits on public and private health spending for the nation as a whole and for each state. Insurance companies, doctors, hospitals and drug companies fiercely opposed the limits on premiums, arguing that they would lead to the rationing of health care.
There is little support in Congress for any proposal that would authorize the Government to regulate or limit private health spending. But there is strong bipartisan support for legislation to limit Federal spending through Medicare and Medicaid. The process of overhauling the health care system now looks, to some people, like an effort to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
 
Subsidies for the Poor
 John C. Rother, chief lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons, said: "The private sector has succeeded in eliminating insurance premium caps. The proposed restraints on the growth of Medicare have increasingly been used as a means of financing not only improved benefits for Medicare beneficiaries, but also the proposed subsidies for low-income people."
Under Mr. Clinton's original plan, all Americans would have had health insurance "that can never be taken away." In trying to curb Medicare payments to hospitals, he justified his proposals by saying that hospitals would no longer need to provide charity care because all their patients would be insured.
But Congress is now considering much more modest proposals that would leave millions of people uninsured. The Medicare and Medicaid cutbacks have not been adjusted to reflect that fact.
The Congressional Budget Office says Mr. Mitchell's bill would have cut $112 billion, or 9 percent, from the projected growth of Medicare over five years. A bipartisan group of about 20 senators who call themselves the mainstream coalition wants to cut the growth of Medicare by $70 billion over five years.
A measure drafted by a group of moderate lawmakers in the House, including Representatives J. Roy Rowland of Georgia, a Democrat, and Michael Bilirakis of Florida, a Republican, would trim $61 billion from Medicare over five years. Mr. Gephardt's bill would reduce the growth of Medicare by $110 billion over five years, mostly by imposing a cap on the program.
 
$56 Billion Cut Last Year
 These changes would all come on top of savings made last year when Congress approved the President's budget plan, squeezing $56 billion from Medicare over five years.
The Mitchell and Gephardt bills, like the Clinton plan, assumed that large amounts of money could be saved by abolishing most of the Medicaid program and giving subsidies to poor people to buy private insurance. The Senate coalition's proposal would also phase out most of Medicaid, on the assumption that its recipients would buy private health insurance.
But experts say such changes may be unworkable if there is no way to pool the purchasing power of Medicaid recipients and other consumers.
Joshua M. Wiener, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said: "For what Medicaid pays on average, you cannot buy a health insurance plan in the private market that covers the Medicaid benefit package. So if there are large Medicaid cuts with no comprehensive reform of the health care system, Medicaid recipients may be worse off than they are now."

Reshaping the Arms Industry
A merger of Lockheed and Martin Marietta would reshape the arms industry. The $10 billion deal continues a steady drumbeat of takeovers and mergers that has grown only louder as the Pentagon's budget declines in the post-cold-war era. [Page A1.] 
 The proposed merger poses a problem for the Clinton Administration: how to encourage a consolidation of the military industry while enforcing antitrust laws. [D5.]
The two leaders of Lockheed and Martin Marietta come from vastly different backgrounds but share a vision. [D5.]
Lockheed shareholders get a premium, but Martin Marietta executives will get the key jobs. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
 
Companies
 General Signal and Reliance Electric agreed to merge in a a stock swap valued at $1.3 billion. [D1.]

Some Wall Street firms are getting into the lending business, arranging loan packages for companies. [D1.]

The Economy

Business Technology

HEADLINE: U.S. Pins Its Hopes on Dividing the Serbs' House

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 30

 BODY:
The United States, frustrated in its attempt to engineer a Bosnian settlement, is eyeing a new policy for ending the war: defeat or ouster of the Bosnian Serb leaders with the help of their former patron, the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic.
It is a high-risk policy -- for the Clinton Administration and for President Milosevic. But after the Bosnian Serbs' crushing rejection of an American-backed peace plan for Bosnia in a referendum, it has emerged as the only alternative to an increase in the fighting. 
 After some wavering, the Bosnian Serb rejection of the peace plan is now categorical and appears to be backed by more than 90 percent of the Serbian population in Bosnia.
"The map is history," said an aide to Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic. "It is completely and totally and utterly unacceptable. You can put it in the archives."
But for the Clinton Administration, which spent months drafting the plan with Russia, Britain, France and Germany, the map's offer of 51 percent of the territory to the Muslim-led Bosnian government and 49 percent to the Serbs amounts to a final attempt to reach what it regards as an equitable peace and will not be withdrawn.
 
Marriage of Interests
 It is in this dogged pursuit of the proposed settlement that the outlines of an unlikely marriage of interests has emerged between the Clinton Administration and its longtime Balkan enemy, President Milosevic.
The United States, bereft of alternatives, wants the peace plan to stick; President Milosevic, leading a country wearied by a long trade embargo, now wants the war he planned and backed to go away because he judges that the economic and political risks for its continuation have become too great.
Thus, for the Serbian President, as for the American, the plan is the only way out of an impasse.
But the critical question for the Clinton Administration is: how far to support, and how far to believe, the man whose vision of a Greater Serbia was the vehicle of his rise to power and the centerpiece of his hold on it before he turned on the Bosnian Serbs three weeks ago and cut them off by closing the Serbia-Bosnia border?
"Milosevic does not have a record of credibility that you would jump to accept," one American official said, alluding to an earlier Serbian embargo on the Bosnian Serbs that quickly evaporated last year. "But this time he seems to mean business. And if we are satisfied that the embargo is airtight, the possibility of easing trade sanctions on Serbia would be looked at with favor."
 
Border Is Now Sealed
 Inspections of the border by United States diplomats during the last three weeks have suggested it is virtually sealed. But officials said the Clinton Administration would not be satisfied that the frontier is "airtight" unless several hundred international monitors were allowed to station themselves on the border.
This stance has already provoked tensions with Russia, whose Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, complained today of "diplomatic inertia" and "little flexibility" among the so-called contact group of countries in rewarding President Milosevic for his new stand. Mr. Kozyrev, at the very least, wants an opening of Belgrade airport.
His desire for quick action is understandable in that the political situation in Serbia is delicate.
If President Milosevic does agree to the placing of several hundred monitors on Serbian soil between his citizens and the Serbs west of the Drina River, he will be ridiculed by his former nationalist allies, the Serbian Radical Party of Vojislav Seselj. More importantly, there could well be some muttering in the ranks of the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army.
 
A Delicate Balance
 On the other hand, if President Milosevic resists the American demand for monitors, and is not rewarded by an easing of sanctions for having turned on the Bosnian Serbs, his political support could erode. What, his opponents will ask, have you gained by betraying our fellow Serbs?
For now, with his control of the media and his deft exploitation of Serbian weariness with the war in Bosnia, President Milosevic has kept firm control. Opinion polls that were hostile to the peace plan have suddenly turned favorable; state television now interviews lovers of peace rather than prosecutors of war.
But the fact remains that he has taken a considerable risk and headed into uncharted territory by dumping the Bosnian Serbs.
"Milosevic wants a lifting of sanctions and so he is prepared to push us into an unfavorable agreement," the top aide to Dr. Karadzic said. "In other words, he is prepared to sell the more than one million Serbs west of the Drina in order to strengthen his political situation. Our people are bitter and appalled by what he has done and if he thinks he can push our leaders from power, it is not going to work."
 
Preparing for Long War
 Certainly, the Bosnian Serbs, even isolated from Serbia, still have considerable assets: the support of the Orthodox Church, of most Serbs living outside the region, and of several opposition parties in Serbia. Moreover, even if the Bosnian Serb referendum was imperfect, it suggests a considerable unity massed behind a powerful army led by the most skillful general in Bosnia, Gen. Ratko Mladic.
"Fuel is our one problematic issue," an aide to Dr. Karadzic said. "But as Serbia has done under the embargo, we will get it at a price. For now we have strategic reserves and our sources, like the Muslims in Gorazde who sell us what the United Nations hands out to them. We are not too worried."
Clearly, the Bosnian Serbs are now preparing for a long war. For them, the peace plan is a recipe for extinction because it divides their territory into three areas and obliges them to give up crucial cities and resources.
They want the plan scrapped and a solution built around an exchange where the Muslim-led government would give up their enclaves in eastern Bosnia for territory to the north and west of Sarajevo.
"The solution lies in dividing Sarajevo and in granting international recognition to our state or entity," the senior Bosnian Serb official said.
 
Balkan Loyalties
 All this is quite unacceptable to the Clinton Administration, which therefore faces the uncomfortable task of fulfilling its promise to press for a lifting of the arms embargo on the Bosnian Muslims after Oct. 15. More, and more intense, war would then follow. Unless, that is, something should happen to Dr. Karadzic.
In August last year, something almost did. Junior officers in the Bosnian Serb militia staged an insurrection in Banja Luka, placing tanks on the street and demanding elections and the removal of the Karadzic leadership, whom they described as war profiteers. In the end, General Mladic managed to calm the uprising.
But links between the Yugoslav Army and the Bosnian Serb forces remain strong. If, as he appears, President Milosevic has the Yugoslav Army behind his new policy, American officials say restiveness may now exist among Bosnian Serb officers.
Moreover, these officials are not convinced of General Mladic's undying loyalty to Dr. Karadzic.
This may be wishful thinking. "General Mladic, as a professional soldier and a nationalist, is totally loyal to Dr. Karadzic," the senior Bosnian Serb official said.
But one thing is clear: if the United States is ever to pry Dr. Karadzic from his army and his commander, the only possible effective vehicle is President Milosevic.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The future of Sarajevo was one of the major points of disagreement in the peace plan for Bosnia that was overwhelmingly rejected by Bosnian Serb voters in a referendum over the weekend. Strollers, taking advantage of the current lull in fighting, filled the streets in the city's center yesterday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: U.S. Backed on Possible Invasion of Haiti

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 30

 BODY:
Intensifying the pressure on Haiti's military rulers to step down, the United States won support today from Caribbean nations for a possible invasion if economic sanctions and diplomatic entreaties fail.
Foreign ministers and military commanders from the 13-member Caribbean Community and Common Market backed a United Nations-approved invasion to restore the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 Four of the seven members that have armed forces said they would contribute a token force of 266 troops to an American-led invasion force of 10,000. The Caribbean troops, from Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, Barbados and Belize, are to begin training immediately at a United States Navy base at Roosevelt Roads, Puerto Rico.
Britain and Argentina also promised to help train troops and to conduct military planning.
 
A Symbolic Visit
 A visit here today by Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch was largely symbolic because the ministers' pledge was known in advance, and the Caribbean troops will not be in an invasion vanguard. But the public endorsement is critical to the Clinton Administration's efforts to make a credible show of force.
"Our military-diplomatic efforts are marshalled and we are determined to return democracy to Haiti with few or no casualties," Mr. Deutch said at a news conference after the meeting.
American and Caribbean officials refused to discuss the timing of a possible invasion. But Mr. Talbott said that the situation in Haiti had taken on "increased urgency" and that "there is a shared sense that the situation cannot continue very much longer."
Mr. Talbott cited the killing on Sunday night of a close friend of Father Aristide, the Rev. Jean-Marie Vincent, and the Haitian military's rebuff of an envoy from United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali who was seeking discussions with the Haitian leaders.
 
High U.S. Presence
 But American officials also said they plan to give tighter economic sanctions a chance to work before resorting to force. A multinational observer force to be stationed on Haiti's border with the Dominican Republic to help spot smugglers will not be in full operation until Sept. 13, which would seem to delay any invasion for at least several weeks.
The unusual high-level American presence at the meeting here was also intended to combat perceptions among some lawmakers and members of Father Aristide's cabinet-in-exile that the Administration had been distracted by the Cuban refugee crisis and was not fully committed to ousting the Haitian generals.
Whether Haiti's junta leaves on its own or at gunpoint, American officials said an initial force of 10,000 troops will go in to establish order; the four countries that committed troops will help monitor police activities. Guyana and the Bahamas are also considering sending troops for this first phase.
 
Last Chance for Sanctions
 Once order has been re-established, a process that Mr. Deutch said could take several months, a second force of about 6,000 troops under United Nations command would replace the American-led force and be responsible for keeping order, reorganizing the military and building a new police force. Several countries that are not joining the first force have said they will probably join the second phase.
But both American and Caribbean officials said they wanted to give sanctions one last chance. The State Department and Pentagon, however, disagree over how long to wait. Mr. Talbott, in particular, has strongly advocated the early use of military force; Defense Secretary William J. Perry leans toward giving sanctions a longer trial.
A maritime embargo and cancellation of commercial flights in and out of Haiti has brought the already weak economy to a standstill. Gasoline costs have jumped to more than $8 a gallon.
But smugglers have turned Haiti's porous 165-mile border with the Dominican Republic into a sieve, running an estimated 40,000 to 50,000 gallons of gasoline across the border daily. After the meeting here, Mr. Deutch, Mr. Talbott and Leon Fuerth, Vice President Al Gore's national security adviser, flew in helicopters over the northern border area and vowed new help to seal the frontier.
Col. William McDonough, of the United States Army, is commanding the observer group.
During the brief visit today to a forward command post in Monte Cristi, in the Dominican Republic, Colonel McDonough said the purpose of the force would be to disrupt as much of the smuggling as possible, while recognizing that there was no leak-proof sanctions.
He said the group would focus on the large tanker trucks that smugglers bring into the border towns to pick up fuel.


GRAPHIC: Officials of Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, Barbados and Belize told United States officials yesterday they would contribute a total of 266 soldiers to a military operation in Haiti. Guyana and the Bahamas did not make a final commitment of forces. The United States will make up the bulk of the proposed 10,000 member force.

HEADLINE: FLIGHT FROM CUBA: THE SCENE;
And Still Cubans Flee: 1,300 More Picked Up

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 30

 BODY:
Cubans continued their steady exodus from their homeland on handmade rafts today, making haste before political changes here and in Washington that they fear could prevent them from leaving.
The United States Coast Guard said that it had picked up more than 1,300 refugees by nightfall, a sign that the exodus was expanding after a weekend lull in which bad weather kept many from leaving. 
 Many here say they believe that a decision may be made to limit the exodus after the Cuban Government opens talks Thursday with the Clinton Administration.
This morning a flotilla of boats laden with hundreds of Cubans bobbed near the horizon, although the flow slowed as the winds picked up. Dozens of rafts continued to appear on the beach, carried there by people invariably citing the troubled economy as their main reason for leaving.
Others brought rafts to sell, with prices varying from $600 to $1,200, depending on how many inner tubes formed the body of the raft. By late afternoon, a heavy rain prompted would-be refugees on the beach to scatter for shelter.
 
The Talk Is of Hardships
 As life elsewhere in Havana continued as usual, with most people clearly making no plans to leave, those on the beaches talked of the hardships brought about by Cuba's economic crisis.
Just before the storm set in, a man in a blue polo shirt stood on the beach looking out to sea through a pair of binoculars. The man, who refused to be identified, said he was a neurologist and mentioned that two younger doctors who worked at a hospital with him had left on a raft a few days ago. "Of course this is discrediting this Government," he said. "People have always left, but not in this great a number."
Recalling the thousands who sailed from the port of Mariel in 1980 and from Camarioca in 1965, he said the boatlift was a sign that things were once again amiss in Cuba.
Curiosity, he said, brought him to the beach; he himself would not depart that way, in a flimsy boat with so much risk. At 46, he said, he does not have the time to start over in a new country with a new language.
"Perhaps I'll go to Spain," he said. "I think it would be easier for me to make a new start there."
As a doctor, he is a member of Cuba's privileged class. He has a car, he is buying his apartment and recently he took a vacation in Varadero, Cuba's premier beach resort. But he explained what a "privileged" life meant in Cuba.
He bought his car 14 years ago, at a special price as a reward for having served four years as a doctor in Africa for his country. That was before the Soviet Union cut off subsidies to Cuba, setting off an economic crisis that led to an enormous gap between wages and the price of goods.
 
The High Price of a Tire
 His car needs two new tires and a new battery.
"I earn 425 pesos a month," or about $5, he said. "New tires would cost me about 2,000 pesos and a new battery is about $60." Many of Cuba's scarcest goods are available only in Government stores that accept only dollars.
"How long do you think I have to work to buy one tire?" he said.
During his vacation, he said, "I didn't spend one peso." The Varadero resort accepts only dollars, which he does not have. "I stayed at a friend's house and we brought all of our own food."
The doctor said he really was not complaining, though, because he has much more than many of his countrymen.
A group of people stood around a simple raft made of two inner tubes piled on two others and separated by a few wooden planks. The contraption was wrapped in yellow rope netting.
Three brothers were inspecting the craft to make sure it was seaworthy. One was 18-year-old Oxaini Carlos Bascaro.
"There is nothing left for me here," he said. "There are no jobs, there is not enough food." It is a refrain heard throughout the beaches as people prepare to set out.
 
The Tourists Take All
 "Here everything is for the tourists," said Mr. Bascaro's brother-in-law, Regino Valdez, who is 25. "Cubans see none of what the tourists have access to here, not the food, nor even the music of Cuba itself."
Mr. Bascaro's sister, Osuni Abilez, had come to wish her brothers well. A gymnastics teacher at a state-run sports center, she said Cuba's economy was not offering much hope to many of its young people.
"I don't want to see them go, but they say they want the freedom to make a better way of life," she said. "All I can do is pray that they make it there, because we hear of so many people who have perished at sea."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Cutters on Patrol
 MIAMI, Aug. 30 (Special to The New York Times) -- United States Coast Guard cutters swept an area about 20 miles off Havana today, plucking people from about 50 rafts. Despite an order from Fidel Castro for the Cuban Coast Guard to stop anyone from leaving with children, some children were picked up today.
Death was also evident in the Florida Straits.
Lieut. Martha Bruner of the United States Coast Guard, who flew a helicopter today spotting rafts for the cutters, said she saw a bloated body floating face-down about 30 miles off Cuba.
"Any time you travel on a raft or a small boat it is going to be dangerous," she said, even in today's calm seas, which were free of the whitecaps and 10-foot swells of the weekend.
Instead, Cubans on rafts encountered two-foot waves and a "nice breeze," Lieutenant Bruner said. "A couple rafts had sails up and eight people rowing," she added.
The flow of refugees peaked last week when the Coast Guard intercepted an average of 2,000 Cubans each day. But as bad weather crossed the straits, just 130 were rescued on Saturday and 84 on Sunday.
"It seems like there's an upward trend here as long as the weather stays," Lieutenant Bruner said.

HEADLINE: RESHAPING THE ARMS INDUSTRY: THE GOVERNMENT;
Deal's Antitrust Issue Is Test for White House

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
The proposed merger of the nation's second- and third-largest weapons makers is bound to test how the Clinton Administration can reconcile two conflicting policies: encouraging the consolidation of the military industry while aggressively enforcing Federal antitrust laws.
The combination of Lockheed and Martin Marietta -- the largest military-industry merger in American history -- would produce the second-largest aerospace company, behind Boeing, and the largest military contractor. It may also force still more mergers in an industry that has responded slowly and painfully to the end of the cold war and the rapid decline in military spending. 
 Senior officials at the Justice and Defense Departments were cautious in their assessment of the deal and said it would be scrutinized for possible antitrust problems.
"There are certain to be very serious antitrust questions about this merger," said Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch, who balanced his concern by also noting that he thought the merger "was generally a good idea for the U.S. taxpayer."
 
Close Collaboration
 Under an agreement reached earlier this year between the Pentagon and antitrust regulators that anticipated large mergers in the military industry, there will be close collaboration between the regulators and the Defense Department to study precisely how weapons systems will be affected and whether the deal will wind up costing the Government more money.
The Pentagon's recommendations will carry great weight, officials said, but the final legal determinations will be made by the Justice Department or the Federal Trade Commission, which began today to consider who would control the inquiry.
In letters to the Justice Department and the trade commission, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat who heads the Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Antitrust, Monopolies and Business Rights, criticized the merger, saying it "could be harmful to taxpayers, small business and consumers."
"If you conclude that the merger is anticompetitive and if the companies fail to act in accordance with your recommendations," Mr. Metzenbaum wrote, "I would urge you to promptly sue to block the merger in Federal court."
But antitrust lawyers said that to the extent the Government intervened, it would not be to block the deal but to require the new company to sell off certain divisions to assure competition for particular weapons. For instance, Lockheed and Martin Marietta are two of the nation's largest suppliers of classified military satellite systems, a market that Mr. Deutch said today would be re-examined in light of the merger.
For months, Defense Secretary William J. Perry has urged military contractors to carry out an orderly consolidation that preserves America's ability to develop the most advanced technology at affordable costs. But at the Justice Department, Anne K. Bingaman, the Assistant Attorney General who is head of the antitrust division, has led a division that prides itself on appearing to be more vigorous than the Republican Administrations of the prior 12 years.
The division has also opposed giving special consideration to arms makers even as the industry undergoes its largest contraction in modern history in response to 65 percent cut in Defense Department spending since 1985.
Still, some experts said today that this merger was bound to get different antitrust treatment because the Government is the military industry's main consumer, and because the issues involve national security.
 
Defense, Not Tennis Balls
 "We're not just dealing with shoes or tennis balls or steel or oil," said Prof. Robert Pitofsky of the Georgetown University Law Center, an antitrust scholar who earlier this year headed the task force whose analysis was the basis for the agreement between the antitrust regulators and the Pentagon. "We're talking about national defense."
While the law makes only a narrow exception for failing companies and no exception for companies operating in distressed industries, some industry executives and antitrust scholars have contended that the law is antiquated and should be construed flexibly. They note that the wide extent of the industrial problems created by the shrinking of such a large portion of the American economy was never anticipated.
Mr. Pitofsky said there were only three instances in more than 300 military-industry mergers in which the Government successfully blocked combinations, the most recent of which occurred in 1992, when the Federal Trade Commission stopped Alliant Techsystems from acquiring a big part of the Olin Corporation's military business. But those proposed acquisitions were significantly smaller deals than today's agreement. Short of trying to block the merger, the Government might order the companies to sell off certain divisions before approving the deal.
The most basic legal question for considering whether the merger should be approved, according to Prof. Eleanor Fox, an antitrust expert at the New York University School of Law, is whether the products and prices of the combined companies would be worse for the Government than they would be if the companies remained as competitors.

HEADLINE: Dole Urges Postponement For Approval Of Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
Only a few days after helping turn back President Clinton's vision of universal health care coverage, Senator Bob Dole has begun urging that Congress not act until next year on another issue important to the Democratic White House, a global free trade pact.
Mr. Dole, the Senate minority leader, said in an opinion article that appeared in The Wichita Eagle on Sunday that while he supported the 117-nation pact, he and his constituents in Kansas had many questions about its cost and its effects on American labor and environmental laws. 
 "We should not race to complete a major trade bill until we know what awaits us at the finish line," he said, adding that the issue could be addressed next year.
If approved by Congress, the pact would cut tariffs around the world by a third and expand the free-trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to cover new industries ranging from farming to accounting. A World Trade Organization would administer the new rules.
 
'Not a Political Issue'
 C. Clarkson Hine, a spokesman for Mr. Dole, said today that the Senator had taken this action because of unresolved issues concerning the trade agreement, and not from any desire to avoid giving President Clinton a political victory shortly before the November election. "It's not a political issue, it's a trade issue," he said.
But Congressional Democrats accused Mr. Dole of playing politics with a pact that, by one estimate, could add $100 billion a year to American economic output in a decade.
"I don't think there is any question that there is a political dimension to this," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, the California Democrat who is acting chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee's trade panel.
 
Potential for Embarrassment
 Mr. Matsui said the United States would suffer international embarrassment if Congress did not pass the agreement this year, because the world's leading trading nations, including the United States, have informally agreed to try to put the pact in place on Jan. 1. The actual terms of the agreement, however, allow countries to wait until July 1 to adopt it and change their tariffs and trade laws accordingly.
A Clinton Administration official who insisted on anonymity said: "We have every intention of working with the bipartisan leadership and finishing it this year. We're not going to play politics with trade."
But Mr. Dole's article in The Wichita Eagle emphasized that his hostility to quick action was broadly grounded in his constituents' misgivings about the agreement. "Calls and letters have been have been flooding my office -- and I am sure my colleagues' offices, too -- on the subject of implementing the W.T.O." the senator wrote. "People are concerned."
Mr. Dole accused the Clinton Administration of not doing enough to explain to the public what was in the trade pact, which was reached last December in Geneva after seven years of negotiations.
 
Position Appears Fixed
 Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate and an outspoken opponent of free trade deals, said that Mr. Dole's reference to constituents' concerns could make it more difficult for him to change his stance later.
Ross Perot, the independent Presidential candidate in 1992, has opposed the GATT deal. He contends that the World Trade Organization violates American sovereignty, will destroy American jobs and will widen the Federal budget deficit.
Sharon Holman, a spokeswoman for Mr. Perot's group, United We Stand America, said: "We feel very strongly that you have to work out all the numbers to be sure we can pay for this."
 
Two Approaches
 President Clinton received some of his highest ratings in opinion polls following Congressional approval last November of the North American pact, which took effect on Jan. 1 and will eliminate trade and investment barriers among Canada, Mexico and the United States by the year 2009.
The House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee have produced bills that use different approaches to raise the money needed to offset the $12 billion in Federal tariff revenue over five years that the world trade pact would eliminate. The House also included a provision that would allow the President to negotiate further trade agreements that could include trade sanctions against countries, including the United States, that use labor and environmental rules as trade barriers.
Mr. Dole expressed concern about both issues in his opinion piece. Mr. Matsui said that a conference of senior House and Senate members was close to resolving the issues. "If we are just given about a week or so, we can finish the conference, send it to the House and Senate floors and get it to the President," said Mr. Matsui, who is a member of the conference.

HEADLINE: 2 More Hints Of Economic Slowdown

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
More signs of economic slowdown emerged today as surveys showed lower confidence among consumers and business executives.
And although the Government reported that sales of new houses rebounded more sharply than expected in July, the outlook in the industry is still for little or no growth in sales in the months ahead. 
 The two indicators join other recent data in suggesting that the pace of economic growth is slowing in the second half of the year. But it will take more significant data, like weak employment figures for August, to placate skeptical traders and investors, who say that the Federal Reserve will have to raise short-term interest rates again this year. The employment report is due Friday.
Consumer confidence, which in June reached a four-year high as gauged by the Conference Board, eased for the second month in August, the business-sponsored research group said today from New York.
"Consumers are somewhat less positive than a month earlier in their assessment of prevailing economic conditions and also less optimistic in their expectations for the months ahead," the board found. It noted "substantially less" optimism than before about the economic situation of families six months hence, with particular pessimism about jobs.
Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich is scheduled to make a major address on Wednesday about an "anxious class" of middle-income workers.
Housing industry officials took only modest comfort from an 8.3 percent jump in sales of single-family homes in July, which was not enough to fully offset June's 11.4 percent plunge, according to figures compiled by the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development.
Rising interest rates have already bitten severely into the housing market, which was a chief propellant of growth late last year, and rates were also cited today as dampening economic prospects generally.
"The trend is still down for sales," said David W. Berson, chief economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association, who said he expects the economy to grow at a rate of 2.2 percent this quarter, compared with 3.8 percent in the spring.
The housing report, showing July sales running at an annual rate of 664,000, 2.6 percent above the July 1993 level, were as good as they were only because many buyers who otherwise would have been driven out of the market were able to turn to adjustable rate mortgages, industry specialists said.
These loans were used in 41 percent of July sales, up from 21 percent as recently as February, said Tommy Thompson, an Owensboro, Ky., builder who is president of the National Association of Home Builders. He said this had cushioned the industry as conventional 30-year mortgages climbed from a low of 6.74 percent in October to 8.62 percent in July.
 
Breakdown by Region
 The July advance was most pronounced in the South, where sales rose 17 percent, but the Northeast posted a 9.8 percent gain from a low level, and sales in the West advanced 6.5 percent. The Midwest showed a 6.2 percent decline.
At the July sales pace, the inventory of 314,000 unsold houses at the end of the month would last 5.8 months, the Government report said. The median sales price in July was $123,000, down from $131,000, a reflection more of transactions in lower-priced homes than of a fall in market prices. The average new house sold for $144,700, down from $156,900.
The Conference Board's report put overall confidence at an index rate of 89, down from 92.5 in June and 91.3 in July. Six regions declined, while three -- New England, East South Central and Mountain -- had gains. New England and the Middle Atlantic States had the lowest readings, by far.
The other reports of lower confidence came from the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors.
The chamber's bimonthly index based on a poll of the small businesses slumped 6.5 points, to 49.9 in August, matching its April level. Nearly 70 percent of those surveyed said higher interest rates already had a negative effect on their businesses.
The wholesalers' index for the current quarter fell to 112.6 from 116.8, while the index for the the year ahead declined to 100.3 from 104.9.
In still another report, the Center for the Study of the States in Albany reported that state collections of sales tax surged 8 percent in the second quarter from the comparable period of 1993, adjusted for legislated changes in rates. Eighteen states had increases in double-digits.
Such revenue gains implies a robust economy during the period covered, but collections have little, if any, value in predicting future economic conditions, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Former Congressman Sets the Pace on the Road to Hartford

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 29

 BODY:
John G. Rowland has been traveling across Connecticut for months now, hammering away at the four issues that he says residents want their next governor to address: jobs, crime, education and welfare.
His message is relentless. Mr. Rowland, a 37-year-old Republican who narrowly lost the 1990 election to Lowell P. Weicker Jr., is far and away the best-known candidate this time, and he wants very much to shape the race while he can. 
Unsurprisingly, all the candidates want more jobs, less crime, better schools, fairer welfare. But Mr. Rowland has most bluntly addressed the state's fragile frame of mind after years of economic trauma in its homes and gang shootings in its cities.
"The wrong people are afraid," he says. Working people fear for their jobs and their safety, he says, while criminals fear nothing.
 
A Conservative Reputation
 Mr. Rowland, who earned a reputation as Connecticut's most conservative Congressman while he represented the Fifth District, which includes Waterbury, from 1985 to 1991, has prescriptions. He says he would revitalize the state's economy by cutting state spending enough to allow the three-year-old personal income tax to be phased out.
He would make prisons places to fear, rather than "Club Meds," and would require life sentences for felons convicted of two violent crimes. Welfare recipients would have to work or undergo job training. Parents would be allowed to choose their children's schools, while the schools and their teachers would be given the means to restore order to classrooms.
The problems city schools face in educating poor children "may not have as much to do with adversity as it does with discipline," Mr. Rowland said at a campaign stop in this wealthy suburb.
Mr. Rowland, who is leading not only in the polls but also in fund-raising, with more than $1 million so far, is waging his campaign almost like an incumbent. When he schedules an event, it carries the weight of a fact-finding mission, as when he toured the East Side of Bridgeport with a police escort this month, or of an official call for action, as when he met with the Legislature's Public Safety Committee immediately after a prison riot in July.
 
An Unusual Election
 Speaking before Republican town committees, Rotary clubs and other groups, he slips in just on time, or a few minutes late, so that he has everyone's attention the moment he arrives. But he rarely seems in a hurry. Outside a Super Stop & Shop on the Post Road here, he finds few shoppers but many campaign volunteers, and he takes the time to shake hands and chat, making sure that everyone who showed up for him is noticed and thanked.
On television, meanwhile, he has begun broadcasting his first ad, vowing to make "our neighborhoods and schools safe from violent crime."
As the early front-runner, Mr. Rowland is finding his toughness and his demands for personal and governmental accountability turned back upon him by his opponents, who are many in this unusual election year. Both Democrats and Republicans have primaries, and even though Mr. Weicker is not running for re-election, his party, A Connecticut Party, is again making the general election a three-way contest.
Suggesting that Mr. Rowland's high standing in the polls is left over from his exposure four years ago, the opponents say his insistence on sticking to the four issues is an attempt to hide his record.
Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer, challenging Mr. Rowland in a Republican primary on Sept. 13, has attacked him as someone whose experience is as a legislator in Washington, not as an executive in Hartford, who after his defeat in 1990 parlayed his Capitol experience into highly paid consulting work for the state's largest military contractors as they laid off thousands of Connecticut workers.
 
A Sense of Discontent
 Mr. Rowland earned $392,406 in 1992 and $361,743 in 1993, including income from his family's insurance agency as well as from consulting for United Technologies, Electric Boat and other corporations.
Other opponents are concerned that Mr. Rowland will succeed in tapping the discontent that has run through the state since the income tax, which has a top rate of 4.5 percent, was imposed in 1991 in the midst of a real-estate collapse and layoffs in Connecticut's defense, banking and insurance industries.
"He gives an irresponsible expression to people's anger," said Roy Ochiogrosso, press secretary for State Comptroller William E. Curry Jr., who is facing State Senator John B. Larson in the Democratic primary. "He's very good at hitting the hot-button issues."
Richard Slawsky, Mr. Rowland's press secretary, responded: "Sooner or later somebody decides that they're behind and what they have to do is attack the front-runner. Bill Curry's in a primary with John Larson, and what does he do? He challenges John Rowland to a debate."
Mr. Rowland has said he will soon release a plan for phasing out the personal income tax, over five years. Eliminating the tax would eliminate $2.6 billion a year, more than 40 percent of the state's tax revenue. Connecticut has an annual budget of about $9 billion.
 
The Fear-of-Crime Rate
 Mrs. Kezer said she would reduce the income tax but that it cannot be eliminated without raising other taxes. Senator Larson has pledged a 25 percent income-tax cut for middle-income families, while Mr. Curry has called for the state to finance a billion-dollar cut in local property taxes.
Mr. Rowland's favorite talking point so far has been crime, and his favorite target has been the state's Prison Commissioner, Larry R. Meachum, whom he says coddles inmates with futile policies that try to rehabilitate criminals rather than punish them.
"The prospect of going to prison in and of itself should be a deterrent," Mr. Rowland said in a detailed anti-crime package he released last week. In it, he called for life in prison for career criminals, making all felons serve more time before parole and cutting prison costs by contracting with other states to take Connecticut inmates.
At a news conference in the State Capitol, Mr. Rowland conceded what his charts and graphs omitted, that Connecticut's crime rate has been dropping since its peak in 1990, when crime was hardly mentioned in the gubernatorial campaign.
A recent voter poll by Quinnipiac College, however, found that 84 percent of those surveyed believed that crime was increasing. Nearly as many said the court system and prisons were not treating criminals harshly enough. The survey of 602 registered voters was conducted from Aug. 8 to Aug. 16. It had a sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
"The sense of fear that people have in this state, especially in the cities, especially at night, is at an all-time high," Mr. Rowland said. "And that fear, regardless of what the stats show in the last year or two or whatever period of time we want to use, that fear has really hurt the quality of life."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After his narrow loss in 1990, John G. Rowland is the best-known candidate in this year's gubernatorial field and his message -- more jobs, less crime, better schools, fairer welfare -- is familiar, too. He was at the Greenwich Town Hall yesterday for a campaign appearance. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)
