HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Buying by Fed Raises Treasury Issues' Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose moderately yesterday, as the Federal Reserve went into the open market to buy securities of various maturities, easing a seasonal shortage of money in the banking system.
The central bank said it was buying Treasury issues with maturities beginning with February 1995. Securities dealers are usually happy when the Fed comes to market to buy, traders say, because it gives them an opportunity to lighten their inventory of securities. And because some market participants had expected the Fed's action, it was not surprising to see prices pushed higher. 
 While the Fed was not expected to disclose the amount of securities it bought until Sept. 8, traders said it could have been about $6 billion.
 
 
Lower Consumer Confidence
 Treasury prices were helped after the Conference Board said consumer confidence dropped in August, while investors largely ignored the Commerce Department's new homes sales report for July, which showed a surge of buying.
The Johnson Redbook release showed retail sales activity of department and chain stores dropped 1.1 percent in the fourth week of August, compared with the equivalent period in July. A week ago, sales were down 1.5 percent. But seasonally adjusted sales were up 8.7 percent compared with the period a year earlier.
Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, characterized the bond market as being divided between traders focusing on daily events and investors looking at longer-term projections. He said long-term investors did not want to wait for the lagging effect on the economy of the Fed's last five interest rate increases before making strategic investment changes.
"I believe we are in the top area of the trading range," Mr. Roden said. "This economy cannot withstand higher sustained rates much longer. It is now running in a narrow line between what could be good for business and what could turn bad for business." He said he saw rates turning lower.
"Six months ago, many in the market were forecasting 8 percent on the long end, yet here we are at 7.50 percent, and that has surprised a lot of people," he said. "People with cash building in accounts want to put this money to work, and are afraid if they wait too long they will miss the boat, where they once feared they would get burned."
 
 
Long Bond Yielding 7.46%
 The 30-year bond rose 13/32 , to a price of 10016/32 , up 7/32 , for a yield of 7.46 percent, down from 7.49 percent on Monday. Rates of bills with shorter maturities traded lower, with a three-month issue down 2 basis points, to 4.57 percent, and the six-month down 3 basis points, to 4.88 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Analysts said the reason the surge in new-home sales in July failed to depress prices much yesterday was that traders were focused on the more forward-looking so-called sentiment data.
 The consumer confidence index eased to 89 in August from 91.3 in July, a number that had been revised lower. Economists polled by Reuters had expected the confidence measure to rise to 92.5.
The market has much more data to analyze this week, but the employment numbers, to be released by the Labor Department on Friday, loom large. MMS International, a market and research analysis firm, expects only a small decline in the unemployment rate by December, to 6 percent from 6.1 percent now, despite projected growth of 3 percent in the gross domestic product.
New-home sales surged to 8.3 percent, to an annual selling rate of 664,000 in July from a revision of 613,000 in June. Economists' forecasts had been for 633,000 in July.
The Commerce Department reported that the rebound in new-home sales for July put the rate 2.6 percent above levels a year earlier, coinciding with data on sales of existing homes. On the whole, the report is consistent with some economists' notion that the housing market has cooled because of higher mortgage rates, but remains reasonably healthy.
But the market failed to draw any meaningful direction from the data, reinforcing its trading range pending the release of the jobs data. Economists expect the employment report to show the economy added 232,000 jobs in August, after adding 259,000 in July, with the unemployment rate remaining steady at 6.1 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips Against Mark, As French Banks Lift Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the German mark and some other currencies yesterday, as an increase in French interest rates fueled speculation that European rates had bottomed after falling for almost two years.
Higher rates could hurt the dollar by making European deposits more attractive. 
 Several leading French commercial banks raised their base lending rates to 7.95 percent from 7.70 percent, effective tomorrow. The move caused currency traders to worry that Germany's central bankers would not lower interest rates after their biweekly meeting tomorrow.
"This is another sign that the long period of European rate cuts is coming to an end," said Richard Vullo, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Bank of Montreal. "The increases definitely knocked the dollar down."
 
Swedish and Italian Rates Up
 Earlier this month, the Swedish and Italian central banks raised interest rates, mostly to shore up their beleaguered currencies.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5760 German marks, down from the day's high of 1.5847 marks, and lower than 1.5780 marks on Monday.
The dollar also fell to 99.57 Japanese yen from 100.02 yen.
But the prospect of stable or higher interest rates in Europe did not set off a significant decline in the dollar, in part because rate increases do not always drive a country's currency up. Often a rate increase spurs investors to sell government bonds, diminishing demand for the currency.
As such, the French franc fell against both the dollar and the German mark, and French bonds tumbled after the French banks raised rates. The franc was quoted in New York at 5.4020 francs to the dollar, down from 5.4010 francs on Monday.
 
Stability Foreseen
 Traders said the dollar is expected to be relatively stable until Friday, when the Government releases its report on employment for August.
A modest rise in employment may be better for the dollar than a large increase because it would ease fears of inflation among bond investors, said Earl Johnson, a foreign-exchange adviser at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
"Most of the numbers are showing that the economy is slowing a little," he said. "That's good for the bonds and the dollar."
The report is expected to show that the economy added 232,000 jobs in August, after a gain of 259,000 in July.
The dollar did edge upward against the British pound and the Canadian dollar. The pound slipped to $1.5339 in New York from $1.5365. And the Canadian dollar fell to 73.07 United States cents from 73.16 cents.

HEADLINE: Gold Mine of Psychiatric Data Discovered in Danish Registry

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN 

DATELINE: RIISKOV, Denmark

 BODY:
DENMARK, known for its superbly crafted furniture, stereo systems and silverware, also offers state-of-the-art psychiatric epidemiology.
Denmark's unparalleled combination of a universal social welfare system and obsessive record keeping has made the country a world laboratory for teasing out subtle patterns in psychiatric data, particularly for severe disorders like schizophrenia, that can be detected only in studies of thousands of people. 
 One of the more alarming recent findings is that suicide rates among patients with schizophrenia have doubled as psychiatric hospitals in Denmark have cut back the number of days they are allowed to stay for treatment. The finding had eluded other researchers, because detecting it required studying both death records and psychiatric records for a vast number of patients. Similar research would be far more difficult in countries like the United States, where hospital stays for schizophrenia have also been cut back.
"We Danes are very good bookkeepers, so we have something you don't find anywhere else in the world: we can follow large numbers of people for a very long time with great precision," observed Dr. Preben Bo Mortensen, a psychiatrist. As senior researcher in the Department of Psychiatric Demography at Denmark's Institute of Basic Psychiatric Research, Dr. Mortensen is at the center of a web of more than 50 international research projects, all drawing on Danish records.
 
Establishment of Registry
 Scientists from around the world travel to join Dr. Mortensen and his colleagues at the psychiatric hospital that houses their institute, tucked by the seashore in Riiskov, a quiet suburb of Aarhus, Denmark's second largest city.
The Danish research is possible because since 1966 a registration number has been used by every man, woman and child in Denmark for a vast range of activities, from entering a psychiatric hospital to getting a job to banking transactions. In addition, virtually all medical care in Denmark is provided by the Government; there are no private hospitals.
"The Danes have a tremendously valuable system of registries," said Dr. David Shore, chief of the Schizophrenia Research Branch at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md. "There's nothing comparable in this country."
Dr. William Eaton, a psychiatric epidemiologist at Johns Hopkins University, who is collaborating on research with Danish scientists, said, "Denmark is the world's best place to work on the epidemiology of severe psychiatric disorders like schizophrenia."
Research that would be inordinately tedious or simply impossible elsewhere is remarkably easy there. One 30-year study, for example, followed more than 6,000 patients treated for schizophrenia, losing track of just 10 people over three decades.
 
Quality of Data
 This level of precision is unparalleled. As a rule of thumb, Dr. Eaton said, in the United States finding 75 percent of a large group after about a decade would be considered a good result. "You worry about the quality of the data if you can't find 30 percent of the people," he said.
Access to Government records for the entire population allows Danish researchers to track, for instance, how often a person has needed psychiatric help and for what problems, or to compare people's psychiatric histories with a national cancer registry or death certificates. By looking at huge numbers of people, the Danish researchers can detect subtle trends that would be missed by other methods or confirm hypotheses suggested by research with smaller groups.
In the study of schizophrenia and suicide, Dr. Mortensen was able to draw on computerized records to track all 9,156 patients admitted to Danish hospitals for a first episode of schizophrenia from 1970 to 1988, and then to comb through a national registry of causes of death, looking for patients from the study.
"You couldn't do this kind of research anywhere else," said Dr. Mortensen. "Because suicide is a rare event, it requires following a huge number of people for many years to detect a relationship. In a country like the U.S., perhaps 80 percent or more of patients would be untrack able after so many years."
In Denmark, as in the United States, economics and changes in treatment philosophy have led to a reduction of the average length of time people having psychotic episodes are kept in psychiatric hospitals. The average stay was about 50 days in the 1970's, and dropped to 30 days by the mid-1980's as part of a shift toward treating patients in the community.
In findings he reported last year in The British Journal of Psychiatry, Dr. Mortensen discovered that during the first year after patients were released from the hospital in the late 1980's, the rate of suicide among them was 56 percent higher than for patients treated in the early 1970's, when hospital stays were longer.
Further analysis of the records by Dr. Mortensen, not yet published in a scientific journal, shows that over the course of four years after their first admission, the suicide rate among first-time schizophrenic patients rose to double that found when hospital stays were longer. Of the more than 9,000 patients in the study, close to 500 committed suicide within four years of release.
People with schizophrenia have an especially high risk of suicide to begin with, 15 times or more the risk for the general population, with young men having the greatest risk. About 10 percent of people in whom schizophrenia is diagnosed eventually commit suicide, Dr. Shore said.
The findings may suggest, Dr. Mortensen said, that the new policies are forcing patients out of the hospital before they have stabilized enough to flourish on their own. On the other hand, Dr. Shore cautioned that there may be other explanations.
"To show a correlation between length of hospital stay and suicide does not mean that one causes the other," Dr. Shore said. "It simply means that we should look further to find the cause. It might be, for example, that the rise in suicides was due to delays in admitting these people to the hospital in the first place, which undermined their hope."
The death records also revealed that patients treated for schizophrenia have a lower-than-average risk of dying from cancer, Dr. Mortensen discovered.
Men in the study who had been treated for schizophrenia had a rate of death from cancer a third lower than for other men, Dr. Mortensen found; for prostate cancer the rate was about half that of the general population, according to a report published by Dr. Mortensen earlier this year in Schizophrenia Research.
For women treated for schizophrenia, the rate of death from cervical cancer was half that of women in general.
 
Possible Cancer Fighter
 It is not schizophrenia that accounts for the lower rates of cancer, Dr. Mortensen said, but it may have something to do with the treatments for it. Research with animals has found that chlorpromazine, a medication frequently used to treat schizophrenia, slows the growth of experimentally induced cancer tumors.
Following up this hypothesis, Dr. Mortensen found in comparing those patients with schizophrenia who developed cancer of the cervix, prostate, lung, bladder or breast with those who did not, that those treated with chlorpromazine had a lower risk of getting cancer.
The Danish registries have been a steady basis for research on the genetics of mental illness. In the 1960's, in one of the first such studies, Dr. Seymour Kety, a psychiatrist at the National Institute of Mental Health, tracked down the psychiatric histories of parents of 18 men and women with schizophrenia who had been adopted in infancy by parents with no mental illness.
Dr. Kety was able to show that a genetic legacy was far more powerful in predicting that a child would grow up to have schizophrenia than the psychological dynamics of the family in which the child grew up. Dr. Kety recently verified his earlier results with data published in the June issue of The Archives of General Psychiatry.
 
False Notion Dispelled
 Dr. Kety's findings played a crucial role in vanquishing what had been the prevailing psychiatric wisdom, that schizophrenia was a result of destructive communications between parents and their children -- an outlook that in effect laid the blame on parents for what today is seen as a disease with biological and genetic causes.
To follow up studies suggesting that complications at birth heighten the risk of schizophrenia later in life, Dr. Mortensen and Dr. Eaton are designing an ambitious study that will involve tens of thousands of people. Drawing on records that describe any complications during childbirth, they will search the country's psychiatric records to establish the degree to which such problems are associated with a higher risk of developing mental illness later in life.
"In the past, studies on this question have involved around 200 or 300 people," Dr. Mortensen said. "Ours will examine between 40,000 to 60,000 people, giving us an immensely greater power of precision. It's like having a stronger microscope."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THERE has been much talk in recent years about something called "the wine lake." Of course, there is no such thing; not literally, anyway. There have been wine-filled swimming pools, even a few water towers. Or so they say. But no lake. 
 It's nothing more than a colorful way of describing the immense surplus of wine that the industry has been saddled with for the better part of a decade. Overproduction is endemic to the wine business. Millions of gallons of wine are distilled into commercial alcohol every year. Most of it is the cheap stuff.
Overproduction of fine wine is less common. Several factors can bring it on; an excellent growing season and a balky public are two of the most common. When those two factors are combined, as they have been in recent years, it can be disastrous, or nearly so, for the trade.
The problem is particularly acute in Bordeaux, where modern grape-growing and wine-making methods produced some exceptionally large vintages in the 1970's and 1980's. But even if the crops had not been so large, the sheer number of good vintages would have filled the cellars and, perhaps, even a swimming pool or two.
In the first half of the century, about half a dozen vintages were worth mentioning and only three were considered memorable: 1929, 1945 and 1949. Between 1950 and 1970, there were five: 1953, 1955, 1959, 1961 and 1966. In the 1970's, Bordeaux entered on a new epoch, with four good vintages: 1970, 1975, 1978 and 1979.
In fact, from 1970 on, good vintages became the norm. Even the poor years were better than the poor years of the past. Unexceptional years like 1972, 1974 and 1977 were considerably better than 1963 and 1965, which were the truly awful vintages of the 1960's.
The 1980 vintage was light but palatable. Only two other years in that decade, 1984 and 1987, were rated below par, and even so, both years produced some pleasant, drinkable wines. Every other year of the decade produced excellent wines, with 1982 particularly outstanding.
The 1980's were a time of excess; even staid Bordeaux wine professionals were predicting that science had conquered nature in the winery and the vineyard. There would be no more bad years, they said.
If anything, the 1990's began on the same high note. Critics rated the 1990 vintage above the famous 1982. Some compared it, inaccurately, to the now legendary 1961. The 1961 was quintessentially French: elegant, intense and some of the best, even now, not ready to drink. The 1990 was rich, fruity, opulent and, except for a few dreadnoughts, almost accessible now.
Meanwhile, major markets, particularly the United States, had been drying up. Lagging economies, new concerns about health and the new world competition for a share of the market all served to dampen Bordeaux's euphoria. The wines were better and better, but more and more difficult to sell.
Then, once more, nature intervened. Both the 1991 and 1992 vintages received relatively poor ratings. In 1991, many famous chateaus sold off their wine in bulk rather than put their names on it.
Almost overnight, it seemed, customers began to look to the older, highly rated but unsold vintages for bargains. Even the much-maligned wines of 1984 and 1987 were said to "have finally come around," and were being offered by newly optimistic wine merchants. Here in New York and elsewhere around the country, the first half of 1994 is turning out to be the best first half in five years or more. And as the merchants gleefully remind themselves, the second half of the year, or more specifically the last quarter, is the most lucrative time of year in the wine and spirits business.
Bordeaux lovers take note: This may be the time to replenish your cellars -- even if your cellars are actually hall closets or six-bottle racks under the kitchen sink.
Following is a selection of Bordeaux wines from four vintages that have come back into the public eye because more recent years have been disappointing. The prices are those listed by several retailers in New York City and the metropolitan area. Discounters may charge less; retailers in less competitive situations may charge more.
From 1985: Chateau Simard, from St. Emilion, $15; Chateau de Sales, Pomerol, $20; Chateau Beau Site, St. Estephe, $19; Carruades de Lafite, Pauillac, the second wine of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild, $22; Clos des Jacobins, St. Emilion, $20.
From 1986: Chateau Cantemerle, Haut-Medoc, $15; Chateau Meyney, St. Estephe, $19; Chateau St. Pierre, St. Julien, $20; Chateau Bourgneuf, Pomerol, $19; Chateau Leoville-Poyferre, $22; Chateau Latour Haut-Brion, Graves, $22; Chateau Lynch-Bages, Pauillac, $27.
From 1988: Chateau de Sales, Pomerol, $15; Smith-Haut-Lafite, Graves, $14; Chateau Lynch-Bages, Pauillac, $29; Chateau Haut-Batailley, Pauillac, $16; Chateau Leoville-Poyferre, St. Julien, $21.
From 1989: Clos l'Eglise, Pomerol, $20; Chateau Bellevue, St. Emilion, $19; Canon-Moueix, Fronsac, $15; Chateau Gloria, St. Julien, $17; Chateau Haut-Bages-Averous, Pauillac, the second wine of Chateau Lynch-Bages, $18; Chateau Phelan-Segur, St. Estephe, $17, and Chateau Prieure-Lichine, Margaux, $20.
Notice that all but two of those wines are under $25; most are under $20, and many are less expensive than they were when they first came on the market in more free-spending times. The Lynch-Bages 1986 at $27 and the 1988 at $29 are true bargains. Jean-Michel Cazes makes wine to rival the first growths at this fifth-growth chateau, and this is a chance to buy it at reasonable prices.
All these wines can be laid down for another five years or so, but a few can also be drunk now, notably the Pomerols, like de Sales, Bourgneuf and Clos l'Eglise.

TASTINGS
Heitz Cellar Grignolino, Napa Valley, non-vintage; about $6.50.
 
Joe Heitz found grignolino growing on his land near St. Helena, Calif., when he bought the place some 30 years ago. Since then, he has become known for his magnificent cabernets, but he has never abandoned his lowly grignolino vines. From them he makes two simple Italian-style wines that perfectly match simple Italian meals. One wine is red, the other rose. Grignolino is pronounced grin-yo-LEE-no in Italy and green-oh-LEE-no in California. Take your choice. In Italy, its native land, grignolino is found mostly in the northwest, in the province of Asti. There it produces light, pleasant wines that are rarely if ever exported. In fact, the dynamic Angelo Gaja, the Italian wine maker, imports Mr. Heitz's grignolino from California, saying none in Italy can match it. In California, Italian grape varieties are all the rage, but hardly any of the wines have lived up to the fanfare they've received. This grignolino, unheralded and unpretentious, is a much better value for the little money it costs.

HEADLINE: The Fracturing of the Middle Class

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich is Secretary of Labor. This article is adapted from a speech to be delivered today at the Center for National Policy in Washington.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Since last Labor Day, the economy has generated more than 2.5 million jobs for Americans. But despite this progress, long-term trends are splitting the old middle class into three new groups: an underclass largely trapped in center cities, increasingly isolated from the core economy; an overclass, those in a position to ride the waves of change; and in between, the largest group, an anxious class, most of whom hold jobs but are justifiably uneasy about their own standing and fearful for their children's futures.
The fundamental fault line through the labor force divides workers by education and skills. As recently as 1979, a male college graduate earned 49 percent more than a man with only a high school diploma -- a sizable difference, to be sure, but not too much for the two to share the label "middle class." By 1992, the gap had widened to 83 percent, and the notion of common prospects had faded considerably. 
 There is a similar divergence in benefits. Employer-sponsored health coverage has declined only slightly for workers with college degrees, covering 79 percent in 1979 and 76 percent in 1993. But the rate for high school graduates has fallen from 68 percent to 60 percent, and among high school dropouts, from 53 percent to 36 percent. Nearly two-thirds of workers with college degrees have employer-sponsored pension plans, but fewer than a quarter of high school dropouts do.
Similarly with the risk of joblessness: unemployment among high school dropouts rose from an average of 7 percent during the 1970's to 12 percent in the 1980's, and it was over 12 percent last year. But over the same two decades, unemployment for workers with college degrees held fairly steady at around 3 percent. This helps explain why Wall Street can fret that unemployment is too low to contain inflation while eight million willing workers are jobless. Markets for skilled labor are becoming tight in parts of the economy. Yet many less skilled workers are walled off from the leading edges of the economy.
What lies behind these widening disparities? Manufacturing jobs were once the gateway to the middle class. While it is a myth that international trade has robbed America of its manufacturing industries, technological changes have diminished the role of labor, especially unskilled labor, in the modern factory. Global trade and investment have surely hastened these changes.
Labor unions have long helped shore up wages and benefits for workers without high-level skills. But today, only 11 percent of the private-sector work force is unionized. Let there be no doubt: a revitalization of the labor movement would help reverse the erosion of the middle class.
But the forces unleashed by technology must be mastered, not merely buffered. As increasingly capable machines join Americans at the workplace -- join them as both co-workers and competitors -- the payoff to education and training has soared, and the penalty for lacking skills has stiffened. The most striking change has been the brash arrival of the computer. Yet while the information highway promises to speed some people to desirable destinations, it may leave others stranded in the technological version of inner-city ghettos. Two-thirds of college graduates use computers at work, but fewer than one in 10 high school dropouts.
Yet the long-term data also affirm the potential for building a new middle class. Some of the fastest job growth in America is occurring among technicians, who defy the categories of the old economy. In my travels I've met vending-machine repair workers who use hand-held computers to identify problems and communicate with the home office, and managers in retail stores who tap personal computers to monitor sales and inventories. Some workers drive trucks equipped with computers and modems and make just-in-time deliveries. Others orchestrate sophisticated spreadsheet and graphics programs to create value in ways unimaginable a decade ago.
The technician jobs that will sustain the core of the new middle class usually require some education beyond high school, but they do not always demand a four-year college degree. Degrees from community colleges, the unsung heroes of the new middle class, are paying off, and their enrollments are rising.
This Administration's work-force agenda is inspired by the evidence that skills matter and that they can be learned. The fruits of our commitment to creating a new middle class are already emerging. Ironically, many of these accomplishments have been little noticed because of the bipartisan consensus supporting them. Bipartisanship summons less attention than ideological brawls.
Consider: 130,000 more children each year can now be made ready to learn through Head Start. School systems have millions of dollars in new incentives to improve their performance. Over the next six years, almost half a million young Americans will start youth apprenticeships.
Starting this fall, 20,000 young people will enter National Service, earning money that they can apply to a college education. The 3.5 million people who take out education loans each year may now repay their loans as a percentage of future income. We are making work pay by delivering tax relief to 15 million working families with modest incomes. And the unemployment insurance system is being transformed into a re-employment system; this year, 150,000 more Americans who lost jobs will get the help they need to find new ones.
American business has its own role to play. Skills learned on the job or in a work-related setting are especially valuable. But with some exceptions, companies do too little training and concentrate on workers who are already skilled. We need a new social compact with American business. In its first year and a half, the Clinton Administration has delivered much of what business has sought to bolster its competitiveness -- lower deficits, low inflation, more open world markets, promotion of American business abroad. Now business needs to do its part, by investing in the skills of all workers.
Unlike the citizens of most other nations, Americans have always been united less by a shared past than by shared dreams of a better future. If we lose that common future, we lose the glue that holds our nation together. As we approach Labor Day 1994 -- the 100th anniversary of America's workers' holiday -- let us commit to building the foundations of a new middle class.

HEADLINE: In America;
A Season Of Service

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Think of it as an antidote to cynicism, a rejection of the rampant selfishness that managed somehow to become fashionable in the 1980's. Think of it as a return to the can-do spirit of the 50's and 60's, when large numbers of Americans believed it was possible to find remedies for violence and injustice, for poverty and ignorance, for the buffoonery and corruption of politicians, and for the wholesale degradation of the environment.
"I challenge a new generation of young Americans to a season of service," said Bill Clinton in his inaugural address. "There is so much to be done -- enough, indeed, for millions of others who are still young in spirit to give of themselves in service, too." 
 On Sept. 12, amid elaborate ceremonies planned for the South Lawn of the White House, the President's national service program will get fully under way. It's called AmeriCorps and it's described as a domestic version of the Peace Corps. Its scope is less than I would have wished, but more than we've come to expect from a sociopolitical environment that over the past decade and a half has been poisoned by greed, a collapse of ideals and contempt for the old-fashioned notion of brotherhood.
In that environment, we were free to choose between the national values espoused by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and those currently embraced by Representative Newt Gingrich. We opted for Mr. Gingrich's.
The President's national service program is a modest step in Dr. King's direction.
Under the program, several thousand young Americans from all kinds of backgrounds will offer their services to organizations working on problems related to education, public safety, social services and the environment. For a two-year commitment, the participants will be paid $7,500 a year and will receive a credit of $9,450 ($4,725 a year) that can be used for college or graduate school expenses.
The program will reach into urban, suburban and rural America. Parts of it have already started. Young men and women are helping to restore wildlife habitats, conducting childhood immunization programs, escorting children and the elderly through dangerous inner-city neighborhoods, counseling drug abusers, providing preventive health services and improving neglected playgrounds, parks and wetlands.
Tiffany Tidwell, an honors graduate from the University of Kansas, is teaching French at a public school in the Mississippi Delta. Leo Negron, who grew up in a tough neighborhood in Chicago, is teaching construction skills to teen-agers. Laura Sullivan, who grew up in a wealthy suburb in Massachusetts, has joined a program in Baltimore that provides assistance to poor women who want to start their own businesses.
"We have a lot of domestic problems that need creative answers," Ms. Sullivan said. "And I wanted to get to know the neighborhoods in the inner cities, rather than just living in the ivory tower of a college community."
She referred to friends who are serving in the military and said: "They are defending us internationally. I feel strongly that there should be a force of young people that are kind of defending us domestically."
Besides providing assistance to many worthwhile organizations, AmeriCorps is a way for young people to see a variety of fellow Americans up close and personal, the way they really are, without the distorting filter of the boob tube. It's a way to get beyond the stereotypes of situation comedy and the local news.
"Whenever possible," said Eli Segal, chief chaperone for this noble effort, "we want youngsters from different geographic areas, from different races and ethnic groups and from different economic backgrounds to pitch in and work together."
Mr. Segal, an assistant to the President, is the chief executive of the Corporation for National Service. He expects to have 20,000 AmeriCorps enlistees spread out across the country by the end of the year. "And if it works," he said, "we could have 100,000 by the end of 1996."
I have always believed that national service should be compulsory. Every American should serve two years in some military or civilian capacity. There should be more to patriotism than singing "The Star-Spangled Banner" at a ball game, or rooting (from the comfort of our living rooms) for the American team to win a nationally televised war.
AmeriCorps is a start.

HEADLINE: Junk Loans, Not Bonds, Are Hot on Wall Street

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
As the underwriting of junk bonds has begun to cool this year, some Wall Street firms are aggressively moving into a business that until now has been the preserve of commercial banks. Call it junk loans.
In recent months, Merrill Lynch & Company, Lehman Brothers Inc., CS First Boston and Goldman, Sachs & Company have raided the ranks of the commercial banks, hiring away executives experienced in the art of putting together corporate loan packages and assembling groups of banks to put up the cash. 
 This month, Lehman Brothers arranged a $50 million loan for Acme Metals Inc., a steel producer in Riverdale, Ill. Merrill Lynch is about to complete its first loan deal, a $126 million credit for the Best Buy Company, an electronics retailer based in Minneapolis.
In lining up such loans, Wall Street has no intention of putting its own capital at risk, a business it flirted with briefly -- with disastrous results -- during the 1980's takeover boom, only to find itself losing millions of dollars on temporary or so-called bridge loans that went sour.
This time, the aim of investment bankers is simply to service corporate borrowers that generally have more difficulty raising cash to expand, make acquisitions or recapitalize, while helping themselves to some of the lush fees that commercial banks have long enjoyed for arranging and syndicating such loans.
It's also tit for tat. Ever since Congress began dismantling the Depression-era regulations that separate Wall Street and the commercial banks, the banks have been eagerly treading on Wall Street's domain by issuing everything from junk bonds to blue-chip stocks. Now Wall Street is striking back, saying that it, too, can offer a full spectrum of services, including loans.
"One-stop shopping is going to be a very significant part of the way we do business," said Bob O'Brien, who recently joined CS First Boston from Chemical Bank to head its loan effort.
But some skeptics wonder if Wall Street really has a future in lending. The strength of the street, according to Christopher L. Snyder, president of the Loan Pricing Corporation, a financial data base that compiles information about the secondary market for bank loans, is structuring deals and distributing securities, not providing the kind of personal service that bankers offer borrowers.
After all, he added, just because Wall Street trades billions of dollars in mortgage-backed bonds does not mean that its investment bankers should write home mortgages.
The investment bankers counter that lining up loans to companies without investment ratings is just an extension of their current business. In the past, Wall Street has raised money for such customers by issuing bonds with high yields -- so-called junk bonds -- to compensate for the added risk.
That business hit record levels last year. But since interest rates began rising in February, the appetite for bonds has diminished while interest in so-called leveraged or junk loans has grown. In the first eight months of this year, the money raised by junk bonds declined 21 percent, compared with the corresponding period of 1993, while the amount of junk loans written in the first half of this year more than doubled, to almost $27 billion, from $12 billion in the first half of 1993.
 
Added Risks, but Variable Rates
 Leveraged loans, like junk bonds, are risky because they are generally made to companies with below-investment-grade credit ratings, meaning that there is a greater chance of default. They are also made at yields above regular market rates.
But unlike bonds, which mostly have fixed rates, the loans have a variable rate that will rise with market interest rates. The loans also give the lender the first claim on the company's assets if it goes bust. So while bond buyers are often spooked by rising rates, banks and other institutions are often more willing to step into the breach with adjustable-rate junk loans.
Acme Metals was looking to raise $370 million to expand its Acme Steel subsidiary when it approached Lehman Brothers for advice. The early structure of the proposed package was a combination of an issue of new common stock and junk bonds, according to Jim Hoekwater, the company's treasurer. Then the Lehman advisers, led by Bart McDade, managing director of the high-yield business, suggested raising $50 million from a leveraged loan.
In its final form, the Acme deal consisted of $205 million in junk bonds in two issues with interest rates of 12.5 percent and 13.5 percent, $118 million in new common stock, an $80 million revolving loan and the $50 million leveraged loan, with an interest rate that floats four percentage points over the three-month London interbank offered rate, which was 5 percent yesterday.
At a current interest rate of around 9 percent, Acme's loan costs the company considerably less than its junk bonds. Mr. Hoekwater was pleased. "They bought us a total package that met our needs, saved us money and gave us greater flexibility," he said.
Junk loans are not really new. During the corporate takeover and leveraged-buyout boom of the late 1980's, loans from commercial banks financed many of the deals. The market peaked in 1989, when more than $186 billion in leveraged loans were written, compared with only $25 billion in junk bonds.
Several Wall Street firms also got into the lending business at that time, making so-called bridge loans to finance corporate takeovers that in some cases turned out to be reckless gambles. In the most celebrated case, First Boston had to be bailed out by its parent, Credit Suisse, to the tune of $650 million after it got stuck holding several of its bridge loans.
That track record may hurt Wall Street in its new effort. "The question is: Will other commercial banks have enough confidence in the credit process that a Wall Street firm uses to feel comfortable enough to buy their paper?" said Mark G. Solow, the senior executive vice president responsible for corporate banking at the Chemical Banking Corporation, the leading arranger of corporate loans.
In the case of CS First Boston, the question is moot because Credit Suisse, the commercial banking unit of First Boston's parent, CS Holdings Inc., will be performing the credit assessments and holding some of the loans made by First Boston.
For their part, the other investment bankers say they are up to the task. "In terms of risk, we feel that we have as good credit skills as anyone in the market," said Seth Waugh, managing director of Merrill Lynch's high-yield bond business.
And in many cases, the people who will be dealing the loans to banks from Wall Street are the same people who have been doing the work at the commercial banks. Merrill Lynch, CS First Boston and Lehman Brothers have raided Chemical's large corporate loan department, while in the most recent example, Goldman, Sachs hired Edward Forst, the managing director in charge of loan sales and trading at Bankers Trust Securities, a unit of the Bankers Trust Company.
"Why would clients believe them when they were at Chemical but not when they are at Merrill Lynch?" asked a fund manager, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
But what makes the market more attractive and less risky for Wall Street now than it was in the 1980's is that the loan business is beginning to look more like the securities business. While commercial banks have traditionally lent money and waited for it to be paid back, a rising number of banks have been trading their loans to other banks, insurance companies, private money managers and mutual funds.
 
Window of Opportunity
 That, ironically, has created the window of opportunity for Wall Street to challenge the banks. Instead of taking a large risk and tying up their capital by holding loans on their books as they did with the bridge loans in the 1980's, the investment banks believe that they will be able to arrange the loans, earning the "skim," or fee, and then sell them to investors, much in the way that they distribute a bond issue.
"It is a natural extension of where our business is going," Mr. Waugh said. "The market has become more liquid. It's a lot more like the underwriting market."
Depending on the type of loan, the investment banks can sell them to other banks, or to a growing number of fund managers and other investors buying loans on the secondary market.
"Through the eyes of a nonbank investor these loans are just senior bonds with short maturities that also have collateral pledged to them," said Jeffrey S. Garner, portfolio manager of Eaton Vance Prime Rate Reserves, a $650 million mutual fund that invests only in corporate loans.
Mr. Garner said the trade in loans might one day grow into a market with volume of hundreds of billions of dollars. "The commercial paper market has grown from $10 billion in 1965 to more than $500 billion today," he said, referring to the short-term paper that top corporations regularly issue to raise cash. "Now the bank loan market for noninvestment- grade companies is beginning to undergo a similar transformation."
But to date, volume on the secondary market is still small. More than $28 billion in new leveraged loans were written last year, yet the volume on loan trading desks at the commercial banks and on Wall Street totaled just $15 billion. That means that some investment banks may be left holding loans on their books longer than they like.
Two weeks after the loan to Acme Metals was closed, Lehman had still not sold it all to investors in the secondary market, according to Mr. Hoekwater, the company treasurer.
"It's a young market," he said. "I think they are making good progress."
A Lehman spokesman said the firm was not concerned by the amount still sitting on its books. "We are exactly where we want to be," he said, referring to the Acme loan.
One restraint on the growth of the leveraged loan trade is that many institutions are barred from investing in instruments that are not investment grade. Another is that loans are not standardized like stocks and bonds. To assess a loan's value, an investor must assess the collateral as well as any covenants that might restrict the borrower's ability to take on more debt or limit the way the credit can be used.
A recent development may help remedy this problem: the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the bond-rating service, has begun rating corporate loans. The new system gauges the risk an investor would take by buying a given loan. The top rating means the expected loss of principal if the borrower defaulted would be less than 1 percent; the lowest rating estimates a loss of more than 20 percent.
"The key to liquidity is standardization," said Mr. Snyder of the Loan Pricing Corporation, "Can you make a trade on the phone, or do you need documents?"

HEADLINE: Castro's Resilient Masses

BYLINE: By Pico Iyer; Pico Iyer is author of the forthcoming novel "Cuba and the Night."

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

 BODY:
The 9-year-old Cuban boy with the cataract in his eye showed me the condoms he had used as balloons at his birthday party. He pulled out the single stick of gum he'd been chewing for a week. He brought over the two tattered photo albums he'd stuffed with pieces of Carnation labels, stickers that said "Knorr's Soup" and ads for Nescafe -- status symbols in the Havana fourth grade. His mother, a policewoman and a staunch Fidelista who refused to accept gifts from a visitor, proudly pointed out photos of her cousins' suburban home and Nissan in Miami.
Everyone in Cuba knows that the country is bankrupt; everyone knows that almost anything must be better than the steady supply of nothing that the Government offers. Everyone can see that the whole island is shuddering to a halt, like the 40-year-old Plymouths that line the streets of a city where gasoline is illegal. Prostitution, which was scarcely visible (if only for security reasons) five years ago, is pandemic now: the tourist hotels are filled with Cuban teen-agers reddening their lips with children's crayons. 
 The Government billboards used to proclaim, "We Are Happy Here." Now they say only, "We Are Here." The official currency is more or less the dollar. And while more and more people turn to santeria, the Cuban equivalent of voodoo, as a source of miracles, the offerings of food they leave out in the streets for the gods are all too often filched by hungry neighbors.
It would not take an ironist to see that after 35 years of revolution, Fidel Castro has succeeded in turning his land into precisely the kind of Babylon he once came to scourge: a nest of brothels and drugs, dependent on foreign income, where the greatest symbols of power are visiting capitalists.
Yet Cubans have been living off next to nothing for decades. On my annual visit to the island in February, I was struck by the fact that the typical income was down to $1.30 a month, and yet this still seemed enough to put food on the table. Friends kept talking about the Golden Age -- before the collapse of the East Bloc in 1989; I didn't remind them that they had been delivering much the same elegies in 1987.
Sometimes it seems as if the country's psychological reserves may be emptying: "Before, we could blame everything on the Soviets," one friend told me. "But now the Soviets are gone, and things are worse than ever." But just as often, people noted that at least there was nobody starving on the streets.
It is easy to forget, amid the dramatic images of people risking their lives to flee in makeshift boats, that Cubans have had a crash course in suffering and sacrifice for decades now. They have developed reserves of resourcefulness and patience that would put the rest of us to shame.
Nearly all of them are seasoned experts at making do and finding ways around the system: trading a little tomato sauce for the promise of some rum, fixing a TV in exchange for a kiss. A tourist hustler I know once invited me to his flat for a dinner of lobster and Champagne. (Now he's serving a year's sentence in a labor camp for trading dollars. It wasn't so bad, he told me with a smile when I visited -- food was guaranteed there, and he was allowed to go home every six weeks.)
All of us know -- and every Cuban knows -- the ironies of a country with well-trained doctors and no medicine, with a highly educated population and no books. Yet what such miseries obscure is that for many Cubans, the alternatives to their all-too-familiar leader are not bright. More than half of all Cubans have known no other president, causing many to prefer the devil they know to the devil they don't.
They look at his lieutenants, and see all of his severity and little of his intelligence; they look across the water to Miami, and see the people who held them down before, they feel, waiting to reclaim their mansions. They note with bitterness that gusanos -- the "traitors" who fled, many of them in the Mariel boat lift -- can now return to the island and be treated as royalty (foreigners with money!).
But they also acknowledge that their leader has made their tiny island, half as populous as Mexico City, a forceful player on the world stage. As in Vietnam, impatience with Marxism is mixed with a genuine, and often fervent, nationalism. There are many who would still prefer a self-ruled Cuba to one that's tarted up.
Most Cubans realize that those who flee the country know almost nothing of what they're going to, beyond what they've seen in foreign magazines. And those who arrive in the land of "Dynasty" dreams with little English and no training in a carrot-and-stick economy often end up in the poorest areas of Miami or New York, hustling drugs or joining gangs. One friend I know who made it here as a political refugee quickly wrote back to his equally restless friends in Havana to stay put: America was not for the weak, he said, and -- believe it or not -- the reports of homelessness and poverty were true!
The most recent letter I got from Cuba, last week, said, "I would like to see the end of this bad dream: no food, no medicine, no transportation, no electricity, no water . . . ." Yet the writer, an actress, concluded, "My country is in crisis, but I am not."
Americans are wise to see the thousands of Cubans taking to the seas as exemplars of a widespread dissatisfaction with a country that asks everything of its people and gives almost nothing in return; but we would be wiser still to recall the many millions more who, through inertia or trepidation or even a kind of qualifiedpatriotism, choose to sit things out.
